DOC.HEAD: Reporter's Notebook: A Tale of Four Ambassadors
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Helms, the archduke of Senate conservatives, is battling the State Department again. And his private war is gumming up President Bush's diplomacy. This is a tale of three diplomats who want to be ambassadors but whose careers have gotten tangled up in a mixture of Senate politics and personal grudges. A fourth candidate lost out when his nomination was withdrawn as the result of objections from the host country. Helms, R-N.C., is angry at the administration over its nomination of George Fleming Jones as ambassador to the tiny South American state of Guyana. Helms suspects Jones of involvement in the 1986 leak of a secret Chilean military report about the death of an American during a violent protest in Santiago, according to a source who asked not to be identified. Helms was infuriated when his own office was blamed for the leak. He has told the State Department that unless it provides 1986 cables from the U.S. Embassy in Chile, where Jones was posted, he would keep blocking the confirmation, the source said. Helms' parliamentary maneuvering to block a Senate committee hearing on Jones' nomination also wound up delaying confirmation hearings for two other ambassadorial nominees - G. Philip Hughes for Barbados and John P. Leonard for Suriname. While the appointments aren't high-level, they illustrate the convoluted dealings of the Senate and the protracted nature of the confirmation process. The administration submitted the nominees' names several months ago and the diplomats may have to wait until the new Congress convenes next year before their cases are resolved. Helms is an old hand at manipulating ambassadorial nominations, using them as bargaining chips in wheeling and dealing with colleagues and the administration. The 68-year-old standard-bearer of anti-communism is running for a fourth Senate term neck-and-neck against Democrat Harvey Gantt. One of his better-known maneuvers was a six-month ``hold'' on the 1987 nomination of April Glaspie to become ambassador to Iraq. He took to the Senate floor last month to say his objections had been vindicated. Glaspie has come in for stinging criticism over her failure to tell Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that the United States was angry about his threats against Kuwait. Having reported to Washington that there was no cause for concern, she left on vacation a day before the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., is upset at Helms' delay tactics, according to a congressional source who demanded anonymity. But he's even more angry at the administration for nominating Hughes. Hughes served as secretary of the president's National Security Council during the Iran-Contra affair. Dodd wants to ask him whether he knew that NSC aide Oliver North was illegally arranging to give the Nicaraguan Contra rebels money from U.S. arms sales to Iran. Dodd also objected last year to the nomination of Hughes' boss, Donald Gregg, to be ambassador to South Korea. Dodd contended that Gregg knew of North's doings, but Gregg eventually was approved. The fourth nomination, Frederick Vreeland to be ambassador to Burma, is being withdrawn, the State Department said Thursday night. A State Department official, who asked not to be identified, said Vreeland's name is being withdrawn because of objections from the military authorities of Burma about pro-democracy statements Vreeland had made during Senate testimony. But Vreeland's nomination had been in trouble from the start. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., had asked Helms to block a vote on his confirmation, and Helms obliged. D'Amato - who isn't a member of the Foreign Relations Committee - and some committee members were furious at the State Department for representing Vreeland as a foreign service officer at a time when he worked undercover for the CIA. Vreeland, by the way, is the son of the late Vogue magazine editor, Diana Vreeland. Some of Vreeland's conservative critics also questioned why, while serving at the U.S. Embassy in Rome, Vreeland played down the role of Soviet and Bulgarian intelligence in the 1981 assassination attempt of Pope John Paul II. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Ruth Sinai covers foreign affairs for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Fundraiser Linked to Riegle Probe
DOC.TEXT: A fundraiser hosted by savings and loan operator Charles H. Keating Jr. plays a major role in a recommendation that an ethics investigation proceed against Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., say sources familiar with the inquiry. Just weeks after the March 23, 1987, fundraiser for Riegle, the Michigan Democrat and four Senate colleagues met with U.S. banking regulators on behalf of Keating - a political donor to all five. The Senate Ethics Committee is trying to establish whether any of the five senators were influenced to help Keating by the $1.3 million he and associates donated to the lawmakers' campaigns and causes. Congressional sources previously confirmed that special counsel Robert S. Bennett had recommended that the investigation continue against Riegle and Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., and Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. Bennett also proposed that Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz., and John Glenn, D-Ohio, be dropped from the investigation. The committee now is at a juncture where it can advance some or all the cases to expanded levels of inquiry, including public hearings, or dismiss senators from the probe. Congressional sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said earlier this week that any links between the senators' actions and the timing of political donations are crucial to Bennett's recommendations. Sources said Thursday that the fundraiser Keating held for Riegle is one of the links cited by Bennett. Riegle has said the proximity of the event and the sessions with regulators were coincidental. One source said Bennett is ``throwing up for the committee the possibility that when a political contribution is so close to an event, is there a way it cannot be connected?'' Riegle's case could be the most difficult of the five. The two senators that Bennett recommended dropping, McCain and Glenn, broke off contacts with banking regulators after an April 9, 1987, meeting attended by all five lawmakers. The five senators were told during that session that criminal referrals would be made to the Justice Department on the conduct of Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. Cranston and DeConcini continued their contacts with regulators until April 1989, when Lincoln was seized by the government - leaving the taxpayers to cover losses that could exceed $2 billion. The two senators said the contacts after April 1987 were in support of a sale of Lincoln that could have saved jobs. Riegle has said he ended his intervention with regulators, as did Glenn and McCain, after the April 9 meeting. But in Riegle's case, Bennett's report gives weight to the timing of the fundraiser hosted by Keating on March 23, 1987, and a meeting a few weeks earlier - on March 6 - between Riegle and the top S&L regulator at the time, Edwin J. Gray. Riegle acknowledged that he suggested to Gray that the regulator meet with senators concerned about the treatment of Keating's S&L. Although Riegle said he did not arrange it, such a meeting was held on April 2, 1987, between Gray and Cranston, DeConcini, McCain and Glenn. Gray contends the senators offered a deal to aid Keating's operation at that meeting, but all four senators vigorously deny the allegation. In contending there was no connection between the fundraiser and the intervention with regulators, Riegle has said the event was scheduled two months earlier. Riegle raised $78,250 from Keating and associates in the event at the Pontchartrain Hotel in Detroit, owned by Keating. In 1988, a year after the event, Riegle announced he returned the money because it could ``create the appearance of a conflict of interest.'' Meanwhile, McCain met with the Ethics Committee privately Thursday, as Glenn had done the day before. Emerging after about three hours, McCain said he ``felt good'' about the session and predicted he would be exonerated before the Senate adjourns later this month. Cranston, Riegle and DeConcini are to appear before the committee over the next two weeks.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush Changes Perceptions But Not the Policy
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, through some fancy rhetorical footwork, is moving toward a more moderate public stance on the Persian Gulf crisis in an apparent bid to recruit more Arabs into the anti-Iraq cause. Until his speech at the United Nations this week, the administration had left open the possibility of a long-term American presence in the gulf and of fashioning a U.S.-led security alliance for the area to ensure future stability. The administration also resisted any linkage between the gulf and the Arab-Israeli disputes, implying that the respective conflicts had more differences than similarities. Many Arabs, although troubled by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, also are wary about what they perceive as massive U.S. interference in the region. To the extent that there are Arab hearts still up for grabs, Bush is trying to woo them - and what better forum to do that than the U.N. General Assembly. In his speech, without repudiating what he and his subordinates had said previously, the president quietly shifted the focus on several sore points in a way that was more palatable to Arab opinion. Bush did what presidents often do: he didn't change the policy, only the emphasis. The administration had left the impression that the U.S. military forces might be in Saudi Arabia for the long haul, but Bush offered a different spin when he said those forces will not remain there ``for one day longer than is necessary.'' Once their mission is completed, ``every single American soldier'' will be brought home, he said. These comments seemed aimed at Arab critics who, although opposed to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, feel offended that American infidels are armed to the teeth and wandering around Islam's most sacred turf. In this category is Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khameini who, while no friend of Iraq, invited states of the region last month to ``fight America's aggression'' in the ``cause of Allah.'' Bush also appeared to put to rest the notion that the answer to long-term gulf stability is an American-led military alliance. Secretary of State James A. Baker III raised that possibility a month ago in congressional testimony, but the president said such a task should be left to the gulf states themselves. Bush thus indicated an awareness about Arab sensibilities about American influence in the region. In his speech, the president stressed his interest in a diplomatic solution in the gulf, declining to repeat his earlier warnings that the presence of 1,000 or so American hostages in Iraq and Kuwait will not deter him from taking military action against Iraq. He also offered something for Arabs who support the restoration of Kuwaiti sovereignty but who are embittered by Israeli occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Once Iraq leaves Kuwait unconditionally, Bush said, ``I truly believe there may be opportunities ... for all the states and peoples of the region to settle conflicts that divide the Arabs from Israel.'' Put another way, Bush implied that unless Saddam Hussein withdraws from Kuwait, no one should expect any progress toward an Arab-Israeli settlement. Previously, the administration had rejected even a hint of linkage between the two conflicts. As officials see it, restoration of Kuwaiti authority would not threaten Iraq, but the establishment of a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza would threaten Israel unless ironclad guarantees are negotiated. In that sense, the two issues are not viewed here as analogous, but Bush made the link anyway without giving anything up. After all, it's campaign season and, like any good politician, Bush is looking for support. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Looks for Repeat of 1988 Senate Upset in Montana
DOC.TEXT: Republican Senate candidate Allen Kolstad has the White House on his side, but Sen. Max Baucus has the money, the lead and widespread appeal among rural Montana voters. Kolstad, the state's lieutenant governor, is a wealthy rancher and grain farmer who is trying to tar Baucus as a liberal in favor of big government. Kolstad's conservative pitch even includes a reminder that he ``opposes Ted Kennedy on most national issues.'' But Baucus pays close attention to rural and economic concerns. Pet issues include aid to rural hospitals, Essential Air Service subsidies for rural airline routes and agricultural trade. He voted against the 1990 farm bill, saying it didn't do enough for farmers. Kolstad was at least 20 points behind Baucus in an independent mid-September poll. In addition, the Republican is up against the largest campaign bankroll in Montana history. Baucus raised $1.9 million in the 18 months ending in June, a princely sum in a state with only 800,000 people. Aggressive fund-raising efforts continue. Baucus says he's just taking precautions. Kolstad had only $267,000 in campaign funds on June 30, but if the race gets closer, he may look to national GOP groups for eleventh-hour fund-raising help. That approach worked in 1988, when political newcomer Conrad Burns narrowly upset two-term Democratic Sen. John Melcher of Montana to become the first Republican U.S. senator from this state in 36 years. The huge infusions of cash used to help Burns are being challenged in a lawsuit and in a complaint before the Federal Election Commission. ``If someone unfairly attacks me, I'm going to respond,'' says Baucus. ``I just have be to prepared for the possibility that I'll face the same deluge of dollars.'' In the 1988 race, Burns, a former farm-and-ranch broadcaster, attacked Melcher as a liberal out of touch with conservative, rural Montana. Kolstad has adopted the same strategy. ``More federal bureaucracy, more federal control, the higher deficits - there are the things I'm going to be fighting against in Washington,'' says Kolstad. Like Burns, Kolstad was recruited by national GOP heavyweights, including President Bush and former President Reagan. Bush raised more than $100,000 for Kolstad when the president traveled to Montana in July. Kolstad cannot claim the mantle of political outsider. He spent 20 years in the Montana Legislature before winning the lieutenant governorship on the GOP ticket with Gov. Stan Stephens in 1988. The Stephens-Kolstad adminstration has not been universally popular in Montana, struggling with tax and budget issues and controversial appointees. Recent polls show his ``negatives'' nearly doubled since a similar poll in mid-June. Kolstad, 58, says he is saving his money for a last-minute barrage of media advertising attacking Baucus on his votes against defense spending, tax cuts and budget-balancing measures. The 48-year-old Baucus, running for a third term, has been working hard to dispel whatever liberal image he may have had. He earns relatively high marks from most liberal interest groups but insists he doesn't care about ratings. ``I don't look left, I don't look right, I look forward - to what is the best solution for Montana,'' says Baucus. ``Most people are more concerned with producing results for Montana than with labels.'' Baucus has barely mentioned Kolstad in campaign materials, preferring instead to emphasize efforts he says have created or protected jobs in economically depressed Montana. While differences between the candidates exist - Baucus is pro-choice on abortion, Kolstad is not, for example - the race has generated few fireworks.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Revamps Fall Prime Time Schedule
DOC.TEXT: ``The Flash,'' CBS' superhero action show, has sprinted away from a Thursday night ratings battle with ``The Simpsons'' and ``The Cosby Show.'' Beginning on Oct. 25, the Scarlet Speedster will start a half hour later, (8:30 p.m. EDT Thursdays) leaving the animated Simpsons of Fox Broadcasting Co. to do battle with Cosby's NBC sitcom, CBS announced Thursday. ABC, NBC, and Fox executives said Thursday there were no changes to be announced in their respective schedules. ``In its two outings, `The Flash' has created tremendous excitement for younger viewers,'' said Peter Tortorici, CBS' senior vice president of program planning. ``By moving to 8:30 we feel that an even larger number of those viewers will have a chance to see it.'' In addition, CBS said the environmental action show ``E.A.R.T.H. Force'' has been placed on hiatus and ``Lenny'' has been put on indefinite hold. ``E.A.R.T.H. Force'' was an eco-failure in the ratings and with critics, who complained that it was underwritten, overacted and that the capital letters and periods in the show's title were too difficult to type. It finished 85th in last week's A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings, and its last broadcast was Sept. 29. ``Lenny,'' which stars Lenny Clarke, will return to the schedule in a time period soon to be announced, CBS said. It ranked 78th last week, and its last episode aired Wednesday at 8 p.m. EDT. ``We are anxious to see it back on our schedule in a time period where more viewers will be available to enjoy it,'' Tortorici said. Moving ``The Flash'' to 8:30 makes it one of the few hourlong TV shows ever to start on the half-hour. ``Top Cops,'' the reality-based police drama, will oppose ``Cosby'' and ``The Simpsons,'' and CBS' sitcom ``Doctor, Doctor'' will move in from Wednesday nights to follow ``The Flash.'' On Oct. 24, CBS News' ``48 Hours'' will move from Saturday nights into the vacancy left by ``Lenny'' and ``Doctor, Doctor,'' the network said. CBS also said the Oct. 25 premiere of ``Sons and Daughters,'' a multi-generational family drama, would be delayed ``until a later date.'' ``Wiseguy,'' starring Steven Bauer, will return to the CBS schedule on Nov. 17 with a two-hour season premiere before moving to its 10 p.m. EST time slot, CBS said. CBS also announced that ``Broken Badges,'' a police show about a unit composed of psychologically and emotionally troubled officers, will begin with a two-hour special Nov. 24 before moving to its regular Saturday night slot.

DOC.HEAD: Small African Nation Facing Ecological Crisis
With PM-Rwanda
EDITOR'S NOTE: The writer recently spent more than a week in Rwanda on a reporting assignment. He departed before the fighting erupted.
DOC.TEXT: The small central African nation of Rwanda faced a population and ecological crisis even before it was invaded this week by armed refugees from neighboring Uganda. An exodus of Asian businessmen from their adopted country was an ominous sign of deteriorating conditions, including overpopulation, soil erosion and AIDS. Western experts say more than 50 families of mainly Indian and Pakistani origin have left Rwanda in recent months in search of fresh opportunities in neighboring Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire - countries also suffering from poverty, disease and violence. Reflecting the trend, the black market price for U.S. dollars, preferably in $100 bills favored for smuggling, shot up to more than double the bank exchange rate of 68 Rwanda francs per dollar. Aid agencies estimate that fewer than 500 Asian families remain in a population of about 8 million people crammed into a rugged landscape only the size of Maryland. Western experts warn that a human and environmental disaster might occur in this decade in the former Belgian protectorate, which gained independence in 1962. The ecological balance is already threatened. Early this year at least 300 people died in sporadic outbreaks of famine in the remote south, said a Western aid worker interviewed by The Associated Press last month in Kigali, the capital. In the west, Lake Kivu, running most of the way along the border with Zaire, had little fish life left because of caustic runoff from cultivated volcanic uplands nearby. Rwanda is Africa's most densely populated country, with an average of 566 people living on every rocky and eroded square mile of land. The government of President Juvenal Habyarimana reports the average Rwandan woman bears 8.6 children, the highest birth rate in the world. At the present rate, the population will double by the year 2006. ``Land pressure is critical. There are simply too many people living on too little land,'' said the aid specialist, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Annually, cultivated land loses at least 1.5 inches of topsoil to erosion. Crops are grown on 60-degree slopes, and in other areas the level of acid in exhausted soil is a fraction away from the reading that would classify the land as barren. In 1981, the average Rwandan's daily nourishment amounted to 2,511 calories. It dropped to 1,804 calories in 1990, and current projections indicate the figure will sink to about 1,400 calories by the year 2,000. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization says that adults need a basic minimum of 2,100 calories a day to lead a healthy life. In 10 years, experts predict, hunger will be widespread and food aid will be needed on a scale not seen since the Ethiopian famine of the mid-1980s. Even if all the remaining patches of nature preserve and forest were turned over to agriculture, additional food production ``would only cover the population growth for two years,'' a Kigali-based European researcher told the AP. ``Without the forests acting as water-retaining sponges, the ultimate ecological collapse would hasten,'' said the researcher, speaking on condition of anonymity. In Rwanda's towns, where only 5 percent of the population live, up to 40 percent of the people are estimated to be infected by the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a mainly heterosexual disease in Africa. A large proportion of these may die within the next decade, say hospital officials. Also, 1 in every 5 babies born in the towns can be expected to die before age 4, having contracted the AIDS virus in an infected mother's womb.

DOC.HEAD: Worldwide Broadcast of `Imagine' Slated For Lennon's 50th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: John Lennon's 50th birthday will be marked with a celebration beyond even the slain rock star's utopian vision: his peace anthem ``Imagine'' playing simultaneously for 1 billion people in 130 countries. ``This idea appealed to me, because not only will we cover the whole world, but also there's something that's very small,'' said Lennon's widow, Yoko Ono, who will speak briefly before the song is played Oct. 9 at 10 a.m. EDT. ``It's not a pandemonium. And I thought that was in John's spirit in a way - we didn't believe in pandemoniums. We believed in just an honest kind of communication.'' Lennon was gunned down outside his Manhattan apartment house in December 1980. The 10-minute event will be broadcast worldwide from the United Nations, and will also feature a short introduction by Marcela Perez de Cuellar, wife of the U.N. secretary general. A taped message from Lennon will be broadcast before ``Imagine'' is played. ``There's no commercials. There's no sponsors. It is a pure, simple, very touching event,'' said Jeff Pollack, the radio and television consultant who came up with the idea. As of Thursday, more than 1,000 radio stations and networks from 50 countries had signed on for the satellite broadcast. U.S. Armed Forces television and radio will hit another 80-plus countries. The event will also air on MTV in 25 countries, said network spokeswoman Andrea Smith. Pollack, the head of the California-based Pollack Media Group, said the idea came to him after an April meeting with Ono where they discussed possible tributes for the 50th birthday. ``I was riding around in a cab in New York City, and then `Imagine' came on the radio. It just flashed: what if we played this song around the world?'' said Pollack. He made the proposal to Yoko, who gave it the go-ahead. Ono believes the recent events in Germany, Eastern Europe and particularly the Middle East point up the importance of Lennon's peace message. ``When this was discussed, we had no knowledge of what would happen in Iraq and Kuwait, you know. And now it seems very appropriate that this be sung all over the world,'' said Ono. ``It's going to be sung in the Persian Gulf. ``I don't know, the timing is incredible. It's beyond me ... It's beautiful.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Actress Jaclyn Smith says television has treated her better than the silver screen. ``I've been offered Hollywood parts, but they were as an `armpiece' or decoration. Or there was nudity,'' the ex-Charlie's Angel says in this Sunday's Parade magazine. ``And they were just not as good as the parts I get in television.'' Smith, 42, admits she's happy working in TV, although Broadway could lure her from the tube. ``Broadway ... now that would be something else. I'd love to do a stage musical,'' she said. Smith, who has appeared in several television movies and miniseries, stars in the NBC movie, ``Danielle Steel's Kaleidoscope,'' later this month. --- LAS VEGAS (AP) - Phyllis McGuire of the McGuire Sisters says there's something about diamonds that make you smile. McGuire, 59, who says her jewelry collection is one of the largest in the nation, put part of it on display Wednesday for the first time at a jewelry store near the strip, as a favor for friend and shop owner Wayne Christensen. ``No two stones are alike,'' said McGuire, pointing to a canary yellow 42-carat diamond ring she was wearing and one in a display case. ``Each have their own personality.'' McGuire, who keeps expensive pieces in Las Vegas and New York bank vaults, declined to reveal their value, saying only that it was ``in the millions.'' She and sisters Christine and Dorothy amassed a slew of gold records in the 1950s and '60s as one of America's hottest trios before splitting up in 1968. They returned to the stage five years ago. McGuire also is known for her relationship with mobster Sam Giancana, who was slain gangland style in Chicago. She says she's writing a book about their time together. --- ANAHEIM, Calif. (AP) - Gene Autry, owner of the California Angels since the baseball team's founding in 1961, has passed on the duties of club president so he can devote more time to his Western Heritage Museum in Los Angeles. Autry, who turned 83 last Saturday, said Thursday the move represents a withdrawal from the daily demands of the team's affairs. ``It just got to be too much for me,'' the former movie cowboy said at an Anaheim Stadium news conference. ``I've been so involved with other things. I'll no longer have to take phone calls every day about the team.'' Named as Autry's successor was Richard M. Brown, an attorney who has represented Autry's broadcasting empire since 1981 and has sat on the Angels' board of directors since 1986. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Rapper Will Smith, better known as The Fresh Prince, says he may have grown up too fast. ``I started my music career at 16, moved out of the house when I was 18 - got my own house, had a car and was worrying about having my taxes done when other kids were going to the prom,'' Smith said. Smith, 22, who now stars in NBC's ``Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' said in this Sunday's Parade magazine he's now making up for his lost teen years. ``It would have been nice to have a few more years just hanging out. So I'm indulging my young tendencies now,'' he said. ``I just bought my Nintendo yesterday, and I have it set up in the living room.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - ``Saturday Night Live'' regular Kevin Nealon took custody of three monkeys abandoned by a Soviet circus that went bankrupt during a U.S. tour. Nealon said Wednesday the Bim Bom circus left the monkeys behind because of ``behavioral problems.'' ``They looked like there was no fight left in them. They looked angry and upset and helpless. It made you want to cry,'' said Nealon's wife, Linda. The couple, who took custody of the monkeys on behalf of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, said they hoped to return them to the wild, where they would not be subjected to trainers' discipline. The last of the original 115-member circus returned to the Soviet Union on Aug. 23. --- RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil (AP) - Percussionist Alvin Patterson of the Jamaican reggae group The Wailers, formerly led by Bob Marley, is recovering in Brazil after undergoing surgery following a stroke. ``Alvin was moved out of intensive care today,'' Sallim Emed, director of the Cajuru Hospital in Curitiba, said Thursday. ''The surgery was successful nd there were no complications.'' Patterson suffered the stroke Sunday shortly before a scheduled concert in Curitiba, a city 1,500 miles southwest of Rio. The operation was performed Tuesday morning. The Wailers, one of Jamaica's most popular reggae bands, were in Brazil for a series of concerts. Marley died in 1981 at age 36 from brain cancer. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Singer Garth Brooks has been named one of the regular performers on the Grand Ole Opry country music show. Brooks, 28, will be the youngest of the more than 60-member cast when he debuts Saturday night. Brooks also is a finalist for five Country Music Association awards that will be presented Monday night during a nationally televised broadcast. He has been nominated for male vocalist of the year, music video of the year for ``The Dance,'' the Horizon Award for a promising performer and single and song of the year, both for ``If Tomorrow Never Comes.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Drawing Less Ambitious Star Wars Blueprint
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is revising its Star Wars plan to build a defense against limited strikes from enemy missiles instead of an all-out attack by the Soviet Union, the project's director says. The change reflects the administration's view that improved U.S.-Soviet relations and the collapse of communism make it less likely that Moscow would unleash its arsenal of thousands of globe-circling nuclear ballistic missiles. It also points up a decline in congressional support for spending billions of dollars a year on the Strategic Defense Initiative, commonly called Star Wars, and the administration's desire to deploy some form of missile defense system in the mid-1990s. The new system, not yet officially announced, is being designed to defend against ``tens or hundreds'' of missiles fired accidentally by the Soviets or deliberately by a Third World renegade leader, rather than the thousands of missiles that would be expected to fill the skies in a full-scale strike by Moscow. Henry F. Cooper, the Pentagon official in charge of the Strategic Defense Initiative, said in an interview Thursday that the revised anti-missile system could be deployed more quickly than the system originally envisioned. He said he could not give a target date for deployment or a precise estimate of the cost. ``I would say it's still somewhat uncertain but obviously less than'' the Pentagon's estimate of $55 billion for the initial phase of the current Star Wars plan. About $20 billion has been spent on Star Wars research since 1984. The administration is requesting $4.7 billion for Star Wars in the current budget year, but Congress is expected to shave at least $1 billion off that figure. The House's version of the 1991 defense budget set Star Wars spending at $2.3 billion. Cooper, who last July took over as the first civilian director of Star Wars, said he decided to push the less ambitious plan in hopes of winning a consensus in Congress that at least a limited defense against missiles is feasible. If that is accomplished, he said, then the administration might eventually gain the needed political support and financing to expand the system. He has nicknamed the new approach the Protection Against Limited Strike system. ``It would not constitute an effective defense against a massive raid, but would provide protection - not deterrence but protection - against an accidental or unauthorized and even deliberate terrorist attack of, I don't know, tens or hundreds'' of missiles, he said. Cooper also raised the possibility that the initially deployed system might exclude the space-based weapons that have been at the heart of Star Wars since former President Reagan launched the idea in 1983 as a way to end nuclear confrontation. ``In my mind it would involve space- and ground-based elements both,'' Cooper said, but later he added: ``We may dispute about whether space-based elements are required - I don't know.'' Inclusion of space-based weapons is controversial because the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty prohibits space-based defenses. Washington is pressing Moscow to agree to modify or drop the ABM Treaty to permit a transition from a nuclear balance based on offensive threats to one based on defense. Cooper, a quiet-spoken former chief U.S. negotiator at the superpower Defense and Space Talks in Geneva, said his ideas for transforming the Star Wars program originated in a classified review he conducted for Defense Secretary Dick Cheney shortly before he replaced Gen. George Monahan as the program director. He said his review found serious problems in the ground-based elements of a ``Phase One'' deployment of Star Wars weapons. Phase One included ground- and space-based satellites to detect missile launches and track their trajectory; a constellation of space-based rockets to knock down the missiles in space; ground-based rockets to destroy missiles re-entering Earth's atmosphere; a ground-based radar to help guide the interceptor rockets, and a command center for human management and control of the battle. Cooper said the revised plan calls for fewer and differently designed ground-based rockets, a vastly reformulated ground-based radar, and fewer ``brilliant pebbles,'' or space-based rockets that would vaporize enemy missiles by ramming them.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Plans to Work Hard and Squeeze in Some Washington Sightseeing
Laserphoto CR1 of Oct. 4
DOC.TEXT: David Souter says he will live up to his monkish, bookish, workaholic image when he joins the Supreme Court next week, but he also hopes to do a few ``touristy things'' after he moves to Washington. Souter, whose primary after-work pleasure seems to be more work, said this week he expects that he will stick to his office and lawbooks at least for his first year in the nation's capital. ``We all know the work load there is enormous,'' he said Tuesday in an interview with The Associated Press. ``I realize what I'm getting into. I intended to work a long week anyway, but I imagine I'm going to have my limits tested.'' He said he understands his fellow justices want him to start as soon as he is sworn in Tuesday morning. ``They very muchwwanted me to start sitting Tuesday because there is always the possibility of a 4-4 decision if they're sitting without a full complement,'' Souter said. What little free time Souter may have already is being mapped out for him by the district's social set. An article this week in The Washington Post named the 51-year-old jurist the city's most eligible bachelor, which Souter said ``sounds pretty good to me.'' ``I've really got to wait and see what effects it brings,'' he said. Potential dates might prepare themselves for a trip to the Smithsonian Institution or the Lincoln Memorial. ``There are some things that I have never done that most school kids have done,'' Souter said. ``I have never, for example, toured the Capitol.'' He did manage a brief peep at the building's Rotunda as he called on members of the Senate Judiciary Committee in July. ``I said to the man from the White House who was with me, `I've just got to go in and look at this for a minute,''' he said. ``I kind of gawked around until I realized that people were moving their eyes from the murals to me, so I retreated. ... ``Someday - I may have to do it with a paper bag over my head - but someday I'm going to do some of those touristy things that I would really like to do.'' His one well-known recreation - hiking - may have to wait until he's able to return to New Hampshire's White Mountains. ``I don't expect much,'' he said. ``Years ago, I did get down into the Blue Ridge (Mountains) once. I'd like to see them again, but we'll have to wait and see. I just don't think there's going to be much time for those excursions.'' His last weekend before joining the court will be spent finding somewhere to live and reading briefs. Souter said his lack of preparation - no apartment, no law clerks, no secretaries - wasn't carelessness, but simply practical. He worried the Senate might not approve his nomination. ``You can chalk it up maybe to, as one of my friends says, a nautical superstition,'' he said. ``Maybe I read too many Greek tragedies. I don't believe something's going to happen like that until it's happened. ``Even apart from that, I think if I were a member of the Senate and I realized somebody was out lining up law clerks or apartments or anything else, I think I would regard it as extraordinarily presumptuous.'' Lining up an apartment, however, should not be hard. Souter's living requirements are simple - he told friends that all he wants is a bedroom big enough for a bed, a living room big enough for a chair, a kitchen and a bathroom. He plans to live in the city for his first year, but later may move, like his high court colleagues, to the Maryland or Virginia suburbs. ``I, after all, have been spending the last 23 or 24 years of my life with a ... 25-minute commute,'' he said. ``I realize it's not so easy, (but) you don't have to look out for cows down there.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Underestimates Poor, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: There are 13 million ``hidden poor'' people in America, those living in destitution but not counted by the official government measure of poverty, the head of a House committee says. Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, chairman of the Select Committee on Hunger, said Thursday that Census Bureau poverty statistics released last week rely on a poverty line standard that is outdated and understates the problem. The Census Bureau's statistics for 1989 show an overall poverty rate of 12.8 percent, or 31 million people - about what it was the year before. ``These rates, as shameful as they are, mask the real depth of the problem,'' Hall said as he opened a hearing on the need for adjustments in the official government poverty measurement. ``Thirty-one million is millions short of what the American people and many scholars think about the number of poor Americans,'' he said, citing studies that put the figure 13 million higher. ``Thirteen million hidden poor. With these additional poor, we're talking about one out of every five Americans living in poverty.'' The official poverty line is based on government measurements established in 1963. There have been annual adjustments since then to account for inflation, but witnesses told the panel those adjustments haven't been adequate. ``That measure represented a reasonable estimate of minimum family needs in 1963, but it has never been updated to reflect changes in consumption patterns and standards of living since the early 1960s,'' said Patricia Ruggles, an economist with the congressional Joint Economic Committee. ``In fact, that measure is based on consumption data from the mid-1950s,'' she said. The poverty scale was based on estimates of minimum adequate food budgets and then tripled, on the assumption that food represents about one-third of total expenditures, Ruggles said. The scale has not been changed to reflect that the average U.S. family now spends 42 percent of its income on housing, she said, or that fewer families have the services of a full-time homemaker to take care of young children. It also does not consider differences in cost of living between regions or urban and rural areas. Updated scales based on more modern estimates of food and housing costs would raise the poverty threshold more than 50 percent to $14,000 to $16,000 or more for a family of three in 1988. The official poverty measure is $9,435, she said. Two government benefit programs whose eligibility standards are tied directly to the official poverty measure - food stamps and Medicaid - use cutoffs substantially higher, around 130 percent of the poverty line. ``These higher eligibility thresholds are perhaps an implicit acknowledgement that our current poverty thresholds do not represent a realistic minimum standard of consumption,'' Ruggles said. A bill passed by the House would provide for a National Academy of Science study of revisions to the poverty line. It awaits Senate action. Hall said many were reluctant to redraw the poverty lines because the numbers of poor would be increased. But he said a more accurate count ``will lead to a new sense of just how urgent our fight against hunger and poverty in America really is.'' William P. O'Hare, director of policy studies for the Population Referece Bureau, a liberal advocacy group, cited polling for his group that showed the public believes actual poverty begins at a higher income. ``Use of the official poverty measure distorts our understanding of poverty and understates the dimensions of poverty and hunger in America,'' O'Hare said. ``Nearly 13 million people who have incomes just above the official poverty line are not counted as poor by the government, but are considered to be poor by their neighbors.''
Editors: A rollcall from the House vote on the Budget agreement is planned. It should move within the next hour. The AP.

DOC.HEAD: House Foe of Arts Endowment Vows to Fight Compromise Bill
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Dana Rohrabacher says he'll fight a new compromise bill on the National Endowment for the Arts as a piece of ``flimflummery'' that will do nothing to halt federal support for obscene and sacrilegious art. The California Republican, a staunch conservative and ardent foe of the federal arts agency, said he will seek to defeat the bipartisan measure drafted by Reps. Pat Williams, D-Mont., and E. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo. The House begins debate on the proposal next week. ``It's a sham and a facade to deceive the voters,'' Rohrabacher said. ``It's a total fraud. It portends to offer some kind of restrictions on federal funding for obscenity, when in reality it opens the floodgates.'' Williams and Coleman, who announced agreement on their compromise Thursday after weeks of intensive negotiations, proposed to extend the NEA's life for three years and let the courts decide whether federally subsidized arts projects are obscene. Rohrabacher said their bill was ``the type of flimflummery that makes Americans cynical about the politicians in Washington.'' He said it reflects the Democratic leadership's loyalty to ``a fringe of freak artists who insist they have the right to federal tax dollars to produce pornography and sacrilegious art.'' Rohrabacher says he will introduce a floor amendment that would prohibit NEA support for a laundry list of taboos, including obscenity, indecency, child pornography and works that attack religion, desecrate the American flag or contain any part of a human fetus. Coleman and Rep. Paul Henry, R-Mich., hinted that the real aim of Rohrabacher and his conservative allies was to dismantle the NEA or abolish it entirely. ``The question is whether to dismantle this agency or make it better,'' Henry said. ``This bill would make it better.'' Williams predicted that their measure ``will pass the House by a significant majority of both Democrats and Republicans.'' The bill could provide House members a way to defuse the politically explosive issue of federal support for ``obscene art'' in an election year. The controversy began 18 months ago when conservative lawmakers and religious fundamentalists attacked the NEA for subsidizing exhibitions of works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano, which they denounced as obscene and blasphemous. The Williams-Coleman compromise would forbid the endowment from financing obscenity. But it would shift from the NEA to the courts the burden of deciding what is obscene, based on the Supreme Court's 1973 guidelines. Under the bill, any grant recipient who is convicted of violating obscenity laws would be required to repay the government and would be barred from receiving further NEA grants for at least three years. In a bow to Republican demands, the bill also would boost the states' share of NEA grant money from 20 percent to 35 percent over the next three years. Coleman originally had sought to shift 60 percent of NEA funds to the control of state arts agencies. The measure also would make sweeping changes in the endowment's grant-making procedures with the aim of making the NEA more accountable to the taxpaying public. It would bolster the NEA chairman's authority to make final grant decisions, and dilute the panels of outside artists and arts managers which select grant applications for approval. Similar legislation is awaiting Senate floor action. Also headed for the House floor is a separate bill to provide $180 million in NEA spending next year, a 5 percent increase over its current $171 million budget. Meanwhile, NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer and evangelist Pat Robertson clashed again Thursday over Robertson's claim that federal funds supported an Atlanta puppet show featuring simulated oral sex. In a Sept. 28 letter to Robertson, released Thursday, Frohnmayer vigorously denied that any NEA funds were spent on the puppet show or its sponsor, the Arts Festival of Atlanta. Robertson ignored Frohnmayer's demand for a public retraction of his ``categorically false'' allegation. The evangelist told his television audience that if members of Congress vote to give the NEA more money next year, ``it shows they are totally out of touch with America and with morality.''

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Theater Bows to Pressure, Cancels Showing of First NC-17 Film
DOC.TEXT: A movie theater bowed to pressure from town officials and canceled the showing of ``Henry and June,'' the first film rated NC-17, the designation that replaced the X rating. Showcase Cinema was to have started screening ``Henry and June'' today. The film based on the diaries of Anais Nin chronicles her affairs with writer Henry Miller and his wife. ``They can call it whatever they want to call it,'' Anthony Taurasi, chairman of the town's board of selectmen, said Thursday. ``If it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck then it's a duck. Let's call it what it is.'' The Motion Picture Association of America replaced the X rating with the NC-17 rating on Sept. 26. NC-17 means no one under age 17 can be admitted to the films. Selectman Frank Geishecker told The Patriot Lddger of Quincy on Wednesday he would consider revoking the theater's license if the film was shown. ``We are not censors,'' he said. ``The censoring is done by the rating bureau. All we care is that we preserve the community standards of the town of Dedham. That is our mission, that is our job.'' Both selectmen admit they have not seen the film released by Universal Pictures. Directed by Philip Kaufman and starring Fred Ward and Uma Thurman, ``Henry and June'' received the NC-17 rating because of two lesbian sex scenes and a shot of an erotic drawing. Ira Korf, chief executive of Showcase Cinema's parent company, National Amusements Inc., said he pulled the film from the Dedham theater because of complaints from the two selectmen. ``I pointed out very strongly this film wasn't rated X,'' said Fred Mound, president of distribution for Universal Pictures. ``There was extreme pressure coming down. Obviously, I'm very disturbed by it.'' The MPAA switch was made exactly to avoid these situations, Mound said. The association changed the designation because the X rating carried the stigma of pornography. Korf said National Amusements had decided to show NC-17-rated films because the new rating means they cannot be confused with hard-core pornography films. Taurasi said that Showcase Cinema had a gentleman's agreement with the town not to show X-rated films that the NC-17 rating was ``just a way around the ratings bureau.'' Dedham is a middle-class suburb with more than 25,000 residents, about 10 miles south of Boston. ``Henry & June'' was to have opened on 77 screens in 31 cities in the United States and Canada today. Instead of ``Henry and June,'' the Dedham theater will show the action-adventure movie ``Darkman.''

DOC.HEAD: Terrorism Threats by Radical Groups Increase
With PM-Gulf-Iraq-Workers, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian groups are increasingly threatening retaliation for any harm that comes to Iraq, especially at the hands of the United States. A group called the Palestinian Popular Army-Black Panther Forces faxed a statement to The Associated Press bureau in Nicosia late Thursday headlined ``Warning'' in bold letters. ``The tempo of imperialist threats against Iraq is increasing day after day with the aim of bringing Iraq to its knees through hunger,'' said the Arabic language statement. ``Orders have been issued to our forces wherever they exist for immediate retaliation on land, sea and air against the aggressor, should Iraq be subjected to any aggression,'' it said. Not as much is known about the group, which has been active by issuing similar statements since the Kuwait invasion. The group is believed to be supportive of Fatah, the main branch of the Palestine Liberation Organization. It was the third such threat in two days by radical Palestinians. The threats have heightened fears of a terrorist campaign against the Western and Arab nations confronting Iraq since the Persian Gulf crisis began. Iraq has been isolated by the international community since Aug. 2, when it seized Kuwait. Since then a U.S.-led multinational force has been sent to the region, and the U.N. Security Council has imposed a land, sea and air embargo on Iraq to try to force it to withdraw from Kuwait. The U.S. State Department Saturday warned Americans traveling abroad that they run the risk of Iraqi-sponsored attacks ``in the near future.'' The Arab Liberation Front, based in Baghdad, said in a statement Thursday it ``will respond decisively and immediately with powerful strikes if Iraqi civilian aircraft are endangered by the United States.'' ``All American interests in the Arab world and in the world at large will not be far from the hands of the revolutionaries who will prove that the whole universe could be a battlefield so that the Americans will know what kind of foe they face,'' the statement said. It was published in Baghdad's al-Thawra daily, the newspaper of the Iraq's ruling Baath Socialist Party. The Arab Liberation Front, which has a few hundred men, has not been very active since it and other PLO factions were forced to evacuate Beirut in 1982 during the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. It is led by Abdul-Rahim Ahmed, a member of the PLO's executive committee. Thursday's warnings came a day after the Palestinian guerrilla leader who masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise liner Achille Lauro said he would attack U.S. aircraft if Iraqi planes were struck in the air embargo. Abul Abbas, head of the radical Palestine Liberation Front, called the air embargo ``the operation of air piracy by one state against another to serve its narrow-minded interests.'' Abul Abbas' statement was published Wednesday in Al-Jumhuriya, another government-run daily in Baghdad. Abbas did not specify what action would be taken. But extremist Palestinian leaders based in Iraq have specialized in attacks on airliners and airports in the past.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Troops Take R-and-R With Tanks at the Ready
With PM-Gulf-Iraq-Workers, Bjt
DOC.DATELINE: IN THE NORTHERN DESERT, Saudi Arabia (AP)
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers call this recreation outpost Panther Paradise, but it hardly lives up to its name. Some soldiers pass the time racing beetles or watching scorpions fight. Others try to run pass patterns on a more or less flat patch of sand that serves as a football field. Still others congregate at the PX, a metal shipping container, or the cinema, a tent with some cots and a television set showing Marlon Brando mumbling his way through ``The Godfather.'' Four hundred yards away, the M-1 tanks of the 2nd Battalion, 69th Armor Regiment, known as the Panthers, lie in wait under camouflage netting, ready to roar into action if the order comes. ``Paradise is OK, but I wish it was a little farther to the rear,'' said Spec. Kristopher McCoy, 20, from Ft. Wayne, Ind. The battalion clerk was among the two dozen troops who on Thursday were enjoying a two-day break from the rigors of training. But they were also waiting, possibly for war with Iraq. The U.S. military command is formulating a policy to allow troops rest and recreation outside Saudi Arabia. Last weekend, the command opened its first full-fledged R-and-R center in the country at a location off limits to everyone else. In addition, individual units have been ordered to set up rest centers close to their front-line positions. This spot, known by the soldiers as Panther Paradise, is one of the first. ``If it got any better than this, I wouldn't know what to do,'' said command Sgt. Major Tim Gabel of Forth Worth, Texas, watching Brando from the doorway of the darkened movie tent where cool is only a relative term. Sgt. 1st Class Richard Hawk of Atlanta, who runs the operation, said the portable showers and wooden-floored tents, including the cinema, are about as luxurious as it can get in the desert. A trio of soldiers tossed a football around, but they quit after a few minutes of trying to run pass patterns in the loose sand. Hawk said that in addition to watching beetles and scorpions, the soldiers occupy themselves playing volleyball, chess, checkers, darts and card games. ``I'd like to have basketball, too, but this stuff ain't too swift,'' Hawk said, kicking the sand. He said he paid $1,500 for chips and dips so the troops can munch away while watching videotapes. Soldiers can also do their laundry and get haircuts. ``Some other units have PXs and some might have a VCR, but even people from brigade headquarters come down here,'' he said. ``We don't turn anybody away.'' Staff Sgt. Raymond Horne, 24, of Brooklyn, N.Y., stands behind the PX counter, selling cigarettes, snacks, magazines and other items. The cold drinks are free. So is the advise he dispenses. ``Basically, the soldiers want to know when we're going home,'' he said. ``I tell 'em, six months - hopefully.''

DOC.HEAD: Slam Dunk Basketball Hoops? Some Would Bench the Plan
DOC.TEXT: Neighborhood beautifiers who say driveway basketball hoops are eyesores want to slam dunk them all. Opponents eager to bench the plan say it's un-American. ``What's the point of having the pristine appearance in Garden City if it's not for our children to enjoy,'' Donna Robins, the mother of three ball-playing boys, said at a village trustees meeting Thursday night. Others in town - including New York Knicks Hall of Famer Dave DeBusschere and ex-New York Nets guard Bill Melchionne - are mounting a fast break to overturn the town's policy. The flap actually began two years ago, when the affluent Long Island town included basketball hoops under a 1924 law banning ``accessory structures.'' Free-standing basketball hoops on the side and front of homes were deemed unacceptable. Hoops attached to homes or garages or free-standing hoops located in back yards were allowed to remain. About 60 people, most of whom opposed the ban, crowded into the small village hall Thursday night. Joseph Asselta, an attorney with two boys and a hoop out front, said he would take the town to court if officials order him to take the basket down. He called the action unconstitutional because town officials had not uniformly enforced the 66-year-old law. The trustees were unmoved. They said letters will be sent immediately to 72 homeowners with offending hoops, giving them 90 days to comply. People who decide to flaunt the law and keep their rims intact face up to a $250-a-day fine, although they should be able to appeal to the local zoning board. ``I think it's absurd, and it seems ridiculous,'' said Melchionne, who played on the ABA champion Nets in 1974 with Julius Erving. ``If they don't have the availability of hoops, who knows what kids will do?'' DeBusschere echoed those comments to The Associated Press after returning from a trip to the Soviet Union. ``I don't buy the idea that it's an eyesore. I think it enhances a neighborhood. It humanizes it,'' said DeBusschere, who has a hoop hanging - legally - in his back yard. ``The sound of a dribbling basketball and the swish of a successful jump shot are the sounds of youtfful energy. ... It is as American as apple pie,'' said village trustee Jack Curry, who offered an alternate plan that was voted down. Mayor John McGowan, a member of the anti-hoops troops, shot back: ``Garden City has nothing against anything all-American. The village wants to keep Garden City beautiful, keep its aesthetic beauty.'' Curry's compromise would have saved all but three of the existing hoops, and ensured all future buckets were 30 feet from the nearest street. That plan was recently rejected by a 5-2 vote.

DOC.HEAD: Loss of Privately Owned Wetlands Dropped in Mid-1980s
DOC.TEXT: An Agriculture Department survey shows the loss of wetlands on private lands nationwide slowed significantly during the mid-1980s. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Thursday that the new figures by the department's Soil Conservation Service, or SCS, indicated wetland losses ranged between 100,000 and 200,000 acres per year from 1982 to 1987, including areas that reverted to open water. This was ``significantly less'' than wetland loss estimates before 1982-87, he said. No previous SCS estimates were available. Spokeswoman Diana Morse said the agency began its five-year surveys in 1977. The new figures comparing 1987 with 1982 were the first, she said. Estimates used in the surveys were based on information collected on 300,000 sample sites across the nation. The latest figures came from the agency's 1987 National Resources Inventory, or NRI, which is conducted on non-federal lands every five years in cooperation with the Iowa State University Statistical Laboratory. Officials said the inventory serves as the principal source of information on the status, condition and trends of soil, water and related resources. It also provides a soil-and-water data base for non-federal rural lands. The report said there were about 82 million ares of wetlands on non-federal rural lands in 1987, down from 83.2 million acres in 1982. However, SCS estimated the loss of wetlands to agricultural and development uses at ``closer to 500,000 acres,'' or an average of 100,000 acres per year. ``The remaining change in wetlands was due to factors such as 300,000 acres changing from private to federal ownership - still likely remaining in wetlands but not included in the SCS non-federal lands inventory - and over 400,000 acres that changed to open water, primarily adjacent to the Great Salt Lake in Utah and in southern Louisiana,'' the report said. Of the nearly 500,000 acres lost to agriculture and development, about 215,000 were converted farmland, including wetlands drying up because of drought, and about 280,000 acres to development. Regionally, the NRI indicated wetland losses over the five-year period were greatest in the Southeast, Mississippi Delta states, and the Great Lakes states. Losses were reported at 170,000 acres in the Southeast, 150,000 in the Delta, and 80,000 in the Great Lakes. Morse said there were no available breakdowns by state and that the SCS considered those estimates too inexact for publishing. She said the regional estimates were the only ones available. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Farm cooperatives, hurting badly a few years ago from the financial crunch on producers, have recovered most of their old zing, an annual report by the Agriculture Department shows. In 1989, the report said, co-ops reported their second-highest net income and third-highest sales. Overall, combined business volume was shown at $70.4 billion, up 6 percent from $66.4 billion in 1988. That was topped only by the record $73 billion in 1984 and the $71.5 billion in 1981. Net incomes in 1989 totaled nearly $1.9 billion, the report said. That was up 12.3 percent from 1988. The record was $1.94 billion in 1980. Randall E. Torgerson, administrator of the department's Agricultural Cooperative Service, said the higher business volume was due mostly to larger output of grains and oilseeds, higher price for poultry and higher prices and sales of fruits and vegetables, fertilizers and farm chemicals. Production of feed grains and soybeans was up sharply last year from 1988, when drought reduced yields. Increased earnings of farm supply co-ops were ``a major contributing factor'' to the near-record income, despite a increase in the number of cooperatives reporting losses in 1989, the report said. Those increased to 574 from 364 in 1988. However, the amount of losses decreased to $82.4 million last year from $164.7 million the previous year. Total cooperative business volume includes the value of products marketed; the sale of farm supplies such as fertilizer, chemicals, fuel and feed to members and other customers; and receipts from services, including trucking, storage, ginning and artificial insemination. Torgerson said the number of farm cooperatives and members continued a longtime downward trend. Co-op units declined to 4,799 last year from 4,937 in 1988, he said. Memberships dropped 1.4 percent to 4.14 million. The number of memberships exceeds the number of farms because many farmers belong to more than one co-op. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - An Agriculture Department scientist says that after 10 years he is close to developing a soybean that has both high protein and high yields. Plant geneticist Joseph W. Burton of the department's Agricultural Research Service said in a report that preliminary results show a boost in protein content to almost 47 percent from about 42 percent. The preliminary results also show excellent yields for the new bean, he said. Overall, it could mean a possible boost in revenue to soybean producers of $1 to $1.50 per bushel. Burton, who works at the agency's soybean and nitrogen fixation research unit in Raleigh, N.C., said it will take another year of testing to determine how best to make commercial use of the new bean.

DOC.HEAD: Arianespace Chairman Calls for Equity in Pricing, Market Access
DOC.TEXT: The new chairman of Arianespace, the European satellite launching company, says it is time the space-faring nations of the world have an equal footing in both their pricing policies and access to markets. Arianespace will not be able to continue its 10 years of successful growth ``if our competitors do not respect the same rules, the same manner of behavior,'' said Charles Bigot, who took over as chairman and chief executive officer two months ago. ``We are facing two kinds of competition,'' he said at a news conference Thursday. ``We are facing competition against American launchers, which are (in) the same kind of economy as Ariane, but we are facing also competition from Soviet launchers, Chinese launchers, which are coming from non-market countries.'' In the competition with the United States, Bigot said, Arianespace hopes to get agreement to open the launch market to everyone. The European firm, he said, has access to only one-third of the market, since the United States will not allow military and government satellites to be launched overseas. ``We consider our American competitors have access to all the market and we hope that in fact, Europe and the United States would get some agreement in order to open all the market to all the launch vehicle companies,'' he said. Bigot said, too, he would like to see a change in the pricing policies of American launch firms. ``There is a small, but important difference between the launcher in the United States and the launcher Ariane about fixed cost,'' he said. ``Fixed cost is what you have to pay to maintain facilities and the tools for producing the launcher.'' In the United States, Bigot said, the governmental market pays for the fixed cost while commercial customers bear only the additional expenses for a given launch. ``The way has to be different,'' said Bigot. ``You have to divide all the fixed cost by the number of launches and you have to attribute to each launch the pro rata part of the expenses.'' Through American accounting, the cost is lower ``and we insist to have the same kind of rules on both sides of the Atlantic,'' he said. Bigot said precautions must be taken with the competition from the Soviet Union and China, which do not operate in a free market economy. ``It is obvious they are not at all evaluating their cost in the same manner,'' he said. ``In fact, they don't know exactly their cost because they are not the same accounting system.'' Arianespace proposes that Europe and the United States work toward an agreement with those countries which would allow for an intermediate phase while they develop their economies. During that phase, they would be expected to ``self-limit'' their marketing activities, Bigot said. ``After this period, we could accept free access to the market - when they demonstrate that they have adopted the same rules for the economy,'' he said. In the first half of the 1980s, satellite owners depended on the space shuttle to launch their cargoes. But after the Challenger accident in 1986, then-President Reagan ordered the National Aeronautics and Space Administration out of the commercial launch business and encouraged private industry to step in. Orphaned by the new policy and by a shortage of launch vehicles, many satellite companies turned to Arianespace, giving that firm a major boost. ``We created and developed the commercial space transport business,'' Bigot said. ``At first we were a challenger. Now we consider in the commercial market we are the leader.'' In the past three years alone, 30 satellites have been launched on Ariane rockets. The three major players on the American launch market are McDonnell Douglas, which makes the Delta rocket; Martin Marietta with its Titan series and Genral Dynamics with the Atlas. All three rocket families are also used to lift military and government satellites into orbit.
