DOC.HEAD: Nomination of Ambassador to Burma to be Withdrawn
With PM-Diplomats on Hold, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A man introduced to the Senate as a veteran diplomat, but described in published reports as a longtime CIA agent, is being dropped as ambassador-designate to Burma. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., said Thursday the State Department told him Frederick Vreeland's nomination would be withdrawn. A department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed the decision to withdraw Vreeland's nomination, saying the Burmese refused to accept him after he made statements urging democratic changes in the Southeast Asian country. The pro-Democracy statements were described as nothing more than ``oft-stated U.S. policy.'' Burma's military junta has refused to yield power to a civilian government elected in May. But D'Amato said he did not believe that was the real reason for dropping Vreeland. The senator said he had planned to question Vreeland about evidence that he led efforts to cover up Bulgarian and Soviet involvement in the 1981 attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II. However, the State Department official who spoke of condition of anonymity said the attempt to kill the pope had nothing to do with the matter. D'Amato said that by law he could not comment on whether Vreeland was a CIA agent. Several published reports have identified Vreeland as an agent working under a diplomatic cover. He was listed in his official biography as an embassy officer in Rome in the years following the papal shooting incident. The biography supplied to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by the administration described Vreeland as a career diplomat with several State Department assignments. Vreeland, 63, is son of the late Vogue magazine editor, Diana Vreeland. Journalist Claire Sterling, in a 1984 book about the assassination attempt, said Vreeland warned her not to pursue the Bulgarian angle and told her she was on a Bulgarian hit list. D'Amato said he recently spoke with Sterling about her allegations and also had some first-hand knowledge of Italian officials' anger over Vreeland's activities in Rome. Ali Agca, a Turk who wounded the pope in St. Peter's Square, is serving a life term in Italy. Agca at first said he acted alone but later claimed Soviet involvement. An Italian court ruled there was not enough evidence to convict three Bulgarians charged in the case. D'Amato said he has met with the new president of Bulgaria, Zhelyu Zhelev, who has said he will pursue an inquiry into any Bulgarian connection to the attempt on the pope. D'Amato said he also wants an inquiry into any U.S. efforts to cover up. The motive for the coverup, said D'Amato, may have been to prevent an escalation of U.S.-Soviet differences or to prevent facts from coming out that might be embarrassing to U.S. officials. A closed-door hearing on the nomination was held in the Senate on Monday, but Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., held up committee approval of Vreeland after getting a letter from D'Amato. While the State Department official confirmed withdrawal of the nomination, department spokesman David Denny said he had no official release on it. Denny said Assistant Secretary Richard Solomon and Burmese Deputy Foreign Minister Ohn Gyaw met on Wednesday. He said Solomon urged the seating of the elected civilian government, protested harassment of U.S. embassy employees in Rangoon and called for a crackdown against opium production in Burma. But Denny declined to give details of Gyaw's response and said he did not know whether there was any discussion of Vreeland's nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Iraq Has Explosive Device Equivalent to Small Nuclear Bomb
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has high-explosive devices that pack the equivalent destructive power of small nuclear bombs, a newspaper reported today. The fuel-air explosives, or FAEs, have 10 times the power of conventional explosives and create a huge fireball and shock wave over a concentrated area, without the radiation fallout associated with nuclear weapons, The Los Angeles Times reported. ``It's not your garden-variety weapon,'' said Henry Sokolski of the Pentagon's international security affairs office. ``These are blast-effect weapons, and what you can't see can kill you.'' Military officials say the United States has no ready defense against the explosives that could devastate oil fields, air bases and troops, the newspaper reported. FAEs can be launched as bombs from airplanes or as warheads on missiles. Pentagon officials said U.S. forces would have the most difficulty defending against a missile-delivered warhead, but there is no clear evidence Iraq has the ability to mount the explosives on missiles. Senators John Glenn, D-Ohio, and Jesse Helms, R-North Carolina, are among five senators who have requested in a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that he launch an investigation to determine Iraq's supply of FAEs. The Times said earlier reports indicated Iraq received the scientific knowledge to build these weapons from the German arms industry. A major German aerospace and defense firm, Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm conducted feasibility studies on an FAE device as part of a missile project with the Egyptian government. That project was terminated in 1988, said company spokesman Willie Vogler. According to reports from the BBC and Der Spiegel, a German magazine, Egypt gave the studies to Iraq. An unidentified congressional investigator told the Times that U.S. technology may have been involved as well, although the United States does not carry FAEs in its own arsenal. The weapons are currently in the arsenals of the Soviet Union, Israel, China, France, West German, Spain, and perhaps some Third World nations in addition to Iraq, according to Pentagon sources.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Chairman Says Evangelist Should Apologize for Arts Festival Criticism
With PM-Arts-Obscenity
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts says evangelist Pat Robertson should apologize for providing ``misinformation'' about whether federal money was used to produce an adult-oriented puppet show. NEA Chairman John Frohnmayer said Robertson misrepresented the truth about the source of funding for the show in Atlanta last month. The evangelist blasted the show on his ``700 Club'' TV program, saying it was produced with NEA grant money. ``This show was privately funded,'' Frohnmayer said at a news conference Thursday. The head of the federal arts agency was in Atlanta to address local arts leaders and reply to Robertson's charges. ``I would call on Rev. Robertson to apologize to Congress to whom he has sent misinformation; to apologize to the people of Atlanta whom he has cast in an unfavorable light; to apologize to those who look to him for truth, rather than half-truths,'' Frohnmayer said. ``We're not going to apologize for speaking the truth and bringing the facts to light,'' Robertson spokesman Ralph Reed said later Thursday. Robertson said in his Thursday morning broadcast that if members of Congress vote to give the NEA more money next year, ``it shows they are totally out of touch with America and with morality.'' His remarks were the latest attack on Atlanta puppeteer Jon Ludwig's play ``Zeitgeist,'' which premiered Sept. 21 at the Atlanta Arts Festival. Robertson previously charged that the puppet show included simulated foreplay, followed by an exhibit of oral sex acts, before an audience of 800 people, including children. Ludwig described the scene as a satirical treatment of sexual temptation, as part of an adult ``morality play.'' He denied it contained depictions of oral sex. Robertson, who was a Republican candidate for president in 1988, said Thursday he had not seen the puppet show, but based his criticism on newspaper accounts. The Christian Coalition, a non-profit organization headed by Robertson, has reported that the NEA gave $132,500 last year to the Center for Puppetry Arts, where Ludwig is associate artistic director. Reed, who is executive director of the Virginia Beach, Va., coalition, said Ludwig ``would never have been offered the opportunity to put on that puppetry show if he hadn't been artistic director of one of the largest puppetry arts centers in the southeastern United States.'' While the NEA acknowledged the funding, Frohnmayer said Ludwig's performance at the arts festival was under a separate arrangement ``independent of his association with the Center for Puppetry Arts.'' The controversy began with the complaint of the Rev. John Norton, a Methodist minister from Marietta, who later withdrew his objections. While Norton said he did not object to the show's content, he said unsupervised children should not be allowed to view adult material. Festival organizers have said they will take steps in the future to make sure children will not have access to such material. In an indirect reference to Robertson, Norton said, ``We do not feel it is appropriate for us to be placed in the position of being connected with the greater issues others have attempted to draw us into.''

DOC.HEAD: Arms Control Treaty Will Lock in Reductions Under Way in Europe
DOC.TEXT: The tentative accord to cut non-nuclear weapons in Europe will lock in reductions now under way and lay out the basis for new relations between East and West, military experts say. The Conventional Forces in Europe treaty would be the largest arms-control deal in history and the first in Europe since the end of World War II. The agreement, announced Wednesday in New York, is expected to be signed by 22 countries next month in Paris. President Bush on Thursday hailed the tentative accord, which would take a far bigger bite out from the Soviet arsenal than the American one. Bush said it would ``decisively improve the balance of military power'' on the continent. Military analysts said the agreement makes it harder for the two sides to change their minds on pullouts that have already been started. ``It makes official and irrevocable these changes,'' said Richard Fieldhouse, senior research associate at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington. ``Unilateral moves are a little too easy to reverse.'' ``In a sense, we are now writing the armistice for the Cold War,'' James Woolsey, the chief U.S. negotiator to the talks, said recently. The talks have been designed to bring both sides to equal ceilings in main battle tanks, armored combat vehicles, artillery, combat aircraft and attack helicopters. The talks, covering an area spanning the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains in the Soviet Union, are between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization of the West and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Even before the signing ceremony, the Soviets have begun pulling equipment out of East European countries, once their staunch allies but now governed by emerging democracies eager to pull away from the Kremlin. A NATO official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Soviets already have withdrawn about 20,000 tanks from the region. The Soviets also have begun removing their troops from Hungary and Czechoslovakia. Still, experts say putting the reductions in writing is important. ``If this were all done without a treaty, you would just be taking the other guy's word for it that their equipment had been taken out of service,'' said the NATO official. The arms talks, which seemed so far-reaching at their start, have lagged behind the political and economic upheavals in Eastern Europe. The negotiations initially were considered a way of forcing change in the East. ``The important thing about the treaty is not so much what it limits, but the fact that it's part of a process that you can build a new political relationship on,'' said Jane Sharp, senior researcher at the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute in Sweden. The treaty will set out an extensive system of inspections on military bases and other areas to make sure no country cheats. The two sides have agreed to limit main battle tanks to 20,000 for each side, artillery pieces to 20,000 apiece, armored combat vehicles to 30,000 each, and combat helicopters to 2,000 apiece. No cap has been negotiated on combat aircraft. However, after long negotiations, bargainers agreed to a limit of 5,150 warplanes in any single country, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said at a joint appearance with Bush in Washington on Thursday. The agreement technically does not limit the number of U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe. The superpowers agreed to skip that step to meet the Paris deadline. However, Gorbachev and Bush, to a far lesser extent, are committed to withdrawing soldiers from Europe anyway.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rise in Japan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs with closing stock, dollar figures; pickup 5th graf pvs, `Traders said...'
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices closed sharply higher in Tokyo Friday, while the dollar plunged against the yen. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rebounded 549.46 points, or 2.47 percent, to close at 22,827.65. Volume was an estimated 450 million shares on the first section. The index shed 571.20 points, or 2.56 percent, falling to 22,278.19 Thursday. The dollar closed at 133.72 yen, down 2.18 from Thursday's close, after trading between 132.75 yen and 133.80 yen. The currency started trading at 133.60 yen, down 2.30 yen from Thursday's close. In bond dealings, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds dropped to 8.110 percent by 3 p.m. from Thursday's 8.235-percent close. Their price rose to 83.15 points from 82.63. Traders said advances overnight in Europe and New York, coupled with slightly lower oil prices and the stronger yen contributed to the rebound. Higher bnd prices and comments by U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan on Wednesday also fueled expectations of lower interest rates. Greenspan, speaking before a congressional committee, hinted at an easier credit policy from the central bank if Congress enacts a compromise on cutting the federal deficit. ``The Japanese investor's mind is very, very good compared to just one or two weeks ago,'' said Hidetada Yoshida of Kidder Peabody International Corp. The prospect of lower interest rates in the United States gave investors hope that the Bank of Japan might also lower rates, boosting industrial activity, he said. ``Investors have digested the conflict in Iraq with the United States, (by) about 80-90 percent. I expect the Nikkei will be up around 26,000 sometime in December,'' he said. Low stock book values also spurred buying, and while foreign institutional investors were taking the bait, he said. ``Japanese institutional investors are very, very chicken because they received huge damages from this crash,'' he said. As of Thursday, the Nikkei average had lost 27.76 percent of its value before Aug. 2, when Iraq touched off the Persian Gulf crisis by invading Kuwait. Also on Friday, one of Finance Ministry's market-boosting measures went into effect, increasing the collateral value of securities used in margin deposits. On currency markets, Greenspan's interest rate comments and concerns about the U.S. budget pushed the dollar sharply down. ``The dollar's drop was fueled by speculative dollar selling in London overnight,'' said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. He said pessimism over prospects for the approval of the 1991 U.S. budget proposal and over the scheduled announcement of the U.S. jobless rate later Friday also prompted the dollar-selling incentives among Japanese investors. ``With little fresh market-affecting news here, however, the dollar will not fall too much in Tokyo,'' Kanai said. ``Many market players are awaiting release of the U.S. jobless rate.'' The dollar dropped against all major foreign currencies overnight in New York due to selling on a widespread assumption that U.S. interest rates will fall in the near future. The dollar in New York closed at 133.83 yen from 136.04 yen. Dealers said the latest dollar selling was triggered by Greenspan's comments. A looser monetary policy would lead to lower U.S. interest rates, which would tend to curb dollar demand by making returns on dollar-denominated investments less rewarding than foreign alternatives. Traders said the index quickly rose as the yen's surge against the dollar, in addition to overnight gains in the Dow Jones Industrial Average in New York, reassured participants.

DOC.HEAD: Reputed New York Mobster Slain
DOC.TEXT: A reputed member of the Gambino organized crime family was found slain execution-style in a Manhattan parking garage, police said. The body of Louis DiBono, 63, of Glen Cove was found sprawled across the front seat of a 1987 Cadillac Thursday afternoon by a parking attendant at the World Trade Center, said police Sgt. Peter Berry. DiBono had been shot in the head three times, then pushed inside the car, Berry said. Robbery did not appear to be a motive because cash was found on the front seat of the car, police said. Law enforcement sources, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said DiBono was a ``made man,'' an organized crime term for a member who is not supposed to be killed without approved by the family hierarchy. The reputed boss of the Gambino crime family is John Gotti. The gropup allegedly is involved in construction-industry and garment-industry extortion, Brooklyn and Staten Island waterfront rackets, narcotics trafficking, and gambling and loan sharking in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Florida.

DOC.HEAD: New York Mayor Orders Wage Freeze, Considers 15,000 Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Labor leaders reacted angrily to word that Mayor David Dinkins is considering laying off at least 15,000 city workers to help close a budget deficit that could go as high as $2.6 billion by next year. ``The mayor has declared war on the unions in the city,'' said Barry Feinstein, president of the 23,000-member Teamsters Local 237. ``He has spit in the eye of public employees through this unilateral action.'' Stanley Hill, head of the 140,000-strong District Council 37 union, said Dinkins' plans would lead to ``total demoralization, anger, frustration'' for his members.``The same way I feel,'' he said. Dinkins said his budget advisers predicted that the layoffs and other agency reductions would save $800 million. The last large-scale layoffs in New York came in 1975, when the city nearly went bankrupt and about 25,000 workers were laid off. The city has about 240,000 workers. While insisting that layoffs were not yet a certainty, Dinkins took steps Thursday to halt all new hiring, promotions and merit raises. The mayor said the freeze would save $115 million in payroll costs in the current 1991 fiscal year and the 1992 fiscal year, which starts July 1. ``It's not at all pleasant - needless to say - but, fiscal stability is essential,'' Dinkins told reporters at City Hall. Philip Michael, the mayor's Budget Director, estimated that revenues in this fiscal year would result in a shortfall of $150 million, and next year's deficit would reach $1.4 billion. Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said the budget gap for next year could go as high as $2.6 billion. She also projected a budget deficit in the current fiscal year as high as $738 million. The mayor cautioned at the news conference that, ``We haven't done any layoffs yet, nor have we called for any layoffs yet.'' But Michael said: ``I think layoffs will have to be an essential part of that solution.'' The mayor's freeze announcement came two days after he proposed a $1.8 billion plan to bolster crimefighting citywide, including hiring nearly 8,000 new police officers. He proposed property taxes hikes and a payroll tax to fund the planned law enforcment expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sues Landlords of Alleged Haunted House, Wants Cash for `Ghost Busters'
DOC.TEXT: A woman who claims the 110-year-old house she once rented is haunted wants her former landlords to pay the fee charged by two ghost hunters she hired to investigate. Jo-Ann Rich, scheduled to appear in Vernon Superior Court today, is suing Kevin O'Donnell and Hayden Houston, for $2,000. She wants them to cover the $185 fee she paid to the ghost hunters, as well as to return a $1,250 security deposit and $500 in rent and interest. Ed and Lorraine Warren of Monroe, who investigated the haunting at the Long Island, N.Y., house made famous in the book and movie ``The Amityville Horror,'' support Rich's claim that the seven-room Victorian house is spooked. Mrs. Warren, who claims she is clairvoyant, said she felt the presence of a confused, somewhat frustrated human spirit in the house. She said she also felt the presence of something evil. Rich moved into the house in the fall of 1988 with her boyfriend and son. She moved out 18 months later, before her lease was up. O'Donnell and Houston are countersuing her for $2,000 for breaking the lease. Rich said she had no choice but to move out after being terrorized by ghosts. She cited several inexplicable occurrences, saying she photographed a pink haze at the top of the stairway and a blue haze over a mysterious candle that would not burn down. O'Donnell has called Rich's claim ``baloney'' and accused her of conjuring the ghost story to get out of her lease after her boyfriend moved out and she had trouble paying the rent. The house, which was built about 1880, has had at least six owners. Among them were Edward and Janet Phillips, who lived there 19 years. The Phillips, now retired and living in Plainville, say they have no recollection of strange incidents. The house is now occupied by a state trooper and his family, who moved there in August. Trooper Mark Dumas said he's heard rumors about the ghosts but puts no stock in them.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Defeat Bitter Loss for Bush, House Leaders
With PM-Budget, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: George Bush went on national television, enlisted the help of three former presidents and a gravely-ill Republican national chairman, and got slaughtered. The ``Don't Worry-Be Happy'' theme of his presidential campaign just didn't prepare his Republicans for swallowing painful budget medicine. He broke his no-new-taxes pledge, but that didn't mean they were ready to follow. ``The politics of the 1980's was `let's pretend,''' said Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Md. ``That psychology is deeply embedded in the politics of America.'' With the most intensive congressional lobbying effort of his presidency, Bush only mustered 71 of 176 Republicans to vote for his $500 billion deficit reduction deal with Congress. Democrats feared giving Republicans an issue and rebuffed their own leaders too, and the budget failed 254-179. Lawmakers just didn't buy the argument that they had to swallow tax increases, cuts in Medicare, and other unpopular measures in order to reduce the deficit. Not five weeks before election day. Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Minority Whip who led Republican opposition, won big and he didn't even get up and speak during the debate. That a deficit plan had to contain entirely bitter medicine was ``a false notion,'' said Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., who helped Gingrich. ``It is possible to put together a good plan for the economy that will pass.'' ``Why was it (the compromise) put forward and pushed ahead with such vigor?'' he asked following the lopsided rejection. The vote clearly was an embarrassment for House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., neither of whom could summon many loyalty votes from their troops despite stirring appeals that earned them standing ovations in the House. But it was surely a much more astonishing loss for the president, who enjoys almost incredible popularity in the polls, whose one-on-one cajoling ability is credited with arranging the international blockade of Iraq, and who appealed to the nation on television to pressure Congress to pass the plan. It's difficult to imagine what more he could have done. He had groups of GOP lawmakers come to the White House so he could lobby them face to face. He kept telephone lines all over town busy, with House members hearing from him even before 7 a.m. ``How painful to him to have to ask each of us personally,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., one of the budget negotiators, who reminded his colleagues during the debate that Bush and his veto were the House Republicans' only defense against the majority Democrats. The president enlisted the help of the three living former Republican presidents - Reagan, Ford and, yes, Nixon - to telephone GOP members and urge them to support the plan. ``I guess Jimmy Carter didn't call anybody,'' speculated Rep. John Myers, R-Ind., one of the normally loyal Republicans whom Bush couldn't win over on this one. Republican National Committee Chairman Lee Atwater, who is battling a brain tumor, sent Republican members a letter warning that without passage of the budget, ``our hard-won gains could be wiped out.'' ``Please do not turn your back on the president,'' Atwater asked. There was evidence that part of Bush's problem was heavy-handed lobbying by some of his staff. Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y., said Bush called him at 6:45 a.m. at home, then his chief of staff John Sununu phoned later, ``and he was a little rough.'' Sununu also got bad reviews at a House Republican caucus earlier in the week - not to mention his comment on television that a GOP senator opposing the plan was ``insignificant.'' Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., didn't like being called insignificant. Rep. Ralph Regula, R-Ohio, said the White House took back its offer of the president's box for a show at the Kennedy Center after he refused to come around. ``There have been better moments,'' he said. --- Steven Komarow has been covering Congress since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Quadriplegic Found Dead Before State High Court Can Issue Right-to-Die Ruling
DOC.TEXT: A quadriplegic man who didn't want to outlive his terminally ill father died before the Nevada Supreme Court got a chance to rule on his request that he be allowed to end his life. The Las Vegas Sun reported Thursday that Kenneth Bergstedt's father, Robert Bergstedt, said his son asked him to help end his life Wednesday night and that he complied by giving him sedatives and loosening his respirator tube. Police said the father told them he awoke Thursday morning in the mobil home the two men shared and found his 31-year-old adopted son dead. ``He said the respirator was loosened during the night,'' said police Lt. Steve Ducharme. Kenneth Bergstedt, in court papers filed earlier this year, said he feared his father would die before he did, leaving him with no one to care for him. He had been paralyzed frmm the neck down since a 1969 swimming pool accident. District Judge Donald Mosley granted Bergstedt's request to die, ruling in June that the death would not be considered a suicide and that anyone who aided him would not face any penalties. But Mosley asked Bergstedt not to end his life until the state Supreme Court could rule on the matter and establish a legal precedent. The high court said it could not issue an immediate ruling because the case required more research. Bergstedt's attorney, Jack Cherry, said if someone did help him die they could not be prosecuted. ``I have a court order saying anyone that helps Kenneth in doing this is not guilty of a crime,'' Cherry said. Police homicide Lt. Kyle Edwards said his office is investigating the death, but added it would be up to others to decide if any charges could be filed. ``At the present time there is a court order that says this is not a crime,'' Edwards said. ``This is a legal issue that's going to go a lot higher than us.'' The older Bergstedt, an amputee who last month was diagnosed as suffering from terminal lung cancer, had taken care of his son since his wife died of lung cancer in 1979. He said previously he didn't want to see his son die, but understood his reasons. ``Let's face it. He's been in jail for 21 years, and I've been his keeper,'' he said. In asking a judge in June to allow him to end his life, Kenneth Bergstedt described his existence as devoid of fulfillment. He said he spent almost all of his time strapped to a gurney and hooked to a respirator, passing the hours by watching television or working with a specially equipped computer. Cherry told the state Supreme Court last month that doctors wouldn't comply with Bergstedt's request to provide him with sedatives so he could die because they feared civil liability and possible criminal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Hatfield Aide Suspends Column
DOC.TEXT: The top aide to Sen. Mark Hatfield has suspended his weekly newspaper column after Hatfield's challenger questioned columns that mentioned contributors to the Republican senator's re-election campaign. Representatives of Democratic Senate candidate Harry Lonsdale criticized Gerry Frank for mentioning Hatfield campaign contributors four times in the past 16 months in Frank's weekly column in The Oregonian. Frank, chief of staff for Republican Hatfield, said there is no connection between the columns and the contributions. He described the criticism from the Lonsdale camp as an ``illegitimate campaign issue'' but decided to suspend the column to avoid further controversy. Judson Randall, assistant to Editor William A. Hilliard, said that The Oregonian endorsed Frank's decision to suspend the column, but would have kept running had Frank desired.
The column, Friday Surprise, will resume Nov. 9, three days after the general election.
DOC.HEAD: State Sues Republican Senatorial Committee On Consumer Fraud Charges
DOC.TEXT: State officials sued the National Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, charging that a GOP fund-raising letter is deceptive and may defraud the public. The suit, filed Thursday by Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo and Director of Consumer Affairs Patricia Royer, asks for a court hearing on the committee's mailing of $25 checks to residents. If a person endorses the check and provides a bank account number, the Republican committee is authorized to automatically withdraw $12.50 a month from that person's bank account. ``In 20 years of experience with consumer fraud, I have never before seen this type of fraudulent action,'' said Ms. Royer. ``I am very concerned that every con artist out there will use automatic funds transfer as a way to defraud the public. Let this quick action serve as a warning that this behavior will not be tolerated in New Jersey.'' The suit was filed in state Superior Court in Essex County. It seeks fines, costs and restitution of any money collected. Ms. Royer said the terms of the agreement that would allow the Republican committee to withdraw $12.50 a month from residents' bank accounts are printed on the reverse side of the check. ``But the print is so small a person with 20-20 vision would have a problem reading it without the aid of a magnifier,'' she said. National Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee spokeswoman Wendy Burnley sharply denied that the fund-raising letter was improper, suggesting that complaints against it may be politically motivated. Ms. Burnley acknowledged that the letter has prompted complaints in at least six states. In addition to New Jersey, Illinois and Alabama have filed suit against the committee, Ms. Burnley said. The attorneys general of Oregon, Minnesota and Michigan also have complained, she said. The letters were sent to 1 million people nationwide, Ms. Burnley said.
DOC.HEAD: Republicans Lose Bid To Be Dropped From Democratic Suit
DOC.TEXT: White House aide Ronald Kaufman and another Republican lost their bids to be dropped from a lawsuit charging the Springfield police union conspired to disrupt the Democratic state convention last June. In a ruling issued Thursday in Hampden County Superior Court, Judge William W. Simons refused to dismiss claims by the state Democratic Committee in its suit against Kaufman and Stephen DeAngelis, a one-time campaign operative for Joseph Malone, a GOP candidate for state treasurer. The suit charges that Kaufman and DeAngelis worked with the police union in its picketing of the convention, which delayed the proceedings for four hours and was politically embarrassing for the Democrats. Simons also ruled that police pickets at the convention had verbally and physically assaulted some persons outside the convention hall. Simons said the Democrats, including five convention delegates, had presented enough facts to support their claims against Kaufman, the Union-News of Springfield reported. The judge also said there is enough of a ``factual dispute'' over DeAngelis' involvement in the convention disruption to allow the case against him to continue. The judge said the Democrats ``state facts which support their allegations'' about Kaufman and ``allege with specificity that Kaufman met with, planned and assisted the picketing by the police union.'' Kaufman is a deputy assistant to President George Bush. The police union and its president, Patrolman Robert Jacobson, also are defendants in the suit. The suit includes allegations that the police union violated delegates' civil rights by keeping them from the convention June 2.

DOC.HEAD: Bull Gets Loose at State Fair, Scatters Crowd
DOC.TEXT: A 2,000-pound Brahman bull snapped its halter rope and got loose at the Mississippi State Fair, sending frightened fairgoers running for cover while a band of would-be matadors gave chase. The bull belonging to the breed used in rodeo riding events took an impromptu tour of the fairgrounds Thursday, dumping a man from his wheelchair and trampling a firefighter who tried to help. ``I looked up and saw a lot of scary looks like there was a gang fight,'' said Johnny Minninger, 32, of Madison. ``All of a sudden, a bull came out of the crowd with about 50 people chasing it.'' Fire Lt. Rudy Brooks tangled with the bull, which knocked him into a trailer ``and under it.'' ``You can see the prints on the back of my shirt,'' Brooks said.``I had him around the head trying to keep from getting my insides squashed out.'' Harold Roosa III, 27, of Kansas City, Mo., an employee of the carnival company Bluegrass Shows, said the bull took off ``straight out toward and directly pass the front gate, made his way to Kiddy Land, past the circus and cut across the midway.'' As he sped past the circus, the bull belted a man in a wheelchair, Roosa said. People in the crowd helped the man, who was uninjured, back into his wheelchair and he promptly rolled off after the bull. The crowd steered the bull past a concession stand and into the livestock judging arena, where he was corralled with a makeshift cage. ``We brought in another bull and a heifer to tame him down,'' Brooks said. Hinds County Undersheriff J.W. Stevens said officials did not know the identity of the bull's owner.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Charge Fraternity Skit Was Anti-Woman
DOC.TEXT: A fraternity party that featured a skit describing the ``perfect female sex organs'' sparked a rally at which hundreds protested, including a campus doctor wearing a sign that said ``Castrate Sigma Chi.'' An estimated 200 to 300 men and women chanted and waved placards outside the University of New Mexico's Sigma Chi chapter Thursday, condemning the party as a promotion of violence against women and a violation of women's rights. The university suspended the Sigma Chi chapter following its annual ``Mafia Wedding'' party on Saturday night. A party skit included a poem describing seven wise men's creation of the perfect female sex organs. At one point, male partygoers were encouraged to grab their loins and shout, ``Feel the power,'' according to an account carried in the campus newspaper, The Daily Lobo. ``Things that have been overlooked before, things that have been OK before, boys-will-be-boys things, are not OK anymore if they ever were,'' UNM Associate Academic Affairs Vice President Jan Roebuck told the crowd over a loudspeaker Thursday. Juba Clayton, director of the UNM Women's Center, led the crowd in chanting: ``Sigma Chi, stop it. You are hurting me. You are raping me. We will not stand for it. It is not funny. Violence against women is not funny.'' Amy Llewellyn, a resident physician in pathology at UNM Medical Center, wore a bumper sticker on her back that said: ``FEEL THE POWER! CASTRATE SIGMA CHI.'' She said later in a telephone interview that the message was meant to be taken figuratively. ``Certainly we weren't insinuating any literal interpretation of that,'' she said. She added that the party skit ``reflects a misogynistic attitude that you would not expect in gentlemen going to college.'' Chapter alumnus Ross Burkstaller, 24, a senior psychology major, acknowledged that he read the poem at the party. ``All I can say is what got out is inappropriate, inexcusable and ignorant, and myself and the others are sorry that it happened and that it offended the women present and the women that heard about it through the media,'' Burkstaller said. Sigma Chi President Dan Holton said the fraternity delivered letters of apology to each sorority on campus, and some fraternity members apologized in person. No Sigma Chi activities other than formal chapter meetings may take place during the suspension and pending administrative review of the incident, said Dean of Students Karen Glaser. The ``Mafia Wedding'' party has been a regular event on the Sigma Chi social calendar since the release of ``The Godfather'' movie in the early 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: Roseanne Barr, Husband File $35 Million Racketeering Suit Against Tabloids
DOC.TEXT: Actress Roseanne Barr and her husband have filed a $35 million federal racketeering lawsuit against the National Enquirer and Star tabloids over their publication of her love letters. The suit was filed Thursday under federal racketeering statutes charging copyright infringement, conspiracy, invasion of property and intentional infliction of emotional distress. The U.S. District Court suit seeks $10 million compensatory damages and $25 million punitive damages from the National Enquirer, Star and the publications' owner, News America Publishing Inc. Last week, Elizabeth Taylor filed a $20 million libel suit in Los Angeles Superior Court against the National Enquirer for alleged false statements. But Miss Barr and husband Tom Arnold are seeking relief under the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, known as RICO. The couple's lawyer, Theresa M. Marchlewski, declined comment Thursday. The racketeering activity, according to the suit, involves the Enquirer's alleged ``participation in a scheme to obtain the private papers and effects of celebrities by inducing and paying persons and entities to steal such information and transport it in interstate commerce.'' The couple also seeks the return of Miss Barr's ``private, written letters and outpourings of love and affection to Arnold embodied in four writings ... purloined and-or published by defendants.'' Excerpts of the letters were published in the Feb. 6, 1990, issue of the Enquirer and the Jan. 30, 1990, edition of the Star, the suit said. Exhibits submitted with the suit included copies of a National Enquirer cover headline reading, ``Roseanne Wedding Fiasco - Plus Amazing Honeymoon Swimsuit Photos.'' National Enquirer editor Iain Calder said from his Lantana, Fla., office that he hadn't seen the suit so he couldn't respond to specific allegations. ``Any legal action against this publication under RICO is so ridiculous that it is clear this is just another pathetic publicity stunt by Roseanne,'' Calder said. ``She is trashing the National Enquirer, but we are in good company. A few weeks ago she was trashing the national anthem.'' Star editor Dick Kaplan said from Tarrytown, N.Y., that he would have no comment because he hadn't seen the suit. ``The lawsuit speaks for itself,'' Miss Barr and Arnold said in a statement released by spokeswoman Cathy Spears. Miss Spears said the couple feels the case should be tried in court and not in the media. ``According to Barr and Arnold, they have suffered grievous injury and will look to the courts to decide the issues involved,'' she said. The suit said the tabloids operate ``a vast network of underground operatives and includes, but is not limited to, agents, employees, friends, relatives and associates of celebrities as well as persons and entities who provide goods and services to celebrities, including plaintiffs.'' Every member of the tabloids' alleged underground enterprise ``conspired with each other to commit the multiple violations of RICO,'' the suit said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Northwest, Along N. Carolina Coastline
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell along the North Carolina coastline early today, and in the Pacific Northwest. Skies were mostly clear in the nation's mid-section, with touches of fog across the Appalachians. Skies were cloudy along the West Coast, and rain fell in Portland, Ore., Seattle and Spokane, Wash. Today's forecast called for the first snow of the season in the mountains of western and central Montana, with 4 to 6 inches accumulated by Saturday. Temperatures were likely to soar into the 90s from the Gulf coast to North Dakota in the Plains, and across the Deep South. That would be 15 to 25 degrees hotter than normal. The Midwest, mid-Mississippi Valley and lower altitudes of the central and lower Rockies were expected to have temperatures in the 80s. Colder weather was pushing behind a cold front that stretched from northern Nevada and Idaho, into Montana. Showers could develop along the Gulf Coast from Texas to northern Florida. The nation's high on Thursday was 104 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Ship Runs Aground but Risk of Breakup Limited
DOC.TEXT: A ship carrying 10,700 tons of liquid ammonia ran aground today on Belgium's main river, but authorities said the risk the vessel would break up was slight, according to the Belgian news agency. The news agency Belga quoted Interior Ministry officials as saying the situation was not critical. No injuries were reported. The tanker was reported aground on the Scheldt River in Antwerp, about 30 miles north of Brussels, the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Sold Its Entire Stock Of Desert Uniforms To Iraq In 1986
DOC.TEXT: Old Sweats, British army slang for seasoned soldiers, has taken on new meaning for Britain's soldiers sent to join the multinational force in the Persian Gulf. While the Britons swelter in army uniforms designed for cooler climes, the Iraqis weather the heat in special desert uniforms that Britain sold them four years ago. The Defense Ministry said Thursday that in 1986, it sold its entire stock of desert uniforms to the Iraqis, thinking that with Britain's reduced defense commitments around the world they would no longer be needed. As a result, most of the 9,000 British soldiers who began arriving in the gulf last week must wear their European camouflage uniforms while they await the arrival of new lightweight clothing. A ministry spokeswoman, who spoke on condition of anonymity in keeping with standing rules, said the uniforms sold to the Iraqis in 1986 date from the 1960s, when British troops were in Aden. ``The uniforms were sold as a normal turnover of stock. The present deployment of forces to the gulf was unforeseen,'' she said. ``It would not have been economic for the army to hold that amount of desert uniforms in stores on a constant basis. She said new lightweight cotton uniforms will be shipped to the British troops soon.

DOC.HEAD: Nun To Quit Order After Judgeship Appointment
DOC.TEXT: Sister Mary Ellen Fitzmaurice, a nun who has been appointed to a judgeship in city Family Court, will leave her religious order because of church doctrine. The Dominican sisters of Amityville issued a statement saying Sister Fitzmaurice, the first churchwoman to take office as a New York City judge - ``has decided to begin the process of separation from her religious congregation.'' Sister Veronica Greeley of the Dominican Sisters said ``church law prohibits clergy ... to assume public offices which entail a participation in the exercise of civil power.'' The church considers judicial authority to be civic power. Sister Fitzmaurice, 41, has been practicing law for 10 years, serving as a law guardian in Queens Family Court and a lawyer with the Human Resources Administration. She was sworn in Thursday by Mayor David Dinkins.

DOC.HEAD: Dartmouth Students Rally Against Off-Campus Paper
LaserPhoto CR3 of Oct. 4
DOC.TEXT: An anti-Semitic quote in an independent Dartmouth College paper known for its strong criticisms of minorities has infuriated people on and off campus who say they won't stand for further such incidents. But trustees and staffers of The Dartmouth Review insist a saboteur placed the Adolf Hitler quote in the publication, and they have apologized. They further claimed that university President James Freedman and others have created ``a lynch-mob'' mentality on campus. About 2,000 people attended a rally Thursday to denounce the quote and the paper. History Professor Bruce Nelson told the crowd the Review ``lacks a shred of intellectual integrity'' and that the quote is the latest example of the ``small-minded, mean-spirited scribblings of the local hate sheet.'' Freedman called the quote an ``egregious expression of anti-Semitism.'' ``For the last 10 years, these shameless voices have ranted that Dartmouth is for some but not for others,'' he said. ``These voices have preached exclusion from the Dartmouth family and have expected us to heed their words. What kind of people did they think we were?'' Even congressmen have responded. On Thursday, 84 representatives signed a letter from Rep. Chet Atkins, D-Mass., to Freedman denouncing the quote. ``Recent inclusion of virulent anti-Semitic remarks has made the Review worthy of condemnation by all those in this nation who are repulsed by wanton expressions of hatred, injustice and cruelty,'' the letter said. Staffers and trustees at the Review say they've suffered unjustly for an act by someone determined to discredit the paper. Trustee Dinesh D'Souza said students at the paper have received death threats, and he strongly criticized Freedman and others for not helping the paper find the perpetrator. ``Unfortunately, Dartmouth officials to date have shown no interest in uncovering what happened, and indeed convened a lynch-mob to make scapegoats of innocent students,'' D'Souza said. ``In a total abdication of their leadership and responsibility, college officials are manipulating the grave issue of anti-Semitism for ends of self-aggrandizement and expediency.'' The Review, published since 1980, has been vilified through the years for its views on women, homosexuals, blacks and Indians. William Cole, a black music professor, resigned in August after the Review attacked him for seven years in print, belittling him as a mediocre teacher. Cole said the attacks compromised his effectiveness. Review staffers also were involved in a 1986 sledgehammer attack on shanties erected on the campus green as part of a protest against segregation in South Africa. Several staffers were suspended. The latest edition of the Review was distributed Saturday, on Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement and Judaism's most solemn day. The quotation, from Hitler's ``Mein Kampf,'' was inserted unattributed into the statement of principles on the Review's masthead: ``Therefore, I believe today that I am acting in the sense of the Almighty Creator: By warding off the Jews, I am fighting for the Lord's work.'' Backlash from the quote caused the Review's president and two staffers to quit earlier in the week. The anti-Semitic quote was not the first time the paper has angered Jews. In 1988, The Review ran a column likening Freedman - who's Jewish - to Hitler and the effects of his campus policies to the Holocaust. D'Souza said the 1988 column was ``sophomoric and in bad taste.'' He said trustees apologized for it at the time. Dartmouth religion Professor Arthur Hertzberg, vice president of the World Jewish Congress, called the latest controversy ``an act of hooliganism'' and attacked the Review's supporters, including syndicated columnists Patrick Buchanan and William F. Buckley and the New York-based John M. Olin Foundation. ``My quarrel is with those who put up hundreds of thousands of dollars with which to contaminate this campus,'' he said. D'Souza suggested the quote was ``surgically implanted.'' He pointed to an apostrophe in the quote that's different from the type used by paper, suggesting it was typed by someone unfamiliar with the paper or added by an outsider. Editor in Chief Kevin Pritchett, who also has taken over as president, said he ``should have been more vigilant. I will do everything in my power to find the person who did this.'' Pritchett said that if anything, the paper is pro-Israel. He also said editors don't check the paper's masthead daily, so it was easy to miss the quote, which appeared within the context of the Review's normal credo, a quote from Theodore Roosevelt.

DOC.HEAD: 1,000 Police Deployed to Stop Riots in Japanese District
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with 1,000 police on streets, 10,000 on alert, demonstrators building barricades. Pickup 10th pvs, `Dogs of...'
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people angry over alleged police corruption built barricades and set them on fire today in front of 1,000 riot police, who were deployed to try to stop street fighting in a rundown neighborhood. At least 106 people, including 83 police, have been injured in the violence in the Nishinari district of Osaka that began Tuesday, police reported. Forty-one people have been arrested. The people who live in the crime-ridden district have long-standing grudges against police, and accusations made public Tuesday that a local policeman took a bribe from a gangster helped trigger the rioting. But authorities and residents said young hooligans from outside the district and leftist extremists had agitated to keep the disturbances going. The scope of the violence is extremely rare for Japan, where issues rarely inflame passions to such a degree. About 1,000 riot police lined main roads in Nishinari and the district police station tonight. A growing crowd of hundreds faced off against the police lines. They formed barricades by burning piles of bicycles in streets already littered with burned cars and other debris. Police officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said another 10,000 riot police were on alert in Osaka, Japan's No. 2 city, to prevent another night of rioting. About 100 undercover police also were mobilized. Police reported two stores were set ablaze by rioters early today, and a train station also was damaged by fire. The rioting caused traffic tie-ups in parts of Osaka as police blocked off several major streets and some rail service was disrupted. Many Nishinari merchants closed their shops. Outside the police station, a group of group shouted insults at the police from a loudspeaker and demanded an apology for the purported bribery. ``Dogs of gangsters, come out, kneel down before us and apologize!'' a man screamed through the loudspeaker. ``Don't you know how much hardship our daily laborers are going through? Why don't you try working at a construction site one day and you will probably realize how much we are abused by this society.'' The chief of the Osaka police headquarters, Masahiro Tsubakihara, issued an apology Thursday in response to reports that an officer was involved in scandal, Kyodo News Service reported. The accused sergeant was arrested Wednesday night, a day after news reports said he took $22,000 in bribes from a local gangster for information on police operations. The district is a high-crime area and is known for its gangs, transient laborers and shabby hotels. Locals say there have been bad feelings between area residents and police, who have adopted hard-line tactics to battle crime, including a 24-hour surveillance camera system on street corners.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Postpones Christian Brando Trial to Nov. 5
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rudof is cq
DOC.TEXT: Prosecution efforts to force Marlon Brando's daughter back to the United State from Tahiti to testify in her brother's murder trial got a boost when a judge agreed to delay the trial. But the endeavor was thwarted at a second hearing Thursday when another judge refused to order Cheyenne Brando's return, saying he lacked the legal right to force her return. ``My personal view is that any American citizen who witnesses a crime should be made available to testify,'' Superior Court Judge Joel Rudof said Thursday. ``But my personal opinion aside, the question is whether there is legal authority.'' In one of her conflicting statements to authorities, Miss Brando said she was present during the May 16 shooting of her 26-year-old boyfriend, Dag Drollet. Christian Brando, 31, charged with murdering Drollet and free on $2 million bail, attended the first hearing Thursday in which a judge agreed to postpone the trial, which had been scheduled to start next week. Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge Robert Thomas gave prosecutors more time to go forward with legal motions designed to obtain Miss Brando's testimony. He set a tentative date of Nov. 5, but said that date could also be changed if witnesses are unable to readjust their schedules. Miss Brando, 20, has been in a sanitarium in Tahiti since June, when she gave birth to Drollet's child. To complicate matters, Drollet's parents have charged her under French law with complicity in her boyfriend's slaying. She was being held in Tahiti by French authorities because of that charge and lacks permission to leave even if she decided to come voluntarily. Prosecutors said they are not giving up on her return and might go back to federal court where they were earlier rebuffed on a similar request. Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop said if all efforts to gain Miss Brando's testimony fail by November, he would go ahead with trial, presenting other witnesses. The judge explained that the law did not allow him to issue a letter of rogatory, an international document which the prosecution sought to use as a vehicle to compel Miss Brando's return from Tahiti. ``It seems to me this should be dealt with by the Legislature,'' Rudof said, noting that a state court cannot issue such a letter although a federal court can. Outside court, Richard Hirsch, a lawyer representing Miss Brando, said that prosecutors had tried to use a novel view of a law normally invoked only as a communications tool between governments. He said the letter of rogatory has never been used in a criminal case and was not the proper procedure for compelling Miss Brando's return. Brando's lawyer, Robert L. Shapiro, vehemently opposed the delay, insisting that the trial should go forward as quickly as possible. He said Miss Brando was mentally unstable and wouldn't be a credible witness even if she returned from Tahiti and agreed to testify. Shapiro told the judge that Miss Brando has given five conflicting statements to authorities about the slaying at the actor's hilltop estate. Marlon Brando, who didn't appear for the brief court hearing Thursday, suggested last week that his daughter was being unfairly hounded by prosecutors and was too sick to testify.

DOC.HEAD: Tiny Temblor Rocks Santa Cruz Awake But Causes No Injuries or Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs penultimate graf to recast.
DOC.TEXT: A small earthquake centered 6 miles north of here jolted large numbers of residents awake, but caused no injuries or damage, authorities said. The quake, which struck at 11:08 p.m. Thursday, measured 3.2 on the Richter scale of ground motion, said Rick Lester of the U.S. Geological Survey. ``We received lots of calls from people who said it woke them up,'' said Denise Franklin, a reporter with the Santa Cruz Sentinel. ``It was two sharp jolts and a boom sound.'' Authorities also received ``quite a few calls'' but no reports of injuries or destruction, said a county sheriff's dispatcher who declined to give her name. The northern California earthquake of Oct. 17, 1989, measured 7.1 on the Richter scale and killed 67 people. The scale measures the magnitude of a quake according to ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one digit represents a tenfold increase of magnitude.

DOC.HEAD: It's Mazowiecki vs. Walesa in Poland's Presidential Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to change `adviser' to `mentor' in second graf. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Walesa announced...'
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, once steadfast allies, will put their political dispute to the voters in the country's first direct presidential election. Ending weeks of doubt about his intentions, Mazowiecki declared Thursday that he will oppose Walesa, his former mentor, in the election on Nov. 25. They are vying to succeed former Communist leader Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. Walesa announced his candidacy Sept. 16. Since then, he has lined up the endorsement of the Solidarity trade union - which he leads - several small center-right Christian-Democratic parties and his own Center Alliance party. Mazowiecki is supported by a new party, Citizens Movement for Democratic Action, and much of the intellectual elite that once belonged to Solidarity. As the East bloc's first non-Communist prime minister, Mazowiecki introduced the region's most radical economic reform plan in January. He has taken a step-by-step approach to dismantling other aspects of the old regime. Walesa, who sponsored Mazowiecki for prime minister, has accused him of moving too slowly. Mazowiecki said Thursday he will run for president because Poland should not stray from the course it has set. As prime minister, Mazowiecki is responsible for running the government, and he is answerable to parliament. The presidency, the government's highest position, controls the army and foreign affairs. ``One has to go forward in a better, faster and more sure way - but along this path, not a different one,'' Mazowiecki told a national television audience Thursday as he made his announcement. ``Poland, which has a great chance in today's world and in Europe, should take the place which is due to it - of a wise country, based on Christian values, of a country of people who are tolerant toward each other, a country that coexists well with all its neighbors,'' he said. Early opinion surveys indicated Mazowiecki has more support than Walesa, the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize laureate, but Walesa appeared to be gaining ground in recent weeks. Mazowiecki, 63, a journalist and former political prisoner, became prime minister on Aug. 24, 1989. Walesa had engineered the Solidarity takeover of power after the Communists failed to win sufficient support to govern in partially free elections that June. For most of the 1980s, Mazowiecki was an adviser to Walesa. But last spring, Walesa began publicly accusing the Solidarity-led government of moving too slowly to privatize the state-dominated economy and to remove former Communists from influential positions in the government and economy. Walesa urged new presidential and parliamentary elections and raised a general call for ``acceleration.'' He said he would not rest until Poland's democratic revolution was completed. Supporters of Mazowiecki accused Walesa of demagoguery and personal ambition. They argued that Mazowiecki's choice of a slow, consistent path to reform is needed to avoid divisive witchhunts. The presidential office becomes vacant because Jaruzelski last month asked parliament to shorten his six-year term after 17 months. There had been growing public demands - instigated by Walesa's supporters - for a popularly elected president and the removal of Jaruzelski as a symbol of the old system. As Poland's leader in 1981, Jaruzelski ordered martial law to crush Solidarity, but he then allowed its historic ascension to power last year.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Eases Socialist Stance
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress, at odds with white businessmen over the country's economic future, has toned down its Socialist policies but still wants to see some industries nationalized. The country's leading black opposition movement released an economic policy document today saying that if it comes to power a top priority would be redistributing wealth through affirmative action programs favoring blacks. The ANC says it envisions a mixed economy, ``but does not believe that market forces alone will result in anything but the perpetuation of existing disparities of income.'' Whites account for only 5 million of the country's estimated 40 million people but dominate the economy. Blacks have an annual per capita income of more than $1,000, one of the highest in Africa, but only a small fraction of white incomes in the country. ``South Africa now has one of the most unequal patterns of distribution of income and wealth in the world,'' the ANC said. South Africa's economy, the most powerful on the continent, currently is in a mild recession and has suffered double-digit inflation since the early 1980s. President F.W. de Klerk's government and white businessmen argue that socialist-oriented policies will produce economic stagnation in South Africa similar to that in Eastern Europe. They say capitalism is the quickest way to raise black living standards. But the ANC, led by Nelson Mandela, says the government must intervene to reduce the gulf between white wealth and black poverty. When Mandela was released in February after 27 years in prison for plotting against the government, he said the ANC wanted to nationalize gold mines, banks and other leading industries. But the 18-page document released today refrained from specific calls to nationalize major industries. It did say, however, that there might be cases for the ``compulsory establishment of new public enterprises.'' The ANC also said it was ``staunchly opposed to current government plans to privatize the public utility corporations.'' The ANC said it would seek to nationalize utilities that are sold off. The ANC acknowledged that ``private enterprise has a major role to play in the economy of a democratic, non-racial South Africa.'' The government over decades has built up a huge bureaucracy, in part to provide jobs for whites. About one in three economically active whites works for the government. But de Klerk has begun to sell off large state industries, saying they will be more efficiently run as private companies. Many blacks see the move as an effort to keep the economy in the hands of whites now that there is the prospect of a black government in the not-too-distant future. De Klerk says he wants to end the apartheid system of racial segregation and draw up a new constitution that will allow whites and blacks to share power. Debate on the future of the economy has been almost as heated as discussion about a political settlement. The government has been running television commercials and placing billboards in black areas saying that capitalism is crucial to economic prosperity. Businessmen have called for government deregulation and increased business opportunites for both whites and blacks. But many black anti-apartheid groups, and black trade unions remain strong advocates of socialism. The South African Communist Party, closely allied to the ANC, also is committed to socialism.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Cheered by Hubble Photographs
DOC.TEXT: The latest photographs from the crippled Hubble Space Telescope have lifted much of the gloom that descended on scientists after a focusing flaw was discovered last summer. At the same time, astronomers acknowledge that one of the $1.5 billion space observatory's prime missions - peering out into the farthest reaches of space - can not be undertaken until the flaw is corrected. When the space telescope was put into orbit 381 miles above the Earth by the space shuttle on April 25, scientists were excited by the prospect of measuring the speed with which the outermost edges of the universe are expanding. Now that work will have to postponed three or four years. ``First of all, the problem with the optics are there, and they will have to be fixed. That is certainly true,'' said Riccardo Giacconi, director of the Space Telescope Science Institute. ``However, the other thing that emerged (as a result of the photographs) is that some of the basic capacity ... has been preserved. ``We can use that optical power but only for sources that are not too far away, that are bright enough.'' In practice, that means astronomers will have to reorder their priorities, and the institute is currently re-evaluating 160 research projects originally planned for the Hubble, Giacconi said. With computer enhancement, studies of relatively nearby objects and phenomena, including novas, will be possible with the same degree of accuracy as originally envisioned, he said. One photo presented Thursday by the science institute offered the clearest view yet of enigmatic Pluto, the ninth and only planet that hasn't been visited by a fly-by spacecraft, and its moon Charon. There also was a shot of startling clarity of Saturn. Scientists said that some photographs from Hubble had 10 times the resolution that would have been possible from earthbound telescopes. The mood at the institute Thursday was much improved from last summer when it was discovered that a mirror on the telescope had manufacturing problems. The observatory's initial pictures were blurred and of severely limited value to astronomers. Scientists are currently weighing how best to repair flaws in the telescope's mirrors. A replacement wide-field camera is now being built at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California and plans call for it to be delivered to Hubble on a space shuttle flight in 1993. Engineers plan to install correcting optics in the replacement camera to compensate for the flawed mirrors. Within the next few weeks, the Hubble's spectrographic instruments are expected to begin transmitting data back to earth on temperature, motion and composition of stars. Results from these studies are usually expressed in numbers and graphs, not pictures.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Louisiana Senate Race, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0433,0631
DOC.HEAD: Suddenly, a Head-to-Head Match Between Incumbent and Ex-Klansman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to ADD details about Bagert's formal withdrawal and votes for him not being counted; to CORRECT attribution of quote to Johnston, sted Bagert, and move graf down. Picks up 9th graf pvs: `Duke scoffed ...' ^LaserPhoto BT1
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana's U.S. Senate race has become a head-to-head match between nn incumbent Democrat reluctantly supported by Republican party leaders over a Republican who was once a member of the Ku Klux Klan. State Sen. Ben Bagert dropped out of the primary race Thursday, saying he feared his Republican candidacy could force incumbent Democrat J. Bennett Johnston into a runoff with ex-Klansman and Republican state Rep. David Duke. Under Louisiana's open primary system, all candidates run on one ballot, regardless of party affiliation. A runoff between the top two finishers is held if no one receives a majority of votes. Bagert said his polls indicated he might pull just enough votes to keep Johnston from getting more than 50 percent of the vote and force the three-term incumbent into a runoff with Duke. GOP leaders say such an event would embarrass the state and the Republican party nationally. Eight Republican senators endorsed Johnston earlier this week. ``I'm not endorsing anybody, but I'm not voting for David Duke,'' Bagert said. Asked if he would vote for Johnston, he said, ``Yes, reluctantly.'' Bagert's staff said he would file papers today with the secretary of state's office to formally withdraw from the election. It's too late to get his name off the ballot. But if he officially withdraws before 6 a.m. Saturday, any votes cast for him will not be counted, Secretary of State Fox McKeithen said Thursday. Polls show that move should greatly enhance Johnston's chances of garnering 50 percent and staving off a runoff. A poll released Wednesday by Mason-Dixon Opinion Research of Columbia, Md., showed Johnston was the choice of 53 percent of voters surveyed. Duke drew 26 percent, while Bagert polled 8 percent, with 13 percent undecided. The poll of 825 registered voters had a margin of error of 3.5 percent. Johnston refused to predict that Bagert's move would assure him victory in Saturday's election and added he was making sure now that his supporters do not become complacent. ``All my supporters understand how important this race is,'' Johnston said. ``The state's on trial. The state has a chance to show what it is, what its values are, to the rest of the country. Duke scoffed at the idea that Bagert's conservative Republican support might move to Johnston's camp. ``They sure don't want a liberal senator to go back there and vote for more taxes and for affirmative action,'' he said in a television interview. Johnston has often voted a moderate-to-conservative line in Washington, supporting defense spending and aid to the Nicaraguan contras. But Duke and Bagert have accused him of being too liberal for Louisiana, citing his role in helping defeat former President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert Bork to the Supreme Court and his support for the Civil Rights Act of 1990. Meanwhile, Duke has said his days as a Klansman and neo-Nazi are behind him, but critics say they don't believe him. They point to his selling of Nazi literature from his suburban New Orleans office, a practice he stopped in 1989 after Republican leaders reported it to the media. Duke ran for president in 1988, first as a Democrat, later as a populist. He ran for the state Legislature as a Republican in 1989 and won a narrow victory over another Republican in an all-white suburban New Orleans district.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Foreign Workers Kept in Iraq to Finish Jobs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to recast lead, clarify. Pickup 5th, `About 4,500...'
DOC.TEXT: Some foreign workers have chosen to remain in Iraq since the Persian Gulf crisis began, but others, such as Portugese stone masons and Soviet oilmen, have been held to avoid further damage to Iraq's economy. More than 500,000 foreign workers have been stranded in Iraq since it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the United States and other countries responded by massing troops in the gulf region to deter possible further aggression. The Iraqis hold 2,200 Westerners in Kuwait and Iraq, some at strategic installations to discourage an attack by the U.S.-led military forces. Some foreign workers have stayed willingly - preferring the certainty of a paycheck to unknown job prospects at home, diplomats said. But the diplomats, most of whom spoke on condition of anonymity, said many other workers who want to leave have found most avenues blocked by bureaucracy. Iraq, suffering the effects of the U.N.-imposed economic sanctions, has kept many workers in the country to keep the economy running, even diverting some to areas in need of a boost, such as agriculture, the diplomats said. About 4,500 Soviet oil industry workers are in Iraq, and a foreign source in Baghdad said the Iraqis are dependent on them. ``If they go, no one else will come in to operate these fields,'' the source said. Polish work crews building roads, pipelines and railroads also are helping Iraq's industries and projects limp along. Many Iraqi construction projects were halted when the U.N. economic embargo cut off imports. The stranded foreigners also include 25 Portuguese stone masons who last month completed marble work on a palace for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, the Portugese Foreign Ministry in Lisbon said. Officials disagree over whether such work violates the U.N. embargo and the responsibilities of the foreign workers. ``As far as I understand, working there would violate the sanctions,'' Swedish Foreign Ministry Spokesman Lars-Olof Lundberg said Wednesday. The British government is more flexible. ``Like many governments, we have concluded that it is unreasonable to ask people who are essentially working under duress to stop working and put themselves at risk,'' a Foreign Office spokesman said on condition of anonymity. U.N. directives regarding the sanctions are ``open to interpretation,'' a Dutch Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said. She said the status of a dredging project in southern Iraq, employing 104 Dutch citizens, is unclear but there is speculation the dredgers are being forced to work. Officials said many Bangladeshis, Egyptians, Indians, Pakistanis and Sri Lankans are being kept at their old jobs. Also, about 2,000 Bangladeshis are working as ``forced labor'' in Iraqi military camps in Kuwait, a Foreign Ministry official in Dhaka said this week. Iraq is trying to grow more crops because of the trade embargo, and some Third World laborers who were working on canceled projects have been diverted to agriculture, a source in Baghdad said. Agriculture Minister Abdul Wahab Mahmoud said in a report published Thursday that Iraqi farmers must redouble their efforts to grow more grain. The Iraqis are slow about giving exit visas, delaying but not preventing some workers from leaving, a European diplomat said this week. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh told reporters Tuesday that Iraq has been slow responding to requests to allow the oil workers to leave. ``Regrettably, the Iraqi authorities clearly show tardiness in considering the documents submitted by the Soviet side,'' he said. But some workers have managed to leave after weeks of pleas and paperwork. A plane carrying 173 Brazilians, mainly weapons technicians and idled construction workers, left Baghdad on Wednesday after appeals and visits by high-ranking Brazilian officials. Eighty-two Brazilians remain in Iraq. Several hundred Bulgarians are stranded in Iraq as well as 66 Czechs, about half of whom are working on an irrigation project, officials said. Of nearly 10,000 Yugoslavs working in construction prior to the gulf crisis, less than 200 remain and are reportedly working on a hydroelectric project. About 5,000 Chinese are also in Iraq, mostly construction workers under state-arranged contracts.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Medical Group Lobbies French Company to Test Abortion Pill
DOC.TEXT: Doctors who hoped to test a French abortion pill must now convince its manufacturer, which called off testing because of public outcry against the drug. State health authorities have indicated willingness to approve a test program for RU-486 at the University of California at San Francisco. But it needs further information from the manufacturer, Roussel-Uclaf. And the researchers need to have the drug itself. RU-486 is not approved for general sale in the United States. In February, Roussel-Uclaf stopped providing RU-486 to the University of California at Los Angeles for tests there. The French company explained the move by saying an abortion pill is too controversial for America. ``We think public and political opinion in the states is not ready to accept either abortion or 486,'' said Ariel Mouttet, the international products manager for Roussel-Uclaf. ``We will resume testing it in the States when the debate and the climate on abortion has been resolved.'' The drug is taken in the first seven weeks of pregnancy under a doctor's supervision. It prevents fertilized eggs from implanting in the uterus. Dr. Marcus Conant, heading the group that wants to test the drug here, said its program would administer RU-486 with the hormone prostaglandin, which causes uterine contractions and reduces the risk of hemorrhaging. Tests at UCLA did not include prostaglandin. Conant said state regulators have ``told us our application looks really good.'' ``They have indicated a willingness to approve our testing protocol for RU 486, but they need information that only the (French) company can provide,'' Conant said. ``And we need access to the drug.'' Testing of RU-486 has backing from such groups as Planned Parenthood and the American Medical Association. Anti-abortion groups oppose it. They have threatened to boycott the products of Roussel-Uclaf if RU-486 becomes available in the United States. Conant and San Francisco epidemiologist Steve Heilig said they hope to meet with Roussel-Uclaf representatives by early next year to urge them to allow testing to continue. ``We think we have a chance to convince them because they're finally moving the drug into Britain and Scandinavia,'' Heilig said. ``We've had some meetings with them in France and we're making some progress.'' RU-486 was approved in France in 1988. Roussel-Uclaf says it has been used with 96 percent success by more than 55,000 women.

DOC.HEAD: Three Britons Home After Daring Escape
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: One of three Britons who made a daring escape from Iraq by boat said today other expatriates shouldn't try to escape the same way because it is too risky. Speaking to reporters upon their arrival at London's Heathrow Airport, Keith Barkworth, 36; Mike Teesdale, 40; and Ivan Manning, 44, said many Westerners in Iraq were plotting escapes. While Barkworth said he wouldn't recommend his own escape rout to others because it was ``too risky,'' Teesdale said he had tried it because, ``I have got a wife and two children and thought I had outstayed my welcome in Iraq.'' The Britons escaped with two Frenchmen, Amedee du Paty, 53, and Janel Cellier de Buriane, 55. The five men bobbed for 25 hours in a 10-foot boat in rough seas before being rescued off the Saudi Arabian coast near Khafji. It was the first report of Western men escaping from Iraq in over six weeks. Baghdad has kept thousands of Western men from leaving both Iraq and Kuwait since its Aug. 2 invasion. The men said they planned their escape for over a month. ``It was Mohammed's birthday (a religious festival) and a revolutionary holiday, so we felt they would be more relaxed than normal,'' Manning said. ``We couldn't let anyone know that we had gone. We needed at least 10 hours to get clear of Iraq, and if we had told anyone they might have thought it safe to tell others within two or three hours.'' Just before they were rescued, the men said they saw what they believed to be three warships on the horizon. They suspected they were not Iraqi and decided to approach. The ships turned out to be two platforms and a barge, and the men were greeted by a fellow Briton and brought on board for food and a bath. The three escaped Britons, who had been working in the Iraqi port of Basra, were reunited with their wives and families today. ``It is a marvelous feeling to be home,'' Teesdale said as he hugged his wife, Margaret.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget
Yeutter Would Oppose Further Cut in Farm Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said today he will oppose any effort to cut farm subsidies more than the amount specified in the defeated $500 billion deficit-reduction package. Yeutter, in a statement, said ``parochial interests overwhelmed the national interest'' in Thursday night's 254-179 House defeat of the budget agreement. ``The House did not have the political courage to cut entitlement programs, and it was unwilling to increase revenues in areas which add little or nothing to U.S. productivity,'' he said. ``This betrayal of political responsibility makes many meritorious agricultural programs even more vulnerable to cuts than before,'' Yeutter said. ``I will strongly resist any efforts to cut agricultural expenditures further in any future budget agreements.''
