Yeutter termed the agreement's $13 billion cut in farm programs ``a heavy hit'' on agriculture. But had the agreement been approved, he said, interest rates probably would have declined. And that would be good news for farmers, since it had been estimated over five years they would save about $5 billion in interest costs and $3.5 billion on other production expenses.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Paroled Because Of AIDS Charged With Three Bank Robberies
DOC.TEXT: A legally blind AIDS victim has been charged with robbing three banks in the two weeks since he was paroled from prison because of his failing health. ``I just think that it is a slap in the face,'' said Parole Board Chairman Kenneth Walker. District Court Judge Gilbert Indeglia ordered Robert Baird, 35, held without bail Thursday on three counts of robbery, said Tom Connell, a spokesman for the attorney general's office. Baird also was accused of violating his probation terms. Baird had pleaded for parole for more than a year before his Aug. 29 release. He accused officials of ignoring the fact that he had acquired immune deficiency syndrome and letting him die in prison. Baird wrote to politicians about going blind after prison officials failed to detect spinal meningitis. He also wrote judges, the American Civil Liberties Union, the Rhode Island Medical Society and the attorney general. ``I am being tortured by the state of Rhode Island through the Department of Corrections,'' Baird told a judge when he appealed for a shorter sentence in May. William Devereaux, Baird's court-appointed lawyer for the past several years, said Baird was hospitalized twice in the past two years. ``On one occasion we didn't think he was going to make it,'' Devereaux said. Baird was sentenced to 50 years, with all but eight years suspended, in February in connection with a bank robbery. He also was sentenced to 10 years, with three years suspended, on a robbery conviction in September 1988, Connell said. Baird's criminal record, which also includes assaults and drug offenses, dates to 1974, said Corrections Department spokesman Joseph DiNitto. Walker said Baird's arrest would not affect the board's handling of future cases. At least five people have received compassionate paroles in the past year because of AIDS. ``The board is such that it looks at each individual case,'' he said. Baird was arrested Wednesday less than an hour after a robbery at an Old Stone Bank branch, said police Detective Lt. Stephen McCartney. A man in sunglasses and a hat entered the bank and told a teller to put money in his bag, then fled with an undisclosed amount of cash, McCartney said. A few minutes later, a cab driver in the area reported a customer acting suspiciously. Police stopped the taxi, which was carrying Baird. He was charged after bank employees identified him as the man who robbed the bank Wednesday and a week ago as well, McCartney said. He also is a suspect in another robbery attempt Wednesday, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Won City Hall In Lawsuit, Sells It
DOC.TEXT: A man who fought City Hall and won the entire building has sold it. Now the city is fighting back. The buyer's identity and the selling price were not disclosed, and City Attorney Eric Vickers said he was unaware of the transaction. But Vickers also said he planned to file an appeal today protesting the original judgment that awarded the building to Walter DeBow. ``You cannot take city property,'' Vickers said. ``The entire transaction is illegal.'' A court awarded DeBow the building and a former industrial site Sept. 27 in compensation for a $3.4 million court judgment he won years ago in a damages suit against this impoverished city. The ruling came after the 55-year-old DeBow suffered permanent brain damage more than six years ago when he was beaten into a coma by a fellow prisoner in the city jail. He was in jail for illegal transportation of alcohol. DeBow has no short-term memory and needs care costing $325 a day. Clyde Kuehn, DeBow's lawyer, declined to give details of the sale. But Vickers has said City Hall is worth about $10 million. And before DeBow received the other property, city officials had been negotiating with a company to buy that site for $5 million to build a trash recycling plant. East St. Louis, a city of 40,000 people, is plagued by debt estimated at $47 million. A $34 million state bailout was enacted in August to raise money though state bond issues.

DOC.HEAD: Cocaine-Filled Propane Tanker Seized At Border Crossing
DOC.TEXT: A propane tank truck halted at the U.S.-Mexico border for being overweight also held an estimated 3.5 tons of cocaine, the Customs Service said. Federal agents still were tallying the exact amount early today. ``Upon verification, it is likely that this will be the largest seizure of cocaine ever made at the ports of entry along the California-Mexico border,'' said Quintin Villanueva, the Customs Service's western regional commissioner. Ron D`Ulisse, a Drug Enforcement Administration spokesman, said that if the estimated amount of cocaine is correct, it would have a wholesale value of about $85 million and a street value in San Diego of about $340 million. The Hidro Gas Juarez truck had been stopped Wednesday and held overnight at the Otay Mesa border crossing in eastern San Diego County because it weighed more than it should have. After waiting more than a day to drain the highly flammable propane, drug-sniffing dogs alerted inspectors to the presence of narcotics late Thursday. Before the cocaine was found, Customs inspectors had been legally required to release the truck's driver, a Mexican national whose name was withheld. ``We started (looking for narcotics) by searching the tires, and by the very nature of the truck, (the inspection) was a very dangerous job and we were proceeding cautiously,'' said the acting customs district director, Tom Hardy. The driver faces 10 years to life in prison and fines up to $4 million if apprehended and convicted of smuggling charges. The largest previous cocaine seizure at a California-Mexico border crossing was 1,290 pounds in 1988. The world's largest cocaine haul of 21.5 tons, with an estimated street value of $20 billion, was made in September 1989 at a warehouse in Sylmar, near Los Angeles. Hidro Gas Juarez is headquartered in Juarez, Mexico, with an office across the border in El Paso, Texas. Company officials were cooperating with authorities, Customs Service spokeswoman Bobbie Cassidy said. Propane is used primarily for heating and cooking in the United States. It also is a raw material for some chemical processes and is used by farmers to dry crops.

DOC.HEAD: 5 Killed in Fire At Detroit Apartment Building for Elderly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to recast and update with five dead; ADDS 3 grafs at the end to UPDATE with arrest, no charges, cause of deaths.
DOC.TEXT: A smoky fire swept through an apartment building for the elderly, killing five people and injuring about 50, some of whom jumped from windows because the building lacked fire escapes. Fire Chief Harold Watkins said the four-story, 76-year-old building also lacked sprinklers. Many of the injured suffered from smoke inhalation while others suffered broken bones from their leaps, he said. ``We tried to stop them from jumping,'' Watkins said of those who leaped from the upper floors. ``We said the ladders would be there. But the smoke was just too much for them. They just couldn't stand it. They jumped.'' The fire broke out Thursday night at the Majestic Manor senior citizens complex in midtown Detroit. It was doused by early this morning. Fire officials said the fire began in a first-floor apartment because of a cooking mishap. A resident who declined to be identified said a neighbor knocked on her door Thursday night to tell her the hallway was filled with smoke. ``So I called the building manager and she told me a man on the first floor had let his skillet burn over and that's what all the smoke was,'' she said. ``So I went back to bed. ``Later, and I don't know what time it was, I woke up and my apartment was filled with smoke. I sleep with the window open, anyway, luckily. Otherwise, I might have been dead.'' Police Sgt. Christopher Buck said today a 50-year-old man was taken into custody while the fire is investigated. No charges were filed immediately. Buck and Deputy Fire Chief Andrew Dempsey said five people died in the blaze. Watkins said the victims died of smoke inhalation and were found on the upper floors.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader's Son Gets 120-Year Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A cult leader's son was sentenced today to a minimum 120 years in prison for the slayings of four members of a family, killings he blamed on his father. Damon Lundgren, 19, appeared calm and stood with his hands folded while Lake County Common Pleas Judge Paul H. Mitrovich pronounced his sentence. Mitrovich ordered that Lundgren serve four consecutive 20-year-to-life sentences on aggravated murder convictions and four consecutive 10-to-25-year sentences on kidnapping convictions. Lundgren was convicted last month on four counts each of aggravated murder and kidnapping in the shooting deaths of Dennis Avery and Avery's three young daughters. He was acquitted in the death of Avery's wife, Cheryl. The Averys were led one by one into the barn, bound and gagged with duct tape, then shot and dumped into a common grave at a farm the cult rented in nearby Kirtland, about 30 miles east of Cleveland. Authorities found te bodies in January. Thirteen cult members were arrested. Some have pleaded guilty to reduced charges. Damon's father, Jeffrey Lundgren, said during his own sentencing hearing that he killed the Averys because his interpretation of Scriptures showed them to be sinners. He was sentenced to death in the electric chair. The cult leader's wife, Alice Lundgren, got five consecutive life sentences for conspiracy, complicity and kidnapping. Mitrovich chastised Lundgren for showing no remorse for his role in the killings. ``You accept no blame. You blame your father. You claim this was your father's doing and none of your own, but Jeffrey Lundgren could not have done anything without the help and devotion of you and his other followers,'' the judge said. ``Society cannot tolerate such excuses. ``You apologized for what your father did and for what happened to the Averys. But you did not apologize for your own part.'' Defense attorney Albert Purola said the sentence was expected. Special Prosecutor Joseph Gurley said: ``We expected no less. The jury had found he was an active participant and found him guilty of these four murders. And the judge in our opinion imposed the appropriate sentence.'' Defense attorneys argued that Damon Lundgren was so strictly raised and heavily controlled by his father that the youth was unable to disobey the cult leader's orders to help wrestle at least one victim to the ground and help bind and gag him. They also argued that the younger Lundgren did not actually pull the trigger. The elder Lundgren sometimes would put a gun to his son's head and tell his son to trust him, Damon said during his sentencing hearing. ``I was afraid that if I disobeyed him, I would end up just like those other people that died,'' he said. ``As far as my father was concerned, those people disobeyed him and he killed them.''

DOC.HEAD: Germans Arrive in Jordan After Being Freed From Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Four Germans held in Iraq since its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait arrived in Jordan today on their way home after being freed by President Saddam Hussein in honor of Germany's unification. The men arrived at Amman airport aboard a regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flight and were taken to the transit lounge to catch a Royal Jordanian flight for Istanbul, Turkey. The flight was scheduled to continue on to Frankfurt later today. German Embassy Charge d'Affaires Matthias Meyer said the four were German citizens who had been working in Kuwaiti companies. He did not give their names. ``They were all in good condition and they were very happy that they were going home,'' Meyer said. The Iraqi News Agency called them ``foreign guests,'' the term for the 2,000 Western men detained in Iraq and Kuwait, several hundred at strategic sites to deter an attack by multinational forces in the Persian Gulf. The news agency, monitored in Nicosia, also did not give their names. Their release is ``an expression of the Iraqi people joining in the happiness of the German people in reuniting their country,'' the news agency quoted Parliamentary Speaker Mehdi Saleh as saying. East and West Germany reunited Wednesday after four decades of Cold War division. The news agency said the four Germans left Iraq with Brigitta Koegler, deputy chairwoman of Democratic Awakening, a center-right group associated with the Christian Democratic Party. Before Germany's reunification, Ms. Koegler had been a lawmaker in the Volkskammer, the former East German Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Encephalitis Cases Mounting in Florida, Curb Nighttime Activities
DOC.TEXT: Officials in central and south Florida are advising people to avoid going outdoors at nightfall because of the increasing risk of bites from mosquitoes spreading encephalitis. The number of cases of St. Louis encephalitis has reached 28 since the first was reported in August. Fifteen people were hospitalized with the disease, which causes brain swelling; two are comatose. Another seven cases are suspected and await further tests. The disease kills about 7 percent of its victims. Little can be done to treat it, but it can be avoided. Health officials are telling everyone to stay indoors after dark and, if they do go outside, to wear protective clothing and insect repellent. The outbreak is Florida's most threatening in 13 years. In 1977, eight people died in the last statewide outbreak of the St. Louis strain of encephalitis, which causes flulike symptoms. Some communities are spraying with insecticide. Others are ordering school activities to cease by dark. In Broward County, school principals have been ordered to cancel nature hikes, camping trips, fishing trips and water-related activities that would increase student exposure to mosquitoes. Broward schools didn't cancel evening school activities, but instead will have their ball fields sprayed with insecticide before night games. A similar tactic is being used in Sumter County. In Martin County, beaches and county parks were ordered closed at night. Pest control companies are also busy. In Marion County, an Ocala pest control company is donating a natural mosquito pesticide to residents near bodies of standing water not treated by local governments.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Lawmaker Sleeps Through Crucial Vote
DOC.TEXT: Rep. George Crockett, D-Mich., who plans to retire this year after a decade in Congress, retired a bit early and was the only House member to miss the vote on a budget agreement. Crockett slept through the House's 254-179 vote early today rejecting the five-year, $500 billion plan to reduce the federal budget deficit. ``It's a little embarrassing,'' said aide Joan Willoughby. ``He didn't intend to miss it.'' Crockett was the only House member who did not vote on the package. Earlier, however, he voted for a motion that brought the bill to the floor and set ground rules for the debate, which lasted past midnight. As the discussion droned on, Crockett ``came back to the office to take a short nap,'' Willoughby said. ``He's 81 years old and he has two hearing aids and he didn't hear the bells'' announcing the vote on the budget package. The vote took place around 1:15 a.m. Friday. Crockett was the first member of the Michigan congressional delegation to announce his support of the budget plan. However, he changed his mind Thursday and had planned to vote against it, Willoughby said. ``He had a chance to read the tea leaves, heard from a lot of people back home, and he decided it was not the best package we could get,'' she said. Crockett returned to his Detroit district this morning and was unavailable for comment, Willoughby said. He announced earlier this year he would retire after his current term expires in January.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Klaus Upgraded to Hurricane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to ADD that klaus 6th hurricane of season and Josephine 5th, new coordinates, background on storm season. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Klaus gained strength off Antigua today and was upgraded to a hurricane after leaving six people dead and two missing in flooding on the Caribbean island of Martinique. The National Hurricane Center in Miami said Klaus had sustained winds of 80 mph this morning, up from 60 mph earlier. It remained stalled 30 miles off Antigua but was expected to start moving again later. It was uncertain whether Klaus, the sixth named hurricane of the season, would reach the United States. ``We expect it in the next two or three days to move toward the northwest and to be north of Puerto Rico and east of the Bahamas. Beyond that, it's too early to say,'' said Bob Sheets, director of the Miami Hurricane Center. Antigua's international airport was closed, said Stan Cieniewicz, administrative officer for the island-based Pan-Caribbean Disaster Preparedness and Prevention Project. He said Klaus was expected to cut between Antigua, a popular tourist spot, and its tiny sister island, Barbuda. Both islands are mainly flat, but Barbuda's 1,500 population is located almost entirely in the capital, Codrington, protected by a reef and lagoon. Early today, Antigua was being swept by high winds and intermittent rain, but there were no reports of damage. Antigua's government radio station, ABS, said schools were closed and residents were stocking up on supplies. It advised residents to stay indoors. Later, both ABS and another staion were knocked off the air by the winds. Authorities on Thursday evacuated hundreds of residents from the French island of Martinique, where the storm left floodwaters nearly 10 feet deep in some places. The dead and missing were reported on that island. Hurricane warnings were issued for the Leeward Islands along an arc from the French and Dutch island of St. Martin in the north to the British colony of Montserrat in the south. Tropical storm warnings remained in effect for Martinique and its sister island of Guadeloupe. ``It stalled again, just hasn't moved. I think later today it'll resume the northwestward drift,'' said hurricane specialist Max Mayfield at the Miami center. ``I think the problem will come in two to three days, when it gets to the northern Caribbean.'' The Hurricane Center said rainfall of 10 to 15 inches was possible for the islands of the northeastern Caribbean. That amount could trigger mudslides and more flash flooding. At noon EDT, Klaus was centered near latitude 17.2 north and longitude 61.3 west, or about 30 miles east-northeast of Antigua. The system's hurricane-force winds extended 30 miles from its center and tropical-storm forces 115 miles out. In Barbados, southeast of Martinique, floodwaters forced the evacuation of a few families overnight and temporarily blocked some roads, although the major tourist hotels on the western coast were unaffected. Islands covered by hurricane warnings included St. Martin, St. Barthelemy, Saba, St. Eustatius, Antigua and Barbuda, Anguilla, the British Virgin Islands, Montserrat and St. Kitts-Nevis. Many of the same islands were battered by Hurricane Hugo, which devastated the region in September 1989 before hitting the Carolina coast. Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Josephine, downgraded last week to a depression, strengthened in the mid-Atlantic to a hurricane late Thursday. Josephine, with top winds of 75 mph, was reported at noon EDT to be heading northeast at 16 mph about 750 miles southwest of the mid-Atlantic Azores archipelago. Josephine, the fifth named hurricane of the season, posed no immediate threat to land, located at latitude 32.6 north and longitude 38.2 west. Tropical storms are upgraded to hurricanes when their maximum sustained winds reach 74 mph. The hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30. Previous hurricanes this year were Bertha, Diana, Gustav and Isidore.

DOC.HEAD: King Says His Subjects Have Low Work Ethic
DOC.TEXT: Some Swedes were in an uproar Friday over their king's unprecedented comment that the Swedish work ethic leaves something to be desired. ``I suppose that we maybe should think about the Swedish work ethic and try and improve it in one way or the other. I assume we're all aware that it is not the best,'' King Carl XVI Gustaf, 44, told Dagens Industri in an interview Thursday. The Swedish monarch very rarely speaks out on political or controversial matters. Reaction came swiftly. Some people agreed with the king but others suggested he was speaking for himself and his acquaintances. ``I wonder if he ever tried to work himself,'' said librarian Anna Simkutte, labeling the royal comment ``utmost rubbish.'' ``I suppose that the king makes his statement from the circles where he dwells himself. In that case, that's an interesting insight into those circles,'' the Aftonbladet newspaper quoted labor federation spokesan Staffan Kellerborg as saying. A shoe repairman, who did not give his name, told The Associated Press he agreed with the king, to some extent. ``There are supposed to be people who can live well between four to eight years without lifting a finger,'' he said. ``But I think that the majority works.'' Critics have said the generous Swedish system for sick leave, holidays and unemployment insurance encourages absenteeism and makes some Swedish-made products too expensive. The king's duties include traveling abroad to promote Swedish industries. He owns large estates and holds mostly a symbolic function as a constitutional monarch.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Witness Says Mapplethorpe Photos Could Cause Child Abuse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with closing arguments. Picks up 6th graf pvs: ``Defense lawyers ...''
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor said today that sexually graphic photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe were convincing evidence in themselves for a conviction in the obscenity trial of an art gallery and its director. But a lawyer for the Contemporary Arts Center said the state failed to show that the exhibit lacked artistic merit. The Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, are charged with one count each of pandering obscenity and one count each of using children in nudity-related material. The misdemeanor charges stem from the exhibit ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment,'' which appeared in Cincinnati for seven weeks last spring. Barrie could be sentenced to a year in jail and fined $2,000 if convicted of both counts. The gallery could be fined $10,000. Frank Prouty, an assistant city prosecutor, said in his closing argument that five photos depicting graphic sex acts involving men and two that showed children with their genitals exposed were enough for convictions. The charges against the gallery and its director, Dennis Barrie, were based on those seven pictures in the 175-photo exhibit. ``The pictures speak for themselves,'' Prouty told the jury in Hamilton County Municipal Court. ``The pictures are the issue.'' Marc Mezibov, the gallery's lawyer, said the state failed to prove its case against the center and Barrie. No presentation was made to back up the assertion that the photographs were not legitimate art. ``Have you thought why it is that no one for the state of Ohio came in and testified that the exhibit had no serious artistic value? Don't you think that if there were people out there who thought that, the state of Ohio would have found them?'' Mezibov said. Barrie's attorney, H. Louis Sirkin, was scheduled to present his closing remarks later Friday, and the case was expected to go to the jury. Defense lawyers Thursday challenged the credentials of the prosecution's only expert witness, Judith Reisman, on grounds that she was not qualified, but Judge David Albanese ruled she could testify. Ms. Reisman said her qualifications included having prepared educational videotapes and slide presentations for the Smithsonian Institution. She also worked as a consultant for television's ``Captain Kangaroo'' show, for former Attorney General Edwin Meese's commission on pornography and for the onservative American Family Association. At issue in the trial are seven photographs a grand jury cited from the 175-photo exhibit. Five of the pictures depict sexually explicit acts involving men and two show children with their genitals exposed. Ms. Reisman testified that photographing nude children can be a prelude to sexual abuse. ``We are putting at risk additional children because many people see themselves as photographers, and many people do use the technique of telling children `this is appropriate because this is in a museum,' `this is appropriate because it is in a book,''' she said. ``That happens to be a standard technique for getting children into a child sex-abuse situation.'' Defense experts have testified that Mapplethorpe, who died last year of AIDS at age 42, was an accomplished and respected photographer, and that photographs of the children were morally and sexually innocent. The exhibit drew more than 80,000 people during its seven-week run, an attendance record for an art exhibit in Cincinnati. It closes this week in Boston, where 103,000 tickets have been sold.

DOC.HEAD: Search for Explosion Victims Ends, Death Toll At Seven
DOC.TEXT: Emergency crews Friday ended their 24-hour search through the ruins of an apartment building after finding the bodies of seven people killed in a suspected gas explosion. Eight people were injured, four seriously, when the explosion shattered the five-story building early Thursday. One child lost a foot and a baby was badly burned. Police said 49 people lived in the low-income housing unit in Massy, a town on the western outskirts of Paris. By late Thursday, all but two residents were accounted for, and they were located at a friend's house Friday. About 170 rescue workers and dozens of emergency vehicles responded to the disaster. Heavy cranes were used to lift chunks of concrete and crumbling sections of roof and walls. Authorities said a gas leak in one of the apartments was the most likely cause of the explosion. But gas company officials said no faults were discovered in outside gas lines leading into the building.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Tamil Activists Blackmail Sri Lankan Refugees
DOC.TEXT: Seven Sri Lankan activists have been charged with blackmailing fellow refugees of their war-torn island to raise money for a guerrilla group, police said Friday. The activists threatened Sri Lankan refugees with reprisals against their families at home unless they contributed money to the Liberation Tigers for Tamil Eelam, said Frede Rosenberg, a police official from the Danish city of Holstebro. Two of the seven men charged in the case, including the leader of the guerrilla group's Danish branch, were placed in custody pending further investigations, Rosenberg said. He said the police have been working on the case for six months and were tipped off by anonymous telephone calls from desperate members of the Tamil community in Denmark, which numbers about 5,000. The activists were demanding monthly blackmail payments and had sent the money to an address in Cyprus, Rosenberg said. Police earlier raided the group's offices in Copenhagen and in the western town of Struer, confiscating membership lists and cash.

DOC.HEAD: China Launches 30th Satellite
DOC.TEXT: China on Friday successfully launched its 30th satellite, a retrievable remote-sensing device that is to be in orbit for eight days, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. The launch is China's fifth this year, its busiest since China sent up its first satellite in 1970. The satellite was launched by a Long March-2 carrier rocket from the Jiuquan space center in northwest China's Gansu province, Xinhua said. It carried animals and plants whose reactions to weightlessness will be studied. Already this year, China has launched two telecommunications satellites, a test satellite and a meteorological satellite. In the next two years, China plans to launch five satellites for foreign buyers of its launch services, which are reported to be much cheaper than in the West.

DOC.HEAD: House Toughens Crime Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 7th graf pvs with 2 new grafs on racial discrimination amendments.
DOC.TEXT: A dozen more crimes would be subject to the federal death penalty and executions would be carried out more quickly, under amendments approved by law and order-minded House members. ``I hope we never bring up another crime bill a month before an election,'' Rep. William Hughes, D-N.J., said Thursday as the House bowed to conservative demands for a major reshaping of the measure. Hughes said campaign considerations were overshadowing the debate, but critics of the bill said stern measures were needed to curb mounting crime. Sarcastic cries of ``kill, kill, kill'' wafted through the House as lawmakers added harsh provisions that Rep. George Gekas, R-Pa., said were being demanded ``by the cop on the beat and the man on the street.'' The bill calls for the death penalty for more than 20 federal crimes, including provisions added Thursday imposing capital punishment for murder aboard trains, planes and automobiles as well as in mail bombings, bank robberies and elsewhere. Assassination or attempted assassination of the president would be punishable by death under the bill, as would treason and espionage. The House today voted 216-204 to leave in the bill a provision allowing death row inmates to use racial statistics in their appeals to show the sentencing courts were biased. Rep. James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., offered the amendment that would have stripped the provision from the bill. Supporters of the amendment said the provision would dramtically weaken and perhaps abolish use of the death penalty. Opponents said there was indisputable evidence that blacks are more likely to be sentenced to die than are whites. President Bush and congressional conservatives have been highly critical of the provision, which was dropped from a Senate-passed version of the crime bill. The House dealt Bush a victory Thursday by toughening provisions giving death row inmates a time limit for filing habeas corpus petitions claiming they have been treated unconstitutionally. Some convicts have filed one such petition after another, in some cases using the process to escape the death chamber for a decade or more. Lawmakers adopted 285-146 a substitute plan by Rep. Henry J. Hyde, R-Ill., that would let states impose a time limit and place curbs on repeated petitions. Hyde said it would stop ``endless, endless, endless delays.'' ``Over 2,350 murderers on death row are waiting for something to happen,'' Hyde said in urging approval of the measure. The version dropped from the bill would have limited priooners to one petition and required competent lawyers for them. But critics said exceptions contained in the provision would have resulted in even longer delays. Tempers frayed as the House prepared to approve a proposal by Gekas to make a dozen more crimes subject to the death penalty. Rep. Craig Washington, D-Texas, complained that Gekas had not answered his question on how it would work. Gekas said it wasn't a ``good question,'' and Washington shouted: ``You wouldn't know a good question if you heard it.'' The House approved the Gekas plan, 271-159. As the bill came to the floor, it would have banned domestic manufacture of any of the semiautomatic assault rifles whose importation has been banned by Bush. The president acted in response to complaints that the military-style weapons were designed for killing humans rather than for sporting purposes. However, the House adopted 257-172 an amendment by Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash., that would allow domestic manufacture of the rifles as long as the parts were American-made. Handgun Control Inc., a Washington-based group that campaigns for firearms restrictions, released a report from Unsoeld's campaign committee to the Federal Election Commission showing a $4,950 contribution from the National Rifle Association shortly after the amendment was introduced. The group said in a statement that Unsoeld ``sold her political soul to the assault weapon lobby in the hope that it will help her get elected.'' ``Absolute baloney,'' Unsoeld replied. She said she had not discussed the amendment with the NRA before introducing it and had not known about the campaign contribution at the time. The amendment was needed, she said, ``because there are a lot of us who support the Second Amendment (right to bear arms) who would feel compelled to vote against the bill otherwise.''

DOC.HEAD: Expected GOP Gain No Longer So Sure
DOC.TEXT: The Oregon governor's race once was dismissed by some as a near-certain GOP gain but the contest has come to life as the candidates hammer each other on crime and other issues. A poll released this week showed Democratic Secretary of State Barbara Roberts pulling even with Republican Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer, who earlier had been seen as the heavy favorite. ``If I'm not careful I may lose my underdog status,'' Roberts quipped in a debate on Thursday. ``I think it's an inevitable narrowing,'' said Frohnmayer. ``I'm just happy that this notion of front-runner is put to rest so people can really focus on the differences between the candidates,'' Roberts' TV ads cast Frohnmayer as an ineffectual attorney general who has done little about Oregon's crime and drug problems. Frohnmayer's ads attack Roberts' record on crime. One charges that the former state legislator voted against a bill allowing policewomen to carry radios they could use to call for help if attacked by a suspected rapist. Both candidates are crying foul over the other's advertisements. Frohnmayer accused Roberts of ``false advertising.'' ``Dave's been painting a picture of me I hardly recognize,'' Roberts maintained. ``Don't be fooled by fancy brush strokes.'' Just a few months ago, some observers had written off the governor's race as a snoozer in which Roberts was a hopeless underdog against the better-financed Frohnmayer. ``A lot of people think the race is already over,'' state GOP chairman Craig Berkman said in July. But a poll published in Thursday's Oregonian showed the candidates neck-and-neck, with Frohnmayer favored by 44 percent of those surveyed, and Roberts by 43 percent. The Sept. 25-30 survey had a 4 percentage point margin of error. Roberts also announced this past week that she had raised $1.3 million for her campaign, considered a respectable amount for someone who got a relatively late start in the race. Frohnmayer had raised $2 million in campaign contributions as of June. His next campaign finance report is due Monday. Roberts jumped into the race one day after Democratic Gov. Neil Goldschmidt's surprise announcement in February that he would not seek a second term because of marital problems. Frohnmayer, one of Oregon's best known political figures, already had spent months putting together an aggressive campaign. Also in the race are independent Al Mobley, a staunch anti-abortionist who says Roberts and Frohnmayer are too liberal, and Libertarian Fred Oerther, who has mounted no visible campaign. Mobley is seen as a possible spoiler in the race, since any votes he gets in November probably will be at Frohnmayer's expense. In the Oregonian poll, Mobley was supported by 7 percent of those surveyed and Oerther was backed by fewer than 1 percent. Frohnmayer and Roberts, meanwhile, have been going at each other for weeks, mainly over the crime issue. The two candidates also have argued over a measure on the Nov. 6 ballot to force a shutdown of the state's only nuclear power plant until the federal government licenses a permanent disposal site for radioactive waste. Roberts said she supports the measure because of concerns about on-site storage of waste at the Trojan nuclear plant, located near the Columbia River. Frohnmayer opposes the shutdown, saying it would leave the state vulnerable to future energy shortages and cost utility customers millions of dollars to pay for replacement energy sources. The candidates also have clashed over proposals to lock away more old growth trees from logging to protect habitat for the northern spotted owl. Frohnmayer has emphasized his support for the timber industry and criticized Roberts for not challenging a federal scientists' report recommending forest preserves for the owl.

DOC.HEAD: Four S.C. Legislators Plead Innocent At Arraignments
DOC.TEXT: Four suspended legislators charged in an FBI investigation of corruption in the South Carolina Statehouse pleaded innocent today to accepting bribes to support a pari-mutuel betting bill. Democratic Reps. Ennis Fant, B.J. Gordon and Larry Blanding each pleaded innocent to violating the Hobbs Act, a federal anti-bribery law, in appearances before U.S. Magistrate Henry M. Herlong Jr. in Columbia. They were each released on $25,000 bond. In Charleston, Republican state Rep. Thomas Limehouse stood ramrod straight with hands clasped behind his back as he pleaded innocent to bribery charges. U.S. Magistrate Robert Carr set a trial date for Dec. 10 in Columbia. Limehouse was released on $25,000 bond. ``I pleaded not guilty and I am not guilty. I look forward to my day in court where I can see that the rest of the story can be told,'' Limehouse said as he left the courthouse. The lawmakers arraigned today were charged Friday in the second round of indictments following the 16-month FBI sting investigation, dubbed Operation Lost Trust, into legislative vote buying. House Speaker Bob Sheehan, a Democrat, suspended the indicted lawmakers Friday. Four lawmakers indicted in August have already pleaded guilty to selling their votes in support of a bill allowing voters to decide whether to allow pari-mutuel betting in South Carolina. A fifth, state Rep. Luther Taylor, is scheduled to stand trial later this month. Blanding, 37, is charged with selling his vote in exchange for $1,300. Fant, 29, was indicted for accepting two bribes for a total of $1,300. Gordon, 57, a 17-year-veteran, was charged with accepting a $1,000 bribe. Limehouse, 31, was charged with conspiracy to solicit bribes, accepting $2,000 and tampering with a witness. He faces up to 50 years in prison and a fine of $750,000. Andy Savage, Limehouse's lawyer, indicated he will question whether charges could be brought under the Hobbs Act since the alleged bribes may not have affected interstate commerce. ``The bill, if it had passed, would have only produced an opportunity for the electorate to vote yea or nay on pari-mutuel betting,'' Savage said. ``There is a serious question ... whether there is an impact on interstate commerce.''

DOC.HEAD: Quake Rattles Capital
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake shook parts of New Zealand on Friday, knocking items off shelves but causing no serious damage or injuries. The quake, measuring 5 on the Richter scale of ground motion, was centered just off Cape Palliser on the southern tip of the North Island. People in downtown Wellington experienced a sharp jolt at 11:50 a.m., followed by a rolling motion that lasted about 30 seconds. Reports said the earthquake also was felt in the southern part of the North Island and the northern part of the South Island. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. A quake registering 5 can cause considerable damage, especially in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Police Lift Curfew In Soweto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 10th pvs to UPDATE with Mandela comment; Pickup 11th, `Also ANC...'
DOC.TEXT: Police said today they were lifting a 10-day-old, nighttime curfew in the black township of Soweto because a sharp drop in political violence and crime no longer made the restrictions necessary. Police imposed the 9 p.m.-4 a.m. curfew Sept. 25 in Soweto and other nearby townships to halt black factional fighting around Johannesburg that has claimed 800 lives in the past two months. Only scattered incidents have been reported in recent weeks, and Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said serious crime in Soweto had dropped by about two-thirds as compared to the 10 days before the curfew. Vlok praised residents in Soweto for ``outstanding cooperation'' with the police. Soweto, just outside Johannesburg, is the country's largest township with 2.5 million inhabitants. The curfew will remain in effect in several other townships, police said. The African National Congress, the leading black opposition movement, has opposed the curfew, saying it was implemented to weaken the normal organizational activities of the ANC. However, many Soweto residents said the curfew, while inconvenient, has made the township safer. In other developments today, Nelson Mandela and other ANC officials met leaders of five black homelands at Mandela's home in Soweto. However, Mangosuthu Buthelezi, leader of the Zulu homeland and head of the conservative Inkatha movement, declined to attend. Most of the township fighting has been between the ANC and Inkatha. Buthelezi says he wants one-on-one talks with Mandela to discuss the violence. The ANC has refused the request, saying Buthelezi has used the fighting to seek a meeting with Mandela that would enhance his stature. After today's meeting, Mandela said all participants agreed an unidentified ``third force'' was instigating the black factional fighting. ``It's not tribal violence at all,'' Mandela said. ``It is orchestrated by certain faceless forces in this country.'' Mandela and other black leaders have accused right-wing extremists, including members of the police and military, of fueling the fighting. Also, ANC and government delegations met in Pretoria to work out details of the ANC's decision to suspend its guerrilla campaign. The two sides have held periodic talks since the ANC suspended its largely ineffective armed struggle Aug. 6. President F.W. de Klerk says it wants to launch full-scale constitutional negotiations soon with the ANC and other opposition groups. De Klerk says he wants to end apartheid and set up a democratic system that allows the 5 million whites and 30 million blacks to share power.

DOC.HEAD: Unidentified Suspects Massacre Nine People in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Six gunmen dressed in military fatigues Friday killed nine people in eastern Colombia, including seven members of one family, police said. The gunmen fled after carrying out the massacre at a cattle ranch near the town of Tauramena, 100 miles east of the capital, Bogota. They were apparently leftist guerrillas belonging to the radical National Liberation Army, according to a statement from police in the state of Meta. It did not explain why the gunmen were wearing military clothes or give a motive for the murders. Although the guerrilla group is the country's most radical and active, most massacres of civilians are carried out by right-wing death squads seeking to crush the guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: Hijacked Soviet Jetliner Lands in Helsinki; Hijacker Surrenders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to CORRECT inspector's name, hijacker's age, ADDS Soviet Embassy requesting extradition.
DOC.TEXT: A man who hijacked a Soviet airliner to Finland today and threatened to blow it up surrendered after negotiating with authorities at Helsinki International Airport, police said. The Soviet news agency Tass said the man, who hijacked the plane during a domestic flight in the Soviet Union, turned out to be unarmed. ``The hijacker wanted to go to Stockholm, (Sweden), but he was told there was not enough fuel ... He is currently being interrogated by police,'' said Chief Inspector Pertti Virolainin. The 40-year-old man, identified by police as Nikolai Ivanovich Selivano, applied for political asylum, Virolainin told reporters. The Soviet Embassy later requested extradition of the hijacker. The hijacked Aeroflot Yak-40 aircraft carried 22 passengers - including two children - and a crew of four, Finnish authorities said. The 28-seat plane was flying northwest of Moscow when the man forced the pilot to change course. ``All the passengers were, of course, very worried and we passed the two children from lap to lap so that they wouldn't run in the aisle,'' said passenger Antonina Urjetskaya, 68, of Novgorod. ``My heart is in bad shape, so I was very worried, but I took a heart pill and I am very glad that the situation ended so well,'' she said. The hijacker was not identified. Tass said he had threatened to blow the plane up but did not say what type of explosives he had claimed to possess. Earlier this year, five domestic planes were hijacked to Finland and Sweden by young men who said they were political dissidents or fugitives from the Soviet army. Swedish and Finnish officials extradited four of them. One was given political asylum in Sweden. The Leningrad air traffic control center told Finnish authorities about the hijacked plane 25 minutes before it landed at the Helsinki airport today. The aircraft was on its way from Novgorod, 310 miles northwest of Moscow, to Leningrad and Petrozavodsk. It was hijacked before it reached Leningrad. The passengers were to be flown back to the Soviet Union after they made statements to the police. A Soviet Embassy official met the passengers at the airport and said if anyone ``wants to stay in Finland, step outside,'' said Yevgeni Khodorkovski, a passenger. Khodorkovski, 32, of Leningrad, laughed at the official. He said he and his wife had received exit visas to emigrate to Israel, but would go home again first and leave the country legally.

DOC.HEAD: Collection of Rome Books Sells for $4 Million
DOC.TEXT: The world's largest private collection of books on Rome sold for about $4 million during a three-day sale that ended Friday, Christie's auctioneers said. Top price for the sale was $240,000 paid anonymously by a European Continental buyer for a 14-volume set of etchings by Giovanni Battista Piranesi. The 18th century artist's etchings of architectural views on a grand scale are still influential today. The books had belonged to Franklin H. Kissner, an American who died in 1988. Kissner was a colonel and deputy director of economics for the U.S. military government in Berlin at the end of World War II. ``He had a lifelong interest in Rome, building up a collection of more than 4,000 rare book titles,'' said Tom Lamb, Christie's book expert. Kissner owned an apartment on the Piazza Navona in Rome as well as his home in New York City's Gramercy Park.

DOC.HEAD: Death Sentence Replays Will Bog Down Courts
DOC.TEXT: Many of the inmates on Oregon's death row are headed back to new sentencing hearings in the state's already sluggish court system because of a U.S. Supreme Court ruling. ``It's not going to shut the system down. But anything with a death penalty attached to it takes more time and effort than those cases without the death penalty,'' said Phil Lemman, an assistant to state Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer. The U.S. Supreme Court agreed Monday with the Oregon Supreme Court that three death sentences should be overturned. The state court had said that, because of a 1989 U.S. Supreme Court decision, the defendants were entitled to have mitigating evidence presented to the sentencing jury. The result is that many of the 23 men sentenced to death before the 1989 decision may qualify for new sentencing hearings. Oregon's capital punishment law, passed by voters in 1984, establishes a two-step court proceeding. The jury first decides whether a defendant is guilty of aggravated murder. If guilty, the jury decides whether the defendant should die by injection. Under the initial version of the law, a death sentence was imposed if the jury unanimously found the defendant posed a future threat of violence, acted deliberately in the killing and killed without provocation. The 1989 Legislature revised the law to take into account the U.S. Supreme Court ruling. The Oregon Supreme Court then fashioned an additional question on mitigating circumstances for jurors to consider. The court said the jury can weigh any aspect of a defendant's background, or any circumstances of the offense that would justify life imprisonment instead. Frohnmayer appealed the state Supreme Court ruling, arguing that it went far beyond constitutional requirements. He said mitigating factors for the jury to consider should be limited to those bearing on a defendant's moral blameworthiness. Lemman said it will be some time before it's determined how many new sentencing proceedings will be needed. In any case, he said, the sessions will require time and expense. ``These are not going to be quick two-hour hearings,'' he said. The law allows evidence from the trial to submitted to the sentencing jury, and witnesses can be recalled to testify. New lawyers also could be involved. The chief criminal judge in Multnomah County, which has the state's biggest trial court system, said new death sentence proceedings will add to the work but probably won't disrupt court dockets. Circuit Judge Philip Abraham said it appears up to six death-sentence cases will require new hearings in his county. ``It will impact the system somewhat, but I don't see it as insurmountable,'' Abraham said. His court system handles about 5,000 felony cases annually and had 31 murder cases pending at the beginning of October. The Oregon Supreme Court already had sent eight death penalty cases back to trial courts for new sentencing hearings at the time of the U.S. Supreme Court decision. Prosecutors have the option of seeking life terms instead of death sentences, and one district attorney so far has case has decided on a life sentence. In three other cases, death sentences were set aside when murder convictions were reversed by the state Supreme Court. All death sentence cases automatically are appealed to the state Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Diana Sees First Lady
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 6th graf, The princess, to say most people paid $3,500.
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush welcomed Princess Diana to the White House today for coffee and a discussion of the AIDS epidemic and a local home that cares for child victims of the disease. ``Good morning,'' Mrs. Bush cheerily greeted the princess as she left her limousine in front of the White House on a sunny morning. They posed briefly for pictures before going in for coffee with the Bushes' daughter, Dorothy LeBlond, and daughter-in-law Margaret Bush, the wife of the Bushes' son Marvin. Diana, who wore a rose-colored suit with purple trim, was accompanied by Lady Jennifer Acland, wife of the British ambassador, Sir Antony Acland. Mrs. Bush wore a long-sleeved blue dress. The princess planned to discuss her interest in AIDS patients with the first lady before heading to Grandma's House, a Washington home for young AIDS victims. Diana attended a charity gala Thursday night to benefit the home. Several prominent organizers boycotted the event on the grounds the ticket prices were too high. The princess was aware of the controversy, said British embassy spokesman Francis Cornish. He said he did not know her opinion of the ticket prices. But, he said, ``You can't wander into somebody else's country and say something's too steep.'' The minimum ticket price was $2,500, but most people paid $3,500, which included the honor of shaking Diana's hand. Despite the acrimony that arose over ticket prices, Cornish said Diana enjoyed the charity event and ``thought everybody else who turned up did.'' Diana wore a fuchsia silk off-the-shoulder dress to the gala. She entered to the strains of Handel's Water Music and presided over a table that included two of President Bush's children, Marvin Bush and Dorothy LeBlond. In addition to Grandma's House, the gala benefitted the Washington Ballet, the London City Ballet and the British-American Arts Association. The 29-year-old princess, who is married to Prince Charles, has had longstanding interests in those areas. She is patron of London City Ballet and has been involved with AIDS patients since 1987. She visited a pediatric AIDS unit at Harlem Hospital last year during a trip to New York City and has made similar visits to adult patients in London. Her second solo trip to the United States began Thursday afternoon with tea at the British ambassador's residence and continued late into the evening at the benefit. A number of women on the event's organizing committee did not attend, among them television personality Barbara Walters and Georgette Mosbacher, wife of Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher. The ostensible reason was that ticket prices, at $2,500 or $3,500, were too high. Mrs. Mosbacher asked for her money back, said Joanna Seymour, media manager for London City Ballet. Celebrities who did show up included Patricia Hearst, Democratic fundraiser Pamela Harriman, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner and the British and French ambassadors. Some 260 tickets were sold, with guests who paid the higher price entitled to shake hands with Diana at a pre-dinner champagne reception. The Departmental Auditorium, its gilded pillars draped with greenery, fruit, flowers and sheaves of wheat, was far from full. But the British and corporate organizers of the evening declared it a success. Seymour said the two ballet companies and Grandma's House would each receive more than $100,000. The arts association was in line for at least $20,000, she said. Seymour said ticket prices were discussed ``ad nauseum'' and determined in consultation with the British and U.S. organizing committees. The bottom line, she said, is that 260 tickets were sold and money was raised. ``It's not a matter of who buys the tickets,'' Seymour said. ``This is not an evening for people to see and be seen at. This is an evening to raise serious money for worthwhile charities.'' The benefit featured a short auction run by John Marion, chairman of Sotheby's New York. A diamond-and-pearl necklace set in 18-carat white gold, designed by a London jeweler especially for the occasion, brought $22,000. A gold and enamel carriage clock with the royal monogram, donated by Diana, sold for $7,500. Each guest received a vial of Christian Dior perfume and a program decorated with gold tassels and seals, inscribed in gold with the night's menu. The dinner included a seafood-filled brioche, filet of beef and an elaborate pastry and fruit dessert on plates individually decorated with chocolate designs before serving. Wine, champagne and cognac were donated, along with 500 gold chairs flown in from Britain to match the flatware. Overhead was expected to be low because most costs were picked up by ADT, the chief sponsor of the gala, and other corporate contributors. ADT describes itself as the leading provider of electronic security protection and vehicle auction services, with operations throughout North America, the United Kingdom and continental Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard Cleared of Asian Discrimination Charges
DOC.TEXT: The Education Department Friday said Harvard University has been cleared of charges its undergraduate admission policies discriminate against Asian-American applicants. Michael Williams, assistant secretary for civil rights, said an examination of records found Asian Americans were admitted to Harvard at a lower rate than white applicants mainly because of the preference given to children of alumni and recruited athletes - groups in which there are few Asian Americans. ``While these preferences have an adverse effect on Asian Americans, we determined that they were longstanding and legitimate, and not a pretext for discrimination,'' said Williams, who made completing reviews at Harvard and UCLA his highest priority when he joined the agency in July. On Monday, the department announced a finding of discrimination against Asian Americans seeking admission to the University of California at Los Angeles graduate mathematics program. UCLA now must offer admission to five Asian-American students who had been ``discriminatorily denied admission.'' Williams said the Office of Civil Rights could find no evidence of a quota at Harvard limiting Asian Americans, who have gone from being 5.5 percent of the class in 1983 to being 19.6 percent of the class of 1994. The two-year investigation included a review of thousands of applicant files and 10 years of applicant data provided by Harvard, as well as dozens of interviews with staff and other individuals, Williams said. Investigatios have been conducted in response to complaints alleging that several schools, including Harvard and UCLA, were in violation of Title VI of the 1964 Civil Rights Act. The law stipulates that recipients of federal funds cannot discriminate on the basis of race, color or national origin.

DOC.HEAD: Parisians Breathe Easier As 18-day Trash Strike Ends
DOC.TEXT: Garbage truck drivers Friday ended an 18-day strike that produced huge piles of uncollected trash on Paris sidewalks and forced emergency action by city officials. Union leaders said the strikers decided to return to work even though their wage demands were not fully met. Jean Tibiri, chief deputy to Mayor Jacques Chirac, said the city decided unilaterally to implement its offer to increase the drivers' pay by $23 to $39 a month, according to seniority. Tibiri said no reprisals would be taken against the 600 drivers who heeded the strike call of the leftist General Confederation of Labor. But he said they would not be paid for the days they were on strike as the drivers had demanded. On Sept. 21, the fourth day of the strike, Chirac announced private firms had been hired to collect the fast-accumulating trash. He also took legal action that forced the strikers to abandon blockades at the three incineration plants where garbage from throughout the metropolitan region is taken. Chirac said the health of more than 4 million people was at risk.

DOC.HEAD: Casiraghi To Be Buried In Chapel Overlooking The Sea
DOC.TEXT: Stefano Casiraghi, Princess Caroline's husband, will be buried at a private chapel overlooking the sea in which he died, the royal palace said Friday. The palace said the private burial service would take place immediately after a public funeral Saturday at the Cathedral of Monaco. Prior to the announcement, there had been uncertainty whether Casiraghi would be buried in the principality or in Italy, where his parents live. Casiraghi's speedboat flipped over Wednesday during the World Offshore Championships. Residents of Monaco were allowed to view Casiraghi's body Thursday at a mortuary near Princess Grace hospital. On Friday, a palace spokesman said, the coffin was closed and taken to the palace for a private family Mass. The funeral service is scheduled for late Saturday morning at a 115-year-old cathedral situated just below the palace. It can accommodate more than 2,000 people. Casiraghi, who was 30, is to be buried in the Chapelle de la Paix. Also buried in the private chapel is another commoner who married into the royal family - dancer John Gilpin, the late husband of Prince Ranier's sister, Antoine. After the burial, some of Casiraghi's fellow speedboat racers plan to ride aboard a yacht to the site where the accident occurred and lay a wreath in his memory. An Italian newspaper, Il Secolo XIX of Genoa, reported Friday that Casiraghi's parents were ``deeply irritated'' by the royal family's decision to display the coffin at the mortuary rather than in the palace. The newspaper, citing unnamed sources, also reported that the Casiraghis and the royal family were at odds about whether the funeral and burial should be in Monaco or Italy. The speedboat championships, in which Casiraghi was seeking to defend his world title, were canceled after crews from the other 41 boats withdrew. Casiraghi had been racing at world-class level since 1984. He had told friends he planned to quit after this season. Casiraghi's death came eight years after Caroline's mother, Princess Grace, was killed in a car accident. He and Caroline were married on Dec. 29, 1983, in a civil ceremony. They had three children.

DOC.HEAD: Banner Message Indicates Marriage Will Fly
DOC.TEXT: Mark Spencer spent $250 asking Lora Sheppard to marry him, and she didn't even notice at first. Spencer, 31, set his romantic stage by gathering about 30 friends for a parking-lot party before Saturday's University of Arizona football game. The engagement ring was tucked in his pocket. Also tucked out of sight was a chilled, 2{-foot bottle of champagne. Not so invisible was the airplane he hired to tow a banner reading: ``LORA WILL YOU MARRY ME SPENCE.'' But Ms. Sheppard, 28, didn't notice the plane. She raised her eyes only after friends began to encircle her and one told her to look up. ``Oh my God,'' she exclaimed. To make sure she got the message, Spencer dropped to one knee and popped the question. ``I just hugged him and said, `Yes! Yes!'' she said later. The two have known each other since July 1989 and had discussed marriage, ``but I was expecting we'd go to dinner or something, and he'd ask me there,'' she added. ``I had no idea it would be this.'' They have yet to set a date, ``but it's definitely on,'' Spencer said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks, Bonds Recover After Sharp Drop on Budget News
With PM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with early afternoon trading. No pickup. Longer version moved on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Stocks and bonds staged a strong recovery today after diving in reaction to House rejection of President Bush's plan to reduce the budget deficit. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks, the best-known measurement of the stock market, tumbled nearly 70 points when trading began but recovered. By early afternoon, it was up 25 points to the 2,540 level. Traders said stocks received a boost when Britain announced that the pound will enter Europe's exchange rate mechanism, effective Monday. That lifted share prices in London, and the enthusiasm transferred to New York. The opening plunge triggered an NYSE restraint on computerized selling strategies aimed at helping stabilize the market, an outgrowth of the stock market crash nearly three years ago. Concern over rising oil prices and persistent turmoil in the Persian Gulf contributed to the drop. But traders apparently decided to place concern over the budget crisis on hold. ``Everybody's disappointed by the (budget pact failure) but in the end I think people have decided not to let it bother them for awhile,'' said Dudley Eppel, a strategist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. In the bond market, a sensitive barometer of the economy and interest rates, the key 30-year Treasury bond was down about $2 per $1,000 face amount, after falling close to $6 earlier in the day. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, rose to 8.81 percent from 8.79 percent late Thursday. The House voted 254-179 early today to spurn Bush's plan aimed at trimming $500 billion from the staggering federal deficit that is keeping interest rates high. The rejection doused investor hopes that the Federal Reserve would take quick action to lower interest rates, which would have tended to make stocks and bonds more valuable. Economists said investors also remained anxious about a possible outbreak of war in the 2-month-old Persian Gulf crisis, which has doubled the price of oil since early this summer and raised the threat of acute inflation.

DOC.HEAD: 300 Sign Up for Kuwait Evacuation Flight
DOC.TEXT: About 300 Americans and foreign-born family members have signed up for an evacuation flight due to leave Kuwait next Wednesday, the State Department said Friday. The passengers will arrive at Raleigh-Durham airport in North Carolina on Thursday after an overnight stay in London, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said. The flight will go from Baghdad to Kuwait and then back to Baghdad before flying on to London. Boucher declined to say how many of the 300 are Americans. The flight will be the first U.S. government-sponsored charter to evacuate Americans and their family members since Sept. 22. About 1,900 Americans have left the two countries aboard these flights since they were instituted a month ago. The large majority have been women and children. The State Department said late last month that at least 900 U.S. citizens remain trapped, including 600 to 700 in Kuwait and 300 to 350 in Iraq. glg

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Prime Minister To Meet Bush
DOC.TEXT: Hungarian Prime Minister Jozsef Antall will meet with President Bush at the White House on Oct. 18, the White House announced Friday. Antall will be in Washington from Oct. 17 to 19 on an official visit that will include a state dinner at the White House on Oct. 18, said Bush's Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater. He will visit Boston, New York and Detroit before arriving in the capital and will fly to Los Angeles Oct. 19 before returning to Budapest Oct. 20, Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Loose Bull Scatters Crowd at Mississippi State Fair
DOC.TEXT: A 2,000-pound Brahman bull got loose at the Mississippi State Fair, scattering crowds and bowling over pursuers. ``If it had of been any other kind of bull but a Brahman, we could have walked right up to it,'' said Jamie Cox, 24, of Edwards. ``But Brahmans are mean.'' The bull snapped its rope behind a barn Thursday night and wandered into a field where cars and livestock trailers were parked. Then the bull, apparently frightened by a growing circle of onlookers, stormed toward the midway. ``I looked up and saw a lot of scary looks like there was a gang fight,'' said Johnny Minninger, 32, of Madison. ``All of a sudden, a bull came out of the crowd with about 50 people chasing it.'' Fire Lt. Rudy Brooks suffered a blow to his left knee when he tangled with the bull. He said it knocked him into a trailer and under it. ``I had him around the head trying to keep from getting my insides squashed out,'' Brooks said. The bull took off ``straight out toward and directly past the front gate, made his way to Kiddy Land, past the circus and cut across the midway,'' said Harold Roosa III, 27, of Kansas City, Mo., a Bluegrass Shows employee. As it sped past the circus, the bull belted a man in a wheelchair, Roosa said. The man was uninjured. The growing crowd steered the bull into a left turn, past a concession stand, and into the livestock judging arena where it was corralled with a makeshift cage. ``We brought in another bull and a heifer to tame him down,'' Brooks said.

DOC.HEAD: Temporary Worker Becomes Temporary Millionaire
DOC.TEXT: A temporary clerical worker became a temporary millionaire when a bank accidentally put $7.5 million in her money market account. Elizabeth Shilling thought at first the nine-digit number on her receipt was a bank code when she deposited $132.28 on Sept. 28 at a PSFS branch. The next day, she realized the bank teller mistakenly had credited her account with $7,500,132.28. Later that day, a note from the bank confirmed the error. ``We apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused,'' it said. The widowed mother of four admitted to fleeting thoughts of moving to a tropical island or buying a word processor, but said she never seriously considered trying. ``I thought it was funny,'' she said Wednesday. ``I knew I couldn't spend the money.'' Bank spokeswoman Rebecca Brinks said errors of such size occasionally occur. Shilling said it wasn't the first time she was enriched by mistake. Once a teller mistakenly credited her savings account with $17,000. Another time a teller gave her $380 when she withdrew only $80. ``I must look poor,'' she said. ``I must look like I need money.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Iraq Blasts U.S. In U.N. Speech, Says World On Brink of War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series. CORRECTS that Aziz speech will be read by an Iraqi envoy, not Aziz. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's foreign minister today accused the United States and its allies of bringing ``the entire world to the brink of a devastating war'' in a quest to gain control of the Middle East's oil. In a prepared speech, Tariq Aziz said the U.N. Security Council was hypocritical when it penalized Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait while allowing Israel to continue occupying Arab lands seized in 1967 and 1973 wars. He proposed that all Middle East problems - ``Palestine, Lebanon, the gulf and others'' - be considered on the same basis. An Iraqi envoy was to read the Aziz speech to the General Assembly this evening. A text of the speech was obtained in advance by The Associated Press. Aziz did not come to New York to deliver the speech because the United States denied landing rights for the plane the Iraqi delegation has used in the past, proposing instead that Aziz take a commercial flight. The foreign minister said in the speech that America and its allies ``are seeking to gain control over the oil reserves in the gulf so as to have a free hand in manipulating the needs of the world, and especially the needs of the peoples of the Third World, for this important commodity.'' He accused Iraq's foes of deploying ``fleets, aircraft and ground forces in the region in a way that has no parallel in contemporary history, thus bringing the entire region, nay the entire world, to the brink of a devastating war.'' Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, prompting the United States and other nations to send tens of thousands of troops and scores of warships to the gulf in a bid to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The United Nations also imposed a trade embargo on Iraq and allowed other nations to use force to uphold it. The speech said the United States and its allies are manipulating world opinion to conceal Kuwait's identity as part of Iraq until 1913, when Britain ``undertook to sever Kuwait from Iraq.'' It accused the United States and its Western allies of ``pushing the world, in the context of one of the most dangerous and pernicious campaigns of disinformation known to history, into a new imperialistic era.'' ``The United States is seeking, in a dangerously coercive manner, to impose its hegemony over the world,'' Aziz said.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Church Leadership Seen As No Impediment To Growth
DOC.TEXT: The Mormon Church's 160th Semiannual General Conference this weekend finds the faith a study in familiar contrasts: a robust and growing membership headed by an aged prophet in declining health. The faith's tradition of succession by apostolic seniority has bred a gerontocracy that averages 70.8 years of age and produces presidents considerably older and more prone to infirmity. ``I don't think anyone has to be told of the negatives of a gerontocracy in terms of the medical realities,'' said D. Michael Quinn, a former Brigham Young University professor who's writing a history of the church's hierarchy. ``The other problem is that you have, at the highest leadership of the church, men . . . who are at least two generations, sometimes three generations, removed from the majority of the population of the church.'' But there are also advantages in having well-seasoned administrators in the governing First Presidency and its advisory body, the Council of the Twelve Apostles, he said. The 160-year-old church is struggling to cope with a rate of growth that has seen membership more than double every 15 years since 1945. At that rate, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, with 7.5 million members and more than 40,000 full-time missionaries, will have 265 million members by 2080, according to a study by Rodney Stark, a non-Mormon professor of sociology and comparative religion at the University of Washington. The church has 4.2 million members in the United States. ``What you have to realize is that a group can look small for a long time and then all of a sudden it just explodes,'' Stark said. ``So just wait until all these people convert their relatives and see how it really kicks in.'' The latest casualty of advancing years is Ezra Taft Benson, the church's president since 1985. Mormons believe Jesus Christ directs the church's affairs through the president, who is considered a ``prophet, seer and revelator.'' Benson, 91, remained hospitalized Friday in serious condition two weeks after surgery for blood clots on the brain. He was able to maintain a full schedule for only the first couple of years of his five-year tenure. His predecessor, Spencer W. Kimball, was mostly incapacitated for the five years before his death in 1985 at age 90. But church spokesman Don LeFevre said the hierarchy doesn't miss a beat when its leader falters. ``When the president of the church becomes incapacitated, the network is already in place and his counselors and the Council of the Twelve Apostles simply carry on,'' LeFevre said. When a church president dies, the office is filled by the president of the Twelve, that body's most senior apostle. Howard W. Hunter, a former corporate lawyer, is Benson's heir apparent. Hunter will be 83 Nov. 14. A widower, he remarried last spring and puts in full days, LeFevre said. Church leaders in 1978 provided for retirement of members of the First Quorum of the Seventy, which acts under the direction of the Twelve, giving some members emeritus status. The move was seen as a way to inject new blood in the hierarchy, but the policy has never been extended to include the Twelve. But eventually, Quinn said, the Mormon gerontocracy likely will face a crisis of succession where the heir to the prophetic mantle is himself ``unable not simply to walk, unable to talk, but unable to function in any recognizable way in front of an audience to even acknowledge he is the president of the church.'' ``They've been spared that thus far, but if that occurs, I don't know what they'll do,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill Seven Rioting Inmates, Wound 107 Others
DOC.TEXT: Police fired on rioting prisoners at a maximum-security jail in the capital Friday, killing seven inmates and wounding 107 others, a senior prison official said. At least 76 jail officials also were injured in the riot at Tihar Jail on the southeastern outskirts of the city, said Hari Prem Kumar, the inspector general of prisons. About 2,500 inmates rioted for more than three hours and also tried to escape, Kumar said. Press Trust of India said the riot was sparked by the death of an inmate Thursday night and later turned into a mass escape attempt. The rioters accused jail officials of failing to give the inmate adequate medical treatment. Press Trust quted jail authorities as saying the prisoner, identified only as Hari Singh, died of natural causes. But United News said there was a report that Singh was killed in a clash between rival gangs. The charges on which Singh had been jailed were not immediately known. Tihar jail houses prisoners who are awaiting trial or have been convicted of ordinary crimes as well as those detained in cases related to violence arising from separatist revolts such as the ones in Punjab and Kashmir.

DOC.HEAD: Smelly Dogs Create Big Stink in `Mayberry'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to restore dropped first name
DOC.TEXT: Something smells in Mayberry, and it's not Aunt Bee's plum-apple pie. A woman has been charged with have malodorous dogs in the town that served as the loose model for the 1960s hit TV series ``The Andy Griffith Show.'' ``I just think it's not right ... not fair,'' said Jan Peters, who owns 11 dogs, including nine puppies. Police Chief Leo W. Shores said that since April 30, his department has had 10 complaints about Ms. Peters' dogs. A complaint Wednesday led to the charges of fouling of the air by odors. Ms. Peters, 38, also was accused of letting her dogs be too noisy. Shafer E. Gwyn, 77, who lives next door, said he hasn't been able to sit on his carport or cook on his outside grill for the past month because of the odor. Officer J.W. Shropshire agreed. ``When I went on his carport, it liked to knocked me down,'' Shropshire said. Ms. Peters said she didn't think her dogs were too loud or too smelly, but she called the animal shelter to have someone pick them up. The violations carry a $50 fine. Ms. Peters said her 8-year-old daughter, Stephanie, cried. ``She loves those babies. She said, `Mama, I won't have nothing to cuddle up to anymore.''' Mount Airy, 35 miles northwest of Winston-Salem, is the hometown of actor Andy Griffith, who portrayed the folksy widowed sheriff whose beloved Aunt Bee helped him raise his son.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Rises Again; Analysts Fear Recession Has Started
DOC.TEXT: America's unemployment rate worsened for the third straight month in September, the government said Friday. Many analysts saw the report as evidence that the economy has quietly slipped into a recession. The increase in the civilian jobless rate to 5.7 percent, coupled with unemployment rises in July and August, marked the first time since the depths of the 1981-82 recession that the jobless rate has increased three months in a row, the government said. ``Let's face it; it's a trend. We've been pushed over the edge. ... We're in a recession and it's going to go on for at least six to nine months,'' said David Wyss, an analyst for DRI-McGraw Hill. The Bush administration insists the economy has not fallen into a recession, but presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said after Friday's announcement that ``we're certainly concerned about the economy.'' Fitzwater said that concern was heightened by the House rejection of a proposed deficit-reduction agreement, which the administration had touted as the budgetary fix needed to convince the Federal Reserve Board to lower interest rates and spur the flagging economy. ``Today, we see unemployment jump to 5.7 percent, which only emphasizes the urgency of this situation,'' Fitzwater said. But many analysts said Friday's report, showing unemployment up 0.1 percentage point and at its highest level since the spring of 1988, made clear that the economy has lost the strength necessary to avoid toppling over the edge into a recession. ``Fallen off? We're in midair and I don't think we've reached the bottom yet,'' said Ian Borsook, a senior economist with Merrill Lynch. More industries lost jobs than gained them in September, causing an overall loss of 101,000 jobs from non-farm payrolls, the Labor Departmet said. About 42,000 of those losses were census workers laid off by the government. But Janet Norwood, the commissioner labor statistics, noted that the weakness in the September job market had hit factories and service industries as well. ``Few areas of the economy are escaping the downward tug of the current economic slowdown,'' Mrs. Norwood said. The nation's employment picture began a downward spiral in July, as the economy failed to produce enough jobs to keep up with the number of Americans looking for work. Since then, the jobless rate has risen 0.5 percentage point from June's 5.2 percent. The rapid jump in unemployment reflects an economy that was showing little signs of life even before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices soaring and increased fears of an imminent downturn. The government's technical definition of a recession - two quarters of economic decline as measured by the gross national product - has not officially been met. Indeed, the GNP for the year's third quarter is expected to post a small gain, even with September's lackluster performance. Many analysts think a full-fledged downturn will take hold in the fourth quarter. The 101,000-job loss in September, though inflated by the census workers, was the biggest job decline since the economy lost 104,000 jobs in June 1986, the government said.
