A year ago, the economy was creating nearly 200,000 jobs a month. The slump in the manufacturing sector continued in September, with factory jobs posting a 66,000-job loss. There have been more than 500,000 jobs lost in that sector since January 1989. Construction also continued its slide in September, posting the fourth decline in as many months as the weakness in the housing market showed no signs of abating. Jobs in that sector have fallen by more than 100,000 in recent months. The service-producing sector, which until a few months ago had been enjoying robust job growth, actually lost 17,000 jobs in September. Within the sector, the services industry itself, which employs one in four non-farm workers, added only 20,000 jobs, one of the smallest gains since the 1981-82 recession, Mrs. Norwood said. Labor costs, which are frequently blamed for worsening inflation problems, rose a sharp 0.5 percent. The average hourly worker made $10.13 an hour in September, up from $9.73 in September 1989. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the September jobless rate was 5.6 percent, up from 5.5 percent in August.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says Its Foes Have Brought World to Brink of War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Iraqi foreign minister's prepared speech, State Department comment on next evacuation flight. TRIMS. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today the United States and its allies have sent forces to the Persian Gulf region because they hope to gain control of the Middle East's oil supplies and that their plan has brought the world to the brink of war. In a speech prepared for delivery to the U.N. General Assembly, Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, said the U.N. Security Council was hypocritical when it penalized Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait while allowing Israel to continue occupying Arab lands seized in 1967 and 1973 wars. He proposed that all Middle East problems - ``Palestine, Lebanon, the gulf and others'' - be considered on the same basis. An Iraqi envoy was to read the Aziz speech to the General Assembly this evening. A text of the speech was obtained in advance by The Associated Press. Aziz did not come to New York to deliver the speech because the United States denied landing rights for the plane the Iraqi delegation has used in the past, proposing instead that Aziz take a commercial flight. The foreign minister said in the speech that America and its allies ``are seeking to gain control over the oil reserves in the gulf so as to have a free hand in manipulating the needs of the world, and especially the needs of the peoples of the Third World, for this important commodity.'' He accused Iraq's foes of deploying ``fleets, aircraft and ground forces in the region in a way that has no parallel in contemporary history, thus bringing the entire region, nay the entire world, to the brink of a devastating war.'' Also today, the State Department said 300 Americans and foreign-born family members have signed up for an evacuation flight due to leave Kuwait Wednesday. The passengers will arrive in North Carolina on Thursday after an overnight stay in London, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said. The flight will go from Baghdad to Kuwait and then back to Baghdad before flying on to London. Boucher declined to say how many of the 300 are Americans. The flight will be the first U.S. government-sponsored charter to evacuate Americans and their family members since Sept. 22. About 1,900 Americans have left the two countries aboard these flights since they were instituted a month ago. The large majority have been women and children. The State Department said late last month that at least 900 U.S. citizens remain trapped, including 600 to 700 in Kuwait and 300 to 350 in Iraq. In other developments: -A respected Western research institute says that if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, Iraq could survive for only weeks. -A newspaper reported today that Iraq has high-explosive devices equal in power to small nuclear bombs. -A Soviet envoy carried a message from Mikhail S. Gorbachev to Iraq on Thursday, and Britain said it supports linking talks on the Palestinian question to an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait. In London, the director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies, Francois Heisbourg, said on Thursday that Iraq ``would not last terribly long'' if war broke out, several days or only a few weeks. But at the same news conference, institute spokesman Andrew Duncan said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein would probably resort to using chemical weapons on Western civilians because of problems attacking well-protected and mobile U.S. troops in the gulf. Meanwhile, The Los Angeles Times reported today that Iraq has acquired explosives equal in power to small nuclear bombs, and it said that has raised concerns that the United States has no ready defense against the weapons. The fuel-air explosives, or FAEs, have 10 times the power of conventional explosives and create a huge fireball and shock waves over a concentrated area, without the radiation fallout associated with nuclear weapons. Military officials say the explosives could devastate oil fields, air bases and troops, the newspaper reported. ``It's not your garden-variety weapon,'' Henry Sokolski of the Pentagon's international security affairs office told the newspaper. ``These are blast-effect weapons, and what you can't see can kill you.'' The weapons can be launched as bombs from airplanes or as warheads on missiles. Pentagon officials said U.S. forces would have difficulty defending against a missile-delivered warhead, but there is no clear evidence Iraq has the ability to mount the explosives on missiles. Five senators have called on Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to launch an investigation into Iraq's supply of the weapons, which the paper said Iraq apparently developed using scientific knowledge from the German arms industry. Meanwhile, diplomatic efforts to end the 2-month-old crisis moved forward. Yevgeny Primakov, a senior adviser to Gorbachev, arrived in Baghdad Thursday carrying an undisclosed message, Soviet diplomatic sources said. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, quoted Primakov as saying a negotiated solution was needed ``to avoid a military explosion.'' He planned to request that some of 5,000 Soviet citizens, most of them oil industry workers, be allowed to leave Iraq, the diplomatic sources said. Also Thursday, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain called on Israel to be prepared to negotiate the Palestinian problem if Iraq withdraws from Kuwait. In a U.N. speech Monday, President Bush said an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait could lead to opportunities for a broad Middle East settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Launch with Nuclear Probe Draws Radiation Monitors
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prepared for the worst, an Energy Department team equipped with millions of dollars worth of radiation monitors staked out Kennedy Space Center for Saturday's launch of a shuttle with a plutonium cargo. ``It would be irresponsible'' not to be ready in the event of an accident, said Energy Department spokesman Dave Jackson. ``There is 23.7 pounds of plutonium in the space shuttle,'' Jackson said Friday. ``Even if there is an accident and no release, we have to document the fact that there is no release ... and make people understand there is no hazard.'' About two-thirds of the 70-member team were to be standing by with portable radiation monitors during the fueling of Discovery late Friday and early Saturday, and during liftoff, scheduled for Saturday morning. Energy Department officials also planned to have a plane circling overhead at launch time to measure radiation in the air in the event of a Challenger-like accident. The danger will linger for 7{ hours after liftoff, when the plutonium-powered satellite is released for its five-year solar journey. If one of the satellite's upper-stage engines fails, for instance, the spacecraft and its plutonium generator could come crashing through the atmosphere. The emergency team is prepared to rush anywhere in the world that the generator might fall, Jackson said. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration say there is a less than one in 1 million chance of Discovery being involved in an accident that would lead to a plutonium-related death. So far, there have been three space accidents involving plutonium generators, during the 1960s and early 1970s. About 20 anti-nuclear activists who say NASA is playing down the danger demonstrated at the space center Friday morning. They stood along a highway leading to the center's main offices, holding signs condemning NASA's use of plutonium as employees streamed by in cars on their way to work. Some of the workers shouted insults at the protesters. Two women, one of them an 81-year-old, were arrested when they entered a restricted area with the intention of sitting on the launch pad. They later were charged with trespassing. Armed security guards prevented reporters from approaching the protesters, many of whom took part in a Sept. 22 demonstration that attracted about 150 people. Concerned about NASA's recent spate of shuttle problems, an environmental coalition asked a federal judge in Washington to delay the launch for at least a year. The judge refused to do so Friday, which came as no surprise to the protesters. The same judge, a year ago, denied a similar request and Atlantis lifted off with a Jupiter probe containing twice as much plutonium as the sun probe Ulysses. That launch, the first in which a shuttle carried plutonium, drew a government radiation-monitoring team of about 200 people, as well as many of the same protesters. Bruce Gagnon, the coalition's state coordinator, said the demonstrations hopefully will persuade NASA to use solar panels instead of plutonium generators on deep-space probes scheduled to go up in the mid-1990s. ``All the excuses are gone now after this launch. They have five to six years to develop a solar alternative,'' Gagnon said. ``It's important that people come out and protest against these things, whether we stop it today or not.'' Neither Gagnon nor any of the other protesters planned to be anywhere near Kennedy Space Center on launch day.

DOC.HEAD: 1991 Guinness Book Packed with 3,000 New Records
DOC.TEXT: The Guinness Book of Records, first published to settle pub disputes and other friendly debates, issued its 1991 edition Friday with 3,000 new records, revealing the lengths people will go to get their names in print. Englishman Dale Lyons ran 29.9 miles in four hours and 18 minutes - balancing a fresh egg in a dessert spoon. In cracking the previous egg and spoon race record, Lyons gained a place in the book. The Royal Army Ordinance Corps broke the round the world driving record between May 13 and June 22, traveling 25,187.8 miles in 39 days, 23 hours and 35 minutes. ``There is a fascination with breaking a record. People like to feel they can actually get their name in a book,'' said Cathy Brooks, the spokeswoman for Guinness Publishing. The latest edition shows that Americans continue to pin their shot at the big time on big food. Students and staff at Lawrence University in Appleton, Wis., froze out the competition in the Largest Popsicle category - constructing one in February that weighed 7,080 pounds. Proving that silliness knows no frontiers, a crew of cooks at a Pizza Hut in Singapore achieved its record by baking a pie measuring 111 feet, 3 inches in diameter. Britain's Army Catering Corps of the Prince of Wales Own Regiment of Yorkshire gave the world a record-breaking Yorkshire pudding of 360 square feet. Asians took the opposite approach, achieving new world records for smallness. Dipak Syal of Yamuna Nagar, India, won a record for minuscule writing by inscribing ``I love you'' and ``I love you, too'' and thn signing his initials ``D.S.'' on a single grain of rice in May. His 813 characters beat the record of Pan Xixing of Wuxi, China, who in March wrote ``True Friendship is like sound health, the value of which is seldom known until it be lost'' on a human hair. ``Minuscule writing has proved very popular,'' Ms. Brooks said. ``We've been receiving massive packages from India all year. Our editors open them up to find one grain of rice inside. The biggest problem has been not losing the potential record breaker under a desk.'' Since the first Guinness Book of Records was published in England in 1955, the fascination with setting records has spread as the book made its way around the world. The first U.S. edition, published under the title Guinness Book of World Records, appeared in 1956. French and German language versions quickly followed. The book has been translated into Japanese, Spanish, Danish, Norwegian, Dutch, Portuguese, Czech, Hebrew, Serbo-Croatian, Icelandic, Slovenian, Greek, Indonesian, Chinese, Turkish, Hindi, Malay, Arabic, Thai, Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, Kannada and Hungarian. In 1990, the first Russian language edition was published. ``Now that we have a publishing partner in the Soviet Union, it is possible to check and verify information in a way which has been impossible in the past,'' said Donald McFarlan, editor of The Guinness Book of Records. The international competition the book has sparked could not have been envisioned by Sir Hugh Beaver on Nov. 10, 1951, the fateful day his hunting party missed a flock of golden plover. Seeking a reason for the failure, Beaver searched a reference book for proof that the golden plover was Britain's fastest game bird. It isn't. The 1991 Guinness Book of Records lists the red grouse as Britain's fastest bird. Finding no definitive reference book set Beaver to thinking. The managing director of Guinness, the beer brewer, pictured unanswered questions arising in debates in pubs throughout Britain. The Guinness Book of Records was born. In 1974, it earned its own place in the record books as the top-selling copyright book in publishing history, with sales of 23.9 million copies. In October, global sales surpassed 65 million, equivalent to 182 stacks each as high as Mount Everest.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Prepares Discovery For 7:35 a.m. EDT Saturday Launch
LaserPhoto CSB1
DOC.TEXT: A judge gave the thumbs' up Friday and NASA counted down toward a launch of the space shuttle Discovery carrying the nuclear-powered Ulysses spacecraft. Two demonstrators opposed to Discovery's radioactive cargo were arrested. Discovery was scheduled to blast off at 7:35 a.m. Saturday. Six hours after launch, the five-man crew is supposed to release Ulysses from the cargo hold. The satellite will then rocket itself out of Earth orbit for a round-about voyage that eventually will take it around the sun to study its so-far unexplored polar regions. NASA officials said Friday the countdown was going well. Fueling of the shuttle, which includes a critical test of its liquid hydrogen plumbing, was scheduled to begin about 11:15 p.m. EDT. Kennedy Space Center spokesman Dick Young said the mission would be unaffected in the event of a shutdown of government agencies because of the dispute over the federal budget. He said funds for the mission had already been set aside and notices had gone out that all employees were to report to work. ``The mood of the team is confident and that's despite distractions and disappointments recently,'' said launch director Robert B. Sieck. ``If the weather is good to us, we'll have some good news'' on Saturday. For NASA, the news has been mostly bad since the last successful shuttle launch in April. The agency has scrubbed four shuttle launch attempts because of hydrogen fuel leaks and learned that there is a serious flaw in the Hubble space telescope. Another problem was added to the list Thursday when workers discovered that a 9-foot, 70-pound metal beam had been left in the engine compartment of the shuttle Atlantis. When the craft was hoisted from a horizontal to a vertical position, the beam clanked around inside the compartment, causing up to 25 dents and dings. None of the damage was believed serious, Sieck said, and Atlantis is still scheduled for a mission in November. The beam is normally used to support a work platform used when the shuttle is being processed on the ground. William Lenoir, boss of NASA's spaceflight program, said the problems are isolated incidents and not signs of the agency's decline. ``I don't see a common thread that connects the Hubble incident, the hydrogen leaks, and the beam,'' Lenoir said at a news conference. A group of 20 demonstrators gathered at a restricted entrance to the space center Friday morning and protested Ulysses' nuclear power supply. They milled around the gate, waving signs and calling to space center employees driving in to work. Two women from the group were taken into custody after they walked past a checkpoint into a restricted area. They were charged with trespassing. In Washington, D.C., a judge rejected a petition by three activist groups that sought to block Discovery's launch with its nuclear-powered payload. They asked for more research into the risks of the spread of radioactive materials should Discovery explode during launch. U.S. District Judge Oliver Gasch rejected the contention, just as he did for a similar claim filed last year before the launch of Galileo, which also was nuclear powered. Ulysses is powered by a radioisotope thermoelectric generator, or RTG, which generates electricity from the heat of 23.7 pounds of highly radioactive plutonium. The United States has used 22 RTGs on earlier space missions, including five moon flights. NASA says the plutonium is housed in a module that has been tested to withstand any probable accident. The agency estimated that in the worst possible accident, there is only a 1-in-44 million chance of 14.5 cancer fatalities over 50 years. After Ulysses is released from Discovery, a two-stage rocket will fire and send the European-built craft streaking toward Jupiter. Ulysses will loop over Jupiter's north pole in 1992 and the giant planet's intense gravity will give it a powerful burst of speed and hurl it back toward the sun's south pole. In 1994, Ulysses will pass within 120 million miles of the sun's south pole and about 18 months later it will pass over the solar north pole. Discovery's commander is Richard N. Richards. The pilot will be Robert D. Cabana. Others in the crew are William M. Shepherd, Bruce Melnick, and Thomas D. Akers.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Foreign Minister To Hold Talks In Washington
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam's foreign minister has accepted an invitation for talks in Washington on humanitarian issues, the Vietnamese state radio said. Nguyen Co Thach will hold talks with Gen. John W. Vessey, a special U.S. presidential envoy, at the invitation of Secretary of State James A. Baker III, the broadcast said. No date was given. It said Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Ho The Lan made the announcement at a news conference in Hanoi on Thursday. A text of the broadcast was seen in Bangkok on Friday. Vessey has been a chief negotiator on humanitarian issues with Vietnam, including the efforts to account for about 2,300 Americans reported missing in action - or MIA - during the Vietnam War. Vessey met with Vietnamese Deputy Foreign Minister Le Mai in New York on Sept. 20, and later reported that the Vietnamese wanted to speed up cooperation on the MIA issue. The resettlement of Vietnamese refugees and migrants in the United States has been the other major humanitarian issue between the two countries. The United States says it will not establish diplomatic relations with Vietnam until the end of the Cambodian civil war, which was sparked by Vietnamese invasion. But Washington has shifted to a more flexible position in recent months, and on Aug. 6 held its first talks with Vietnam on peace efforts in Cambodia.

DOC.HEAD: Tass to Open Bureau in Israel
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet news agency Tass will open a news bureau in Israel, an official said Friday, as relations between the two countries continue to improve. The exact location of the Tass office - Jerusalem or Tel Aviv - has not been decided, said Tatyana Kitayeva of the news agency's international department. The bureau chief will be Alexander A. Zhurdo, she said in a telephone interview. At a United Nations meeting on Sunday, the Soviet Union and Israel announced plans to open consulates in each other's countries, a major step in restoring relations that were cut after the 1967 Middle East War. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Israel would open a consulate general - the highest level consulate - in Moscow, and the Soviets would open a consulate general in Tel Aviv. It also has been announced that direct airline flights between the Soviet Union and Israel would begin within a month. Such flights could accelerate the exodus of Soviet Jews to Israel, which already is straining to accommodate more than 100,000 Soviet emigres who arrived since last year.

DOC.HEAD: Primitive Indian Group Entering Agricultural Wave
DOC.TEXT: The Yanomami Indians, the largest known primitive tribe in existence, may be changing from a nomadic to a stable community, two leading scientists said Friday. Some groups in the tribe - which inhabits the tropical Amazon rain forest along Venezuela's border with Brazil - are also experiencing a population growth equal to about 2 percent a year, they said. Charles Brewer-Carias, a Venezuelan naturalist, said the population growth coupled with a change in cultivation habits were basic conditions for transition to a stable community. Brewer-Carias and Napoleon A. Chagnon, an anthropology professor at the University of California at Santa Barbara, led a 40-day expedition that in recent weeks contacted four Yanomami groups. About 14,000 Yanomamis inhabit the Venezuelan Amazon and 9,000 live across the border in the Brazilian rainforest, scientists say. It is believed the Yanomamis migrated from the Caribbean region thousands of years ago. Because they burn their dead and drink a solution of the ashes, evidence of them is hard to trace. The Yanomamis hunt with poisoned arrows and many use primitive tools. They shun clothes, decorate their bodies with fruit dye and flowers and live under huge palm huts in small communities. The Yanomami are the largest tribe with little or no contact with the modern world. The Yanomami groups are based on parental ties. But once they reach a number of 200 to 250, parental relationship weakens among Yanomami and they apparently split forming a new group that settles elsewhere, scientists say. Chagnon, who has studied the Yanomami Indians for 25 years, said his conclusions on population growth among the Venezuelan groups come from studies on the reproduction of Yanomami women from different villages. On the Brazilian side of the border the Yanomamis haven't been as lucky, suffering at the hands of gold prospectors, who have brought disease and chemicals to the primitive communities. Speaking from California, Chagnon said he also has collected data on settlement and migration. He said most existing Yanomami villages emerged from a single village between 120 and 150 years ago, and then scattered. The original village had a population of no more than 300. Their descendents dispersed over 12 villages and now number over 2,000. ``They increased more than six-fold during the past 120-150 years. By demographic standards, that is a very high rate of expansion. It would be a high rate even if it were half of this,'' he said. Chagnon and Brewer-Carias are co-directing a project to study the Yanomami and other Indian cultures over the next 10 years. The recent expedition, which covered the High Siapa River basin near the Brazilian border, was supported by the University of California and Fundafaci, a private Venezuelan foundation. Brewer-Carias said the expedition found evidence that new splinter groups were spreading over the Brazilian-Venezuelan border. Some have shifted cultivations from banana to manioc. ``It seems they are experimenting with new staples,'' Brewer-Carias said. It took nine hours of helicopter flight before the expedition found and contacted the first Yanomami group ``still untouched and up to that moment totally isolated from our culture,'' Brewer-Carias said. In Brazil the Yanomamis have been pushed deep into the jungle by gold prospectors, who have invaded their lands seeking gold and diamonds. About 3,000 have died over the past three years, most from exposure to disease. Because of their isolation, the Indians have no immunity against common viruses and can easily die from flu or cold.

DOC.HEAD: Princess Diana Visits 3-Year-Old `First Lady' With AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Princess Diana visited two first ladies Friday - one who lives in the White House and another, only three years old, who is infected with the AIDS virus. The younger ``first lady'' earned her nickname because she was the first child placed at Grandma's House, a home for children with the deadly virus. The little girl, dressed in bright pink overalls for the occasion, grabbed Diana's hand when they were introduced. The princess scooped her up, carried her upstairs during a tour of the Victorian row house, and readily agreed when she asked to ride around the block in Diana's dark green Rolls Royce. As cameras flashed and whirred, the princess stepped out of the car with ``the first lady'' in her arms - a symbolic picture that gratified the founders of Grandma's House, who have kept its location unpublicized out of concern about prejudice and fear. ``That kind of picture... a person of her stature coming...'' said the Rev. Debbie Tate, president of a crisis housing organization that runs Grandma's House. ``It shows that it's all right to love a person with AIDS, it's all right to care about a person with AIDS, it's all right to hug a person with AIDS... It won't hurt you.'' Tate said the little girl had not been diagnosed yet with full-fledged AIDS, but the virus was progressing. Once that diagnosis is made, she said through tears, ``the first lady'' could be expected to live about a year. Diana's whirlwind trip, her second solo visit to the United States, ended less than 24 hours after she arrived in the country. She attended a gala Thursday night to benefit Grandma's House and ballet companien Washington and London, and had coffee Friday morning at the White House with Barbara Bush and others before her motorcade went to the children's residence. President Bush appeared for the last 10 or 15 minutes of the 35-minute White House meeting, according to British Embassy spokesman Francis Cornish. He said Bush congratulated Diana on her work and compared her causes to those he honors with his ``thousand points of light'' program. Diana, wearing a dusty pink suit with purple trim and matching purple pumps, knelt down on the floor of the Grandma's House playroom to get closer to the children there. ``Aren't you excited we have the princess with us today,''' a man said to the children. Diana was said to have blushed and murmured, ``Don't put it that way.'' The princess concluded her visit by cutting a red ribbon to open Grandpa's House, a nearby house that will double the program's capacity from six to 12 children. The brief ceremony was witnessed by Mayor Marion Barry and his wife, Effi. Diana strode across the street to shake hands with well-wishers, creating an instant commotion, and then she was gone. ``It touched my heart. She was very, very warm, very much a caring person for the children,'' said Joan McCarley, Tate's sister and the executive director of Grandma's House. McCarley said the money raised by the gala - more than $100,000 - also meant a lot to her small operation. ``It will open other doors'' for the abused, fragile and neglected children who need the home's refuge, she said. Still, the gala, with its $2,500 minimum ticket prices that jumped to $3,500 for those who wanted to shake Diana's hand, was a sore point of the short royal visit. Several prominent U.S. organizers did not attend, and one even asked for her money back. Cornish said the princess was aware of the controversy, but said he did not know what she thought of the ticket prices. He added, ``You can't wander into somebody else's country and say something's too steep.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: A health food store clerk who sang the national anthem to Sinead O'Connor from behind the meat counter got the ax after the Irish pop singer complained. Ms. O'Connor refused to perform at a New Jersey concert this summer if the ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' was played. She has let it be known that she objects to any national anthems being played at her concerts, even the Irish anthem. The singer is also known for her nearly shaved head and her hit ``Nothing Compares 2 U.'' Former meat clerk Mike Rechtien said that on Tuesday, Ms. O'Connor entered Mrs. Gooch's Natural Food Market. When she approached the counter, he said he told her, ``I have a song for you.'' With that, Rechtien, a struggling musician, launched into ``Oh say, can you see ... '' According to her publicist, Ms. O'Connor asked the store not to punish Rechtien. But store officials said Rechtien was fired from his job because ``the store maintains a strict policy on harassment of any kind including verbal, physical or visual.'' He worked there six weeks. ---= NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - A critic of Mayor Bill Boner, known for his romantic affairs as well as his politics, said she would turn down a chance to confront the mayor on national television because she's afraid he will embarrass Nashville. Newlywed Boner and his fourth wife, aspiring country singer Traci Peel, are to appear on Phil Donahue's nationally syndicated talk show this month. Jo Ann North, a city councilwoman and critic of Boner, was invited to appear on the same show, but says she'll decline. North fears Boner will only embarrass his hometown, which has been trying to polish its image to attract a National League baseball franchise. ``If I thought I would have an opportunity to talk about all the wonderful things in Nashville and promote Nashville, I'd do it in a heartbeat,'' North said. ``The only good thing that can come out of this is the promotion of Traci Peel's career.'' Boner and Peel married Monday in Hawaii. They began dating while he lived with his third wife. Their affair gained wide attention after a reporter called the couple one evening and Peel commented that the mayor's passion could last seven hours. Bumper stickers soon appeared, proclaiming: ``Seven hours for Traci, three years for Nashville.'' A Nashville car dealer offered to pay Boner's $75,000 salary if the mayor would resign before his term ends next year, but Boner angrily rejected the offer. --- LONDON (AP) - Writing made Russian novelist Leo Tolstoy famous but the family talent has proved costly for one of his descendants, historian Count Nikolai Tolstoy. Last year, the High Court in London ordered Tolstoy, 55, to pay a record $2.8 million in damages for writing a pamphlet in which he called Count Aldington, a 76-year-old World War II veteran, a war criminal. Now that libel judgment has forced Tolstoy into bankruptcy, he said. The pamphlet said that in May 1945, when he was army Brig. Toby Low, Aldington handed over 70,000 anti-Soviet Russian Cossacks and anti-Communist Yugoslavs to the Soviet Army and Marshal Josip Broz Tito, knowing they would be tortured and killed. Aldington testified at the libel trial that he believed assurances from the Soviets and Tito that the prisoners would be lawfully tried. He said the jury's ruling vindicated his reputation. --- KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (AP) - Britain's Prince Richard, the Duke of Gloucester, arrived at this Southeast Asian archipelago Friday for a six-day visit that will take him from the sultan's house to the field of sports. The Prince, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, was received at Kuala Lumpur's International Airport by officials of the Malaysian Foreign Ministry and the British High Commission. Also on the agenda is a reception by Malaysian ruler Sultan Azlan Shah at the national palace. He also will meet members of the national ambulance corps and pay calls on the country's ministers of finance, trade and industry and youth and sports.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Spends $2.3 Million In Less Than Three Months
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo, seeking re-election to a third term, has spent almost $2.3 million in less than three months and still has almost $6.1 million in the bank, his campaign committee reported Friday. Comparable figures for Republican challenger Pierre Rinfret weren't immediately available. Two weeks ago, Rinfret said his campaign was broke and he threatened to quit the race unless Republican leaders came up with money for him. He has since said his campaign fund-raising has improved and that he won't quit the race. A recent statewide poll, conducted by the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, found that 60 percent of those surveyed favored Cuomo while less than 15 percent opted for Rinfret. While the cash-rich Cuomo campaign has held no major fund raisers since its July 15 filing with the state Board of Elections, it still managed to raise $625,871 since then, according to records filed with the state Board of Elections. That includes more than $279,000 in interest payments on the money the Cuomo committee already had in the bank.
DOC.HEAD: Rep. Bob Neuenschwander Decides Against Write-in Campaign
DOC.TEXT: State Rep. Bob Neuenschwander says he won't conduct a write-in campaign because of voter apathy, the deer season and his hard-to-spell last name. The four-term lawmaker lost to former House Majority Leader Irv Anderson in the Sept. 11 Democratic primary. ``I feel confident that, if my name were on the ballot in November, I could win by 1,500 votes,'' said Neuenschwander. ``But to wage a write-in campaign with a name like Neuenschwander and to overcome voter apathy by urging a sticker campaign with the election just four days after the deer season opener is just not in the cards.'' He said he had considerable support if he had mounted a write-in campaign. ``I had one group that called that said they had been practicing writing my name,'' he said. ``One lady told me that after 15 minutes of practicing, she still hadn't got it right.''
DOC.HEAD: Candidate's Wife Says Safety Was Motive For Taking Down Opponent's Signs
DOC.TEXT: The wife of Republican congressional candidate Dick Waterfield says her motivation for tearing down campaign posters belonging to her husband's opponent was safety, not politics. Gail Waterfield was spotted by Hartley County Sheriff Johnny Williams Thursday morning in a Waterfield for Congress campaign car tearing a poster for Bill Sarpalius poster from a utility pole. When asked what she was doing, Mrs. Waterfield told Williams she was pulling the posters because they were posted illegally on telephone poles, the Amarillo Globe-News reported. Sarpalius, a Democrat, is the incumbent and he faces Waterfield in the November election. Waterfield spokesman David Crowder brushed aside as ``ridiculous'' assertions that the removal of the Sarpalius election posters was politically motivated. Mrs. Waterfield took down the signs, he said, for safety reasons. ``Signs placed on utility poles are illegal regardless of whether they're campaign or otherwise. Signs on utility poles pose problems for the individuals that service utility poles,'' Crowder said. Sarpalius spokesman Robert Hinkle, who speculated the signs were posted by supporters, said he was stunned to learn it was Waterfield's wife removing their signs. ``Gail may be more anxious about going to Washington than Dick is,'' Hinkle said. ``If you believe she was ripping them down because it was unsafe, I've got some property ... to sell you.'' James Hoard, spokesman for Southwestern Public Service Co., said late Thursday that posting signs on power poles is illegal in most cities, but he wasn't sure what the law was in the outlying areas.
DOC.HEAD: Hunt Campaign Pulls Ad With Hubbert's Name Misspelled
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Guy Hunt, whose recent television ads have focused on teacher competency, pulled one commercial after his campaign staff discovered his opponent's name was misspelled. The Hunt campaign sent a new series of ads to TV stations late last week. But on Sunday, the campaign notified stations that one of the ads was not to be run until a replacement could be sent. The reason was that Hubbert's name was spelled ``Hubbard.'' ``It was done in production in Washington,'' Hunt campaign spokesman Terry Abbott said. ``The ad was scrapped before it ever went on the air.'' Abbott said he understood the ad with the typographical error might have run in some TV markets, but if so, it was against the campaign's instructions. Hunt's new ads blame Hubbert for Alabama not testing its new teachers and link him with Bill Baxley, the 1986 Democratic gubernatorial nominee, and Joe Reed, the black political leader who is Hubbert's associate at the Alabama Education Association.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Removes WWII Allies' Rights, Enacts First Law
LaserPhotos BON2,4
DOC.TEXT: Germany's new Parliament on Friday ratified an international treaty that grants full sovereignty to the nation, formally ending 45 years of special rights by the World War II Allies. Parliament also rescued plans for nationwide elections Dec. 2 by approving a new balloting law - the first time former East German lawmakers cast parliamentary votes alongside colleagues from the West. Some eastern newcomers seemed moved by the occasion, which came two days after East Germany and West Germany became one. ``I'm awed that I - from Mecklenburg - am permitted to speak to an all-German Parliament,'' said Conrad-Michael Lehment, a resident of that former East German city and a member of the Free Democrats. The 144 eastern lawmakers, joining 519 representatives from the west, crowded into the Bundestag, a humble structure that once housed part of Bonn's water system. ``I warmly welcome you to the waterworks,'' parliamentary president Rita Suessmuth joked to the new lawmakers. On Thursday, the first all-German Parliament since 1933 held a symbolic session in Berlin, capital of the new nation. Bonn is Germany's seat of Parliament. The new 663-member Parliament's approval formally ends special rights conferred on the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain after the Allies defeated and divided Nazi Germany in World War II. Under the rights, the Allied powers controlled transit between sectors of Berlin and could veto any laws in the city. They also prohibited the West German carrier Lufthansa from flying to Berlin, because its planes would have had to fly over what was then East Germany. The treaty was already signed in Moscow on Sept. 12 by West and East Germany and the four Allies. A broad majority of government and opposition lawmakers approved the new election law by a simple show of hands. The legislation replaces an election treaty that was rejected by the Supreme Court on Sept. 29. The court said the old treaty gave unfair treatement to small parties. The overruled treaty would have required a party to win 5 percent of the vote across Germany to earn a seat in the Bundestag. The new law in effect sets up two separate election areas in the united Germany. Lawmakers in former East Germany will have to receive 5 percent on their own turf, rather than polling that amount across the united country. That will give smaller partes like the Party for Democratic Socialism - East Germany's renamed Communists - a better chance of winning parliamentary seats. However, the Democratic Socialists voted against the new plan, saying it opposes any minimum vote for winning parliamentary seats. Such a system, said party leader Gregor Gysi, ``manipulates the will of the voters.'' Parliamentarians needed to quickly come to agreement on an election law so the vote could be held as scheduled Dec. 2. The united Parliament's first working session was relatively civil, but accusations flew nonetheless. Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier, from the West German branch of the opposition Social Democrats, charged that Chancellor Helmut Kohl's unity policies had created ``concern, fears and discontent'' among East Germans. Despair is rising on former East German territory because of rising unemployment resulting from the rough transition from four decades of communism into capitalism. Finance Minister Theo Waigel presented a new supplementary budget to the lawmakers that would raise federal borrowing this year by $17 billion. Most of the borrowed money would be used to create new jobs and housing and to bolster pensions and social welfare payments in the eastern part of Germany. Also during the parliamentary session, former Communists and other leftists joined with the Social Democrats in calling for further disarmament in united Germany. Horst Ehmke, a security expert for the Social Democrats, said all nuclear weapons should be removed from Germany. Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann, from the Party for Democratic Socialism, said Germany should scrap compulsory military service.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Find New Government Seat A Surprise, And Expensive
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers from now-extinguished East Germany were in town Friday, dismayed by Bonn's steep hotel prices and eager to move into offices hastily being furnished. Some offices for legislators from the former Communist Party were ready in what was once a kindergarten, located near the Parliament building. Lawmakers from other parties were also moving into new rooms. But they were shocked at prices in Bonn, the parliamentary seat of united Germany. Asked how he found his hotel, Wolfgang Thierse of the Social Democratic Party said:``Very expensive. I have never before in my life slept for 215 marks ($140) a night.'' ``You're not there long enough to get your money's worth,'' Thierse said. At the offices of the former Communist Party, now called the Party of Democratic Socialism, lawmaker Sabine Fache was busy setting up her office after attending Friday's Parliament session. ``We had a good flight from Berlin. It was a Lufthansa flight late last night. That was a first,'' Ms. Fache said, laughing. The four World War II allies prohibited Lufthansa, the national airline, from flying between West Germany and Berlin because its planes would have had to fly over East German territory. That changed with German unity. Missing in Bonn from the 23 Democratic Socialist deputies was former East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow, on a visit to Japan. Virtually all of the other 144 Parliament members from the East made the trip West to Bonn. After being driven past Parliament buildings, the newcomers were split among several hotels in the city, Ms. Fache said. ``Ours was a little hotel on the outskirts. We weren't too happy because there was no restaurant open. We ended up going to a little pizza place about 11 p.m.,'' Ms. Fache said. Bonn, a sleepy city along the Rhine, is notorious for closing down early, unlike the bustling metropolis of Berlin. But Social Democratic Party delegates said they had expected more distance from some of Bonn's deputies, Ms. Fache said. ``But it wasn't like that. They gave us tips on what to do, they were friendly. We were surprised. Maybe they still see us as exotic,'' she said. Ms. Fache is a Social Democratic Party candidate for the Dec. 2 elections from Altenburg, 150 miles south of Berlin. New parliamentarians from other parties, many of whom arrived on the same Lufthansa flight, were also scattered among various Bonn hotels. Most were eager to get down to business. ``I really can't talk about my feelings,'' said former East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and now a member of the Bonn Cabinet. ``I just want to get down to work.'' And he meant it - the soft-spoken politician was the first member to arrive for Friday morning's Cabinet meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Proposes Legislation To Give Trade Benefits To Andes Nations
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday proposed legislation to give a decade of preferable trade benefits to Peru, Colombia, Ecuador and Bolivia in thanks for their cooperation in the war against drugs. The Andean Trade Preference Act is patterned after the Caribbean Basin Initiative that gives special trade benefits to Caribbean nations. The Andean proposal Bush sent to Congress also addresses the long festering trade dispute with Colombia over cut flowers, by making them duty free. It would authorize duty free treatment for 10 years for some imports from the countries along the Andean mountains, which also are the principle source and production countries for the cocaine trade. Products ``particularly sensitive to import competition'' will not be duty free, the White House said. Those products include, textiles and apparel, canned tuna, petroleum products, watches and watch parts. Luggage, leather apparel and flat goods will still be dutiable but under a duty reduction program. The administration is trying to provide economic incentives and assistance to South American countries that have suffered in cracking down on lucrative drug industries that greatly buttress their poor economies. ``The idea behind this legislation is to give the countries an extra boost ... by providing a special 10-year access to the American market,'' Bush said as he signed the transmittal to Congress. The trade measure is a follow up to the drug summit meeting Bush held with the presidents of Peru, Bolivia and Colombia in Cartagena, Colombia. He promised to work on expanding economic opportunities for countries that cooperate with U.S. efforts to interdict drugs and halt production of illicit narcotics. Enactment of the measure, Bush said in a letter to Congress, ``will permit the United States to support the efforts of the Andean countries to eliminate the production, processing and shipment of illicit drugs.'' Bush had promised Colombia's President Cesar Gaviria when they met at the United Nations on Saturday that he would seek special trade benefits for Colombia including removal of tariffs on flowers, the country's second biggest export after coffee. Colombia exports 80 percent of its flower crop to the United States. The administration, responding to complaints from American growers, had accused Colombia of ``dumping'' cut flowers in this country at unreasonably low prices and had sharply increased tariffs on Colombian flowers.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader's Son Sentenced to 120 Years in Prison for Slaying Five
DOC.TEXT: The teen-age son of a cult leader was sentenced Friday to a minimum 120 years in prison for helping to kill four members of a family, crimes he blamed on his father. Damon Lundgren, 19, stood with folded hands and appeared calm as Lake County Common Pleas Judge Paul H. Mitrovich sentenced him for his role in the deaths of Dennis Avery and Avery's three daughters. He was acquitted in the death of Avery's wife, Cheryl. The Averys belonged to the religious cult headed by Damon's father, Jeffrey Lundgren. The Averys were led, one by one, into a barn on April 17, 1989, bound and gagged with duct tape, then shot and dumped in a common grave. Damon Lundgren received consecutive sentences of 20 years to life for each of four counts of aggravated murder, and consecutive sentences of 10 to 25 years on each of four counts of kidnapping. He would not be eligible for parole for at least 80 years. Defense lawyers said they would seek a new trial. Mitrovich chastised Damon Lundgren for not accepting responsibility. ``You accept no blame. You blame your father. You claim this was your father's doing and none of your own,'' the judge said. ``Jeffrey Lundgren could not have done anything without the help and devotion of you and his other followers. Society cannot tolerate such excuses,'' he said. The teen-ager was the last of his family sentenced in the case. His father received a death sentence. His mother, Alice Lundgren, was sentenced to five life terms for conspiracy, complicity and kidnapping. Friends of Damon Lundgren's sat in the court gallery and wept as he was sentenced. Tey had offered a petition bearing 514 signatures of people asking that he receive the minimum sentence of life with chance of parole after 20 years. ``I know the kind of person he is,'' said former classmate Jim Ford, 19. ``I know the kind of person his dad is, and I feel his dad had everything to do with the cult and the killings,'' Ford said, ``and he was a very overpowering person, and Damon was the type of person who could be pulled into someone who could lead him around.'' The Averys were killed at a farm the cult rented at Kirtland, about 30 miles east of Cleveland. Authorities found the bodies Jan. 4. Thirteen cult members were subsequently arrested. Some have pleaded guilty to reduced charges. Jeffrey Lundgren, 40, was defrocked as a lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints before forming his cult. He said he considered himself a prophet of God and received instructions to kill the Aveys through interpretation of Scriptures. Defense lawyers argued that Damon Lundgren was so strictly raised and controlled by his father that he was unable to disobey orders to help wrestle Dennis Avery to the ground and help bind and gag him.

DOC.HEAD: NRA Enlists In Program On Safe Use Of Firearms In National Forests
DOC.TEXT: The National Rifle Association has enlisted in a program to encourage conservation and the safe use of firearms in national forests, the Agriculture Department said today. F. Dale Robertson, chief of the Forest Service, said the agency's long-term plans are ``to improve wildlife habitat and recreation opportunities'' and that he is pleased to have the NRA as ``a partner in this important effort.'' Robertson said both share an interest in promoting safe firearms use and reducing vandalism on public lands. J. Warren Cassidy, NRA executive vice president, said much of the group's effort will involve local affiliates working directly with Forest Service managers on individual national forests and grasslands. The Forest Service said activities to be developed by the agency and NRA affiliates will vary widely. For example, the agency said the NRA and the National Wild Turkey Federation are cooperating this weekend in a two-day camp for about 100 youths in the George Washington National Forest in Virginia. The camp, for youngsters under 16, is being held to teach hunting ethics and firearm safety, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: House, Weighing Bush Pleas, Voters' Threats, Went With Voters
DOC.TEXT: Fear of a voter revolt outweighed fear of President Bush or House leaders when lawmakers defeated the $500 billion budget package. ``It was the combination of tax increases and spending cuts, coming one month before an election'' that doomed the plan, said Rep. Edward Madigan, R-Ill. No amount of economic theory, or reasoning, or leadership pressure could overcome that, he said. ``The point is, we can't get whipped into line,'' added Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla. ``The public really spoke out on this.'' Bush, trying to emulate the success of President Reagan, tried to boost the package by going on national television Tuesday night and asking voters to call their congressmen. They did - 8 to 1 against the deal in Edwards' office. Other lawmakers reported similar results. And in the days leading up to the vote, the White House tacitly admitted that a vote for the plan was politically stupid. House members running for the Senate or for governor were immune from the lobbying. ``All of us statewide candidates got a bye,'' said Rep. John Rowland, R-Ct., who is running for governor. All eight GOP House members running for the Senate voted against the president and are bragging about it back home. Likewise, the Democrat and two Republicans running for governor opposed the measure. Of 33 members of both parties running in tight re-election races, only two voted for the package. In at least one case, an endangered GOP incumbent offered his leaders his vote and they told him to vote ``no.'' For the bulk of the House, Bush's pleas for the good of the economy, long-term gain, and lower interest rates paled against the calls of voters staring at gas tax increases and higher Medicare bills. The voters won, hands down. The president wasn't the only one who demonstrated a lack of clout. Bush enlisted former presidents Reagan, Ford and Nixon in his lobbying campaign, and Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater, ill with cancer, sent a letter. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., usually can count at least on the Massachusetts Democrats to support a party position. But that state is practically defining voter anti-incumbent feelings these days, and all but one of the ten voted against him. House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., persuaded only three of the other seven Illinois Republicans to go along. House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., couldn't even squeeze a vote out of his three housemates: Reps. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., Marty Russo, D-Ill., and George Miller, D-Calif. Of the congressional leadership, only Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., seemed to carry any weight. With Dole strongly behind it, the entire Kansas delegation voted for the plan despite its $13 billion cut in agriculture spending.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Ask Probe of Iraqi Weapon
DOC.TEXT: Five senators Friday called for a Pentagon investigation of how Iraq might have obtained the technology to make fuel-air explosives for extremely powerful bombs that can spread their blast over a wide area. The senators are concerned that a German company, Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm, may have given away the formulas needed to make the explosives. These weapons, used by U.S. forces in Vietnam, atomize liquid fuel like propane into a widely spread fine mist, and then ignite it. They are highly effective against troops in the open but not very useful against hardened targets like fortifications. One expert, Jann Nolan of the Brookings Institution, called them ``highly overrated.'' ``It is vita that an immediate and full investigation be made of what technology was transferred to Iraq and by whom,'' stated the letter to Defense Secretary Richard Cheney from Sens. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., Alan Dixon, D-Ill., Connie Mack, R-Fla., John Heinz, R-Pa., and John Glenn, D-Ohio. The senators said that the German concern, a subsidiary of Mercedes-Benz and the country's largest aerospace firm, could have transferred the bomb technology while working on the Egyptian-Iraqi-Argentine Condor 2 ballistic missile program in the mid-1980s. The Pentagon sought to play down any fears over the weapon itself, and said it had no evidence that Iraqi fuel-air explosives had come from a U.S. technology leak through Messerschmitt or any other company or country. The United States, the Soviet Union, China, France, West Germany, Spain and Israel all have the weapons, a Defense Department spokesman said. ``This is old technology. It's not unique or advanced.'' Helms has been a persistent critic of Western defense contractors, particularly those in Germany, who have allegedly sold weapons to potential adversaries of the United States. A congressional source said that Iraq is able to use the weapons either as bombs dropped from an airplane or as warheads on missiles. The missile threat is seen as the greater menace to U.S. and allied troops in Saudi Arabia, because allied defenses against aircraft are excellent, the source said. This source spoke on condition that he not be identified. Henry Sokolski, an assistant secretary of defense for international security affairs, told the Los Angeles Times that officials are concerned because a fuel-air bomb or warhead is ``not your garden-variety weapon. These are blast-effect weapons, and what you can't see can kill you.'' A Pentagon official said Friday that Sokolski ``is not taking press calls.''

DOC.HEAD: Night Football Canceled in Parts of Florida Due to Mosquito-Borne Disease
DOC.TEXT: Some high schools canceled Friday night football games because encephalitis spread by night-flying mosquitos has been confirmed in 12 Florida counties and a growing number of people are presumed to have the virus. Health officials urged Floridians to wear protective long-sleeve clothing and load up on bug repellent when they are outdoors at night. Weary mosquito control fighters in Hillsborough County alone logged 250 calls in one day from frightened homeowners wanting them to spray or identify bugs and from northerners concerned about coming to Florida. The state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services confirmed 28 cases of the St. Louis strain of encephalitis and listed 10 more as presumed cases as of midday Friday - all in central and southern Florida. ``Where it goes from here is anybody's guess,'' said Ernie Durfee, HRS spokesman. Encephalitis is an inflammation of the brain that causes fever, sore throat, headaches, confusion and muscular weakness. In severe cases of this incurable disease, it causes convulsions, coma and death. The St. Louis strain of the disease is named for the city where it was discovered in 1933. ``Many people who get infected may not have a disease they can recognize as being caused by that virus,'' Dr. Thomas Hoffman of the University of Miami medical school said. ``The most important thing is precaution - precaution against insect bites.'' Hardest hit since the first case was discovered in August has been the state's central Atlantic coast. Indian River has 10 cases and three more presumed cases, and Orange County - home to the state's biggest tourist attractions - has three confirmed and another person presumed to have it. Fifteen people are hospitalized and two - both over age 55 - are comatose, health officials said. ``We watched the epidemic unfold in front of us, right from the beginning until today. And we feel that possibly the worst part of the epidemic may still be ahead,'' said Jonathan Day, an entomologist with the University of Florida's Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences The season for transmission of the virus typically runs until mid-December. As mosquitoes continue to breed and bite, the disease can be expected to spread with them, Day said. ``If we get a cold snap it will kill them. It's all up to Mother Nature,'' Durfee said. Very few mosquitoes actually are carriers, said Durfee. He said the disease is cyclical, occurring every 10 to 15 years because of a combination of factors such as rainfall and mosquito hatchings. The St. Louis strain last surfaced in Florida 13 years ago with 110 cases confirmed and eight deaths attributed to it. Durfee said infants and those over 55 are most susceptible because babies have undeveloped immune systems and older people have depressed immune systems. School boards in Polk and St. Lucie counties decided all school activities, including high school football games, will be rescheduled to end before dark. In Manatee County, Southeast High School switched its junior varsity football game from Thursday night until Monday afternoon. Counties stepped up truck and aerial spraying. ``We have a $1 million budget and a county with more than 800,000 people,'' said Dough Wassmer of Hillsborough Mosquito Control. ``That amounts to about a can of Raid for each family.'' He said the 21 workers were putting in more than 60 hours a week to cover 1,020 square miles. ``We had a call from Pittsburgh asking if it was safe to come down and another from Rhode Island asking about a trip to visit a relative,'' Wassmer said. ``We tell them we have 800,000 residents in Hillsborough County and to our knowledge two are reported sick. That's pretty low odds.''

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslav Army Seizes Regional Defense Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: The army took over the headquarters of Slovenia's regional defense forces Friday, raising speculation the government was reasserting its authority in the rebellious northern republic. The army seizure led to protests by about 200 people who gathered outside the building. Slovenian policemen also rushed to surround the headquarters and other buildings in the capital, apparently to prevent further army movements. The army, meanwhile, sought to play down the takeover, saying in a statement broadcast on state radio that the military had not occupied the headquarters but were only ``securing the building in accordance with regulations.'' ``There was no violence and there are no dangers for anyone,'' Jelko Kacin, Slovenia's deputy defense minister, said in a telephone interview. State radio reported the protesters dispersed peacefully. On Thursday, Slovenia's parliament proposed a plebiscite on independence from Yugoslavia and declared 30 federal laws incompatible with the republic's newly drafted constitution. Slovenia's moves for independence, and recent clashes between Yugoslavia's two biggest ethnic groups, the Serbians and Croatians, have strained the unity of the 72-year-old nation. Slovenia is one of six republics that form Yugoslavia. Serbia is the largest republic and Croatia is second-largest. According to Slovenian radio, 16 military police officers drove up to Slovenia's home guard building in downtown Ljubljana during the night and took over the headquarters peacefully. It said 30 civilian employees were permitted to leave the building. Slovenia's government, which advocates turning Yugoslavia into a loose confederation of sovereign states, issued a statement protesting the action and called it a ``provocation aimed at inciting ... conflicts.'' But the Slovenian authorities also said the headquarters building, which belongs to the federal government, had been evacuated by the territorial defense forces on Thursday. Last week, the Slovenian defense forces took over the local militia, sacking an army general and replacing a dozen other territorial army officers loyal to Belgrade. Yugoslavia on Tuesday ordered the army to reassert control over the reservist defense force. Home guard forces were formed from local inhabitants in all six Yugoslav republics in the late 1960s. One Western diplomat in Belgrade described the army action Friday as ``symbolic.'' ``Now the army can say they fulfilled the ... order to take control of the territorial defense and the Slovenes can say they still command their own home guard,'' said a Western diplomat in Belgrade, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Art Gallery, Director Acquitted of Obscenity Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES previous, minor editing.
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Friday acquitted an art gallery and its director of obscenity charges for exhibiting sexually graphic photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. Dennis Barrie, director of the Contemporary Arts Center, smiled as the verdict was read. Spectators in the courtroom shouted and applauded, and Barrie hugged his lawyers. In the nation's first obscenity trial of an art institution, the gallery and Barrie were acquitted of misdemeanor charges of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. Barrie could have been sentenced to one year in jail and fined $2,000, and the gallery fined $10,000, if convicted of both counts. In closing arguments, the prosecutor said the sexually graphic photographs were convincing evidence in themselves for a conviction. But a lawyer for the Contemporary Arts Center said the state failed to show the exhibit lacked artistic merit. The misdemeanor charges stemmed from the exhibit ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment,'' which appeared in Cincinnati for seven weeks last spring. Frank Prouty, an assistant city prosecutor, said in his closing argument that five photos depicting graphic sex acts involving men and two that showed children with their genitals exposed were enough for convictions. The charges were based on those seven pictures in the 175-photo exhibit. ``The pictures speak for themselves,'' Prouty told the jury in Hamilton County Municipal Court. ``The pictures are the issue.'' Marc Mezibov, the gallery's lawyer, said the state failed to prove its case against the center and Barrie. No presentation was made to back up the assertion that the photographs weren't legitimate art. ``Have you thought why it is that no one for the state of Ohio came in and testified that the exhibit had no serious artistic value? Don't you think that if there were people out there who thought that, the state of Ohio would have found them?'' Mezibov said. Barrie's attorney, H. Louis Sirkin, reminded jurors that the same exhibit was shown hn Philadelphia, Chicago and Berkeley, Calif., without incident. ``Is Cincinnati that different? Are we that childish? Are we not big enough to say we can't accept what other cities have seen?'' Sirkin asked. Judge David Albanese instructed the jury shortly after noon. On Thursday, defense lawyers challenged the credentials of the prosecution's only expert witness, Judith Reisman, on grounds that she was unqualified, but Albanese ruled she could testify. Ms. Reisman said her qualifications included having prepared educational videotapes and slide presentations for the Smithsonian Institution. She also worked as a consultant for television's ``Captain Kangaroo'' show, for former Attorney General Edwin Meese's commission on pornography and for the conservative American Family Association. At issue in the trial were seven photographs a grand jury cited from the 175-photo exhibit. Ms. Reisman testified that photographing nude children can be a prelude to sexual abuse. ``We are putting at risk additional children because many people see themselves as photographers, and many people do use the technique of telling children `this is appropriate because this is in a museum,' `this is appropriate because it is in a book,''' she said. ``That happens to be a standard technique for getting children into a child sex-abuse situation.'' Defense experts have testified that Mapplethorpe, who died last year of AIDS at age 42, was an accomplished and respected photographer, and that photographs of the children were morally and sexually innocent. The exhibit drew more than 80,000 people during its seven-week run, an attendance record for an art exhibit in Cincinnati. It closes this week in Boston, where 103,000 tickets have been sold.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Angered at Mubarak Disclosures on Iraqi Contacts
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel reacted angrily on Friday to disclosures by Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak of secret Iraqi contacts with the Jewish state. However, one official acknowledged informal contacts with Iraq during the 1980-1988 Persian Gulf war, and a source said exchanges continued through intermediaries during the current crisis. Mubarak's statements followed several press reports saying Iraqi-Israeli contacts occurred in recent weeks. But his highly public statments were the first to draw Israel's ire. Eliyahu Ben-Elissar, chariman of the Israeli Parliament's defense and foreign affairs committee, on Friday accused Mubarak of ``psychological warfare'' and said his comment was aimed at undercutting Iraq, not Israel. ``He (Mubarak) wants to shame Iraq in the Arab world,'' Ben-Elissar told Israel's army radio. He added: ``Why in the world is he involving us at a time when we are trying so hard - by the by, at the request of the Egyptians, the Americans and others - not to get involved?'' Despite repeated Iraqi threats to attack Israel in the current crisis, Israel has maintained a low profile to avoid undermining U.S. efforts to mobilize moderate Arab countries to counter Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Mubarak made a speech Thursday marking the 17th anniversary of Egypt's last war with Israel. In it, he said Iraq and Israel have had indirect contacts for years and cited secret exchanges in 1987 and 1989 through a Harvard University professor. Mubarak said he was disclosing the exchanges in reply to Iraqi allegations that Egypt was subserviant to the Israeli and U.S. intelligence services. He also implied that Egypt had access to Israel's intelligence data under their 1979 peace treaty. Israel radio quoted unnamed army officials as expressing ``shock'' at this statement and denying there is any exchange of intelligence with Egypt. The Foreign and Defense ministries declined to comment on Mubarak's statements. Avi Pazner, an aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said in response to a smiliar report earlier this week he was unaware of any Israeli-Iraqi contacts during the gulf crisis. The first report on such contacts was late last monthin the London-based Economist's Foreign Report. It said Iraq in recent weeks has been sending messages to Israel via Jordan's King Hussein. ``Iraq offered not to attack Israel if Israel would agree not to attack Iraq in the event of a war in the gulf,'' the Foreign Report said. ``Israel replied, again through King Hussein, that it had no plan to attack Iraq or to be involved in the gulf crisis.'' State-run Jordan radio carried a different version, saying Saddam had sent a message to Israel via Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda. The Foreign Report said the contacts included meetings between Israeli officials and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and his deputy, Nizar Hamdoon. It said at least two proposed meetings with an Israeli Cabinet minister fell through. A former Israeli government adviser on Arab affairs acknowledged that during the gulf war ``in a great variety of ways, Israel and Iraq were delivering messages to each other.'' The adviser, who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity, said the contacts were through intermediaries and were continuing. ``Since Saddam's threat to burn half of Israel, such messages have been going back and forth a number of times to prevent any misunderstanding,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Brown Wants California To Move Up Primary
DOC.TEXT: Democratic National Chairman Ron Brown said Friday he's disappointed the Calimaries and it hasn't had much influence on the nomination recently. Iowa's first-in-the-nation presidential caucuses are held in early February. ``I think it's ridiculous for the most populous state in the country to play virtually no role in the nomination of candidates of either party,'' Brown told a news conference. He said the California Legislature still has time to act. Any move to settle the party's nomination earlier would serve the party's interest, he said. Brown said that as party chairman, ``I have a responsibility to push the party toward unifying behind a nominee as early in the process as possible so we can start running against George Bush rather than against each other.'' ``The more states that move earlier in the process the better I like it,'' he told a news conference. Despite that, Brown said, there's no move to replace Iowa as the initial test. ``I wish other states would move up because that gives us a chance of getting a consensus candidate who can run against and beat George Bush,'' he said. ``None of that threatens Iowa's first-in-the-nation caucus status.'' Every four years the state gets heavy attention as candidates stump throughout Iowa. The political parties like the caucuses because the presidential candidates running in the state give them major organizational and financial help. But there's a quadrennial effort to shuffle the primary lineup, because officials in many other states argue that the caucuses give far too much influence to a tiny and unrepresentative state. In addition, the complex party rules and long string of primaries virtually assures that Democrats won't have a nominee until very late in the process, while Republicans settle their primaries earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Firebombs, Rocks Thrown at Police in Rare Japanese Rioting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Most of ...' to fix typo in armed troopers.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TOK10
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 people angered by police corruption took to the streets Friday night, burning barricades and pelting riot troopers with firebombs and rocks in a crime-ridden neighborhood. At least 106 people, including 83 police, have been injured in the violence that began Tuesday in the Nishinari district of Osaka, Japan's No. 2 city. More than 40 people have been arrested. The scope of the violence is extremely unusual for Japan, where public issues rarely inflame passions to such a degree. The rundown neighborhood is known for its gangs, transient laborers and shabby hotels. Locals say there long have been bad feelings between the area's poor residents and police. ``Dogs of gangsters, come out, kneel down before us and apologize!'' a man screamed through a loudspeaker to police. ``Don't you know how much hardship our daily laborers are going through? Why don't you try working at a construction site one day and you will probably realize how much we are abused by this society.'' By 1 a.m. Saturday, a crowd estimated earlier at more than 1,000 laborers from the district and outside youths had dwindled to about 600, police said. But many laborers had dispersed and those remaining were largely high school-age youths, some of whom appeared to be enjoying themselves. One was an 11-year-old boy who said he was ``just here to be on television.'' A man who refused to identify himself said he had come from Kyoto, 30 miles away, because ``I thought this may be a once in a lifetime chance for me throw stones at police and get away with it.'' Most of the crowd had filtered away by 3 a.m. Saturday, leaving behind a street littered with broken glass, rocks and burned debris. A cordon of about 20 armed troopers continued to guard the police station. Earlier, about 2,500 police carrying large metal shields were in position along main roads in Nishinari and in front of the district police station Friday night. Four vehicles equipped with water cannons guarded the station's main entrance. Police used the water cannons repeatedly to douse the more than 1,000 people confronting them. The crowd, which included day laborers from the district and young people from outside it, scattered each time but then regrouped. Large piles of burned vehicles and bicycles formed barricades and blocked traffic. Protesters threw firebombs and rocks. ``We are now starting to arrest the main figures, especially the ones who are agitating the crowd,'' police Sgt. Rentaro Ataka said around midnight. Police officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 10,000 more riot police were on alert to prevent another night of rioting. About 100 undercover police also were mobilized, they said. Rioting did not spread beyond the neighborhood, but it caused traffic tie-ups in parts of Osaka as police blocked off several major streets, and some rail service was disrupted. The violence was touched off Tuesday by the arrest of a local policeman on suspicion of having taken $81,000 in bribes from two gangsters. After hearing the news, menial laborers with longstanding grudges against police began massing around the police station. Authorities and residents said young hooligans and leftists from outside the district later joined the disturbance. Rentarou Ataka, a police spokesman in Nishinari, said youths from outside the area had seen the initial rioting on television and decided to join in. He described other troublemakers as ``ultraleftists,'' but said the scope of their participation was unclear. In recent years, there have been few such disturbances in Japan other than occasional battles between riot police and leftist extremists who oppose expansion of Tokyo's Narita airport. Police reported two stores were set ablaze early Friday and a train station also was heavily damaged by fire. Several shops, including a 24-hour convenience store, were looted. Osaka's police chief, Masahiro Tsubakihara, issued an apology for the officer, who was arrested after reports he provided information about police operations against gangs.

DOC.HEAD: Shooting Incident in Gulf of Fonseca, Government Radio Reports
DOC.TEXT: Six members of the Nicaraguan coast guard and navy were missing Friday after being fired on by crews of two speedboats, the government radio station said. The incident occurred in Nicaraguan waters off the Cosiguina reefs in the Gulf of Fonseca, shared by Nicaragua, Honduras and El Salvador, Radio Nicaragua said. The report said the six Nicaraguans were patrolling the area Thursday morning in a boat when they spotted two Piranha speedboats traveling from Honduras. When they tried to stop the speedboats, machine guns were fired at them, the station said. The crew has not been heard from since and the boat has not been found, the report said. Spokesmen at the Interior Ministry and the Sandinista People's Army in Managua said they had no immediate information on the reported incident.

DOC.HEAD: Immigration Advocates Celebrate Victory in Big Case
DOC.TEXT: Two years after dozens of Hispanics were rounded up at a racetrack, lawyers say they have won a major victory over government officials who tried to deport the people without proving they were illegal aliens. The case was widely viewed as a test of alien rights. The defendants refused to answer questions about how and when they entered the country, citing Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination. The Immigration and Naturalization Service argued that this silence, on its own, demonstrated that the defendants were illegal aliens. Last year, an immigration judge agreed. But three weeks ago, the federal Board of Immigration Appeals reversed that ruling, ending the deportation proceedings against one of the defendants. The appeals board said the INS approach would shift the burden of proof at a deportation proceeding. Since the decision, people have come forward to say federal immigration officials used similar tactics in other cases, said Dan Kanstroom, a Boston College law professor who assisted in the appeal. But he said the Boston case marked the first national test of this strategy. ``It's very important that it stopped here,'' he said. Daniel Levy, staff attorney at the National Immigration Law Center in Los Angeles, said if the government's arguments had been upheld, it would have significantly broadened INS powers. ``They would have been able to stop anybody on the street, send them to court, and if the person remains quiet, the person could be deported,'' Levy said in a telephone interview. Verne Jervis, spokesman for the INS, said Friday that agency officials were still reviewing the board's decision and had not decided what action to take. During the dawn raid Oct. 21, 1988, at Suffolk Downs, authorities seized 83 Salvadoran, Mexican, Brazilian and Cuban stable hands. Of those people, six were found to be in the United States lawfully. Some of the remainder returned to their homelands, while others admitted their illegal status and applied for asylum. By the time the appeals board issued its decision, 30 defendants remained. On Friday, lawyers who teamed up to fight the INS gathered to plot their next moves. The appeals board decision specifically discussed the case of only one defendant, but Kanstroom said it would apply to the others. The clients can choose to have their deportation proceedings terminated, or may eventually decide to return home or can take other steps such as seeking political asylum, he said. Judith Gail Dein, one of the lawyers who filed the appeal, said no matter what the clients decide, the appeals board has sent a strong message against the violation of people's basic rights. ``It feels real good that somebody put a stop to that,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: 70,000 Costa Rican Workers Strike to Protest High Prices
