DOC.TEXT: More than 70,000 service workers struck for 24 hours Friday to protest government austerity measures that have increased the cost of living. Employees stayed off the job at six of the main hospitals, schools, city governments, the health ministry, National Bank and some other institutions. ``So far, the strike is a big success,'' said Jose Joaquin Melendez, coordinator of the Permanent Workers' Council. The council, with about 110,000 government and private sector workers, called the strike. Only emergencies were being attended at the largest hospital. ``We do not agree with the constant increases in (prices of) goods. While the government asks workers for austerity, the legislators and presidents of institutions are given extremely high raises,'' Melendez said. Health ministry, university and some other workers also were demanding raises of up to 15 percent to compensate for the loss of buying power. Presidents of government institutions earn $2,500 a month. Legislators recently got $900 a month raises to the same level. A government employee earns an average $200 a month and a farm worker $75. Since President Rafael Angel Calderon took office May 8, prices of rice, beans, eggs, milk and other staples have risen 30 percent. Four increases have doubled fuel prices, and water and electricity rates also have gone up. The government says the measures were needed to reduce the high fiscal deficit, estimated this year at $370 million, or 6 percent of the gross domestic product. The country's currency, the colon, has been devalued 20 times the past four months. Inflation for the first nine months of the year was 17.7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Networks Plan Limited Shuttle Coverage
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Only the Cable News Network planned live coverage of Saturday's scheduled launch of the space shuttle Discovery, network executives said Friday. Spokesmen for ABC, CBS and NBC said there were no plans to interrupt their regular programs for live coverage of the launch, set for 7:35 a.m. EDT from Cape Canaveral, Fla. CNN's John Zarella will provide live updates preceding the launch and throughout the day. CNN also plans live coverage of the shuttle landing, scheduled for 9:42 a.m. EDT Wednesday at Edwards Air Force Base in California. The shuttle's four-day mission is to launch the $750 million solar probe Ulysses into orbit.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Banking Slump Could Lessen Nation's Global Influence
DOC.TEXT: The decline of American banks compared with their foreign competitors threatens to harm an already weak U.S. economy and diminish the nation's world influence, a congressional report concludes. A House Banking Committee task force, chaired by Rep. John J. LaFalce, D-N.Y., strongly suggested that the Depression-era constraints barring banks from expanding into new services such as securities underwriting and insurance must fall if U.S. banks are to regain their edge. ``There appears to be little doubt that repeal of the securities restrictions imposed on U.S. banks would enhance the competitiveness of U.S. banks globally,'' it said. The panel also criticized remaining barriers preventing banks from expanding across state lines and compares the convoluted U.S. regulatory system with its more streamlined counterparts overseas. The 488-page report, which was conceived as a fact-finding study rather than a vehicle for legislative recommendations, has not been issued yet. A draft circulated to the 20 task force members was obtained by The Associated Press. It stresses the importance of a competitive banking system to the economy. ``We must have a successful, productive economy if we are to address societal needs and solve societal problems, and a successful financial services delivery system is at the crux of a successful and productive economic machine,'' the task force said. The panel was formed last November and held a series of hearings through August with appearances from all of the major U.S. financial regulators as well as private U.S. and foreign business executives. Its research is intended by LaFalce, a strong advocate of expanding bank powers, to serve as the basis for debate next year, when the Bush administration intends to submit its plan for the most significant overhaul of the U.S. financial system in 50 years. Dramatic changes in financial services technology have increasingly shifted business away from banks toward other firms, particularly brokerage houses, the report said. ``It is clear that the relative competitive position of U.S. banks has deteriorated significantly as the U.S. banking system has remained static in a changing world,'' it said. Yet, ``the U.S. continues to develop policy for its financial services industry in a myopic and, indeed, isolationist way,'' it said. As Europe prepares for economic union in 1992, its banks are increasingly adopting the universal banking model, combining traditional commercial banking with securities underwriting and insurance, the task force said. The Japanese financial structure is more split, on paper, but unofficial cooperative relationships among firms, known as the ``keiretsu'' system, allow Japanese banks to provide a wider array of services than U.S. banks, it said. Thus it will become more difficult for U.S. banks, functioning under a decades-old system, to compete at home and abroad, it said. ``Increasingly, U.S. banks will be competing at home and abroad against foreign financial institutions that can offer customers a full array of financial services products U.S. banks are not capable of providing,'' it said. Foreign banks, particularly Japanese banks, are making increasing inroads in the United States, the report noted. In California, for instance, Japanese banks control about one-quarter of all banking assets. Because of laws restricting the geographic expansion of U.S. banks, often it is easier for a foreign bank to acquire a U.S. institution, it said. Increasing foreign ownership of U.S. banks raises important questions about Americans' ability to manage their own economy, it said. If foreign control of U.S. financial institutions had been greater after the 1987 stock market crash ``the situation could have proved more difficult (for the Federal Reserve) to control,'' the report said. ``When credit is scarce, U.S. companies could find themselves at the tail end of a very long queue, behind borrowers from Britain, Japan, West Germany, and other countries,'' it said. Also, a diminished U.S. banking industry ``leaves U.S. policymakers in the awkward position of being unable to help procure finance for the economic policies they encourage foreign governments to take.''
