DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE CRIME ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Soviet Military Chief Cautions Against Use of Force Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The military chief of the Soviet Union said Friday that ``the most important thing'' in the Persian Gulf crisis is preventing it from escalating into a war. ``I very much want everybody to attune their consciousness to the idea that you've got to find a political settlement and not be thinking about how best to use military force,'' said Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev, chief of the Soviet general staff. President Bush has not ruled out using the more than 170,000-strong U.S. sea, air and land force in the gulf to try to dislodge the Iraqi army from Kuwait. The Washington Post reported Friday that Bush has begun consulting with Congress on the possible use of force. Moiseyev spoke at an unusual joint news conference at the Pentagon with his American counterpart, Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Powell accompanied Moiseyev on a cross-country tour of U.S. military and civilian sites, including a visit Friday to North Island Naval Air Station near San Diego, and to the Cheyenne Mountain Complex in Colorado, headquarters of the North American Air Defense Command. Moiseyev said that after leaving Washington on Friday evening he would stop in Havana for a meeting with the chief of the Cuban general staff. At the news conference, Moiseyev deflected questions about the likely Soviet response to a U.S.-led attack on Iraqi forces in Kuwait. He stressed several times that Moscow saw enormous danger in any military conflict in the gulf. ``The most important thing for all of us is to not allow a military conflict to develop out of this situation,'' the general said through an interpreter. ``We have not exhausted the whole of the arsenal of political possibilities that we have at our disposal,'' he added, referring to the nations against Iraq. Moiseyev also stressed in response to questions about the presence of Soviet military specialists in Iraq that they are gradually withdrawing and that their role is relatively unimportant. ``These are not advisers,'' he said. ``These are technicians.'' The general said the 206 Soviet military specialists in Iraq include 42 interpreters, 15 members of a management team and 146 ``technical specialists.'' He did not mention the function of the other three. Moiseyev spoke warmly of his week-long visit to the United States, his first. In addition to seeing military installations and equipment, Moiseyev and his staff visited national memorials in Washington, an automobile plant in Michigan, and San Francisco. ``We discovered America for ourselves,'' he said. ``We got convinced that Americans are determined to keep the peace, cooperate and further strengthen normal ties with the Soviet Union. Much has changed in our perception of America.'' Powell and Moiseyev signed an agreement on military exchanges for 1991 and 1992, including a visit by Powell to the Soviet Union next summer and a visit to the United States early next year by the Soviet commander in chief of Far East Forces.

DOC.HEAD: Outrage At New Government Restriction On Exit Door Seats
DOC.TEXT: Advocates for the blind, the obese and Hispanics on Friday questioned a federal regulation that says people with disabilities and no understanding of English cannot sit next to exit doors on U.S. airlines. The Federal Aviation Administration regulation says only people who are able and willing to open exit doors in emergencies and understand flight crews and assist them with evacuations may be seated next to the doors. The regulation took effect Friday. People barred from such seats include parents with small children, people considered too frail to operate the door, passengers with broken limbs and other disabilities, the obese, children under 15 and the blind. Some airlines already prohibit blind travelers from sitting in exit-door seats and several sightless people have been arrested in recent years for refusing to move from seats. Marc Maurer, president of the National Federation of the Blind, said the rule is discriminatory and called it ``an example of the fear that people have of being blind.'' ``A blind person is accustomed to dealing with working without lights,'' he said. ``They don't have a single piece of evidence that shows that blind people are hazardous, yet they make this judgement.'' Others said they were concerned with how the FAA would determine obesity or the ability to read and understand English. ``I understand the FAA's concern, but I feel they're making, certainly, an arbitrary judgment about the mobility of fat people,'' said Sally E. Smith, executive director of the National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance. ``We're very concerned about the potential disparate effect of the proposed regulation on Hispanics and others,'' said Charles Kamasaki, vice president for research advocacy and legislation for the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic organization. ``Are they going to give IQ tests? What constitutes limited English proficiency. Even if the regulation were justified, we're concerned about its application in practice,'' he said. Paul Steucke, a spokesman for the FAA, said airlines were directed to come up with their own guidelines to determine who is qualified to sit next to the exits. ``There's discretion involved,'' he said. ``You might have somebody who's 250 pounds. If they're 6-foot-4 there probably won't be a problem. If they're 4-foot-1, there might be.'' William E. Oriol, a spokesman for The National Council on the Aging, aid the organization was still examining the regulation. Reaction from passengers who traveled through three U.S. airports on Friday was mixed. Some said they were concerned about the English-only provision. ``They already have everything written in English and Spanish anyway - maybe they should have bilingual people sitting there,'' said Jennette Heck, who flew in to Miami from New Orleans. ``But I don't think handicapped people should sit right by the door - they could get hurt in the panic.'' Martin Cohen, 48, of Easton, Pa., favored the rule. ``I have a young child, and when I'm traveling with her, they don't want us to sit next to the emergency door,'' said Cohen, who was at Boston's Logan International Airport. ``The idea is to get the exit open in a plane crash. You should have someone who could open the exit.'' Jeff Bank, 27, of New York, who also was in Boston, said: ``You have to do what's necessary to protect all the passengers, and it just makes sense.''

DOC.HEAD: Mapplethorpe Photo Exhibit Closes, Controversy Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Mapplethorpe verdict in Cincinnati; pickup 3rd graf pvs, `It has...' SUBS 17th graf pvs, `Morality in...,' to DELETE outdated material.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Mapplethorpe Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A traveling exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs closed Friday, leaving in its wake protests and a conservative attack on the National Endowment for the Arts. At an earlier stop in Cincinnati, the exhibit prompted an obscenity prosecution of an art gallery and its director, a case that ended Friday in acquittal. The jury in the nation's first such prosecution of an art gallery rejected prosecutor's argument that seven of the pictures were obscene. Cincinnati's Contemporary Art Gallery and its director, Dennis Barrie, were acquitted of charges of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. Some say the furor surrounding the trial and the traveling exhibit has helped the art world by drawing record crowds to galleries and forcing artists to become politically active to support their work. ``It has brought a lot of artists out of their studios to organize and demonstrate their own moral and political strength for the first time since the end of the Vietnam War,'' said David Ross, director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston where the photos were exhibited. ``I think the silver lining has been that the art world has been ... given a sense of direction that it didn't have before.'' The exhibit combined Mapplethorpe's explicit homoerotic photographs - the source of the controversy - with cool, elegant portraits and photographs of flowers. Mapplethorpe helped organize the show shortly before he died of AIDS in March 1989 at age 42. Boston was the last stop on the exhibit's seven-city tour. About 103,000 people saw the show during its nine weeks at the institute, about twice the number that visited the museum all last year, said Arthur Cohen, director of marketing. Membership in the museum also has surged recently, he added. But Cohen said the increased income from the show was offset by higher security and insurance costs. The net income came to less than half the amount lost in grants recently. ``We're not even coming out even,'' he said. In Washington, D.C., 48,000 people saw the show during its three-week stay at the Washington Project for the Arts. A popular 10-week exhibit there usually draws 8,000, said Philip Brookman, who curated that show after it was canceled at the Corcoran Gallery of Art 17 months ago. ``Our membership has increased quite a bit. Our attendance has been consistently high since the Mapplethorpe show,'' Brookman said. ``It was received very positively by critics and the public at large. Mothers came in with their children.'' Others saw the show's aftermath differently. ``We're worse off for Mapplethorpe. In the long run, we're much worse off,'' said Rita Burke, president of Morality in Media of Massachusetts. Burke said the lesson for her in the Mapplethorpe show was that the normal person is helpless to fight the media. ``I think it has raised consciousness to how difficult it is for the average person who is really turned off by material like this,'' she said. ``I find that an awful lot of people are giving up. They wring their hands.'' The exhibit attracted little attention in its first showings in Philadelphia and Chicago, but in Washington it caught the eye of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. Helms and other congressional conservatives were angered by several photographs with homosexual and sadomasochistic subjects. Their attack forced the Corcoran to cancel the show in mid-1989. Since then, the focus has shifted to two photographs of two children with exposed genitals. Morality in Media was unsuccessful in attempts to bring criminal charges against the Boston institute. The controversy has also forced the national endowment's new director, John Frohnmayer, to institute a requirement that artists sign a statement agreeing to not use NEA funds to make obscene art. Some have turned down grants in protest. Frohnmayer also rejected four grants, approved by peer review panels, that would have gone to controversial artists. The ``NEA Four'' - as they are known in arts circles - filed suit in federal court on Sept. 27, asking for the $23,000 in grants or a review of their applications. The four had all received NEA grants in the past.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Hits the Northern Rockies; Heavy Rains and Flooding in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Winter took aim at the Rockies Friday, while usually dry southwest Texas braced for another round of heavy rain and flooding. A winter storm warning with snow advisories was posted for the mountains and passes near the Continental Divide in northern Montana and Wyoming. Advisories for snow Friday afternoon and night were posted for the mountains and foothills of southwest and central Montana, as well as for the higher elevations of south-central Montana Friday night. Gusty wind marked the eastern edge of the storm. Unseasonably warm afternoon temperatures were expected to drop by as much as 35 and 40 degrees Friday night. A snow advisory for Friday night also was posted for the higher elevations of the northern mountains of Wyoming. There were heavy thunderstorms during the afternoon over southwest Texas. The storms moved northeast during the morning and reached Brownsville near noon. The storms brought strong, gusty winds along with locally heavy rain and and the possibility of flooding. By midday, showers and thunderstorms extended from northern Maine, through New Hampshire and Vermont into southwest New York state. Small hail fell at Caribou, Maine, near noon. Showers stretched from west-central Montana, through the Idaho panhandle into central Idaho. Scattered showers and thunderstorms were also over eastern Florida, south-central Louisiana, southern Texas and southwest Texas. Heavier rain included 1.62 inches at Melbourne, Fla. Friday morning's low for the Lower 48 states was 21 at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 38 at Cutbank, Mont., to 93 at Tampa, Fla. Hurricane warnings remained for the northern Leeward Islands, tropical storm warnings were posted for Guadeloupe and nearby islands. A hurricane watch was posted for the British and U.S. Virgin Islands. Hurricane Klaus was northeast of Antigua, drifting toward the northwest.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Does Bit in Soap Opera
DOC.TEXT: First lady Barbara Bush will appear as herself in the Oct. 18 installment of ABC's daytime soap opera ``All My Children.'' Mrs. Bush will not be shown with other inhabitants of the show's fictional Pine Valley, but rather appears at the program's end in a public service announcement benefiting the National Bone Marrow Registry, ABC said. The first lady's brief spot complements a current story line in which the survival of a child stricken with leukemia depends on receiving a bone marrow transplant. Mrs. Bush outlines hhe simple, painless test for bone marrow compatibility and urges viewers to contact the National Bone Marrow Registry.

DOC.HEAD: Rewards Given Out In Drug-Tampering Cases
DOC.TEXT: A $250,000 reward will be paid to a California woman whose testimony helped convict her mother in two killings with cyanide-laced Excedrin, a spokesman for a pharmaceutical group said Friday. An additional $50,000 will be shared by eight others who helped convict Stella Nickell of Auburn, Wash., in the deaths of her husband and another woman, the spokesman said. The Nonprescription Drug Manufacturers Association had offered the rewards for information leading to an arrest in the June 1986 killings, which led to the nation's first trial in a product-tampering death. Cynthia Hamilton, 30, the Nickells' daughter who now lives in Garden Grove, Calif., testified that Mrs. Nickell repeatedly talked about ways to kill her husband, Bruce Nickell, who was 52 when he died. Prosecutors said Mrs. Nickell put cyanide in capsules of Extra-Strength Excedrin and gave them to her husband. She also planted other bottles of cyanide-tainted Excedrin in stores in local stores to divert suspicion, authorities said. Mrs. Nickell had three life insurance policies on her husband. The other victim was Susan Katherine Snow, 40, also of Auburn, who authorities said had bought the poisoned capsules. The deaths sparked a nationwide tampering scare and prompted Excedrin manufacturer Bristol-Myers Co. to recall its over-the-counter capsule medications. Mrs. Nickell was convicted two years later. The reward is the second paid by the pharmaceutical group. Another $300,000 was shared by nine people who helped police arrest a Florida man in 1986. Authorities said he put rat poison in capsules of several SmithKline Beckman Corp. products in Florida and Texas in a failed scheme to manipulate the price of SmithKline stock. ``We offered the rewards as a deterrent because we feel that the best way to deter tampering is to catch the tamperers,'' said John T. Walden, a senior vice president of the Nonprescription Drug Manufacturers Association. Rewards authorized for two other drug-tampering cases remain unpaid. The association authorized a $200,000 reward for information leading to an arrest and conviction in the 1986 death of Diane Elsroth of Yonkers, N.Y., who took cyanide-laced Tylenol, he said. The same amount is offered in the 1982 Chicago-area deaths of seven people, who also were killed with tainted Tylenol capsules, he said. The eight who will also share in the reward in the Nickell case are: Thomas Noonan of Auburn, Wash., $15,000; Bonnie Anderson of Federal Way, Wash., $10,000; Denise Button of Seattle, $7,500; Sandra Scott of Auburn, $7,500; Katy Parker of Auburn, $2,500; Gerald McIntyre of Kent, Wash.; Lynn Force, of Seattle, $2,500; and Melinda Denton of Seattle, $2,500.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Calls up 844 Reserve Members From Four States
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force on Friday said it ordered 844 reserve and national guard members to active duty to support the U.S. buildup in the Persian Gulf. Called up were: -206 members of the 914th Tactical Airlift Group of the Air Force Reserve at Niagara Falls, N.Y.. -187 members of the 927th Tactical Airlift Group of the Air Force Reserve at Selfridge Air Force Base, Mich. -224 members of the 130th Tactical Airlift Group of the Air National Guard at Charleston, W.Va. -227 members of the 136th Tactical Airlift Wing of the Air National Guard at Dallas. The callups bring to 5,167 the number of Air Force reserve members activated since President Bush on Aug. 22 authorized the Pentagon to use reserves in Operation Desert Shield. The total number of reserves called up from all services is 27,947.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Votes To Ban Charcoal Lighter Fluids By 1992
DOC.TEXT: Air quality officials Friday ordered makers of charcoal lighter lluid to cook up a cleaner-burning product by 1992 or face a ban on barbecuers' favorite fuel. The Air Quality Management District, trying to clean up the skies over the Los Angeles area, took on a summer way of life for 2 million Californians by voting 10-1 to impose strict standards on lighter fluid and self-starting charcoal briquettes. Experts say lighter fluids contribute more harmful emissions than many people would think - an estimated 2 tons per day of smog-forming hydrocarbon emissions. That's a little more than the average oil refinery belches into the air each day. On a hot summer day, fluids can emit up to 4 tons of emissions. Board member Mike Antonovich, the only one to oppose the plan, called it a waste of time and said it placed an unfair burden on store owners. He said backyard chefs could get around the plan by buying lighter fluid at stores outside of the air quality district, which covers four counties around Los Angeles. The rule doesn't set any penalties for using the lighter fluid, just for selling it, he said. ``Instead of aiming our big guns at the automobiles ... we're nuking the barbecue,'' Antonovich said. The barbecue industry opposed the plan and asked for more time to reformulate its products. Lighter fluid sales amount to more than $5 million in Southern California every year. ``Industry is willing, able and ready to reformulate,'' said Pat Meehan of the Barbecue Industry Association. ``We're concerned about air quality, too.'' Most members of the Naperville, Ill.-based association make charcoal briquettes and fluid rather than electric or other lighters. But board members said the industry has had plenty of time to improve its lighter fluid and that it still has a chance to reformulate its products. ``I've been trying to clean the air for 20 years. Where've you been?'' asked board member Marvin Braude, representing Los Angeles County. ``You could have done it last year, the year before, or five years ago.'' Braude drew hisses from the audience when he cut off Meehan in mid-sentence and said he didn't want to hear from the industry representative any more. While the board considered the plan inside, the AQMD staff cooked hot dogs and stuffed bell peppers outside. The charcoal was lighted by wood chips, newspapers and electric prods - methods officials say are cleaner than lighter fluids. Inside the hearing room industry representatives illustrated their presentation with slides showing cans of lighter fluid, different sizes of barbecues and clumps of charcoal briquettes. Speakers included a condominium owner who said his complex had banned lighter fluids because elderly residents were getting ill and a campground operator who urged the board to continue selling lighter fluids because other methods, he said, were dangerous. The strict lighter fluid rules are the latest in a series of tough measures the AQMD has taken to clean Southern California skies. So far this year the district's four-county area has recorded 35 first-stage smog alerts - the least serious of three levels of alert, when children, the elderly and those with respiratory diseases are warned to avoid strenuous activity. The district covers Los Angeles, Riverside, Orange and western San Bernardino counties. The lighter fluid rule requires manufacturers to drastically reduce lighter fluid emissions and bans the sale of fluids exceeding the new limits as of Jan. 1, 1992. Merchants who violate the rule face fines as high as $25,000 per day. The new limits would reduce the allowed emissions of volatile hydrocarbons from .09 pounds per ``barbecue event'' to .02 pounds. According to the barbecue industry, emissions from fluid and self-starting charcoal represent .2 percent of the total emissions in the Los Angeles Basin, less than the AQMD contends. Cars, by comparison, emit 31.5 percent of the total. Barbecue industry spokeswoman Sandy Burton said the industry and the AQMD would continue to work together on testing methods and that the industry may well be able to bring its products into compliance. ``It's not a matter of being happy or not happy right now,'' she said. ``We're going to continue to work on this.''

DOC.HEAD: Peruvian Government Extends State of Emergency in Lima and Callao
DOC.TEXT: The government extended Friday for 60 days the state of emergency in the Lima metropolitan area and neighboring port of Callao, granting the army sweeping powers to combat leftist guerrillas. The state of emergency places Lima, its largest city, and Callao, its biggest port, under military control. Authorities can restrict freedom of movement, ban public meetings, detain people without charge and conduct searches without a warrant. Lima, home to one-third of Peru's 22 million residents, was previously controlled by the police. But one of President Alberto Fujimori's first acts on being sworn in on July 28 was to hand Lima and Callao over to army control. Over half of Peru's population lives under military control. Eight departments and one province, in Peru's southern and central highlands, as well as the northern jungle, have been declared emergency zones. Political violence has claimed more than 20,000 lives in the 10 years since the Maoist Shining Path guerrillas took up arms. The government first decreed the state of emergency in December 1982 in the Andean department of Ayacucho, birthplace of the insurgent group.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf of Boner item in AM-People, a0640, to UPDATE with Boner asking grand jury to investigate offer to buy out last year of his term.
DOC.TEXT: A critic of Mayor Bill Boner, known for his romantic affairs as well as his politics, said she would turn down a chance to confront the mayor on national television because she's afraid he will embarrass Nashville. Newlywed Boner and his fourth wife, aspiring country singer Traci Peel, are to appear on Phil Donahue's nationally syndicated talk show this month. Jo Ann North, a city councilwoman and critic of Boner, was invited to appear on the same show, but says she'll decline. North fears Boner will only embarrass his hometown, which has been trying to polish its image to attract a National League baseball franchise. ``If I thought I would have an opportunity to talk about all the wonderful things in Nashville and promote Nashville, I'd do it in a heartbeat,'' North said. ``The only good thing that can come out of this is the promotion of Traci Peel's career.'' Bonerand Peel married Monday in Hawaii. They began dating while he lived with his third wife. Their affair gained wide attention after a reporter called the couple one evening and Peel commented that the mayor's passion could last seven hours. Bumper stickers soon appeared, proclaiming: ``Seven hours for Traci, three years for Nashville.'' A Nashville car dealer offered to pay Boner's $75,000 salary if the mayor would resign before his term ends next year. Boner on Friday requested the Davidson County Grand Jury investigate the offer as a possible violation of state law. Boner reiterated that the mayor's office is not for sale and that he didn't intend to resign.

DOC.HEAD: Shutdown's Effects Would Begin to be Felt at Once
With AM-Budget Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 8th graf pvs, ``If a, with Postal Service, Amtrak unaffected.
DOC.TEXT: While the brunt of a government shutdown Saturday would not hit for three days, visitors to the Statue of Liberty, the Washington Monument and Yellowstone National Park would feel the effects at once. White House Budget Director Richard Darman told agency heads they should be ready to send home all non-essential employees scheduled to work Saturday. His memo cited the failure by Congress to pass legislation to fund the government byond a midnight Friday deadline. The bulk of the federal work force of 2.4 million was told to report to work Tuesday - even if only to be sent home after a few hours. Monday is a federal holiday. Barring a last-minute compromise, this would be the fourth time over the past decade that the federal government has sent its employees home because its authority to spend money expired. The last time, in 1986, the impasse lasted half a day. Then, the Statue of Liberty, the Washington Monument and St. Louis' Gateway Arch all were closed because Park Service workers were sent home. This time, tourists to the nation's captial would find the Smithsonian Institution's 12 museums closed too. White House gardeners hung up their rakes and left. The Park Service prepared to shut down these monuments Saturday and to ``padlock everything that can be padlocked,'' said Bob Walker, a spokesman for the Interior Department. ``If a visitor wants to drive into Yellowstone or Shenandoah Park, there'll be no one there to keep them out - or charge them a toll to get in. But those people would be largely on their own,'' Walker said. ``If their car broke down, there would be no friendly ranger to help them.'' The Postal Service would not be affected by the shutdown because it is not dependent on government appropriations. Amtrak rail passenger service would not be immediately affected for the same reason. It does, however, receive a large government subsidy so that its operations would be hard hit if the budget impasse is long lasting. President Bush convened an emergency Cabinet meeting to discuss details of a government shutdown. His spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said there would be significant disruptions of government services beginning on Saturday and each day they would grow ``a little worse.'' Each agency decides what is an essential service. But, generally, employees whose jobs are needed for protecting public health or safety - such as air traffic controllers, prison guards and the military - would be allowed to keep working. ``Beginning Saturday morning, the head of each agency must be prepared to implement his or her existing plan for closing down operations,'' Darman said in a memo to the agency heads. Only those services needed to ``protect life and property'' will be permitted to continue in the absence of a budget agreement, Darman said. A spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, Bob Buckhorn, said that ``if we have a shutdown, essential services remain in place,'' including air traffic controllers. Other FAA employes who deal with safety would also continue working, he said. Every office in the Commerce Department except the National Weather Service would be affected by a shutdown, a Commerce spokesman said. The shutdown would hit NASA at an awkward time. Shortly before midnight, fueling is to begin for an early morning launch of the space shuttle Discovery. No one is suggesting a layoff for the five astronauts who, during the four-day mission, are scheduled to deploy the Ulysses probe on its five-year journey to the sun. However, the government technically will lack the authority to pay employees for their work because none of the 13 appropriations bills needed to fund the government for the fiscal year that began Monday has been enacted. After the government was forced to shut down briefly in 1981, 1984 and 1986, Congress voted to reimburse all federal employees for lost pay. This time, the situation was complicated by the fact that the government's power to borrow money was also expiring at midnight Friday - unless Congress passed and Bush signed an extension of the federal debt limit. At the Agriculture Department, workers who normally work on weekends - primarily Forest Service workers - were told they would likely be sent home Saturday. Kelly Ship, a department spokeswoman, said only that a handful of the department's 100,000 employees nationwide would be considered essential and expected to report to work during a shutdown, she added. State and county offices of major USDA agencies, such as the Farmers Home Administration and the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, would close. Federal meat and poultry inspection, however, would continue during a general shutdown, she said. A Pentagon spokesman said senior department officials were in closed meetings Friday afternoon discussing what actions would be required on Saturday if the government were shut down. The spokesman, Jim Turner, said the department would not comment on its contingency plans. The Pentagon has more than 3 million employees, including 2.1 million uniformed personnel. It appeared unlikely that any forced shutdown of Defense Department operations would affect the deployment of more than 170,000 servicemen and women in the Persian Gulf. At the State Department, officials said that all personnel are expected to show up Tuesday but that non-essential employees would be sent home. No estimate was available on the number of employees in that category. The officials, asking not to be identified, said the impact on overseas posts is likely to be minimal for the time being. They added that the budget situation would not affect the State Department task force monitoring the Persian Gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Minister in Jordan Calls for Attacking American Troops
DOC.TEXT: A fundamentalist Cabinet minister and senior clergymen on Friday urged Moslems to retaliate against the U.S. military intervention in the Persian Gulf. ``We cannot retaliate against the United Saates itself because vast oceans separate us. But we now have the opportunity to retaliate against the American troops and other crusaders who are a stone's throw from us,'' Ali al-Fakir, minister of religious affairs, told 10,000 worshippers attending a prayer sermon. Al-Fakir, a sheik who was elected to Parliament last year, previously has stressed that political statements he makes at Friday prayer gatherings or reflect only his personal opinion and not that of the government. ``I assure you that you will take them captives and shackle them with chains as Moslems did with crusaders'' in the 12th century, he told the crowd at Hamzah Mosque in the suburb of Marka, five miles east of Amman. Fakir also blasted Egypt and Syria for committing troops to the U.S.-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Saudi Arabia. Many Moslems view the presence of non-Moslem forces in the kingdom that harbors Islam's holiest shrines at Mecca and Medina as an insult to their faith. ``That decision by Cairo and Damascus was inspired by material motives. Which is dearer to the nation, Kuwait or Palestine?'' he said criticizing the Arabs' failure to fight Israel to regain territories lost in the 1967 war, including Jerusalem. ``Which is more sacred, the oil wells or Jerusalem's Al-Aqsa Mosque?'' he said, referring to Islam's third holiest shrine. The Jordanian government has officially condemned the invasion of Kuwait and called for an Iraqi withdrawal. However, as a close ally of Iraq it has denounced the foreign military intervention in the region, urging an Arab solution to the problem.

DOC.HEAD: David Duke Attacks GOP Tactic in Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: Former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke predicted Friday that the withdrawal of the Republican Party's U.S. Senate candidate would help Duke defeat incumbent Democrat J. Bennett Johnston. Both Johnston and Duke predicted an outright win in Saturday's open primary. State Sen. Ben Bagert, the party-sanctioned Republican, withdrew Thursday. He said his polls indicated he could draw just enough votes from Johnston to force the Democrat into a Nov. 6 runoff against Duke, who is campaigning as a Republican. Duke threatened at a news conference to sue the state over absentee ballots cast for Bagert. Duke wants those voters to have another chance to vote over several days next week. About 62,000 absentee ballots - a state record - were cast, officials said. ``The people of Louisiana are sick and tired of back room deals,'' Duke said. ``Most of the Bagert votes are conservative and would go against a liberal incumbent. ... We have thousands of Louisianans who are being disenfranchised from this very important vote.'' Secretary of State Fox McKeithen has said that votes for Bagert will not count and will not figure into the official percentages that determine whether a runoff is needed. Johnston, a Democrat seeking his fourth term, predicted an overwhelming turnout against Duke, a Republican state representative. ``There is a message going out to the voters tomorrow,'' Johnston said at rally. ``There is no place in Louisiana. There is no place for Nazism in this state.'' Smiling and appearing relaxed, Johnston implored his supporters to vote, especially in light of Thursday's withdrawal by Bagert. ``We're going to surprise them at the polls tomorrow,'' Johnston said. Johnston, who garnered the unprecedented endorsement of eight of his Republican Senate colleagues, has said that Duke's politics would cost Louisiana military installations and other federal projects. ``This election is about a definition of Louisiana,'' Johnston said. ``I think when it is over ... we're going to be a better state for it.'' Jack Kemp, secretary of housing and urban development, endorsed Johnston on Friday. ``I was for Ben Bagert. Now that he's dropped out ... I'm announcing my support for Bennett. There is no place in the Republican Party for the politics of racism, bigotry and anti-semitism and the politics of essentially negativism,'' Kemp said. National GOP leaders have shunned Duke and barred him from receiving any party funds. Despite the condemnation, Duke has been the chief threat to Johnston from the first day of the campaign. Pollsters have said there may be a ``hidden vote'' for Duke that has not emerged on any survey of voters. State officials have said voter turnout could be over the 75 percent mark. In addition to the Senate race, Louisiana voters decide Saturday on a proposed lottery and cast ballots for seven congressional races. Democrats are hoping to break a 4-4 tie in the state's U.S. House delegation. State Sen. Foster Campbell, a Democrat, is trying to unseat Republican Rep. Jim McCrery in the 4th District. GOP Rep. Clyde Holloway faces two Democratic state senators - Joe McPherson and Cleo Fields. In the 2nd District, 12 candidates are vying to replace retiring Rep. Lindy Boggs, a Democrat.

DOC.HEAD: NC-17 Film Canceled; Movie Industry Group Cries Censorship
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `Showcase Cinema...,' to UPDATE with director's comment. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `What two...
DOC.TEXT: Under pressure from town officials, a theater canceled ``Henry and June,'' a movie that premiered Friday with the new adults-only rating NC-17. The Motion Picture Association of America said the decision brought back ``the dark ages of censorship.'' And Professor Alan Dershowitz of Harvard Law School, who is representing ``Henry and June'' director Philip Kaufman, said Kaufman was considering legal action against the town. ``It's a clear violation of the constitution and a clear violation of civil rights,'' Dershowitz said. ``The only basis on which you can legally ban movies is if they are legally obscene, and the ratings don't go to that.'' The MPAA replaced the X rating with the NC-17 rating on Sept. 26. NC-17 means children under age 17 cannot be admitted. Showcase Cinema called off Friday's opening of ``Henry and June'' at its Dedham theater after complaints from two selectmen. The film is based on the diaries of Anais Nin and chronicles her affairs with writer Henry Miller and his wife. Kaufman said his movie covers a range of important adult themes, including sexuality, creativity and duplicity. ``There's this kind of blindness to this film that I find not only confusing and unfair,'' Kaufman said. ``It's also, I feel, not part of the tradition of a free country. It amounts to censorship.'' ``What two city officials in Dedham have done is to go backward into the dark ages of censorship, when witches were burned at the stake,'' said MPAA chief executive officer Jack Valenti. Anthony Taurasi, chairman of the town's board of selectmen, said Showcase Cinema had a gentleman's agreement with the town not to show X-rated films and that the NC-17 rating was ``just a way around the ratings bureau.'' ``They can call it whatever they want to call it,'' Taurasi said. ``If it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck then it's a duck. Let's call it what it is.'' Both Taurisi and selectman Frank Geishecker said they had not seen the Universal Pictures release, which stars Fred Ward and Uma Thurman. An MPAA spokeswoman said she had heard of no other disputes over the NC-17 rating. Ira Korf, chief executive officer of Showcase Cinema's parent company, National Amusements Inc., said Friday his company had thought NC-17 would be added to the rating system, rather than replace the X designation. ``We thought that the X would remain,'' Korf said in a statement. The association changed the rating designation because the X rating carried the stigma of pornography. ``Henry and June'' was given the NC-17 rating because of two lesbian sex scenes and a shot of an erotic drawing. Korf said National Amusements had not seen the rating guide in writing and wanted to examine it further before taking a permanent stand on the NC-17 rating. ``We decided that we would respect the local community's wishes until we have had time to further study the matter,'' Korf said. More than 25,000 people live in Dedham, about 10 miles south of Boston. ``Henry & June'' was scheduled to open on 77 screens in 31 cities in the United States and Canada Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Five Dead, Dozens Injured in Senior Citizen Apartment Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with authorities reporting four victims died in fire and one was dead before fire began, picks up 7th graf pvs, `Police and ...'; INSERTS one graf after penultimate graf to ADD names and ages of other fire victims.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DT1,2,3
DOC.TEXT: Elderly residents said Friday they watched in horror as panicked neighbors jumped from windows to escape a fire in a four-story senior apartment house. Four people were killed and dozens injured. The body of a fifth person, who apparently died in his apartment a few days earlier of a heart attack, was found in the smoking ruins. ``I got out, but some was too scared. They just jumped,'' said Alison McCants, 61, her hands still shaking hours after the blaze was extinguished. McCants, who lived on the third floor, said she planned to remain in the partly charred building, possibly on a cot in the basement. ``I don't have nowhere else to go.'' The fire broke out Thursday night at the Majestic Manor in Detroit's midtown Boston-Edison neighborhood. It was extinguished early Friday. Fire Chief Harold Watkins said the 76-year-old building lacked fire escapes and sprinklers. About 65 tenants over age 50 pay about $190 a month to live in the building, which is an apartment building, not a care home. Owner Harold Stehlik of Dearborn Heights didn't return calls Friday. Dr. Bader Cassin, chief medical examiner at the Wayne County morgue, said four people died of smoke and soot inhalation. The fifth, an unidentified male, suffered a fatal heart attack in his apartment and had been dead, unnoticed by neighbors, several days when the fire broke out, Cassin said. Dozens of others were treated for smoke inhalation, police Sgt. George Anthony said. Police and fire officials said they were uncertain of the cause of the fire. Apartment manager Geraldine Larkin said she believed the fire started from cigarette butts in a garbage can in a stairwell, although fire officials also were checking the possibility of a stove fire. Police questioned a 50-year-old resident but released him, Anthony said. Larkin said she was uncertain whether the man was involved. ``He had burned a skillet earlier. I was so angry I said, `You set this,' and they took him to jail,'' Larkin said. ``I might have jumped the gun.'' Damage occurred on all four floors of the west wing and the third floor of the east wing, Larkin said. Some residents moved to vacant apartments that escaped damage. Others packed up to stay with friends. Diamond Stewart, 58, said he climbed out the window of his apartment when he saw a fire department ladder appear through the smoke. ``I heard somebody holler `fire.' I couldn't see nothing but smoke,'' Stewart said. ``I came out the kitchen window through the fourth floor. I was lucky.'' Laverga Jones, 31, and her boyfriend, Elmer Slater, in his 60s, died trying to escape through a window in Stewart's apartment, said Jones' sister, Ladena Williams. She said her sister was four months' pregnant. ``She was trying to get out and she tripped,'' said Williams, who ran from her grandmother's house nearby when she heard about the fire. ``They told me Virgie was dead. I said no way. I looked all over for her. I can't believe this.'' The fire also killed Matthew Carter, 50, and Roland Cooper, 42, Cassin said. About a dozen residents gathered in the lobby at midmorning Friday. Some wearing bathrobes carried canes as they looked at the blackened brick walls, broken glass and crushed flowers in the courtyard where their neighbors fell or jumped.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Vetoes Textile Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush vetoed a bill Friday imposing tight quotas on imports of textiles and shoes, saying the measure ``picks the pockets of U.S. consumers'' by drastically driving up prices to the tune of $2,600 per family over four years. He called the measure ``reprehensible'' and said it would cause an ``economic calamity'' by forcing a collapse of international trade talks. Congress had ignored threats of a veto in enacting the legislation, which imposes quotas of its own on imports of textiles, textile products and nonrubber shoes. Trade in textiles is regulated by international agreements which impose other quotas. ``This highly protectionist bill would damage the national economy, increase already artificially high costs to consumers of several basic goos and abrogate our international agreements,'' Bush said in a veto message. Disputing claims by the bill's supporters, Bush said the textile industry was doing well. Domestic production has been up slightly since 1987, he said, and unemployment in major textile-producing states is lower than the national average. ``Economic indicators illustrate that the problems this bill is intended to address do not exist,'' Bush said. ``The consumer costs of all restrictions on textile and apparel imports are conservatively estimated to increase to a total of $160 billion over the next five years,'' Bush said. ``That amounts to an onerous $2,600 for a family of four over that same period. ``These costs would continue to rise annually,'' he added. ``In essence, this legislation picks the pockets of U.S. consumers in order to subsidize the textile industry at a cost of $70,000 annually per job saved.'' Bush said there would be swift retaliation against the United States by nations hit by the quotas. U.S. companies would be particularly hard hit in agriculture, aerospace, high technology, capital goods and services, he said. Moreover, he said, ``this protectionist bill unquestionably would result in a mass exodus of perhaps half the 100 nations'' participating in the international trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

DOC.HEAD: Head Of Bush's Church Urges Peaceful Gulf Solution
DOC.TEXT: The head of President Bush's church on Friday urged that ``he remain steadfast and never give in to the trap of war'' in the present Middle East crisis. Presiding Episcopal Bishop Edmond L. Browning said an atmosphere of tensions, apparent diplomatic stalemate and ``threat of war'' had moved him to speak out on the situation. In a statement addressed to the church's bishops and its 2.5 million members, including Bush, Browning called for ``cooperative and peaceful solutions.'' ``In spite of the near unanimity of the United Nations in confronting the crisis, the time is fraught with danger,'' he said. ``Huge armies and armadas, led by those of our own country, face each other with the promise of unimaginable destruction and havoc.'' Although supporting the U.N. sanctions against Iraq's ``naked aggression,'' and saying Iraq must withdraw completely from Iraq, Browning questioned some Western motives. ``For what reason has our nation unleashed the greatest military force since the Vietnam war?'' he said. ``Are we not justified in suspecting that the reason is primarily economic, having to do with unimpeded access to oil?'' He urged examination of ``our national priorites and our addiction to unnecessary consumption.'' He said he prayed that Bush adhere to U.N. resolutions ``and I pray for him as he wrestles with the difficult decisions of his office. I urge that he remain steadfast and never give in to the trap of war.'' Declaring this ``is not a time for propaganda but for sober truth,'' Browning cautioned that ``we not demonize, stereotype or oversimplify'' in assessments of the Iraqi people. ``Resist the misplaced national pride which refuses to recognize the face of Christ in your brother and sister in Iraq and the Middle East.'' Browning said the crisis is interconnected with the Palestinian problem and must be seen in that light rather than as an isolated incident. He said, ``I continue to believe firmly that the United Nations and the Arab states themselves, working in concert, offer the best hope for a bloodless solution to the conflict.''

DOC.HEAD: Cousins To Receive Schweitzer Prize
DOC.TEXT: Author Norman Cousins will be awarded the 1990 Albert Schweitzer Prize for Humanitarianism for his work on behalf of innovative approaches to physical and emotional healing. The Schweitzer Prize, which carries a $10,000 award, is given annually by the Alexander von Humbolt Foundation in New York and is administered by Johns Hopkins University. The prize was established in 1986. Cousins, 75, is presently adjunct professor in the School of Medicine at the University of California-Los Angeles. Cousins, who edited The Saturday Review for 35 years, has written 25 books, including ``Anatomy of an Illness,'' a candid account of his successful battle against cancer. Cousins will receive the prize at a ceremony at Johns Hopkins on Oct. 18.

DOC.HEAD: Director Resigns, Mayor Says Zoo Operations Due For Overhaul
DOC.TEXT: Zoo Director Warren Thomas announced his retirement Friday, less than a month after federal inspectors cited the zoo for more than 100 violations of the Animal Welfare Act. Mayor Tom Bradley said Thomas' departure provides an opportunity to re-examine zoo operations, but denied the director was being forced out of the $83,000-per-year job he held for 17 years. ``This was a volunteer action on his part,'' Bradley said at a news conference. Thomas's last day on the job will be Jan. 4. ``I will leave with a variety of emotions, one of which will be, of course, sadness,'' Thomas, 59, said in a news release. ``However, my successor will inherit one of the great animal collections of the world, and a dedicated group of experienced zoo professionals. And I'm proud of that, too.'' Last month, the U.S. Department of Agriculture cited the zoo for more than 100 violations, including storage of toxic substances near food additives and medicine, dead mice, inadequate housing and run-down animal barns. If not remedied, the violations could lead to thousands of dollars in fines and revocation of the zoo's license. A bond measure on this fall's election ballot would provide some $30 million for badly needed repairs. Federal inspectors who visited the zoo on Thursday said most of the problems had been corrected, said Assistant Recreation and Parks Director Sheldon Jensen. Thomas also came under fire for allegedly keeping a cash account for special projects without notifying his city government supervisors. The Los Angeles Times reported that Thomas funded the account with fees paid by film crews that used the zoo. The Greater Los Angeles Zoo Association, which held the account, said Thomas withdrew money for various zoo projects and for a recent trip. The association said there was no indication any of the money was misspent.

DOC.HEAD: Win, Lose Or Draw: Government Comes Out The Loser In Mindanao
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with rebel surrendering; Picks up 8th graf, `It would ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Philippines, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The mutiny on the Philippines' second-largest island again tarnished the image of President Corazon Aquino's government, which stood to lose no matter how the revolt ended. Politicians demanded firm action against Col. Alexander Noble, who launched the seventh rebellion against Mrs. Aquino's 4{-year-old government on Thursday. Noble organized a private army after taking part in a failed coup in December. He surrendered early Saturday after trying to sneak out of the military garrison he captured two days earlier. ``Government must now take the strongest possible measures to ensure that this become the last challenge that (military rebels) ever make against constitutional authority,'' said House Speaker Ramon Mitra. Such statements have accompanied the previous coup attempts against Mrs. Aquino since she took power in the February 1986 ``people power revolution'' that overthrew President Ferdinand Marcos. Ordinarily, however, the mutineers simply surrender after protracted negotiations. Key leaders of past revolts have disappeared. Ordinary soldiers are then sent to different units for retraining. Senior commanders appeared fearful that bloodshed would further divide the armed forces and encourage sympathy for ``brother soldiers'' within the ranks. It would also play into the hands of renegade officers who portray the Aquino government as elitist and corrupt. In a statement Friday, the underground Young Officers Union accused the military leadership of barking ``orders from their air-conditioned rooms and cellular-equipped luxury cars'' while disregarding the hardships of common soldiers. Sen. Ernesto Maceda, chairman of the Senate defense committee, alluded to this when he urged the government to address problems of pay, promotions and living conditions in the military. ``How many times do we have to give this warning before President Aquino listens?'' Maceda said. ``The Aquino government must for once to meaningfully and substantially respond to the problems of our people.'' The latest revolt was all the more embarrassing because the military had been predicting for months that mutineers would stage an uprising on Mindanao, possibly as a prelude to a coup attempt in Manila. Furthermore, the military launched operations in August to capture Noble and regaled the media daily with reports that the colonel would soon be captured. Instead, he and his forces managed to travel more than 100 miles across northern Mindanao encountering no resistance. ``There is little likelihood that Noble can topple the Aquino administration, but there is a very real threat that the Aquino officials may expire from sheer embarrassment,'' commentator Luis Beltran wrote in The Manila Standard. ``Unfortunately, it looks like the only thing this administration is capable of capturing is the common cold.'' Most Filipinos have little sympathy for military rebels. But the inability of the government to control the dissidents has discredited a civilian administration that seems unable to deliver basic services, control prices and guide national development. That concern has been reflected in the business community, which is already alarmed over the prospects of economic decline brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis and the effects of July's earthquake that killed more than 1,600 people. Economists already have revised economic prospects downward because of rising oil prices and the return of thousands of Filipinos who were working in the Middle East. In a speech Friday, Herman Montenegro, chairman of the annual conference of the Chamber of Commerce, warned of a crisis of confidence in Mrs. Aquino. ``The government must dispel the fear that a military coup is a distinct possibility at any time,'' he said. Also Friday, the Central Bank reported businesses transferred $148 million abroad in the first six months of the year - an increase of more than 400 percent over the same time last year. In an editorial Friday, the pro-government newspaper The Manila Chronicle warned that instability was sapping the nation's viality. ``The government's mistakes and shortcomings of the past ... have exhausted the nation,'' the newspaper said. ``Though most people still look forward to the 1992 elections for some possible relief, there are those who are becoming seduced by the idea of an earlier, more radical change.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Robert H. Reid has been the AP bureau chief in Manila for the past four years.

DOC.HEAD: Bass Family Doubles Contribution To Yale To $40 Million
DOC.TEXT: Texas businessman Sid Bass, saying he was repaying a debt he owed Yale University, announced Friday the second $20 million contribution from his family in five months. The latest donation will be used to strengthen Yale's humanities programs and to renovate two classroom buildings. ``It's a pleasure to repay a great debt I owe to this university,'' Bass, a 1965 Yale Graduate and university trustee, told a news conference. ``I am very proud that the humanities here is so strong and it is my pleasure to emphasize that course of interest at the university.'' The school will use $5 million to endow five junior faculty research fellowships that will enable non-tenured members of the humanities faculty to pursue yearlong research projects. The university will use $10 million to renovate two Yale College buildings and the remaining $5 million will be used to create Yale's first classroom improvement endowment for future renovation projects. In May, Sid Bass's brother, Edward, announced a $20 million gift from the family to establish the Yale Institute of Biospheric Studies to support study of the global environment. The Bass family has a fortune estimated at $5 billion by Fortune Magazine. Sid Bass, 48, is president of Sid R. Bass Inc. of Fort Worth, which has interests in oil, gas, real estate and agriculture. Edward Bass is chairman and chief executive officer of Fine Line Inc., a diversified venture and investment capital company, and has numerous other business intrerests. The $40 million from the Bass family of Forth Worth, Texas, is the biggest donation Yale has received since Paul Mellon, a 1929 graduate, contributed more than $12 million in 1966-67 to construct the Yale Center for British Art and an art collection worth an estimated $35 million.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Meets With Gorbachev Aide, Iraq Responds to Bush Address
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Soviet response to speech, Iraqis walk out after criticism, details on fuel-air explosives from Pentagon. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein carried on talks with a top Soviet official Friday while his foreign minister accused the United States and its allies of pushing the world ``to the brink of a devastating war.'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering called Iraq's address to the General Assembly ``an insult to the Iraqi people, who deserve to be told no more lies.'' The United Nations speech, prepared by Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, was uncompromising, accusing the Security Council of hypocrisy for criticizing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait while allowing Israel to continue occupying Arab lands seized in the 1967 and 1973 wars. The speech came in response to President Bush's demand for Iraq to end its 9-week-old occupation of neighboring Kuwait. Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir Petrovsky later rebuked Iraq, saying, ``We cannot but feel some satisfaction at the unprecedented unity in the Security Council. ... That, we think, is the promise that the United Nations can deal with this highly dangerous international crisis.'' In Washington, the State Department said about 300 Americans and foreign-born family members have signed up for an evacuation flight due to leave Kuwait on Wednesday. U.S. officials estimate at least 900 Americans remain trapped in Kuwait and Iraq following Saddam's invasion of the oil-rich emirate Aug. 2. Aziz accused America and its allies of ``seeking to gain control over the oil reserves in the gulf so as to have a free hand in manipulating the needs of the world, and especially the needs of the peoples of the Third World, for this important commodity.'' The speech, delivered Friday afternoon by Iraq's second-ranked U.N. representative, Sabah Talat Kadrat because Aziz was not in New York, reiterated Saddam's view that all Middle East problems - ``Palestine, Lebanon, the gulf and others'' be considered on the same basis and ``on an equal footing.'' Kadrat stalked out of the hall later with the entire Iraqi delegation when a Kuwaiti delegate, D. Razzooqi, replied that ``there are no falsifications of facts similar to what we have heard from the representative of dictator Saddam Hussein.'' ``We are going to return to Kuwait, God willing, we will return,'' Razzooqi declared. Saudi Arabia's Ambassador Samir Shihabi accused Iraq of ``an unforgivable crime, a crime to shine in the history of crimes'' by ``swallowing up other countries through looting, through pillage, through invasion. Noting that Kuwait had helped finance Iraq during its war with Iran in the 1980s, Shihabi said, ``It seems that Kuwait was feeding a snake, a snake which would swallow up its neighbors.'' Bush demanded an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait but suggested before the world body Monday that there could be ``opportunities'' later to promote negotiations on Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Britain and France have made similar suggestions, which could allow Saddam a face-saving exit from the oil-rich emirate. In Baghdad, Saddam met with an aide to Mikhail S. Gorbachev and accepted a message from the Soviet president. The official Iraqi News Agency did not disclose the contents of the message. The news agency said Saddam and the Soviet envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, discussed the gulf crisis and stressed ``the desire for peace.'' Soviet diplomatic sources reported that Primakov urged Saddam to cooperate with U.N. resolutions demanding the Iraqi pullout. It was not clear if they discussed the plight of 5,000 Soviets unable to leave Iraq. About 4,500 of the Soviets in Iraq are key oil industry workers. Most are employed in new oil fields being developed by Iraq. ``The Iraqis are now dependent on these oil people,'' a source in Baghdad said on condition of anonymity. ``If they go, no one else will come in to operate these fields.'' Other Soviets in Iraq are military advisers who had been training Iraqi soldiers in the use of Soviet-made weaponry and other equipment. Moscow was Iraq's largest weapons supplier before Aug. 2, but cut trade after the invasion. Meanwhile in Washington, five senators called for a Pentagon investigation of how Iraq might have obtained the technology to make fuel-air explosives for extremely powerful bombs that can spread their blast over a wide area. The explosives have 10 times the power of conventional explosives and create a huge fireball and shock wave over a concentrated area, without the radiation fallout associated with nuclear weapons, according to Pentagon officials. The senators are concerned that a German company, Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm, may have given away the formulas needed to make the xplosives, which were used by U.S. forces in Vietnam. Military officials say the United States has no ready defense against the explosives, which could devastate oil fields, air bases and troops, the newspaper reported. The United States now has 170,000 troops in Saudi Arabia and on ships in the area, making up most of the estimated 200,000-member international force. The Pentagon says Iraq has massed 460,000 troops in Kuwait since the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Nun To Leave Order, Take the Bench
DOC.TEXT: A Dominican nun has decided to leave her religious order to don judicial robes. Mary Ellen Fitzmaurice was sworn in Thursday as a Family Court judge by Mayor David Dinkins. Fitzmaurice became the first nun in city history to become a judge. The job required her to leave the order because ``church law prohibits clergy ... to assume public offices which entail a participation in the exercise of civil power,'' said a statement from Sister Veronica Greeley, prioress of the Dominican Sisters of Amityville. Sister Greeley said Fitzmaurice ``has decided to begin the process of separation from her religious congregation.'' The parting was apparently amicable. Sister Greeley described the new judge as someone with ``intelligence, competence, compassion and mercy'' who will make fine contributions to the court. Fitzmaurice, 41, has been practicing law for 10 years, serving as a law guardian in Queens Family Court and an attorney with the Human Resources Administration. She refused to speak to reporters at the swearing-in ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Family of Former Atlanta Archbishop Says He's in Midwest Program
DOC.TEXT: Former Atlanta Archbishop Eugene A. Marino, who resigned this sumrates for the rich. To boost pressure on budget writers to forge a spending plan for the five-day-old fiscal year, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush would not sign any such temporary financing bill. ``We would close down the government at midnight'' Friday unless Congress completes a broad budget outline by then, Fitzwater said. Only those services needed to ``protect life and property'' will be permitted in the absence of a budget, White House budget director Richard Darman wrote in a memo to agency chiefs. With the long weekend about to start, it seemed likely that the full brunt of the shutdown would not be felt until Tuesday. But the Park Service was preparing to close the Statue of Liberty, the Washington Monument and other tourist favorites, at least for the weekend. Most of the nation's 2.4 million federal workers were told to report on Tuesday - after Monday's federal holiday - even if only to be sent home after they arrived. Congressional leaders of both parties met with administration officials to grope for a deficit-cutting plan that would be acceptable to lawmakers just a month shy of Election Day. Democrats sought support for a new plan with fewer cuts for the elderly and the poor, but there were no signs that Republicans were willing to accept it. Democrats also said they would be willing to consider cuts in the capital gains tax rate, a Republican proposal, in exchange for higher taxes for the rich. Budget negotiators had rejected the tradeoff last week. Earlier, in a Thursday night session that stretched into Friday morning, a rebellious House overwhelmingly defeated the $500-billion compromise package of tax boosts and spending slashes that Bush and congressional leaders preferred. That vote was an embarrassment to administration officials and top lawmakers of both parties, who had waged an all-out lobbying thrust on behalf of the measure. Uncertainty reigned on Capitol Hill. ``This thing could be - who knows?'' said a confused Rep. Robert Matsui, D-Calif. The president has 10 days to decide whether to sign a bill he is sent by Congress. Until a measure is signed, it does not become law. Democrats hoped that by sending the emergency spending bill to Bush, the president - and not Congress - would be blamed for the closure. But lawmakers of both parties agreed that all sides looked bad in light of the seemingly endless budget battle. Rep. Jack Buechner, R-Mo., tugged on a tie bearing a Mickey Mouse pattern and said, ``Everybody ought to have these on today.'' The House's 254-179 rejection of the budget was driven by unhappiness among members of all stripes. Conservatives disliked its $134 billion in taxes and as well as its spending cuts they considered overly gentle. Liberals thought the $60 billion in Medicare reductions, including cuts in benefits, were too steep. They said the plan's higher levies on gasoline, heating oil, tobacco and alcohol would hit the poor too hard. And members of both parties said they resented the process by which the package was written - four months of closed-door summit talks involving only congressional leaders and administration officials. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said he believed that as a result, lawmakers should try to write a budget themselves, perhaps with reduced Medicare cuts and a lesser tax burden for low-income people. ``We will, of course, keep in touch with the White House, but I do not anticipate ... the resumption of anything that would be called summit talks,'' he said. Foley said he wanted a budget that would be supported by a majority of Democrats and Republicans. ``I am not of the opinion that political warfare is of some value at this point,'' he said. But not all lawmakers agreed. Conservative Republicans urged Bush to keep the government shut down until Democrats agreed to limit federal spending. ``A budget plan ought to be put together by the president in consultation with Republicans,'' said Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas. ``Tell the Democrats to put up their best shot. We'll sustain every veto he's got.''

DOC.HEAD: Hijacked Soviet Jetliner Lands in Finland
DOC.TEXT: An unarmed Soviet man forced an Aeroflot airliner on a domestic flight with 26 people aboard to land in Finland on Friday and then asked for political asylum. The Soviet Embassy requested the extradition of the 40-year-old hijacker, identified by police as Nikolai Ivanovich Selivanov, the Foreign Ministry said. The hijacker surrendered soon after the 28-seat Yak-40 aircraft touched down, police said. None of the 21 other passengers or four crew members was hurt, and the plane flew to Leningrad later Friday evening. The hijacker walked out of the plane to meet Finnish police, who took him to central Helsinki for interrogation. Passengers said the man used no violence to hijack the plane but warned them it would explode if something happened to him. One passenger said the hijacker claimed to have recently left a mental institution. ``The hijacker wanted to go to Stockholm, but he was told there was not enough fuel,'' Chief Inspector Pertti Virolainen told a news conference. The small aircraft landed in Helsinki two hours after takeoff from Novgorod, 310 miles northwest of Moscow. It was on its way to Petrozavodsk via Leningrad. ``Fifteen minutes after we took off, a thin, pale nervous-looking man walked up to the hostess and handed her a note,'' said Yevgeni Khodorkovsky, a 32-year-old passenger. Passengers said the hijacker walked up and down the aisle of the plane and visited the toilet several times. ``He kept on looking out of the windows and when he saw the islands below he smiled,'' said passenger Antonina Urjetskaya, 68, of Novgorod. ``I heard the hijacker saying that he had a friend on board and if something happens to him then his friend would blow up the plane,'' Mrs. Urjetskaya said. The hijacker mentioned no motive for the hijacking except ``rather unclear, strange circumstances in his life,'' Khodorovsky said. ``He said he had been unemployed for six months, that his father was an invalid and he had just come out of a mental institution.'' The passengers included a 2-year-old and a 4-year-old child. ``All the passengers were of course very worried and we passed the two children from lap to lap so that they wouldn't run in the aisle,'' Mrs. Urjetskaya said. ``My heart is in bad shape so I was very worried, but I took a heart pill and I am very glad that the situation ended so well,'' she said. When the hijacker left the plane, she said, he announced he knew he had done something wrong, but would rather be in jail in Sweden, than in the Soviet Union. An air hostess had announced that the plane was landing in Stockholm. The passengers were taken by bus to an airport personnel cafeteria where they were interviewed by police. A Soviet Embassy official at the airport asked if anyone else wanted to stay in Finland, Khodorkovsky said. ``The official's request was met with laughter.'' Khodorkovsky, of Leningrad, said he and his wife had received exit visas to emigrate to Israel. Earlier this year, five domestic planes were hijacked to Finland and to Sweden by young men who said they were political dissidents or fugitives from the Soviet army. Swedish and Finnish officials extradited four of them. One was given political asylum in Sweden.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Says Continental Settles Denver Crash Suit for $10 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with airline spokesman saying only one of four settlements was this week. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Twenty-eight...
DOC.TEXT: The families of four people killed in the 1987 crash of a Continental Airlines jet in Denver will share $10 million in an out-of-court settlement, a lawyer says. Plaintiffs' Attorney Michael Sydow said Thursday the case against the airline was settled a few hours before it was scheduled to go to court on Monday. But Continental spokesman Ned Walker said Friday the settlement reached this week involved the family of just one victim. The other three settled about eight months ago, Walker said. Sydow was in court Friday and unavailable to answer questions about the discrepancy, an assistant said. Walker declined to give the amount of the settlement, which he noted will actually be paid for Continental by the airline's insurance company, United States Aviation Insurance Group of New York. Twenty-eight people died and 54 were injured when the Continental DC-9 crashed while attempting to take off in a snowstorm at Stapleton International Airport on Nov. 15, 1987. The Houston-based carrier already has paid more than $20 million to settle 36 other crash-related cases, lawyers said. The National Transportation Safety Board ruled the crash was caused by a combination of weather factors and pilot errors. The NTSB noted that the first officer, who was at the controls and killed in the crash, had little flight time on DC-9s. Investigators also noted that the takeoff came 27 minutes after the jet was last de-iced. Sydow said $4.5 million will go to Mary Cook of Boise, Idaho, and her daughter, Kay Gosse. Mrs. Cook's husband, Richard Cook, died in the crash, Sydow said. Helen Hideshima of Denver will receive $2.5 million for the death of her husband, Mako Hideshima; Byron Owens of Nyssa, Wash., will get $750,000 for the death of his wife, Terry; and David Daniel of Nampa, Idaho, $2.2 million for the loss of his wife, Tamara, the attorney said. Daniel was seated next to his wife in the plane. Sydow has two remaining cases filed on behalf of families of crash victims pending against Continental.

DOC.HEAD: More Graves Found As Freeway Widening Continues
DOC.TEXT: Archaeologists are uncovering more graves of freed slaves than they originally believed were beneath a city park in the path of a freeway-widening project. Officials originally believed Freedman's Cemetery contained less than 100 graves. But new excavations, prompted by the widening of Dallas' Central Expressway, have uncovered about 1,100 graves, said archaeologist Jerry Henderson. Officials now estimate that more than 2,000 slaves and freed slaves were buried in the cemetery, which operated from 1861 to 1925. The cemetery was largely forgotten and covered by the park, and recently was rediscovered because of the freeway widening project. The project threatens about 150 known graves, but Ms. Henderson said workers could find up to 800 graves that must be moved to make way for the new road. Scientists hope to catalog the vital statistics of 800 bodies before reburying them to learn more about the slaves' lives, said Jerome Rose, chairman of the University of Arkansas anthropology department. ``I think it would ba a fantastic contribution to Afro-American history,'' Rose said.

DOC.HEAD: Art Gallery, Director Acquitted in Mapplethorpe Exhibit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to add trial length. SUBS 6th graf, `Spectators in...' to add jurors ushered from courtroom.
DOC.TEXT: An art gallery and its director were acquitted Friday of obscenity charges by a jury that rejected prosecution claims that sexually graphic photos by Robert Mapplethorpe lacked artistic value. The two-week obscenity trial was the nation's first of an art gallery. ``What a great day!'' gallery director Dennis Barrie told reporters. The jury of four men and four women returned the verdicts after slightly more than two hours. Barrie smiled slightly as a clerk read the verdict. When the clerk finished, Barrie smiled broadly, said ``All right!'' turned in his chair and hugged his attorney, H. Louis Sirkin. Spectators in the Hamilton County Municipal Court room shouted and applauded. The jurors were ushered out of the courtroom. Judge David Albanese expelled gallery board Chairman Roger Ach and Robert Allen, whose video production company sponsored the exhibit, when they jumped out of their seats to hug Barrie. The jury cleared the Contemporary Art Center and Barrie of misdemeanor charges of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. Barrie could have been sentenced to one year in jail and fined $2,000, and the gallery fined $10,000, if convicted on both counts. ``Obviously, this is a very emotional moment. It's been a very hard time for me,'' Barrie said. ``We did something very important for this city. We stood up for the First Amendment. ``This is a major battle fought here today. It's a major battle for the arts and for freedom of expression in America.'' However, the Rev. Donald E. Wildmon, whose American Family Association in Tupelo, Miss., has fought National Endowment for the Arts funding for exhibits such as Mapplethorpe's, said: ``This is not a landmark, Pearl Harbor decision. This was just another obscenity trial. ... ``I think this really puts the NEA issue right back in the political arena where it belongs.'' In closing arguments, defense attorneys contended there was no basis for the charges of using children in nudity-related material since the mothers of the children gave their consent. The prosecution contended that consent was not in writing when the exhibit opened. The defense also noted the U.S. Supreme Court's three-pronged test of obscenity: Material must appeal to a prurient interest in sex, be patently offensive according to contemporary community standards and must lack redeeming artistic, scientific or political value. ``The jury has made its decision. We accept it,'' said Frank Prouty, assistant city prosecutor. During closing arguments, Prouty told jury members it was up to them to decide the artistic merit of the photographs. ``Are these Van Goghs, these five pictures?,'' he asked. ``A forearm rammed up a rectum - that's art? A finger stuck in the head of a penis - is that art? A canister ... or something ... stuck up your rectum - is that art? Another picture where you have a man urinating into another man's mouth - is that art?'' The fifth photo is a self-portrait of Mapplethorpe with a bullwhip in his rectum. ``All five pictures - think of it - art?'' Prouty asked. He told the jury to judge what they considered to be art using contemporary community standards, not the standards of art experts who testified for the defense. Prouty recited the fable of the vain emperor who, although naked, believed he was fully clothed because his subjects praised his imaginary clothing. ``The art world wants to tell you these are art. And the townspeople sat there and watched the emperor walk down the street without any clothes on, but yet all his advisers told him `You have a beautiful coat,' because nobody wanted to come out and tell them that it's not art. ``You are the townspeople. Don't let somebody from outside come in and say it is art. You say whether these five pictures are like the emperor without any clothes on.'' Sirkin, Barrie's attorney, said the five photos no doubt offended some people but had serious artistic merit. He quoted from a speech by John Kennedy: ``Society must set the artist free to follow his vision, wherever it takes him. We must never forget that art is not a form of propaganda. It is a form of truth. The highest duty of the writer, the composer, the artist, is to remain true to himself.'' ``That's exactly what Dennis Barrie did,'' Sirkin said. ``He wanted to share with this community a beauty that he felt was shown by an artist, Mr. Mapplethorpe.'' Sirkin reminded jurors that the same exhibit was shown in Philadelphia, Chicago and Berkeley, Calif., without incident. ``Is Cincinnati that different? Are we that childish? Are we not big enough to say we can't accept what other cities have seen?'' Sirkin asked. Defense experts have testified that Mapplethorpe was an accomplished and respected photographer, and that photographs of the children were morally and sexually innocent. Mapplethorpe died last year of AIDS at age 42. The exhibit drew 81,000 people during its seven-week run last spring, an attendance record for an art exhibit in Cincinnati. It closed Friday in Boston, where 103,000 tickets were sold. Attorney Marc Mezibov, representing the gallery, said the state failed to prove its case. No presentation was made to back up the assertion that the photographs were not legitimate art. ``Have you thought why it is that no one for the state of Ohio came in and testified that the exhibit had no serious artistic value? Don't you think that if there were people out there who thought that, the state of Ohio would have found them?'' Mezibov asked.
