East St. Louis Sues Court for City Hall Giveaway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with city suing judge who gave away city hall to pay damage award. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `The St. Clair...
DOC.TEXT: This financially troubled city sued a judge who gave away City Hall to pay a debt, but the new owner's lawyer says the property's already been sold. The suit, filed Friday in federal court, seeks to reverse the Sept. 27 county circuit court ruling awarding City Hall and some other city land to the guardians of a man who won a $3.4 million judgment after being injured in the city jail. Mayor Carl Officer contends in the $125 million lawsuit that the ruling by St. Clair County Circuit Judge Roger Scrivner was part of a pattern of racism against the predominantly black city. The mayor also called for a U.S. Senate investigation of the circuit court. The mayor's suit, filed in U.S. District Court on behalf of the people of East St. Louis, alleged the circuit court ``has engaged in a pattern and practice of racially motivated conduct that has deprived the city of East St. Louis and its citizens of due process of law.'' The mayor also asked the circuit court to reconsider Scrivner's decision and bar him from handling other cases involving the city, said City Attorney Eric Vickers Scrivner awarded City Hall and a piece of city-owned industrial property to Walter DeBow, 55, who suffered permanent brain damage after being beaten into a coma by a fellow prisoner at the city jail more than six years ago. DeBow has no short-term memory and is being cared for at a head-injury rehabilitation center in New Jersey. Calls for comment to Scrivner and the chief judge of the court weren't returned Friday. DeBow's attorney, Clyde Kuehn, said Friday he'd already made a deal to sell City Hall. He refused to name the prospective buyer or give the price. Kuehn said Scrivner's ruling was the only way to get the city to pay its debt to DeBow - about $4 million because of interest. ``The rights that were enforced in circuit court were the rights of a black man, and a good guy too,'' said attorney Clyde Kuehn, referring to the allegation of racism. ``You can win a $4 million verdict, but you don't win until they pay.'' DeBow, who was in jail on charges of illegally transporting alcohol when the beating occurred, needs the money to pay for his $325-per-day care, his family said. The city's lawsuit seeks $25 million in actual damages and $100 million in punitive damages. The St. Clair County Recorder of Deeds said Friday the property was placed in a trust Oct. 1, with Eric Rhein as guardian. A phone call to Rhein's Belleville law office was not immediately returned. City Hall is worth about $10 million, Vickers has said. And city officials had been negotiating with a company to buy the other piece of property for $5 million to build a trash recycling plant. East St. Louis is plagued by debt estimated at $47 million. Gov. James R. Thompson signed a $34 million bailout bill Aug. 30. The money will come from state bond issues. The population of the city, which has one of the nation's highest murder rates, fell from 55,000 in 1980 to 40,000 this year, the Census Bureau estimates. Selling the property rids DeBow of responsibility for paying property taxes, which could be as high as $400,000 annually on City Hall alone, Kuehn said Thursday. It also eliminates potential liability for injuries on the property, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sequence of Events in Obscenity Trial
With AM-Mapplethorpe Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events in the obscenity case based on photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe: -April 1987-Dec. 1988: Mapplethorpe assembles an exhibition called ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment'' in consultation with Janet Kardon, curator of the Institute for Contemporary Art in Philadelphia. -Oct. 1988: Dennis Barrie, the director of the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati, decides to host the show, calling the photos ``the most stunning photographic show I'd seen in years.'' -March 1989: Mapplethorpe dies at age 42 of AIDS in Boston. -June 1989: The Corcoran Gallery in Washington, D.C., cancels a planned Mapplethorpe exhibition. The gallery director says she acted to defuse debate over government support to the arts. -March 16, 1990: Hamilton County Sheriff Simon L. Leis Jr. says in an interview that he considers parts of the planned 175-picture exhibition legally obscene and says he plans to take legal action if Cincinnati police don't act. -March 27: The Contemporary Arts Center files a lawsuit seeking a court ruling on whether the pictures are obscene before the exhibition opens. -April 2: Cincinnati police vice officers review the Mapplethorpe exhibition at the gallery's request, but decline to file charges. -April 6: A Hamilton County Municipal Court judge dismisses the gallery's lawsuit. The exhibition opens with a private showing to more than 4,000 dues-paying gallery patrons. -April 7: The exhibition opens to the public, and more than 8,000 see it the first day. A county grand jury indicts the Contemporary Arts Center and Barrie on misdemeanor counts of pandering obscenity and using children in material involving nudity. The indictment covers five pictures depicting sex acts and two showing children with their genitals exposed. -April 8: U.S. District Judge Carl B. Rubin issues an injunction barring police from seizing the photographs at the gallery. -April 16: Barrie and the Contemporary Arts Center plead innocent before Judge David J. Albanese in Hamilton County Municipal Court. -April 19: County Prosecutor Arthur M. Ney turns the case over to city prosecutors, saying his office cannot handle it because it involves only misdemeanor charges. -April 23: The Association of Art Museum Directors, which represents directors of 176 museum directors in the United States and Canada, promises to pay any fine imposed on Barrie and the Contemporary Arts Center. -May 26: The exhibition closes after more than 81,000 people pay to see it, making it the largest arts event in Cincinnati history. -June 20: Albanese, rejecting defense arguments that the artistic quality of two pictures of children make them immune from child-nudity law, orders Barrie and the gallery to stand trial Sept. 24 on the child-nudity charge. -Aug. 1: The exhibit opens in Boston at the Institute for Contemporary Art. -Sept. 5, 1990: A Municipal Court clerk in Boston refuses a request by critics of the show to file obscenity charges. -Sept. 6: Albanese rules that jurors in Barrie's trial will consider only the seven photos named in the indictment, saying they need to find that only one of the pictures is obscene to return a conviction. The judge orders Barrie and the gallery to stand trial Sept. 24 on the obscenity charge. -Sept. 24, 1990: The trial begins. -Oct. 2: Mrs. Kardon testifies that she considered the pictures to be artistically important. She says she found the pictures of the two children non-sexual and morally innocent. -Oct. 3: Barrie testifies in his own defense, saying he recognized the controversial nature of the photos before the exhibition began. But he says Mapplethorpe was an important artist whose work the public should be able to see. -Oct. 4: Judith Reisman, the prosecution's only expert witness, testifies that the photos of sex acts lack artistic value and that the photos of the children could encourage child abuse. -Oct. 5: Jurors deliberate just two hours before finding Barrie and the Contemporary Arts Center innocent on all charges. The exhibit closes in Boston, after 103,000 people paid to see the photographs.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Group Won't Use Fund-Raising Technique Again in Alabama
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Recasts lead, 2nd graf to add detail, increase total of letters; SUBS 8th graf to delete now-outdated reference to Burnley not having any immediate comment Task Force; adds 2 grafs of comment from Burnley
DOC.TEXT: A Republican group agreed Friday it will no longer use a controversial fund-raising technique in Alabama, said the state attorney general and the GOP organization. Alabama Attorney General Don Siegelman said he will abandon a lawsuit against the Republican Presidential Task Force, which mailed about 1 million fund-raising letters nationwide in August and early September. The task force is a fund-raising program of the Washington-based National Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee. Each three-page letter from the task force contained a $25 check and a three-page letter explaining that by depositing the check, the recipient agreed to have $12.50 a month automatically transferred to the Republicans' Candidate Support Program. The letters said a person could cancel after two months. If not, the withdrawals would continue. The back of the $25 check reiterated the automatic withdrawal, but Siegelman said the print was so small one could hardly read it. ``Solicitations which could trick people into making involuntary contributions must not be tolerated,'' Siegelman said in a prepared statement. The attorney general said he agreed to drop his lawsuit after receiving a commitment from the group not to send letters to Alabama in the future. In addition, the group will send to each person who received the original letter another letter stating that monthly contributions of $12.50 are being withdrawn from their bank accounts. Task force spokeswoman Wendy Burnley confirmed Friday night that an agreement had been reached and that it applied only to the specific mailing made to Alabama voters. Siegelman said the case began with a complaint from the daughter of a 76-year-old Hamilton woman who was prepared to deposit the check before her daughter examined it carefully. Burnley has acknowledged that the letter prompted complaints in at least six states. State officials in New Jersey and Illinois have filed suit. Attorneys general of Oregon, Minnesota and Michigan have complained. Burnley said Friday night that the group will have discussions with the attorneys general in Oregon, Minnesota and Michigan after the November elections. She said the Illinois suit is pending and that there will be a court proceeding next month in the New Jersey suit.

DOC.HEAD: Rajneeshee Accused of Plotting To Kill U.S. Attorney
DOC.TEXT: A follower of the late guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh was arrested in Germany in a plot to kill the chief federal prosecutor in Oregon, authorities said Friday. Carol Matthews, 40, a New York native also known as Prem Samadhi, was arrested Thursday by police in Baden Baden, Assistant U.S. Attorney Baron C. Sheldahl said. ``We are beginning the extradition process,'' Sheldahl said, adding that it would be months before Matthews could be returned to the United States. Matthews is one of three Rajneeshees being held in Germany in connection with an alleged wiretapping scheme and a conspiracy to kill U.S. Attorney Charles H. Turner during 1985 and 1986 at Rajneeshpuram, the sect's former commune in central Oregon. Federal prosecutors said Anand Sheela, who as the guru's secretary led the sect, devised the murder plot because she believed it would derail state and federal investigations for immigration fraud and other offenses. Sheela left the United States in December 1988 after serving 29 months in a California prison for crimes related to the sect's activities in Oregon. They included the poisoning of 750 people by contaminating salad bars in The Dalles with salmonella bacteria cultivated in the sect's laboratory, the operation of a wiretapping scheme that intercepted all telephone calls in Rajneeshpuram, and immigration fraud. Matthews is the fifth Rajneeshee arrested within the past month in connection with the alleged plot. Catherine Jane Stubbs, 45, a native of Australia; and Richard Kevin Langford, 40, a native of Syracuse, N.Y., were arrested three weeks ago in West Germany. Ann Phyllis McCarthy, 43, a German native, was arrested in South Africa. British citizen Susan Lissanevitch, 43, was arrested in England. Sheela has not yet been arrested in the plot, although Turner said recently that authorities have a ``pretty good idea'' of her whereabouts.

DOC.HEAD: Southwest Airlines Accused of Age Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: A class-action lawsuit accusing Southwest Airlines of discriminating against older pilots was filed by the U.S. Equal Opportunity Commission on Friday. The lawsuit, filed in the U.S. District Court, alleges that Southwest has not hired a pilot older than 45 since 1987. Southwest Airlines, which serves 13 states, employs 800 pilots. A spokesman for Southwest denied the allegations. ``We think their statistics are simply incorrect,'' said Jim Parker, vice president and general counsel for Southwest Airlines. Since 1987, Southwest Airlines has hired 39 pilots over 45, Parker said. ``Their figure is simply untrue,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Gets To Weather Service Computers
DOC.TEXT: The National Weather Service lost power to its main computers in Suitland, Md., on Friday because the air conditioning went out, officials said. While technicians were attempting to power up backup computers In Kansas City ``some reports got lost in the process,'' said Washington lead forecaster John Billet. The power loss occurred about 8 p.m. and the computers were brought back on line about an hour and 15 minutes later, he said. He said some hourly observations that airport authorities file to the NWS to compile their reports were delayed or got lost.

DOC.HEAD: Donovan Takes On Chafee Family In Ad Against Mayoral Opponent
DOC.TEXT: Charles J. Donovan is running against Republican Lincoln Chafee in the mayor's race, but the Democrat seems to be taking on the entire Chafee clan. Donovan, a state senator, ran an ad in the Warwick Beacon blasting not only Chafee but the Republican's father, Sen. John Chafee, his brother, assistant U.S. Attorney Zechariah Chafee, and two of his cousins - independent Providence mayoral candidate Fred Lippitt and Duncan H. Doolittle, a former DiPrete administration official. Donovan criticized the Chafees and their cousins for collecting state or federal pensions and working in what the Democrat called ``patronage'' jobs. ``The apple doesn't fall far from the family tree,'' the ad said. It pictured the heads of all five men as apples hanging from a tree. ``A little desperate over there,'' Zechariah Chafee said. ``Gosh,'' said Edward Quinlan, Sen. Chafee's spokesman. ``Fred Lippitt is running for mayor of Providence.'' ``I wonder if he's forgotten where he's running,'' said Lippitt's campaign manager, Richard White. Donovan stood by the ad, but said he had no gripe with Sen. Chafee. ``I really do kind of like his father,'' he said, ``but issues are different than personalities.'' Lincoln Chafee said the ad was incorrect because it implied that he receives a city pension for his service as councilman and that his brother gets a federal pension. Both said they were still ineligible. Sen. Chafee, who will turn 68 this month, started receiving a state pension of $6,200 a year at age 60 after serving six years in the Rhode Island House and three terms as governor, Quinlan said. The ad, which ran Thursday, made no mention of Donovan's state pension. Donovan, 52, receives $34,271 after taking early retirement this year from his 20-year job with the state school lunch program, and a $4,800 pension for his time in the legislature.

DOC.HEAD: An ``American Dream'' That Will Be Tough to Sell
DOC.TEXT: ``American Dream,'' an emotional, uncompromising documentary of the Hormel meatpackers strike in the mid-1980s, is very much hot off the presses. It was completed the day before its screening Thursday at the New York Film Festival, and the director hopes the success of ``Roger and Me'' means there's an audience for her film, too. But it will be a tough sell for Barbara Kopple, whose 1976 movie, ``Harlan County U.S.A.,'' won an Academy Award for best feature documentary. ``American Dream'' tells a bleak story, with little of the irony and dark humor that made ``Roger and Me'' so entertaining despite its account of corporate greed and indifference in Flint, Mich. Speaking at a press conference at the festival, where the movie received an extended ovation, Kopple spoke of the years she spent in Austin, Minn., the location of the strike, and her desire to gain national attention for the documentary. ``I think `Roger and Me' is a film that takes a different look at the problems of working people and I enjoyed it very much,'' said Kopple, whose other films include ``No Nukes'' and ``Civil Rights: The Struggle Continues.'' ``I just want to follow in its footsteps,'' she said. The film begins in 1984 with Geo. A. Hormel & Co. asking workers to accept wage cuts although the company was turning a profit. Hormel, which said it needed the reductions to remain competitive, had enjoyed good relations with workers over the years and several plants agreed to the concessions. But Austin's Local P-9 of the United Food and Commercial Workers decided to fight. Ray Rogers, a maverick consultant known for organizing J.P. Stevens textile mills in the South, was recruited and the union followed his policy of confrontation. Hormel would not back down, and on Aug. 17, 1985, the nearly 1,500 members of Local P-9 walked off their jobs. The national union urged Rogers and P-9 President Jim Guyette to negotiate, but they angrily refused and most of the workers supported them. The strike dragged on for months and became increasingly bitter. Workers lashed out at Hormel and fought with each other as the company filled their jobs with replacement workers. Some employees, their strike fund cut off by the national union, crossed the picket lines. Hormel eventually returned the plant to full capacity and most of the strikers never returned to work. Some remain in Austin, others looked for jobs elsewhere. Kopple had access to local and national union officials. She shows meatpackers breaking down and crying and lifelong friendships being destroyed. There is a brief moment of humor, a closeup of a billboard reading: ``Enjoy Austin: Where the Good Life Is Here to Stay.'' ``There was a lot of media there for the strike,'' Koppel said, ``but I'm not a newsperson. I have a much more personal style. I wanted to get inside people's heads. I'm very sympathetic to people's making decent wages and wanted to make an explanation of what happened.''

DOC.HEAD: Sculpture Made From U.S. and Soviet Missiles Unveiled at U.N.
DOC.TEXT: A sculpture of St. George slaying a dragon made from the wreckage of American and Soviet nuclear missiles was dedicated Friday on the grounds of the United Nations. ``The nuclear dragon is the ultimate evil,'' said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze at a ceremony attended by U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III, U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and the artist, Zurab Tsereteli. ``Here are these monsters, born not of the artist's imagination, but of the cruel realities of our time, the Pershing and SS-20 nuclear missiles,'' Shevardnadze added. ``They have been beheaded and destroyed not by the artist's fantasy but by the will of the governments and people of those countries where they once came into being.'' The 39-foot-high monument depicts in bronze St. George atop a rearing horse. Holding a long pole topped by a tiny cross, the rider spears broken SS-20 and Pershing missiles. The missiles form the body of a two-headed dragon. Entitled ``Good Defeats Evil,'' it weighs 40 tons. Pershing and SS-20 missiles were dismantled under the Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which was signed Dec. 8, 1987, by President Reagan and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Shevardnadze said his country was giving the sculpture to the United Nations in honor of its 45th anniversary, which is celebrated this month. Tsereteli told several hundred people who gathered at the sculpture dedication that he got the idea for the monument in a dream in which St. George was slaying dragons made from missiles. After the INF treaty was signed, Tsereteli got hold of some actual missile parts and gave them to an international group of children who were attending an art workshop with Soviet children in his native Georgia. ``The children destroyed these missiles,'' he said, explaining that observing the children helped inspire him. Tsereteli, 56, is the Soviet Union's artist laureate and has been named People's Artist of the U.S.S.R. In 1976, he was awarded the Lenin Prize, which honors contributions to culture. With his 12-year-old grandson, Vaseli Tsereteli, the artist placed a bright yellow bow with long streamers on the green sculpture. Tsereteli said this symbolized his hope for peace in the Middle East and fulfilled the dream in which he visualized the sculpture as green and yellow.

DOC.HEAD: Nine More Lobbyists Subpoenaed in Ethics Investigation
DOC.TEXT: Nine more lobbyists were subpoenaed Friday in a growing criminal investigation into lawmaker ethics, while a prominent state senator amended a disclosure report to include three 1989 trips. Assistant State Attorney Anthony Guarisco ordered the lobbyists to produce records of every occasion they spent more than $100 on a legislator over the past five years. The subpoenas are identical to those already issued to a half-dozen others. ``We're not through yet,'' Guarisco said. ``This thing will continue, and we'll go through as many as we can get to.'' The investigation is aimed at finding legislators who accepted gifts, travel and other perquisites from lobbyists worth over $100 but failed to report them as required. Sen. Gwen Margolis, a North Miami Beach Democrat who could become Senate president after the November elections, sent a letter to the Division of Elections this week amending her financial disclosure reports. She disclosed 1989 trips to Chicago, the Bahamas and to Moscow - all paid for by others. Margolis couldn't be reached for comment Friday, but she has said she was confused about whether they should have been included. All but two of the lobbyists subpoenaed Friday appeared in a St. Petersburg Times story Sunday that described some of the biggest spenders among the 4,000 Florida legislative lobbyists. Guarisco confirmed prosecutors used the story as a guide. Those subpoenaed have a wide variety of clients in such fields as tourism, alcoholic beverages, insurance and other industries. They often spent money on legislators by providing hunting trips.

DOC.HEAD: Basketball Player Says He Will Move to Wellesley Despite Police Action
DOC.TEXT: Boston Celtic basketball player Dee Brown says he plans to move to this affluent Boston suburb, even though police interrupted his house-hunting trip by holding him at gunpoint on the ground. Brown, who is black, was confronted Sept. 21 by officers seeking a black bank robbery suspect. ``I'm going to make my home in Wellesley,'' Brown told WBZ-TV in Boston in interview broadcast Friday. But Brown also authorized his lawyer to consider filing suit against the town, after private negotiations failed to work out a settlement over his detention by police. ``The town has chosen the position that racism was not a factor and that all of the police procedures were proper and correct,'' Brown's attorney, Alan Margolies said, in an news release. ``We disagree.'' Margolies said he had offered the town a deal to resolve the case, but was rebuffed. He did not return telephone calls seeking details of his settlement proposal, nor would Wellesley officials disclose it. However, town officials said they were surprised by the attorney's announcement that talks had broken off. ``My understanding is and always has been that we were having ongoing discussions,'' said Barbara Shanahan, chairman of the Wellesley Board of Selectmen. ``We want to make things right.'' In two meetings with Margolies on Sept. 24 and Thursday, Shanahan said officials promised to bring in Justice Department experts on race relations to talk with residents and police. Blacks make up less than two percent of the town's population, according to state estimates. Brown, 21, is the Celtics' top draft choice. The 6-foot-1 point guard participated in the first day of training camp Friday. Brown said he had received letters and petitions from Wellesley residents asking him to move there. ``You don't want a rap like that on your town, that every time a black person (or) a suspicious person or everybody that doesn't look like a Wellesley citizen, you have to check them or ID them,'' Brown said. Shanahan said she was ``delighted'' that Brown was moving to Wellesley. ``He will be warmly welcomed,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Teens Suspended for Garlic Odor
DOC.TEXT: School officials raised a stink and handed a pair of smelly students three-day suspensions for eating too much garlic. Lake Worth High School juniors Paul Martikainen, 16, and Tomi Ilves, a 17-year-old vegetarian, were intrigued by tales of garlic's power to cleanse blood and keep blood pressure down. So the pair said they each munched half a garlic head Wednesday night and three or four heads each for breakfast Thursday. Classmates and teachers weren't pleased by the aroma. One instructor told the boys twice to stop eating garlic at school, Principal David Cantley said. By third period, they were sent to the office. ``This isn't like we were doing it on purpose to get anybody mad,'' Martikainen said. ``We were blowing in each other's face, and we couldn't sense a garlic smell.'' School Board counsel Abbey Hairston said the suspensions are appropriate because ``there was some disruption and some complaints that those students were odoriferous.'' The Fresh Garlic Association in Sausalito, Calif., says studies show garlic may improve circulation and lower cholesterol. ``But there is one thing they recommend, and that is not to overdo it,'' association spokesperson Caryl Saunders said.

DOC.HEAD: Belgian Paratroopers Arrive as Firing Reported near Rwanda Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with France saying its forces engaged in defensive fire in the capital, comments from Belgian defense minister; EDITS to conform, trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: About 500 Belgian paratroopers were flown into Belgium's former colony of Rwanda on Friday in a bid with French forces to quash a rebel uprising, authorities said. Diplomats from Kigali, Rwanda's capital, said small-arms and artillery fire that broke out overnight in the city outskirts had died down later Friday. French military officials in Paris said its forces engaged in defensive fire early Friday against armed men while tightening ranks around the French Embassy. The French soldiers ``were obliged to ripost, in a purely defensive manner'' to ``armed elements,'' the army press service said. It said it was not known whether there were casualties. The French Defense Ministry denied as ``absolutely false'' reports that its forces engaged in gunfire around the airport at Kigali. The scattered shooting in this impoverished country in central East Africa marked the sixth day of unrest since the rebel force made up of Rwandan refugees invaded from neighboring Uganda. Diplomats from Kigali, a city of about 160,000 residents, said the French and Belgian forces were helping Rwandan forces maintain control of the capital. The French Defense Ministry said its troops, 150 sent Friday in addition to 150 dispatched earlier, were there only to protect French citizens and the diplomatic mission. Belgian Defense Minister Guy Coeme said four companies of paratropers, or about 500 men, arms and vehicles were being flown in. Coeme said the Belgian troops would cntrol Kigali airport and roads around it. He declined to give more details. A U.S. Embassy spokesman said the arrival of the French and Belgian troops had bolstered the morale of government troops in the mountainous nation the size of Marlyand. ``They're happy to see that their friends are backing them up in their time of need,'' Tom Martin, a U.S. Embassy spokesman in Kigali, told CNN in a phone interview. ``It's also made a big difference for all the expatriates,'' he said. ``It's made everybody feel a lot safer, not just the Belgian and French citizens who the troops were sent in to protect.'' Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana, in an afternoon address broadcast nationwide, said government forces were in ``full control'' of the situation. According to Martin, the dissent is over the poor economic conditions of Rwanda, which has suffered from declining world prices for its main export crop, coffee, as well as food shortages and tribal conflict. Martin said support for the rebels appeared limited. Diplomats, interviewed by telephone on condition of anonymity, said it appeared no foreigners had been hurt in the unrest. An estimated 250 Americans are in the country of 6.7 million residents, including tourists. ``It looks like the French, Belgians and Rwanda militias have things under control,'' one diplomat said. ``However, the streets still are not safe.'' There are an estimated 670 Frenchmen in Rwanda, and Radio France Internationale said the French Embassy was arranging for 200 citizens to fly out of Rwanda, perhaps as early as Friday night. In Bonn, the government said some of the 400 German nationals in Rwanda would be evacuated on planes, and others in truck and car convoys to neighboring Burundi or Zaire. Belgium rushed paratroopers and military equipment said to include two C-130 transport aircraft to Rwanda to protect its 1,630 citizens there. The rebels, Rwandan refugees mostly from the minority Tutsi tribe, invaded across the northern border with Uganda on Sunday. Many deserted from Uganda's army. Estimates of the size of the invading force have ranged from several hundred to several thousand. Rwanda's government Friday urged people to stay indoors and banned gatherings of more than two people and unauthorized travel. A dusk-to-dawn curfew ordered Tuesday remained in effect. Rwanda's Habyarimana, of the majority Hutu tribe, has ruled Rwanda since seizing control in a bloodless 1973 coup.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Rests in Miller Spy Case
DOC.TEXT: The defense rested in the third sex-for spying trial of Richard W. Miller without calling the former FBI agent to testify. Miller's lawyer, Joel Levine, said he didn't put Miller on the stand in U.S. District Court because he suffers from auditory dyslexia, a condition that affects his verbal abilities in stressful situations. Judge Robert M. Takasugi is hearing the case without a jury. Closing arguments were expected Tuesday. Miller did not testify in his first trial, which ended in a hung jury, nor in his second trial, which ended in him being sentenced to life in prison. A federal appeals court overturned the conviction. Miller, the only FBI agent ever charged with betraying his country, did testify in pretrial hearings, which Takasugi will consider as evidence, Levine said. The portly Miller, who had chronic money problems, was arrested in 1984 and charged with passing documents to Svetlana Ogorodnikov in exchange for sex, an overcoat and promises of $50,000 in gold and $15,000 in cash. He was a member of the Los Angeles FBI office counterintelligence unit at the time. Levine said he would argue that Miller's auditory dyslexia makes his statements to FBI interrogators questionable. ``I've told the truth and I always have,'' Miller said during a pretrial hearing. ``I did not give anybody any documents.'' Levine also declined to call to the stand Miller's two alleged Soviet contacts, Ms. Ogorodnikov and her husband, Nikolai Ogorodnikov. The couple pleaded guilty to espionage charges. The husband has finished his prison term, but the wife remains in prison. Earlier, Miller's lawyers requested deportation of Ogorodnikov be delayed so he could be called as a witness. Levine said Friday that he wasn't needed to testify.

DOC.HEAD: Outbreak of Legionnaires' Disease Restricts VA Heart Transplants
DOC.TEXT: An outbreak of Legionnaires' disease has forced doctors to temporarily stop performing heart transplants at one of just three veterans' hospitals that perform such surgery, officials said Friday. Two heart recipients at the Salt Lake VA Medical Center have gotten the disease, the Department of Veterans Affairs announced. VA spokesman Warren Longley said patients awaiting transplant surgery at the Salt Lake VA hospital may be referred to one of two other Utah hospitals for the operation. ``We want it made clear there won't be any delay should an organ become available,'' he said. Longley said the patients apparently became infected after taking drugs to prevent organ rejection. The drugs suppress the immune system, making patients more to infection, he said. One of the patients, identified by family members as William ``Tink'' Badget, of Sheridan, Wyo., was listed in critical condition following a transplant earlier this week. Officials withheld the name of the second patient. Badget's family said he was showing no signs of rejecting the new heart but that the Lgionnaires' infection was compromising his respiratory system. Legionnaires' disease got its name from a 1976 outbreak at an American Legion convention in Philadelphia. The sometimes-fatal disease is caused by a common bacteria that grows in water, including that in air-conditioning ducts. Longley said the second patient suffered a mild infection and had recovered both from the illness and the transplant. He was expected to be discharged over the weekend. Only two other VA hospitals perform heart transplants, in Richmond, Va., and Chicago, Longley said. Longley said doctors have not yet determined where the infection at the VA originated.

DOC.HEAD: Renegade Colonel Surrenders After Rebellion Fails
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with arrest of Noble's chief civilian ally, INSERT new 4th graf; EDITS thereafter to conform. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CGO2-3, MLA3,5
DOC.TEXT: A renegade colonel who led a revolt on the Philippines' second-largest island surrendered Saturday, ending the seventh military rebellion crushed during President Corazon Aquino's four-year rule. Mrs. Aquino had refused to negotiate with the rebels and promised to crush them. Col. Alexander Noble surrendered unconditionally at 3 a.m. t Sen. Aquilino Pimentel on Mindanao island, said Pimentel and military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa. Brig. Gen. Emiliano Templo, a military spokesman, said Noble's chief civilian ally, Reuben Canoy, had also been arrested. Canoy is leader of the Mindanao Independence Movement and joined Noble in proclaiming self-rule for the island. Pimentel said he would bring Noble, 42, to Manila later Saturday and turn him over to the military. Government troops were rounding up Noble's followers ``group by group,'' de Villa said. ``The small disruption in northern Mindanao is over,'' he said. ``We have recovered the camps that they seized. We are normalizing the conditions in these two cities.'' There was no immediate comment from Mrs. Aquino. Officials said she was notified shortly after Noble gave up. In Cagayan de Oro, 500 miles south of Manila, a grim-faced Noble claimed his objectives of drawing attention to problems of Mindanao had been achieved. ``At least the basic issues can be resolved peacefully,'' Noble told reporters. ``It's a good pattern for everyone for national reconciliation.'' Noble and his forces launched their rebellion early Thursday, seizing military camps in Butuan and Cagayan de Oro and proclaiming independencefor Mindanao. De Villa said Noble's followers in Butuan, 70 miles east of Cagayan de Oro, had surrendered. The report could not be immediately confirmed. De Villa said Noble and another renegade officer, Lt. Col. Victor Erfe, tried to slip out of Camp Evangelista, headquarters of the 4th Infantry Division, before dawn Saturday but changed their minds and surrendered to Pimentel. Local officials said Noble gave up after several hours of negotiations. About 2 a.m., Noble telephoned Pimentel and said he was ready to surrender, local reporters said. Pimentel sent a car to pick up Noble, and Noble's troops then filed out two-by-two in civilian clothes, witnesses said. In Manila, Col. Juanito Rimando said about 150 of Noble's troops had been taken into custody as of midmorning. Officials had estimated Noble had about 300 troops and up to 600 civilians with him. De Villa said he had been contacted by the division commander, Brig. Gen. Miguel Sol. Sol disappeared soon after the takeover and was ``temporarily'' relieved. De Villa quoted Sol as saying he had ``escaped'' Noble's troops and wanted to return to government control. Pimentel, a former mayor of Cagayan de Oro, flew to the city on Friday to offer himself as a negotiator to end the crisis. During a radio interview, Pimentel said he would accompany Noble to Manila later Saturday and that the colonel would be handed over to military authorities. ``They want me to continue their cause for Mindanao, which is for the national government to give enough attention,'' Pimentel said. ``I don't see anything wrong with that.'' Military officials here suspected that Noble's goal was not independence for Mindanao but to create a diversion. They suspected that Noble wanted to force the government to deploy troops from Manila. Military dissidents would then strike in the capital and try to topple the government. Troops were placed on full alert in Manila and garrisons in the capital were reinforced. But there was no sign of any unusual troop movements here. It appeeared that Noble gave up after realizing that his mutiny had not led to any general uprising on Mindanao or in the Manila area. Earlier Friday, about 150 elite Scout Rangers from the 23rd Infantry Battalion in the Mindanao city of Iligan had declared their allegiance to Noble. Local journalists said the Rangers joined the revolt because of an air raid Thursday on their garrison. Military officials said government planes fired on the camp while attacking and destroying a rebel helicopter. Late Friday, the mutinous rangers left their camp and marched to the heart of Iligan, where they planned to camp overnight. Government forces did not attempt to stop them to avoid a firefight in the industrial center. Earlier in the day, Noble offered to negotiate with the Aquino government and met later for about 90 minutes with local clerics. Mrs. Aquino's administration has come under increasing criticism for failure to provide basic services and to maintain law and order. Noble was formerly chief of staff of Mrs. Aquino's guard force, but he turned against her and joined a coup attempt last December. He later fled to the jungles of northern Mindanao, where he organized a private army of Higoanon tribesmen. Noble said he wanted talks with the Moro National Liberation Front, a Moslem guerrilla group that has been waging a 20-year-old struggle for self-rule. Mindanao is the home of the 5 million member Moslem community in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Higher Than Expected Rate of AIDS Infection Through Oral Sex
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents, particularly grafs 8-10.
DOC.TEXT: A new analysis of the sexual behavior of dozens of men infected with the AIDS virus has implicated oral sex between men as a greater risk than many scientists had assumed. The researchers looked at 82 men at three continuing San Francisco Bay area studies who tested positive for HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. Of the 82, 17 percent reported they engaged in oral sex and no other behavior that carries a high risk of catching AIDS. ``Oral sex was not implicated as a major risk factor in previous studies,'' one of the primary researchers, Warren Winkelstein, said Friday. ``What this study does is show pretty clearly that it is a strong risk factor. ``We've always pointed out that oral sex was a potential risk. Now, we've confirmed it,'' added Winkelstein, professor of epidemiology at the University of California at Berkeley's School of Public Health. Kent Taylor, spokesman for the federal Centers for Disease Control, said the findings were important. ``We're looking for more information on the transmission by way of oral sex because not a lot has been documented in this area,'' Taylor said. ``I would say this is a very interesting finding. This is obviously a very difficult topic to research.'' Epidemiologist Michael Samuel, who presented the analysis this week at the American Public Health Association annual meeting in New York City, said the men analyzed became infected between 1984 and 1990. More than half of the 82 men engaged in receptive and insertive anal intercourse and receptive and insertive oral sex, according to the study. Thirty-four percent didn't engage in anal receptive intercourse - which is known to carry a high risk of AIDS transmission - but did participate in at least one of the other three behaviors. And 17 percent of the infected men reported only oral intercourse, either receptive or insertive. Samuel said that the infection risk also was elevated with the use of a douche or enema before anal intercourse, countering a belief by some that such actions might decrease a chance of HIV infection. The data also confirmed findings of others studies: that ``the risk was unmistakably higher for those with two to four partners than for those with one partner.'' The new findings do not address the risks of oral sex between men and women. They also do not indicate how the AIDS virus was transmitted during the oral sex, or to what extent condoms or any other protective measures could have prevented infection. On Oct. 1, 1989, the San Francisco Health Department reported the first two documented cases in which men became infected with the AIDS virus through oral sex. Former Surgeon General C. Everett Kopp had warned four years before that oral sex might be a transmission path for the AIDS virus. But at the time health authorities and parts of the gay community were debating the issue. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring. As of August 146,746 have been diagnosed with AIDS in the United States since reporting began in 1981. As of Aug. 31, 89,761 deaths had been recorded.
Here is a statement of president Bush on the temporary budget resolution passed by Congress Friday night. The statement was read by Marlin Fitzwater, the president's spokesman.

The hour of reckoning is at hand. At midnight the Congress of the United States must face up to the shutdown of government services and resulting confusion that will be strewn across this land because we could not produce a budget. It is deeply discouraging that the governing bodies of this country would wrangle with the nation's fiscal affairs for nearly a year and fail. Tonight, because there is no budget, the United States government under existing law does not have the authority to continue operations, and I will not be a party to the process that would once again put off meeting its responsibilities for a few more days. I will not sign the continuing resolution passed by the House and Senate tonight, which simply delays once again the most serious constitutional responsibilities of government, to manage the people's money. At midnight tonight our national parks and monuments will close. Cleanup at hazardous waste sites will cease. Social Security offices will accept no new applications. Border inspections will be delayed. In one agency after another, thousands of federal employees would no longer be able to serve public tasks necessary for the public good. The people of America did not send their representatives to Washington to produce these consequences. As I said in my inaugural address, they did not send us here to bicker, and tonight I challenge the Congress to act as quickly as possible to produce an acceptable budget. Don't wait for people to lose confidence in their government. Act now, tomorrow, as soon as possible to produce a budget that reduces the deficit, avoids recession and puts our economy on the path of sustained growth. I stand ready to work with the members of Congress and to produce a responsible plan. After months of hard work we produced a budget agreement that would have cut a real 500 billion dollars off out deficit over the next five years. The White House and the Congressional leadership of the Democratic and Republican parties worked hard to put together that agree and put in place the largest deficit reduction in history. It's a sad commentary that the full House did not have the courage of those convictions. But surely the reality of a government closedown will convince everyone that a solution must be found. It is time to act responsibly on this problem and produce a fiscal 1991 budget.

DOC.HEAD: Student Activists Willing To Compromise In 10-Day UDC Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top five grafs new with word protest will end; picks up 6th graf: ``Operations at,''
DOC.TEXT: A student leader at the University of the District of Columbia Friday said students would end their 10-day protest and occupation of a campus office building. Mark Thompson, spokesman for the protesting students, said the Board of Trustees had agreed to msot of their demands. Earlier, he said students might be open to compromise on their insistence that the 11 mayoral appointees to the university's 15-member board of trustees resign. ``There must be at least some personnel changes on the board if not all - if not immediately, then soon,'' Thompson said. The students will now propose a bill in the City Council to reorganize the board, he said. Operations at the 12,000-student school have been on hold since as many as 500 students barricaded themselves inside a campus building Sept. 26 and presented 44 demands, including improvements in academic and athletic programs. Most of the demands were granted early in the negotiations. Trustees and student leaders met early Friday, but gave differing accounts of whether an agreement was close. Earlier in the day, trustee Alonza Evans said the board made additional concessions to the students in an attempt to end the standoff at the Student Affairs Building. Those included a public apology by trustee Richard Gross for remarks made during negotiations that students said belittled the school and a meeting with the city's new mayor after Election Day to discuss university problems. Students said five board members had resigned by Wednesday, but university spokesman John Britton said that number had been reduced to three by Thursday afternoon. A. Knighton Stanley withdrew his resignation, and Britton said student reports that trustee Herbert O. Reid had agreed to resign were incorrect. Stanley offered his resignation again Friday, however.

DOC.HEAD: Austria at Turning Point in Europe, But Campaign Turns Inward
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Austria is searching for a new role in Europe with the fall of the Iron Curtain and rise of a united Germany, but campaigning for parliamentary elections Sunday has focused on domestic issues and mudslinging. Emerging populist and environmental parties could deal the worst blow to the main Socialist and Peoples' parties since the republic's formation in 1945. The Socialists, in government since 1970, have been hurt by a series of corruption scandals. Several of their officials have tampered with public funds, and alleged cover-ups from the past are now in the courts. Former Socialist Chancellor Fred Sinowatz was recently found guilty of perjury. The conservative Peoples' Party, which joined the Socialists in a coalition after the last elections in 1986, has suffered because its leadership is often perceived as weak. The Peoples' Party, headed by Vice-Chancellor Josef Riegler, also still bears the burden of its support four years ago for President Kurt Waldheim, who is accused of concealing his World War II past. Waldheim is not a major issue in the campaign, however. The opposition parties stand to gain from the weakness of the governing coalition. The right-leaning Freedom Party, under populist leader Joerg Haider, has garnered considerable support in recent years, gaining strongly in regional elections. Haider, 40, hopes to win more than 20 percent of the vote. In 1986, the Freedom Party won 9.7 percent of the vote for 18 of the 183 seats. The Green-Alternative Party, holding eight seats in Parliament, hopes to double its mandate. It has been among the most critical of Haider, with one Green leader, Peter Pilz, calling Haider's party a mixture of ``right-radical and populist-opportunist.'' The Socialists now have 80 seats and the Peoples' Party 77. The Socialists, who in opinion polls are just ahead of the Peoples' Party, have categorically excluded coalition with Haider, who has relentlessly criticized the government. Some in the Peoples' Party have hinted at a coalition with the Freedom Party if it draws votes away from the big parties. Riegler himself, however, has ruled out governing with Haider. According to pollsters, an unusually high 25 percent of voters were undecided or determined not to vote about two weeks before the election. With the governing parties on the defensive, the campaign has been marked by mutual accusations and name-calling. A Peoples' Party poster with a photo of a yawning hippopotamus says, ``Mouthing off is not enough,'' a reference to Haider's repeated criticism. Haider turned the hippopotamus to advantage at a recent rally. ``Where would we be if we hadn't opened our mouths in the last four years?'' Haider asked an approving Vienna crowd. Besides, he said, a hippopotamus ``has the ability to become extremely old and survive all others.'' In a televised debate 10 days before the election, Socialist Chancellor Franz Vranitzky and conservative leader Riegler also exchanged barbs. The Socialist Party campaigned heavily on the merits of Vranitzky, a charismatic 50-year-old whose background in banking and performance as chancellor endear him to many Austrians. Riegler scathingly compared the Socialists to a store vendor saying, ``Don't look at my goods, but I have a very attractive salesperson.'' Vranitzky charged Riegler was unable to coordinate a clear line on major issues. Haider has struck more emotional chords. A Freedom Party poster in the capital cries: ``Vienna must not become Chicago,'' a reference to rising crime that many Austrians believe is perpetrated by immigrants. The government last month imposed visa restrictions for Poles and sent troops to the open border with Hungary in an attempt to cut down on illegal immigration and black market labor. Haider has urged tougher measures since East Europeans have been allowed to travel freely. Campaigning in Vienna, Haider earned applause when he admonished Eastern Europeans: ``What was valid for our parents and grandparents must also be valid in Eastern Europe. In 1945, we also had nothing and had to work. So work hard and build it up again.'' While other parties have preferred to chart a new European course for Austria after the elections, Haider has demanded an end to restrictions imposed on the country by the victorious Allies in World War II. Among those restrictions are arms sales and other trade with Germany, which under Hitler had annexed an independent Austria in 1938.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Begins Fueling Discovery for Saturday Morning Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with fueling underway, no leaks immediately found; picks up 7th graf pvs, ``The mood...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB1
DOC.TEXT: NASA workers loaded rocket fuel on space shuttle Discovery Friday, preparing the craft for a Saturday morning launch of the spacecraft carrying the nuclear-powered solar probe Ulysses. Pumping more than half a million gallons of liquid hydrogen and oxygen into the fuel tank was a critical test of the shuttle's rocket plumbing system. Fuel leaks earlier caused four launch scrubs in Discovery's sister ships, but officials said no leaks were immediately found Friday night. Discovery was scheduled to lift off at 7:35 a.m. Saturday. ``Everything is going according to plan,'' said NASA spokesman Dick Young. Earlier Friday, a judge rejected a petition by anti-nuclear activists who wanted to prevent NASA from launching the nuclear-powered Ulysses. The action, in a Washington federal court, cleared the way for launch preparations to continue. Two demonstrators opposed to the radioactive cargo on Discovery were arrested Friday morning at the Kennedy Space Center. Six hours after launch, Discovery's five-man crew was scheduled to release Ulysses from the shuttle cargo bay. The probe is designed to rocket itself out of Earth orbit for a roundabout voyage that eventually will enable it to study the unexplored polar regions of the sun. Young said Discovery's mission would be unaffected by any government shutdown resulting from the federal budget dispute. He said funds for the mission had already been set aside and notices had gone out that all employees were to report to work. ``The mood of the team is confident and that's despite distractions and disappointments recently,'' said launch director Robert B. Sieck. ``If the weather is good to us, we'll have some good news'' on Saturday. For NASA, the news has been mostly bad since the last successful shuttle launch in April. The agency has scrubbed four shuttle launch attempts because of hydrogen fuel leaks and learned that there is a serious flaw in the Hubble space telescope. Another problem was added to the list Thursday when workers discovered that a 9-foot, 70-pound metal beam had been left in the engine compartment of the shuttle Atlantis. When the craft was hoisted from a horizontal to a vertical position, the beam clanked around inside the compartment, causing up to 25 dents and dings. None of the damage was believed serious, Sieck said, and Atlantis is still scheduled for a mission in November. The beam is normally used to support a work platform used when the shuttle is being processed on the ground. William Lenoir, boss of NASA's spaceflight program, said the problems are isolated incidents and not signs of the agency's decline. ``I don't see a common thread that connects the Hubble incident, the hydrogen leaks, and the beam,'' Lenoir said at a news conference. A group of 20 demonstrators gathered at a restricted entrance to the space center Friday morning and protested Ulysses' nuclear power supply. They milled around the gate, waving signs and calling to space center employees driving in to work. Two women from the group were taken into custody after they walked past a checkpoint into a restricted area. They were charged with trespassing. In Washington, D.C., a judge rejected a petition by three activist groups that sought to block Discovery's launch with its nuclear-powered payload. They asked for more research into the risks of the spread of radioactive materials should Discovery explode during launch. U.S. District Judge Oliver Gasch rejected the contention, just as he did for a similar claim filed last year before the launch of Galileo, which also was nuclear powered. Ulysses is powered by a radioisotope thermoelectric generator, or RTG, which generates electricity from the heat of 23.7 pounds of highly radioactive plutonium. The United States has used 22 RTGs on earlier space missions, including five moon flights. NASA says the plutonium is housed in a module that has been tested to withstand any probable accident. The agency estimated that in the worst possible accident, there is only a 1-in-44 million chance of 14.5 cancer fatalities over 50 years. After Ulysses is released from Discovery, a two-stage rocket will fire and send the European-built craft streaking toward Jupiter. Ulysses will loop over Jupiter's north pole in 1992 and the giant planet's intense gravity will give it a powerful burst of speed and hurl it back toward the sun's south pole. In 1994, Ulysses will pass within 120 million miles of the sun's south pole and about 18 months later it will pass over the solar north pole. Discovery's commander is Richard N. Richards. The pilot will be Robert D. Cabana. Others in the crew are William M. Shepherd, Bruce Melnick, and Thomas D. Akers.

A dozen more crimes would be subject to the federal death penalty and executions would be carried out more quickly, under amendments approved by law and order-minded House members. ``I hope we never bring up another crime bill a month before an election,'' Rep. William Hughes, D-N.J., said Thursday as the House bowed to conservative demands for a major reshaping of the measure. John McCain, R-Ariz., and John Glenn, D-Ohio, be dropped from the investigation. ---= HARARE, Zimbabwe (AP) - The small central African nation of Rwanda faced a population and ecological crisis even before it was invaded this week by armed refugees from neighboring Uganda. Western experts say more than 50 families of mainly Indian and Pakistani origin have left Rwanda in recent months in search of fresh opportunities in neighboring Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire - countries also suffering from poverty, disease and violence. DOC.HEAD: CAGAYAN DE ORO, Philippines: SUBS 4th item pvs, `Government forces...' to UPDATE with reported rebel surrender.
DOC.TEXT: A renegade colonel who led a revolt on the Philippines' second-largest island surrendered after trying to leave the military garrison he seized two days earlier, the military chief said Saturday. Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa said Col. Alexander Noble surrendered unconditionally at 3 a.m. to Sen. Aquilino Pimentel, after he and a companion tried unsuccessfully to slip out of Camp Evangelista in Cagayan de Oro, 500 miles south of here. De Villa said government troops were rounding up Noble's followers ``group by group'' and that the situation in Cagayan de Oro had returned to normal. De Villa also said Noble's followers in Butuan, 70 miles east of Cagayan de Oro, had surrendered. The report could not be immediately confirmed. Noble and his forces launched their rebellion early Thursday, seizing military camps in Butuan and Cagayan de Oro and proclaiming independence for Mindanao, the country's second largest island.

DOC.TEXT: A renegade colonel who led a revolt on the Philippines' second-largest island surrendered Saturday after trying to sneak out of the military garrison he seized two days earlier. It was the seventh military rebellion smashed during President Corazon Aquino's 4{-year-old government. Mrs. Aquino had refused to negotiate with the rebels and promised to crush them. Col. Alexander Noble, 42, surrendered unconditionally to Sen. Aquilino Pimentel on Mindanao island, said Pimentel and military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa. Pimentel said he would turn Noble over to the military in Manila. Government troops were rounding up Noble's followers ``group by group,'' de Villa said. ``The small disruption in northern Mindanao is over,'' he said. ``We have recovered the camps that they seized. We are normalizing the conditions in these two cities.''

DOC.HEAD: IN THE SPIRIT OF HITCHCOCK: Yuppie Mayhem and Icebox Logic
DOC.TEXT: John Schlesinger lately has been thinking a lot about Alfred Hitchcock. Actually, he hasn't had much choice. Schlesinger's latest film, ``Pacific Heights,'' is a psychological thriller with irresistible connections to the master of suspense himself. Questions are bound to arise. Based on a true story, ``Pacific Heights'' stars Melanie Griffith and Matthew Modine as a young couple who purchase a large Victorian house in San Francisco and plan to rent rooms on the ground floor. But they are nearly ruined when smooth-talking Carter Hayes (Michael Keaton) occupies one apartment and refuses to pay, manipulating the legal system so Griffith and Modine end up on the wrong side of the law. Hitchcock would have loved it. He specialized in making a little mayhem with ``ordinary'' lives, turning an advertising executive into a fugitive in ``North by Northwest'' and placing a dead body in a small New England town in ``The Trouble With Harry.'' There's more. Schlesinger gave a minor role to Tippi Hedren, Griffith's mother and the star of two Hitchcock films, ``The Birds'' and ``Marnie.'' He also makes a most Hitchcock-like cameo; Schlesinger's the heavy-set man with a white beard riding the elevator with Griffith. (In Hitchcock's ``Spellbound,'' the director is seen leaving an elevator at the same time as Gregory Peck.) Your defense, Mr. Schlesinger? ``I haven't made a study of his films in order to ape him,'' said the director, who has made some pretty fair movies himself, including ``Darling,'' ``Sunday, Bloody Sunday'' and the Academy Award-winning ``Midnight Cowboy.'' ``But what Hitchcock used to do quite often was take normal life, yuppie life, and from normalcy have something gradually creep up on you. And as a child I saw `The Lady Vanishes,' that wonderful film with Dame May Whitty, and was haunted by the image of a bandaged head. ``As far as the appearance, I used to appear in all my films, and then I said, `This is ridiculous, Hitchcock did this all the time,' so I stopped.'' Schlesinger fans will spot some of the director's own touches in ``Pacific Heights,'' a sense of understatement, an insistence that all ends remain loose, and an ever-observant camera that cases a room, item by item, like an electronic house detective. ``I like the idea of using a camera to tell the story about people,'' he said. ``My doctor in London, you can barely go sit in his consulting room because it's filled with frogs, little funny things hanging from the ceiling. There's a scene in a lawyer's office. I thought why not make the lawyer collect frogs and introduce her with that image.'' Schlesinger, born in London in 1926, was a character actor for stage, film and televison and also made documentaries; ``Terminus'' won the Golden Lion for best documentary at the 1961 Venice Film Festival. The following year he established himself as one of England's finest young directors with ``A Kind of Loving'' and then made ``Billy Liar'' and ``Darling,'' for which Julie Christie won an Academy Award for best actress in 1965. He also managed to top Hitchcock, who never won an Oscar, by receiving one in 1969 for ``Midnight Cowboy.'' His theory of directing: Life is double-edged and movies should be, too. No Schlesinger film ends with a couple walking hand-in-hand into the sunset (if it did, he'd probably make them escaped convicts) or a guy with flowers arriving on top of a car, as in a certain popular romantic comedy. ``When I first heard about `Pretty Woman' I said, `Ugh.' But it's a very well-confected film. . . . I had a good time. ``If I've ever had any commercial success, it's been a total fluke. I wouldn't have known `Midnight Cowboy' would have done so well.'' Schlesinger doesn't condemn ``Pretty Woman'' because he's also been guilty of relegating reality to a supporting role. In ``Marathon Man,'' a 1976 thriller with Laurence Olivier and Dustin Hoffman, a vicious Nazi (Olivier) risks going to the Jewish quarter in New York in search of diamonds. Great action, Schlesinger notes, but unnecessary - he didn't have to go to the Jewish quarter to find about the diamonds. And in the middle of ``Pacific Heights,'' Modine overhears Keaton discussing his con game and has the incriminating evidence he's been hoping for. But Modine doesn't act on it, and fails to tell police or his lawyer. ``It would have ended the film,'' laughed Schlesinger, who in his defense again summoned the spirit of poor Mr. Hitchcock. ``There's an expression applied to Hitchcock's films called `icebox logic.' Icebox logic is as long as the film plays for the audience as they're seeing it, it doesn't matter if they go home and later, when they open the fridge to get out the milk,' say to themselves, `Now wait a moment, why did they do this?' ''

DOC.HEAD: Molestation Case Becomes TV Movie
DOC.TEXT: You wouldn't be wrong if you thought today's tragedy is tomorrow's TV movie. Producers commonly scour newspapers, magazines and TV news shows, seeking fare for ``fact-based'' flicks. Whatever happened to what you might call ``fiction-based'' TV movies? They exist, but viewers are more interested in the other kind, says producer Steve Tisch, who has made both: ``And selfishly, networks are more interested in true stories. It's almost a joke, but if they can say `Based on a true story,' they feel it gives them three or four (more) ratings points.'' Tisch should know. He co-produced ``The Burning Bed,'' a 1984 NBC movie based on the true story involving wife-beating. The fourth highest-rated TV movie in history, it got a 52 percent share of the audience. Now he has ``Judgment,'' another true-story dramatization. Premiering Saturday on cable's Home Box Office, it's written and directed by Tom Topor, a former New York reporter and author of the Broadway drama ``Nuts.'' ``Judgment'' is about a Louisiana couple whose son was among a number of young boys sexually molested by their parish priest. (The real priest pleaded guilty to 11 criminal counts and was sentenced to 20 years in prison). Played by Keith Carradine and Blythe Danner, the couple, devout Catholics, refused the Catholic Church's offer of a secret financial settlement that the other parents were willing to accept. In the film, the couple also wants the priest sent to prison. The local district attorney balks, explaining that a conviction is unlikely. But he refers them to an old friend, a veteran trial lawyer played by Jack Warden. They sue the church, accusing it of concealing information about the priest's past history of child molestation. As their attorney explains things, he wins the civil case and then, ``I take the transcript of the trial to the D.A. He goes to trial, he wins.'' While ``fact-based'' films may get the ratings, they sometimes can backfire for a network, if only in terms of the network's image. Case in point: ``Good Night, Sweet Wife: A Murder in Boston,'' a CBS movie that aired last month. The movie dramatized a headline-making tragedy last year in which a pregnant woman, Carol Stuart, was shot dead. Her husband, Charles, later apparently committed suicide. The dead woman's family sharply criticized CBS, saying the film set a ``dangerous precedent'' that could sacrifice the privacy of other grieving families for the sake of profits. Such criticism is unlikely to happen with ``Judgment,'' for several reasons. Tisch's previous TV films generally have drawn praise for their taste and responsibility, and, he said, the couple depicted in ``Judgment'' wanted their story told and ``enthusiastically allowed us to make the movie.'' Their one restriction: Their real names weren't to be used. Unlike the families in the CBS movie, the Louisiana couple also was paid for rights to their story, although Tisch said they had no say in how the story was told. He declined to say how much they were paid. With ``fact-based'' TV movies so rampant, Hollywood's producers may seem like the new version of ambulance chasers, rushing minions to the scenes of nationally publicized crimes and tragedies to snap up the movie rights even before the victims' tears dry. But Tisch didn't go after the story of the Louisiana couple. It was brought to him, he said, by a CBS News producer, Rob Hershman. The TV journalist had first done the story as a segment on CBS' fast-paced, now-defunct ``West 57th'' series. Hershman, who still works for CBS News, is getting a co-producer's credit on ``Judgment.'' Tisch's other efforts range from the successful Tom Cruise sleeper hit of 1983, ``Risky Business,'' to ABC's acclaimed but short-lived series ``Call to Glory'' to last year's CBS bomb, ``Dirty Dancing.'' Television movies have occupied a large part of his career, but more are based on fiction than fact, said Tisch, a nephew of CBS president Laurence A. Tisch. ``I would say that of the 14 or so television movies I'd done, maybe four or five have been based on true stories,'' he said. ``Yes, they get ratings. Yes, people are interested in watching true stories. But I've always taken the position that I'm going to be morally responsible, and in my movies educate as well as entertain.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... CELLO THERE, AMERICA: ``CBS This Morning'' co-anchor Paula Zahn, a classical cellist, will play a duet Thursday morning with the noted cellist Yo Yo Ma. Zahn, a fine musician, appeared with her cello earlier this year on NBC's ``Late Night With David Letterman.'' After a few bars of a classical piece, she suddenly shifted into a sly version of the Beatles' ``Day Tripper.'' Alas, the show cut to a commercial just as she really got rolling ...

DOC.HEAD: South African Hostels: Dirty, Dreary Beds of Violence
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Muzi is a Zulu in alien territory, a migrant in a settled township, and needs no time to think when asked what he hates most about living in a workers' hostel. ``Everything is bad,'' he said. ``There's no privacy, even in the toilets. Nothing's being done.'' He sat on one of four beds in a dark concrete-block room beneath a roof of corrugated metal, a stocky, bearded man with his arms wrapped across his chest. Grease and dirt stained the floor and walls. A lone electric wire stretched overhead. ``Staying here, you end up drinking,'' Muzi said. ``I'm so tired of waiting.'' The squalid hostels, long a source of many social ills, have become flash points of political violence that has killed nearly 800 blacks in townships around Johannesburg since Aug. 12. Many of the vicious street clashes have pitted hostel dwellers, usually Zulus like Muzi, against township residents from other tribes. Most of the Zulus support the conservative Inkatha movement based in their homeland in Natal province, and many township residents support the African National Congress. Even South Africa's white government, architect of the apartheid system that spawned the hostels, has called for change. President F.W. de Klerk visited a Soweto hostel in September and, standing in a urine-stained hall, said the conditions were unacceptable. Officials have suggested converting some hostels to family dwellings, but no action has been taken. More than 130 hostels housing nearly 200,000 people dot the 31 black townships around Johannesburg. Muzi, who is 32 and has two children, is one of countless blacks who for decades have left their families in impoverished rural areas to seek work in Johannesburg, the financial hub of South Africa. He would not reveal his last name. Apartheid laws made the move difficult, requiring a migrant to obtain a job first in order to live in an urban township. Most restrictions were repealed in the 1980s, but overcrowding in the townships has left migrant workers little choice but to live in the cramped, single-sex dormitories without heat or indoor plumbing. Miserable living conditions combined with tribal and political rivalries encourage fighting. ``The evil migrant labor system . . . lies at the root of the current conflict,'' said a group of national church leaders, including Desmond Tutu, the black Anglican archbishop who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize. Other observers say it's more complicated. John Kane-Berman, head of the respected Institute of Race Relations, a private organization, said personal disputes, political and tribal differences, human nature and poor living conditions contribute to the violence. ``It's a lot of different factors, and one might not be aware of them,'' he said. For example, rooms in many hostels are segregated by tribe. If a man has a fight with someone from another room and his friends get involved, he said, a personal dispute has the appearance of tribal fighting. He insisted that tribal differences play a role, despite statements to the contrary by black leaders. ``It's not fashionable in liberal circles to talk about black ethnic rivalry because the government used that argument as part of its divisive strategy,'' he said. Kane-Berman said township residents look down on the poorly educated rural workers, creating class differences, and the frustration and danger of hostel life compound the problems. More than 5,000 people live in some hostels, like Jabulani and Merafe in Soweto. Residents pay monthly rent of about $6 for a bed in a room that usually is shared by with at least three others. Many turn to prostitutes, alcohol and drugs while away from their families. ``The compounds are a social disaster, not only in terms of separating breadwinners from families, but in terms of the psychological strains placed on the workers in them,'' Jerry Majatladi, spokesman for the National Union of Mineworkers, told the Star newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: The Bottom Line Discipline
DOC.TEXT: An immense difference exists between the techniques and procedures for cutting expenses in private industry and cutting them in government. The products and services are different, of course, and the method of doing business is, too. While the private sector is profit-seeking the government is a not-for-profit organization, and it almost always achieves that goal. But there is an even vaster difference, one that involves the recognition of reality. Governent budget cutters tend to shirk from the task, even to evade or fudge the issues. Should a business do that it would go bankrupt. Businesses have indeed gone under after futile attempts to hide from the realities. In the end, the bottom line always catches up to them. The banks shut them off. Creditors bring them to court and mete out the remains. Governments aren't like that; they persist. Some Third World nations owe more money than they can count, and the same might even be said about the U.S. government. Some budget ``agreement'' numbers had a strange appearance. The budget cut package assumed, for example, that long-term interest rates might fall to 5.3 percent, a level unseen since 1967, and that short-term rates might decline to 4.2 percent, which would be a post-1972 record low. Questionable assumptions also were made about economic growth, that the rate would nearly double over the next year and exceed even that pace in 1991 and 1992. Considering taxes would be higher, that scenario was suspect. Some of the devices used in cutting government budgets could never exist in the private sector, such as tossing certain expenses off the books, throwing them ``off budget.'' Business could never get away with writing off a creditor. Neither could the management of a business ever convince shareholders and directors that it was really cutting to the bone when it was merely cutting the rate of previous spending projections. The budget summitteers did that. Businesses all over the country are cutting these days. Some are doing so because they fear a recession is under way and might get worse, and others, such as Chase Manhattan Bank, are cutting simply to exist. The choices for private-sector firms are painful but unavoidable; they must close plants and lay off workers. Some companies, in fact, are choosing to shrink themselves on a more permanent basis. They are abandoning product lines and selling off divisions, retreating to their basic core of expertise - back to their original self. Government could never do this. Its customers simply would never let it happen. Should it make the attempt, its elected officials and directors would lose their jobs as quickly as voters could make their way to the polls. In short, the marketplace makes business relatively honest. The bottom line is an impartial disciplinarian, one that doesn't forgive and seldom tolerates excuses. While it has been known to miss some crooks and charlatans, usually it steps right in and slaps down fuzzy thinkers and financial tinkerers. Yes, it can be bent through creative accounting and tax loopholes, but compared to political accounting it is inflexible. It is where the buck stops, and that seems not to be the way of politics. A public-sector official, therefore, might find anything like a bottom line an intolerable intrusion, a dangerous presence, an infringement on style to be enacted out of existence.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday, October 8.
