DOC.HEAD: Food, Gas Shortages Plague Caribbean Nation; Protests Mount
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Francia Martinez stood in line for rice, beans and flour. She wanted sugar, too, but knew there would be none of that sweet staple. Sugar, the foundation of this Caribbean nation's economy for 400 years, is gone from store shelves. It is being shipped to foreign buyers, who pay more than Dominicans can afford. ``Nobody understands what's going on in this country,'' said Freddy Sanchez, waiting in a nearby gas station line that was four blocks long. ``Prices go up, but we're still short.'' Mrs. Martinez, taking shelter from the midday sun under a black umbrella, said she was ``lacking everything at home'' for her husband and three children. Rising consumer prices and shortages of gasoline, food, electricity - even water - are causing hardships and widespread protest among the Dominican Republic's 7 million people. Two nationwide protest strikes since August have led to violence between security forces and demonstrators in which at least 14 people have been killed and 90 wounded. Police report 2,300 arrests, but strike leaders say the number is higher. A few days before a strike in September, three Santo Domingo university students were killed by the explosion of a bomb they were making on campus. Police found an arsenal of explosives in Santiago, the second-largest city. Protest began when President Joaquin Balaguer imposed economic austerity shortly before beginning his second consecutive four-year term in August. He ended subsidies for such basic goods as flour, cooking oil and gasoline, causing prices to triple in some cases. Gasoline has risen since August from 55 cents a gallon to $1.42, with added help from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Balaguer's government could not afford the normal level of oil imports after the Persian Gulf crisis drove world prices up, so it began importing about one-third less and rationed gasoline. ``There's no flour, sugar, gas, medicine because the country has no dollars, no foreign currency, no reserves,'' said Andres Dauhakre, a leading economist. ``Certainly the crisis in the Middle East doesn't help.'' Economic problems have mounted since world sugar prices collapsed and U.S. import quotas were cut in the 1980s. Last year's crop was smaller than usual. The Dominican Republic, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti, has a foreign debt of $4.1 billion. By conservative estimates 28 percent of its workers are jobless and annual inflation is 70 percent. A $500 million building spree largely tied to the 500th anniversary in 1992 of Columbus' discovery of America has created schools, roads, housing, irrigation dams and monuments, but the government has financed it by the inflationary means of printing money. Power plants have deteriorated from neglect, causing blackouts of up to 18 hours a day. Many homes and factories have their generators, but fuel shortages make them unreliable. Breakdowns of electric pumps cause water shortages. The International Monetary Fund demanded the austerity measures. Balaguer, 84 and blind from glaucoma, says they are necessary and has urged Dominicans to conserve. ``We have to use less gas, go out less, go to the beach less,'' he said recently. ``We must appeal to Dominican patriotism so that we can overcome this crisis.'' There is no current agreement with the IMF. Because the country could not pay interest on most of its debt in the past year, it is ineligible for loans and has no credit. Talks with the IMF are under way, but Dominicans are wary. The last IMF program in 1984 led to higher prices and riots that took 100 lives. Tourism, the really bright prospect, is expected to net $1 billion this year, but visitors may start choosing islands with fewer problems. Officials blame the unrest on supporters of leftist former President Juan Bosch, 81, whom Balaguer defeated by 1 percent of te vote in May. Jose Luis Arteaga, Balaguer's economic adviser, said: ``The opposition thinks the Balaguer government is illegitimate because of the elections. They want to make life impossible for us.'' Bosch accused Balaguer, his longtime political foe, of widespread vote fraud, but an independent electoral board said a lengthy review of voting tallies produced no evidence. Balaguer's narrow victory deprived his conservative Social Christian Reformist Party of a congressional majority and critics accuse him of ruling by decree. To soften the the austerity measures, the government gave public employees a 30 percent pay raise and froze some prices. The freezes have led to speculative buying, creating further shortages. Unions demand a 150 percent general raise. The minimum wage now is equivalent to $72 a month.

DOC.HEAD: Rise of Fundamentalists Worries Women's Movement
DOC.TEXT: The women's rights organization Khalida Massaoudi leads is the largest in this Moslem nation - 400 members in a total population of 26 million. Ms. Massaoudi, 32, worries that the shift to democracy will do nothing to end tyranny for Algerian women. Her fears deepen with each political advance by the fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front, known as the FIS. ``The biggest danger for us is if the FIS take power,'' said the soft-spoken teacher of high school mathematics. ``It will prolong the totalitarianism Algeria has already known too long.'' She said the Marxist revolutionaries who ruled Algeria unchallenged for 28 years had given the fundamentalists a ready-made framework for oppressing women under Islamic law. The National Liberation Front, or FLN, imposed one-party rule on Algeria after winning independence from France in 1962. Many FLN leaders were devout Moslems despite their Marxist phisosophy, and wrote into the constitution that Algeria would be an Islamic nation. Ms. Massaoudi said each member of her Independent Association for the Triumph of Women's Rights is a heroine in a society ``that has never made a gift to women.'' ``For the crushing majority of women in this country, the only world is the family,'' she said. Although barely 5 feet tall, Ms. Massaoudi stands out in her working-class neighborhood. She holds a job, lives alone, leaves her red hair uncovered and asks no man's permission to go out. Algeria's work force of 8 million includes only 380,000 women. Most of the rights leader's female neighbors cover themselves with long robes and scarves before leaving their houses, and nearly always are accompanied by another woman or a male relative. Women served in the National Liberation Front during the eight-year guerrilla war and Islamic tradition coexisted uneasily with Western concepts of women's rights during the first generation of independence. Women in Algiers and Oran wore skirts and trousers, but most rural women concealed themselves behind veils. Divided as it was between devout Moslems from rural areas and more secular leaders from the cities, the FLN sidestepped the issue of women's rights. Then, in 1984, the National Assembly passed the Family Law in response to pressure from Islamic fundamentalists. It was reformist in theory, restricting polygamy, giving women a say in educating their sons after age 10 and allowing women to initiate divorce proceedings. In practice, according to Ms. Massaoudi, law codified second-class status for women. One of its victims was a woman who would identify herself only as Keltoum. Her husband declared them divorced in January and threw Keltoum, 31, and their five children out of the house. He didn't need a court ruling. Under Islamic tradition guaranteed by the Family Law, Keltoum's husband divorced her simply by telling her the marriage was over. Had Keltoum sought a divorce, she would have had to prove in court that he had committed adultery or had not wanted children. ``I can't imagine saying such things before a judge,'' she said. ``No Algerian woman could.'' An electoral code passed in 1986 allows husbands to cast their wives' votes, which contributed to the sweeping municipal and regional election victory by fundamentalists in June. ``That law was the final stab in the back by the FLN,'' Ms. Massaoudi said. ``The FLN dug the grave for women and put them in it.'' The FLN has a women's wing, as do other parties, but they remain under the control of male hierarchies. President Chadli Bendjedid has proposed reforming the election law, but the fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front accuses him of bending the rules to help the FLN. With solid support among Algeria's swollen ranks of unemployed young men, the fundamentalists have the strongest party as the spring parliamentary elections approach. Most followers of the fundamentalist party favor separate education for males and females. ``The woman is sacred,'' said Dilinjer Boualem, 55. ``We want them to learn, to do medicine, as the (Islamic) law says. But mixing, this we are against. It is forbidden for Moslem people.'' On rights to work, they are more vague. An article in the Salvation Front's newspapr said women should work ``when necessity arises.'' ``The woman who goes to work and preserves her honor, modesty and purity, who honorably fulfills her task, then comes home as clean as she left . . . should not, in our humble opinion, be considered as having disobeyed the commandments of God,'' it said. One test of modesty is whether a woman wears the hijab, a scarf covering the head and neck. Increasing numbers of women, even in Algiers, are doing so because of religious conviction, social pressure or reasons of fashion. Others refuse, even those who will not speak to a Western journalist without permission from a male relative. Rhodia Belkacem, a 21-year-old secretary who binds her long black hair with gold combs, said: ``I could never go out in a hijab. Nobody's threatened me, but I'll never wear it, even if they kill me.''

DOC.HEAD: Bear Market Offspring: Tax Losses
DOC.TEXT: The news isn't all bad for stock-market investors these days. Just consider the bumper crop of potential capital-loss tax writeoffs the market decline of 1990 has produced. As a note of cheery reassurance, that may have a hollow ring. But a good many stock traders will be thinking along precisely those lines through the remainder of the year, seeking a chance to shift some of the burden of their ill fortune onto the shoulders of Uncle Sam. The basic rule they follow is that losses on financial investments - not just stocks, but also other securities like bonds and mutual-fund shares - can be deducted within limits against income when you fill out your tax return. First, a loss realized on a security sold during the year is used dollar for dollar to offset any capital gain you might have realized, such as on the sale of a stock. If you have losses that exceed your investment gains, they can normally be deducted against your other income up to a limit of $3,000. Net losses of more than $3,000 can be carried forward indefinitely to future years. Hence the annual exercise known on Wall Street as ``tax selling,'' in which investors juggle their portfolios to minimize the amounts they will owe the government. A generation ago, tax selling often was cited as a primary force behind the market's fluctuations in the closing weeks of a year. In recent years it has drawn less attention. That is partly due, analysts say, to the increasing dominance in the marketplace of investing institutions, such as pension funds, that are exempt from current taxation. In addition, there have been relatively few losses for investors to consider taking in most years of late, thanks to the mighty bull market of the 1980s. Even in 1987, when the market crashed in October, stocks wound up the year about where they started. Not so in 1990. Through the first three quarters of the year the Dow Jones industrial average was down about 11 percent, and some broader market measures showed losses twice that size. Thus many observers believe tax selling could put some extra pressure between now and mid- to late December on stocks such as the depressed bank issues and small ``growth'' companies that have been particularly poor performers to date. In their dealings with individual investors who are considering selling a losing investment to get the tax benefits, brokers generally advise them to act early and avoid the December rush. What if an investor wants to take a tax loss, but also wishes to keep his or her position in a stock, expecting better times ahead? To avoid a ``wash sale'' that invalidates any tax loss, you cannot sell the stock and buy it back within any 30-day period. Of course, selling in, say, mid-November and buying a stock back 31 days later exposes you to the risk of missing a sudden rally in the interim. An alternative strategy is to ``double up,'' buying an additional lot of the security first and selling the old investment at least 31 days later. ``Although this will enable you to maintain your original investment position, it will also double your risk for at least 31 days,'' points out the Consumer Reports annual Guide to Income Tax Preparation. ``Your decision should be based primarily on whether you want to own the stock, not on some perceived tax benefit that increases your risk. Otherwise, if the stock continues to drop, you have simply increased your loss.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Oct. 8

DOC.HEAD: Many Feel Budget Compromise Squeezed Farmers Too Much
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to update with budget rejection by House
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says he would oppose any attempt to increase his department's share of budget cuts, but farm leaders say that isn't enough. They are predicting that the $13 billion in cuts included in the deficit-reduction package rejected by the House last Thursday would send the farm economy into a tailspin. It was not immediately clear if any new budget agreement would make further cuts in the USDA budget. All of the $13 billion would have come out of Commodity Credit Corp. operations. The CCC is synonymous with commodity price supports - the arcane and expensive world of acreage reduction, loan rates, target prices and deficiency payments. Plainly, the budget plan would have cut federal subsidies to farmers, a major portion of annual income over many years. Although declining from a peak of $16.7 billion in 1987, those direct payments are expected to be around $9 billion this calendar year. The American Farm Bureau Federation sounded a complaint common among agriculture leaders. Farm programs, it said, account for less than 1 percent of the federal budget, yet the agreement requires those to absorb 10 percent of the total federal reduction. Dean Kleckner, federation president, also cited tax increases that he said would hurt agriculture. ``The proposed tax increases threaten to harm an already shaky economy,'' he said. ``That in itself is bad for agriculture, but the provisions affecting agriculture make matters worse.'' Among the proposed tax hikes was an increase of 12 cents per gallon on fuels, which Kleckner said would hurt rural people because they drive greater distances for services and have no public transportation alternatives. David Senter of the American Agriculture Movement said, ``In effect, farmers are going to lose a major part of their income due to this budget agreement.'' Other factors add to the impact of budget cutting on farmers, said Leland Swenson, president of the National Farmers Union. Grain prices are depressed and operating costs are rising because of the Mideast crisis and soaring prices of crude oil. The $13 billion slash in USDA programs would ``throw the farm sector into a tailspin'' financially, he said. Even Yeutter, who endorsed the package adopted by budget negotiators, recognized that the cuts would ``squeeze agriculture hard'' and that there would have to be a lot of belt-tightening. Yeutter said the House defeat of the plan on Thursday night made USDA programs ``even more vulnerable to cuts than before.'' He said the House vote was a ``betrayal of political responsibility'' to do something about the deficit. ``I will strongly resist any efforts to cut agricultural expenditures further in any future budget agreements,'' he said. An irony in all this is the general improvement in the financial health of U.S. agriculture in the last few years. Yeutter, in a Sept. 24 letter to Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, said the expiring 1985 farm law helped the farm sector rebound from the doldrums of the early 1980s. Farm equity, or net worth, bottomed out at $552 billion in 1986, he said. It's now estimated at $688 billion, which he called a ``truly spectacular'' improvement of $136 billion in four years. Yeutter said farm debt, which peaked at $193 billion in 1982, has been clipped to $127 billion in eight years. ``That puts American agriculture in a much better position to deal with the economic shocks of the coming decade, including the ones we've felt in recent weeks,'' he said. The purpose of Yeutter's letter to Leahy was to note the challenges ahead and urge the chairman ``to design farm legislation accordingly'' as Senate and House conferees work out compromises for the 1990 farm bill. Meanwhile, USDA economists are trying to decipher what may happen to farm income in 1991 after being at record or near-record levels since 1985. One measure favored by the economists is net cash income, the amount left over after paying cash expenses during a calendar year. In 1990, says the department's Economic Research Service, this could be a record, in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion. But 1990 farm income will not bear the brunt of the recent jump in energy costs prompted by the Mideast crisis. Not only gasoline and diesel, but petroleum-based fertilizers and other agricultural chemicals will be hit. Couple those effects with whatever Congress decides about cutting farm subsidies, and 1991 - and probably the presidential election year of 1992 - will shape up as extremely tricky for economists peering into crystal balls. A major upturn in exports could go a long way to ease the financial crunch on farmers, pushing up market prices and creating demands for greater production. But if that happens, it won't be quick. At the moment, USDA forecasters are still working on 1991 export projections. A hint of what may happen was included in the October issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, however. It said that both the value and the volume of U.S. commodity exports are expected to decline.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Oct. 7

DOC.HEAD: Repeating for all needing
TWA Planning Layoffs Due To Fuel Prices
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines will lay off between 450 and 500 employees nationwide Friday because of high fuel prices, an airline official said Thursday. Spokesman Donald Morrison said the layoffs would be among lower and middle-management and clerical workers and would not disrupt service. He said furlough notices would be sent out Friday. More layoffs, and possibly flight reductions, could come later, he said. TWA, whose hub is St. Louis, has 33,000 employees. The cuts are expected to affect about 100 workers in St. Louis. Bill Hoar, chief vice president, told KSDK-TV in St. Louis that the layoffs were due to ``exorbitant'' fuel prices, not TWA's financial status, which he called solid. TWA, headquartered in Mt. Kisco, N.Y., lost $300 million last year and had to pay $366 million in interest expense on debts of $2.5 billion. TWA Chairman Carl Icahn has been trying to reduce operating costs for the airline and has tried to get concessions from the pilots before he'll modernize TWA's fleet, one of the oldest in the industry.

President Bush and congressional leaders pressed reluctant lawmakers to support the $500-billion deficit-cutting plan, as Congress neared its first votes on the election-year package of tax boosts and spending cuts. White House and congressional vote-counters Thursday sought majorities from both parties but acknowledged they were shy of their goal - especially among House Republicans. The first votes would be on an outline of the five-year plan that Bush and congressional leaders completed last weekend after four months of bargaining. Votes on specific spending cuts and tax increases were planned in two weeks. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Former Lincoln Savings and Loan Association owner Charles H. Keating Jr. asserted his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination in a reply to administrative charges filed by federal regulators. According to documents released Thursday, Keating also asked the Office of Thrift Supervision to postpone any hearing until after he resolves separate criminal charges in Los Angeles. Keating has been jailed in Los Angeles since Sept. 18 in lieu of $5 million bail in the 42-count criminal case, and his lawyers said he had neither the time nor freedom-of-travel necessary to prepare a defense to the agency's action. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Justice Department subpoenaed records of major U.S. oil companies to further its investigation of steep gasoline prices increases. The department announced Thursday it had sought records from a large number of oil companies, independent refiners and marketers. In August, government lawyers began interviewing petroleum industry executives to seek explanations for the steep rise in gasoline prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. --- DETROIT (AP) - Ford Motor Co. gave the United Auto Workers union a comprehensive proposal for a new national labor contract that, according to one company official, mirrors the contract reached with General Motors Corp. The union, which ratified a three-year agreement with GM late last month, has insisted that the UAW-GM agreement serve as a model for contracts with Ford and Chrysler Corp. The Ford contract was presented Thursday. Except for one provision on overtime pay, Ford isn't expected to have trouble agreeing to a contract similar to GM's. --- SAN JOSE, Calif. (AP) - American computer and semiconductor makers, feuding for years over a computer chip trade agreement with Japan, announced a new trade plan that could bring lower prices to consumers. The proposal Thursday for a new five-year agreement to succeed the 1986 U.S.-Japan Semiconductor Trade Agreement, set to expire next July 31, marks the first time chipmakers and computer makers have joined to achieve the same trade policy. The proposal would end price controls on imported memory chips and remove an irritant in U.S.-Japanese relations. --- KANSAS CITY, Mo. (AP) - Pipeline companies that allegedly profited illegally from higher natural gas prices in the early 1980s agreed to a $432 million settlement in an antitrust suit brought by utilities. Consumers should get 100 percent of the settlement after legal costs, probably in the form of credits on their bills and lower rates, the attorneys general of Missouri and Kansas said Thursday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - New England Telephone and New York Telephone have agreed to pay $1.4 million to the U.S. Treasury and a $35.5 million rebate to long-distance customers to resolve allegations they overcharged customers through a subsidiary. The payment, announced Thursday, resolves apparent violations of Federal Communications Commission rules governing transactions between regulated telephone companies and unregulated affiliates. The FCC had ordered the companies to return $35.5 million to customers because of alleged overcharges to NYT and NET by Materiel Enterprises Co., an unregulated Nynex purchasing subsidiary. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The federal judge overseeing the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. bankruptcy withdrew from the case because he is considering a job at a law firm that has represented a Drexel creditor. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard C. Buschman III said Thursday he was stepping down from the bench after seven years to return to better-paying private practice. --- CHICAGO (AP) - United Airlines employees moved closer to their proposed buyout of parent UAL Corp. after a Dutch bank agreed to join four U.S. banks in loaning the employees' group $350 million each. The development Thursday brought the total tentative commitments to $1.75 billion, still short of the $2 billion in bank loans the workers need for a bid of $165 to $175 a share, or $3.6 billion to $3.8 billion, according to one person familiar with the situation. ---

Blue chip stocks rallied in a mixed and sluggish session in the stock market Thursday. The Dow Jones industrial average, down about 20 points at midmorning, closed with a gain of 27.47 at 2,516.83. The dollar dropped against all major foreign currencies. Bond prices rose sharply. A powerful three-day surge in pork belly futures prices peaked; livestock futures were mixed; energy futures were mixed; precious metals retreated; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Playskool Makes a Run On Fisher Price, Turns Babies Into Big Business
LaserPhoto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Babies cost bucks. That translates into big business for Playskool, a name once associated almost exclusively with toys. Today, Playskool sells everything from sleepwear to safety latches, bibs to cribs. It's in a close race with Fisher Price as the leader in items for infants and toddlers. The number of products under the Playskool name has more than tripled since 1983, said Bob Stebenne, president of Playskool Baby, the division that deals with articles other than toys. Playskool Baby will put more than 30 million products on the market this year, he said. Playskool still makes a complete line of baby toys, including Raggedy Ann dolls, Gumby, Lincoln Logs and Mr. Potato Head. Its 1991 line will include a $33 collapsible baby carrier for parents on the go, a $5 snack dispenser that resembles a bird feeder, and a versatile clothing line that grows with the child through a system of fasteners. ``We are honestly the most diversified company out there when it comes to what we do,'' Stebenne said, though Fisher Price disputes that claim. The change at Playskool started about six years ago, after toy maker Hasbro Inc., based in Pawtucket, R.I., acquired Playskool with its takeover of Milton Bradley. By then, Hasbro already owned Glenco Infant Items and its Tommee Tippee line. ``We changed that whole product range from Glenco to Playskool because we knew we had a lot of equity in that Playskool name,'' Stebenne said in a telephone interview from Dallas, where he was preparing for the Thursday opening of the annual Juvenile Products Manufacturers Association convention. Through the rest of the decade, Playskool continued to expand. It purchased Child Guidance from CBS Toys, the Pur line of infant feeding and care products and introduced a line of medical products for daily health care needs. Last year, Hasbro started licensing the Playskool name to companies that make humidifiers, tape recorders and other types of electronic equipment. ``I think the marketing concept quite honestly was, how can we strengthen the Playskool brand name, and the way to do it was introduce it to new moms both pre-natally and post-natally,'' said Stebenne. An estimated 4.1 million babies will be born in the United States this year, which gives Playskool and its competitors an enormous opportunity to promote their items. Playskool Baby is planning to give new parents about 2.2 million complimentary baby baskets, which include coupons and free products. Overall, Playskool Baby estimates it will reach 70 percent to 80 percent of new parents through various marketing strategies, Stebenne said. ``I think all companies are looking to broaden their product offerings. I think Playskool just saw a number of niche opportunities and went after them,'' said industry analyst Gary Jacobson, of Kidder, Peabody & Co. in New York. Bob Mann, executive vice president of Playskool, said he believes the company took the lead in the infant toy market last year from the Fisher Price division of Quaker Oats Co. But Strawn Cathcart, Fisher Price vice president of marketing, says his company still leads that market, although it does not offer medical products or safety items like outlet covers and cabinet latches. ``We do a lot more than Playskool does,'' Cathcart said. ``Playskool does not, except through licensing, compete in the juvenile business.'' Still, industry analysts say Fisher Price has faltered recently, allowing Playskool to gain an advantage. John McMillin, a Fisher Price analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York, said that company faltered by introducing too many expensive items that aren't selling well. The result is that Fisher Price likely will only break even this year after a decade of growth. ``We did introduce a number of high price products that proved to be less than successful in the marketplace and we've taken care of those problems,'' Cathcart said, ``but it does not for a minute mean that we were taking our eyes off the infant and juvenile area.''

DOC.HEAD: Housing Construction Slump Has Florida Feeling Unemployment Pinch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Real estate manager Lynn Mooney, whose turf is the retirement community of Sun City Center, usually has her hands full with retirees looking for a good buy. But this year is different. Snowbirds, as the refugees from colder climes are known, are having trouble unloading their homes. So for now, at least, they're staying with the snow. ``With the real estate market so bad up north right now, it's harder for them to just sell their homes and come down here - they have to wait,'' Mooney said. And that, economists say, is hurting Florida's construction business and unemployment rate, which at 6.7 percent is outpacing the nation's 5.6 percent. ``We're seeing the same kind of ripple effect in just about every state where retirees from the Northeast tend to settle,'' said Robert Villanueva, economic forecaster for the National Association of Home Builders. He added that new housing starts in Florida have dropped 18 percent; in California, 19 percent. In the past, retirees would come to Sun City Center and plunk down up to $300,000 for a new home - money they don't have now, Ms. Mooney said. And some who do come are forced to take out mortgages or forgo their dreams of a retirement home in favor of renting or moving into a condominium, which also adds to the slump in new construction. Construction unemployment took the biggest bite out of the state's 5.5 million-person workforce, according to August figures from the Florida Dpartment of Labor. Unemployment in construction rose nearly 5 percent in the past year, accounting for 15,900 jobs. Depository institutions lost 6,000 jobs in the same period and manufacturing 5,000. While Florida's unemployment is high, none of the blame can go to its biggest industry - tourism. Employment in the service sector, which includes hotels and amusement parks, grew nearly 7 percent in the past year, picking up 105,000 new jobs. ``It's hard to pin unemployment on one thing,'' said Becky Rust, an economist with Florida's Labor Market Information Bureau in Tallahassee. ``High interest rates, expectations of a recession and a continually growing population don't help at all.'' Economists say those factors will also help to keep the state's construction and related employment in the dumps for years. Villanueva predicts new home starts in Florida won't begin to recover until at least the middle of the decade, with a slowdown in the influx of retirees a factor. Demographer Stephen Golant of the University of Florida said economics won't be the only reason for the retiree slowdown. In a recent study, he predicted the drop will continue through the 1990s as the population of the 65-74 age group shrinks in the nation's colder climes. Between 199O and 2000, he predicts an 8 percent drop in the number of elderly migrating to Florida from the Northeast and Midwest. The 1980 census showed that, as migration peaked in the late 1970s, more than 80,000 people over age 60 were moving to Florida annually.

DOC.HEAD: Skepticism About UAL Deal Returns
DOC.TEXT: Skepticism about the proposed worker buyout of UAL Corp. is returning even as United Airlines employees move closer to getting bank financing for a bid. Analysts said a sharp drop in UAL's stock price Thursday reflected investor doubts that UAL's board will accept the employee offer, which is expected to value the airline company at $165 to $175 per share, or $3.6 billion to $3.8 billion. The board accepted a bid from the group of $201-per-share or $4.4 billion in April. The buyout group is racing to meet a Tuesday deadline imposed by the board to put together financing for the deal. Samuel Buttrick, airline analyst with Kidder Peabody and Co., said that when the board gave the employees a two-month extension on Aug. 9, ``the board made it clear that they would be hard pressed to accept any offer that was not commensurate in value'' with the $201 per share bid. ``Are they going to take a $175 deal? They are under no mandate to do so,'' said PaineWebber Inc. analyst Edward Starkman. UAL stock fell $6.37{ to $105.37{ a share Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock had risen earlier in the day after a Dutch bank agreed to join four U.S. banks in each loaning the workers $350 million. About 20 other banks were to have responded by Thursday to requests to participate in the deal, which requires at least $2 billion in bank financing. One person familiar with the transaction, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the four lead banks would not decide until at least Friday whether the other banks had offered enough loan money, in addition to the $1.75 billion already committed, to keep the deal alive. The New York Times quoted unidentified sources Thursday as saying bank financing was assured but the employee group still lacked $1 billion in financial commitments from non-bank sources. The Dutch bank NMB Postbank Groep N.V. agreed to contribute $350 million in financing for the employee bid, said Greg Flynn, vice-president for corporate finance, in a telephone interview from New York. NMB was the first foreign bank to commit funds to the deal and the first major lending institution to line up behind the four lead banks: Bankers Trust New York Corp., Manufacturers Hanover Corp., Security Pacific Corp., and First Chicago Corp. The lead banks' agreement was contingent on the participation of other banks, most of them foreign, to complete the loan package, a source told The Associated Press. The source said the lead banks wanted the total amount of bank financing commitments to be ``well in excess of the $2 billion'' that the buyout group needs.

DOC.HEAD: Government Considers Plan To Let Banks Advertise Trust Funds
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission says he will impose securities rules on banks if another federal regulator lets them advertise a type of trust fund that could put them in competition with the trillion dollar mutual fund industry. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency says that's okay but notes that banks are exempt from certain SEC regulations. But the mutual fund industry is opposed to allowing banks to advertise the trust funds will put investors at risk while giving banks an unfair advantage over the more heavily regulated mutual funds. Supporters and opponents of the proposed rule change aired their views Thursday before the finance subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which oversees both the SEC and mutual funds. Under the proposed change, the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates 4,000 national banks around the country, wants to allow banks to advertise collective investment funds separately from their other services. Bank trust departments are allowed to combine individual trusts, like those maintained for wealthy widows and minors, into collective funds for administrative purposes. The comptroller's office wants to lift a ban preventing banks from advertising the availability and performance of those combined funds, in effect, letting them be marketed as ersatz mutual funds. Mutual funds, small banks and some members of Congress have criticized the proposal as risky after the savings and loan debacle and reports of underfunding of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., which guarantees bank deposits. There also is concern that financial products sold in banks will give customers the impression they are federally insured, which they are not. That was a problem arising out of the failure of Lincoln Savings and Loan, where some investors lost their life savings in securities sold at the thrift. ``Without appropriate safeguards in place the potential for investor confusion is substantial,'' Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., said at a hearing before the finance subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Markey is chairman of the panel. But Robert L. Clarke, the comptroller of the currency, said that while the negative reaction is large, the issue is small. ``The revisions we are contemplating would not expand bank powers,'' Clarke said. He said banks already are permitted to advertise the service along with others but not separately. ``The government doesn't tell supermarkets that they cannot advertise carrots unless they advertise all the other vegetables in the produce section,'' he said. ``Why then should the government keep banks from advertising common trust funds services separately from other trust services?'' Markey suggested that since Congress is trouble-shooting the country's banking laws, the comptroller's office should wait to implement the change until the Bush administration presents its opinion. Clarke said afterward that he had no timetable for making a decision. Supporters of the proposed change testifying Thursday included Wells Fargo Bank's William E. Aldinger III, speaking for the Coalition of Regional Banks, and Richard W. Heiss, of the Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit, representing the American Bankers Association. Opponents included David Manning of the Community Bankers Association of Illinois and Peggy Miller of the Consumer Federation of America. The SEC doesn't oppose the change, but SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden told the panel it would impose its own regulations on banks if they are allowed to market their collective trust funds. But Clarke noted that banks are exempt from two of the four laws that govern mutual funds. Therefore the SEC would be unable to regulate the sales practices of banks vending funds as it now can for mutual fund salesmen. That would deny investors the protection of those laws, Breeden said. ``In our view, the commission believes these statutory exemptions for banks are no longer appropriate,'' he said. David Silver, president of the Investment Company Institute, which represents the mutual fund industry, said ``these loopholes leave serious gaps for investor protection.'' He said the industry doesn't oppose bank entry into the mutual fund business as long as appropriate investor safeguards and equal regulation are in place. Silver also warned that banks would be permitted to double charge trust customers for management fees on the common trust fund as well as the individual trust accounts.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Asserts Fifth Amendment Rights in Administrative Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Former savings and loan owner Charles H. Keating cannot fully defend himself against federal administrative charges without risking a conviction in a separate criminal case, his attorneys say. Keating asserted his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination in a reply to the charges filed by the Office of Thrift Supervision. He also asked OTS to postpone a hearing on the case until after he resolves the criminal charges. Keating's lawyers, in documents released Thursday by OTS, said it was difficult for their client to focus on the administrative proceeding because he has been jailed since Sept. 18 in lieu of $5 million bail in the 42-count criminal indictment in Los Angeles. On Aug. 9, the thrift office filed administrative charges seeking $40.9 million in reimbursement from Keating for his actions as chairman of the American Continental Corp., the Phoenix-based holding company for Lincoln Savings and Loan, based in Irvine, Calif. It also sought to ban him from ever owning or working for a bank or savings institution. His lawyers said further refusal to testify at a hearing would risk an unfavorable ruling in the administrative case. But, they said, waiving his Fifth Amendment rights would risk a conviction in the criminal case, where Keating faces a maximum jail sentence of 10 years. ``Besides putting Mr. Keating in a no-win position, the very real threat of future criminal prosecution would no doubt cause key third-party defense witnesses to invoke their Fifth Amendment rights in the (thrift office) proceeding, further undercutting Mr. Keating's defense,'' they said. The government loses little by delaying the hearing because Keating, with a negative net worth of $4 million, ``lacks the wherewithal to satisfy any judgment,'' his attorneys said. Moreover, Keating is willing to agree not to participate in the affairs of any federally insured depository institution, the documents said. Regulators seized Lincoln in April 1989, later estimating the taxpayer cost for protecting depositors at as much as $2 billion. Besides Keating, others asserting their Fifth Amendment rights in the thrift office case are: Judy J. Wischer, former president and chief executive officer of American Continental; Robert J. Kielty, who was a senior vice president and general counsel of the company; Charles H. Keating III, a former executive vice president and the elder Keating's son; and two of Keating's sons-in-law who were vice presidents, Robert J. Hubbard and Robert M. Wurzelbacher Jr. In an unrelated case, Thomas Spiegel, former chief executive and chairman of Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif., denied thrift office charges filed against him July 5 and amended Sept. 4. Spiegel was accused by the thrift office of squandering millions of the S&L's funds on luxury condominiums, limousines, a gun collection and such exotica as ``survival chamber bathrooms with bulletproof glass and an independent air and food supply.'' In a reply dated Sept. 21 but released Thursday, Spiegel's lawyers asked for dismissal of the charges and reimbursement from the government for attorney's fees and other expenses. Columbia, which is under new management and has not been seized by regulators, is the industry's largest holder of junk bonds.

DOC.HEAD: Northeastern Phone Companies Settle Overcharge Allegations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: New England Telephone and New York Telephone will make a voluntary $1.4 million payment to the U.S. Treasury and cut their long-distance rates $35.5 million to resolve allegations that they overcharged customers from 1984 to 1988. The $1.4 million payment, announced Thursday as part of a consent decree between the companies and the Federal Communications Commission, is a record amount and is identical to a proposed fine the FCC had announced in February. But the FCC said the payment was not a fine and it was making no finding of wrongdoing. The commission said it was ending its enforcement action against the companies. The $35.5 million is the interstate portion of an alleged $118.5 million in overcharges for equipment, supplies and services the FCC had said the two phone companies paid Materiel Enterprises Co., the unregulated purchasing arm of New York-based NYNEX Corp., from 1984 to 1988. NYNEX is the parent firm of New York and New England Telephone, The FCC had said the $35.5 million was charged to long-distance companies such as American Telephone & Telegraph Co., MCI and US Sprint for connecting with the local phone network. The long-distance companies pass those charges on to residential and business customers. Toby Webb, NYNEX vice president for government affairs, said he could not estimate how much long-distance phone bills would be affected by the $35.5 million rebate. Local phone rates will not be affected. NYNEX agreed to the $35.5 million rebate, to be made within 30 days, and also said the two phone companies would reduce their capital accounts by $32.6 million to ``remove the alleged excess profits on plant and equipment purchased from MECO (Materiel Enterprises).'' ``We hope this puts to rest any questions concerning NYNEX's desire to comply with all FCC regulations and policies in transactions among affiliate companies,'' NYNEX Chairman William C. Ferguson said in a statement. NYNEX had claimed the FCC was incorrectly subjecting NYNEX to accounting rules that were established in 1977 for AT&T and its unregulated affiliate, Western Electric Co. NYNEX said Thursday it continued to hold that view. Webb said the $1.4 million contribution to the Treasury will be paid by NYNEX shareholders, and will not effect telephone rates. He estimated the consent decree would have an effect of about 12 cents per share on earnings in the third quarter. ``That doesn't mean per-share earnings will go down by that much,'' since other factors are involved, he added. The agreement ends one of several pending federal or state actions against NYNEX, one of the seven regional Bell holding companies that were created in 1984 from the old Bell System. NYNEX also has been the focus of investigations into bawdy parties in Florida for NYNEX employees and vendors that included prostitutes. NYNEX has denied that any ratepayer funds were involved in the conventions. In May, the Justice Department filed a one-count criminal indictment alleging that NYNEX had violated the information services restrictions in the 1982 consent decree that created the regional Bell companies. NYNEX denied any wrongdoing. On Wednesday, New York state utility regulators authorized a study into whether NYNEX should be forced to divest New York Telephone. In its February announcement, the commission said New York Telephone, New England Telephone MECO apparently had violated FCC rules governing transactions between regulated telephone companies and an unregulated affiliates. FCC Commissioner Andrew C. Barrett said in a statement Thursday he believed the FCC could have won its case in court. However, he said the commission still had sent a clear message to phone companies that ``if they violate our rules, they should be prepared to pay the penalty.''

DOC.HEAD: Slow-Moving Economy Expected to Push Jobless Rate Even Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires. Will be led with 8:30 a.m. EDT report.
DOC.TEXT: America's climbing unemployment rate, which has fanned fears that the nation is skidding into a recession, isn't expected to improve any time soon, analysts say. They will get their first look at the nation's economic activity for September with today's release of the Labor Department's unemployment report. In advance of the report's release, many economists said the unemployment rate probably rose last month to 5.7 percent from August's 5.6 percent. That would mark the third consecutive jump in the jobless rate and put it well above the 5.2 percent rate recorded in June. In July and August, the ranks of the jobless swelled by 550,000 people as the unemployment rate for the two-month period jumped 0.4 percentage points. The recent increase in joblessness reflects a U.S. economy that was showing little signs of life even before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices soaring and increased fears of an imminent recession. An uptick to a 5.7 percent unemployment rate - which would be the highest level in more than two years - would provide further evidence of an economic downturn, said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. ``A rise to 5.7 percent does not suggest a caving in of the economy - it simply underscores the slide,'' said Sinai, one of many analysts who believe the nation is already in a recession. Government data to back up the theory is not yet available. Many analysts expected the Labor Department's report to probably show that the nation's industries produced around 50,000 new jobs last month, excluding the lost jobs caused by the temporary census workers laid off by the government. A jobs gain of 50,000 would be considered mediocre, especially when compared with the robust jobs gains of last year, when the economy was producing nearly 200,000 jobs a month. Before the recent rise in unemployment - caused largely by the economy's failure to produce many new jobs - the jobless rate had stayed relatively low and stable, fluctuating within a tenth of a percentage point of 5.3 percent for much of the past year and one-half. Many economists say the only reason the unemployment rate has not risen faster in recent months is because fewer Americans are entering the work force. ``One of these months, there will be a more normal growth in the labor force, on top of weak jobs growth. We'll see a big jump in the unemployment rate and it will be very scary,'' Sinai said.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Rebounds, Dollar Plunges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rebounded on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today, but the gains were held in check by Congress' failure to pass the proposed U.S. budget. The dollar, meanwhile, plunged against the yen. Analysts said the surge higher indicated investors had digested the Finance Minstry's market-propping measures announced Monday and were less skittish about the Middle East crisis. The government's steps included slightly shorter trading times for stock options and an increase in margin deposits, which went into effect today. Stocks continued to receive support from U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's comments earlier in the week that hinted lower interest rates were likely. But news of the U.S. budget's failure hit the market in the early afternoon, depressing the day's gains. ``Just at the time you think you are out of it, the bear market swats you upside the head again,'' said Darryl Whitten, a Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. analyst. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected stocks rebounded 549.46 points, or 2.47 percent, to close at 22,827.65. It fell 571.20 points, or 2.56 percent, on Thursday. Trading was moderate on the first section, with an estimated 450 million shares changing hands. Masaki Sumi, a manager at Sanyo Securities, said that beyond the Finance Ministry's measures, ``fundamentally . . . you can't find many positive factors. So most institutional investors are sidelined. And a small amount of buying can push up prices.'' Traders said big losses have kept institutional investors out of the market. As of Thursday, the Nikkei had lost 27.76 percent of its value before Aug. 2, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Negatives such as inflationary pressures and higher oil prices are expected to keep interest rates high. The usual bear market that chases a long bull session probably will last until well into 1991, despite the record bounce on Tuesday after the Finance Ministry's announcement, Whitten said. On Tuesday, the market scored a 2,676.55-point surge, its biggest in history. The direction of trading next week will depend on how Wall Street responds to the budget's failure and to U.S. September unemployment figures, due out today in Washington, he said. The dollar, meanwhile, suffered from the stock market's rise, the prospect of lower interest rates in the United States and from a weakening U.S. economy. Lower interest rates tend to curb demand for dollars by making returns on dollar-denominated investments less attractive. The dollar closed at 133.72 yen, down 2.18 from Thursday's close. In bond dealings, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds dropped to 8.110 percent by 3 p.m. from Thursday's 8.235 percent close. Their price rose to 83.15 points from 82.63.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose against major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said the vote by the U.S. Congress to reject the deficit-cutting budget package boosted the dollar. The deficit reduction deal was expected to lead to lower U.S. interest rates, but with its rejection interest rates are now expected to remain high, dealers said. Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated securities more attractive to investors. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 2.18 yen to a closing 133.72 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 133.12 yen. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9125, compared with $1.9115 late Thursday. Other dollar rates at midmorning in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.5372 German marks, up from 1.5340; 1.2847 Swiss francs, up from 1.2760; 5.1473 French francs, up from 5.1400; 1.7340 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7300; 1,150.50 Italian lire, up from 1,150.00, and 1.1500 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1485. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $393.00 an ounce at midmorning, down from $396.25 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $393.20, down from $396.25. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.47 to close at a bid $391.95. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.69 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's $4.71.

DOC.HEAD: Ladies' Home Journal Selling in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: A Russian-language edition of Ladies' Home Journal hit the newsstands in Moscow with a cover story on America's 50 Most Powerful Women. ``We know both American and Soviet women are achieving greater power than ever before,'' editor-in-chief Myrna Blyth said. ``Women share so much, can understand and empathize with each other so easily.'' The Soviet information agency Novosti began selling Ladies' Home Journal in Moscow Wednesday, the magazine said. Among the features in the November issue's 32-page Russian-language section are an interview with first lady Barbara Bush and recipes for those staples of American life: pizza and apple pie. And America's most powerful women? The list includes USA Today publisher Cathleen Black, singer-actress Cher, U.S. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, advice columnists Ann Landers and Abigail Van Buren, photographer Annie Leibovitz, NBC newswoman Jane Pauley, tennis star Martina Navratilova and author Danielle Steel.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Faults Federal Rail Inspections
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Hearing begins 9 a.m. EDT; lead expected; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government's rail inspection system isn't good enough to guarantee that trains are running safely, the General Accounting Office said today. Last year, the government failed to inspect 1,164 miles of track, skipping over 18 percent of all railroads that own track. The Federal Railroad Administration also did not verify the accuracy of 54 percent of the accident or incident reports filed by railroads, said the GAO, the investigative arm of Congress. ``FRA does not have assurance that the nation's 580 railroads are running safely,'' GAO Associate Director John W. Hill Jr. said in testimony submitted for a hearing today by the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on transportation, tourism and hazardous materials. ``We found that 32 railroads did not receive any type of inspection in 1989. Typically, these were the smaller, short-line railroads, which have higher accident and injury rates than overall industry averages,'' Hill said. Because there are no standards telling railroad inspectors how often they must examine tracks, signals, equipment and operating practices, there is no way to know whether the lack of annual inspections translates into a special safety risk, he said. The GAO also criticized the FRA for failing to pay special attention to railroads with poor safety histories or a string of accidents. ``While the number of Union Pacific accidents in Idaho more than doubled between 1986 and 1988, the total number of Union Pacific inspections in Idaho decreased nearly 38 percent during this time period,'' Hill said. Federal Railroad Administrator Gilbert E. Carmichael said the report ``broadly confirms many of my own conclusions.'' ``FRA must improve the training of its inspectors ... and it must use its data more scientifically in planning inspections and in assuring consistent application of safety regulations,'' he said. But Carmichael also said that rail safety improved during the 1980s. He said his agency's success should be measured by ``overall safety performance from the railroads'' and not ``whether each instance of noncompliance is corrected.''

DOC.HEAD: TWA Planning Layoffs Due To Higher Fuel Prices
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines, struggling with increasing fuel prices, is expected to issue lay-off notices to as many as 500 employees across the country today. TWA Spokesman Donald Morrison said Thursday the layoffs would center on management and clerical employees and would not disrupt service. ``This whole thing is fuel-related,'' Morrison said. ``It doesn't have anything to do with everything else that is going on.'' In the United States, TWA is paying more than 90 cents a gallon for jet fuel - roughly twice as much as before Iraq invaded Kuwait. More layoffs, and possibly flight reductions, could come later, Morrison said. TWA, which has its hub in St. Louis, has about 33,000 employees worldwide. The cuts are expected to affect about 100 of the roughly 8,000 workers in St. Louis. The airline has been taking other steps to cut costs to counter the surge in fuel prices and a slowdown in travel. In the past two weeks, the steadily shrinking carrier has decided to pull out of two more cities, close its flight base in Los Angeles and stop hiring and training new pilots and flight attendants. TWA also put the squeeze on its advertising agency, Young & Rubicam Inc., but its bid for lower rates backfired when the firm took the unusual step of giving up the airline's $45 million account. TWA Chairman Carl Icahn, told The Wall Street Journal that the airline would replace Young & Rubicam by doing some of the work itself and hiring a ``small creative shop'' to do the rest. TWA said Wednesday that it might make even more cuts in the new schedule that takes effect Oct. 28. The airline already has announced it will pull out of Harrisburg, Pa., and Oslo, Norway. Since the beginning of the year, TWA has abandoned Long Beach and Burbank, Calif.; Madison, Wis.; Midway Airport in Chicago; Freeport and Nassau in the Bahamas; and Stuttgart, Germany. Last week, the airline said it intended to close its pilot base in Los Angeles on Jan. 1 and shift about 300 West Coast crew members to bases in New York and St. Louis. Icahn told leaders of the Air Line Pilots Association that cost studies showed the closing would save the carrier money over the next two years. The union is questioning that claim, saying the expense of retraining pilots who shift to new cockpit positions or new equipment might eclipse the projected savings. Three of TWA's rivals - USAir Group Inc., Pan Am Corp. and Midway Airlines Inc. - already have announced layoffs in response to the problems that have gripped the industry. TWA, headquartered in Mt. Kisco, N.Y., lost $300 million last year and had to pay $366 million in interest on debt totaling $2.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Chairman Sold Stock Below Price Sought in Buyout: Report
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. Chairman Stephen M. Wolf sold most of his UAL stock rights far below the price he has asked from the union group trying to buy the company, according to a report published today. Wolf sold 200,000 of his 208,333 stock rights for $150 per share this spring, the Wall Street Journal reported. John C. Pope, UAL's chief financial officer, recently sold 50,000 of his 60,000 rights, the Journal reported, citing unnamed persons familiar with the transaction. The union group trying to buy the parent company of United Airlines is racing to meet a Tuesday deadline to secure financing. UAL's board accepted a $201-per-share, $4.4 billion bid in April. But the employee group is expected to value the airline at $165 to $175 per share, or $3.6 billion to $3.8 billion. Wolf was concerned the union group would find a way to nullify his rights if he waited to sell until after the buyout was complete, the newspaper said. Wolf and Pope sold the rights ``in light of (the unions') clearly stated intent to replace them with their own senior management'' if the buyout succeeds, a spokesman for Wolf told the paper. Union officials discounted that explanation, saying Wolf would not have lost his rights under a change of management, the Journal reported. ``He obviously has no interest in seeing the deal close,'' a union official said. ``It would be pretty inconsistent for (UAL directors) to say shareholders can't get $170 today when Wolf sold for $150,'' said a UAL shareholder who asked not be named. ``We're offering the shareholders more (than $150 a share),'' said Frederick C. Dubinsky, president of the United pilots union, one of the unions involved in the buyout bid. ``How can Wolf tell the board our offer isn't enough?'' Wolf has denied trying to block the buyout bid. UAL stock fell $6.37{ to $105.37{ a share Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock has traded as low as $87.25 since Wolf sold his shares.

DOC.HEAD: Kirin Beer, Tropicana to Market Orange Juice in Japan
DOC.TEXT: Kirin Brewery Co. said Friday it will establish a joint venture with Tropicana Products Inc. to market orange juice and frozen fruit products in Japan. Kirin, Japan's leading beer brewer, said the new company will begin marketing Tropicana 100 percent orange juice and frozen items in Tokyo's metropolitan area in March. The company tentatively is called Kirin-Tropicana. Florida-based Tropicana, the largest U.S. orange juice maker, would be an equal partner in the venture. The deal will enable Kirin to add U.S. brand-name juices as well as its own frozen products to its product line, while easing Tropicana's entry into the Japanese market. The venture comes ahead of the scheduled 1992 liberalization of U.S. oranges into Japan's orange market.

DOC.HEAD: Polly Peck May Sell Del Monte Stake
DOC.TEXT: Polly Peck International PLC may seek to raise cash by selling a stake in its Del Monte fruit and produce business to the public early next year, reports published today said. The Wall Street Journal said proceeds from a possible sale of 40 percent of Del Monte for $400 million would be used to pay off some of Polly Peck's $1.58 billion in long-term debt. The Journal account, quoting unidentified sources close to the company, said the public offering also would ease pressure from short-term lenders, who have clamped down on credit lines to Polly Peck. Separately, the London-based Financial Times quoted Polly Peck Chairman Asil Nadir saying the interest in Del Monte would offered on the New York Stock Exchange. Polly Peck bought Del Monte, the world's largest distributor of bananas, last year from RJR Nabisco Inc. for $875 million. Polly Peck also has interests in consumer electronics and the leisure industry. Polly Peck's lines of credit were tightened after the Sept. 20 trading suspension in the company's shares. The suspension stemmed from an inquiry by Britain's Serious Fraud Office into a possible stock manipulation scheme in Polly Peck shares. The suspension, which is still in force, has given Polly Peck a liquidity problem, the company said earlier this week. Bankers for the cash-starved conglomerate were meeting with the company's managers today to discuss the liquidity problem and arrange a credit package. The critical meeting came as the Foreign Office confirmed a report in today's Financial Times that Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd sent a message to the Turkish government last week. The Financial Times said the telegram, signed by Hurd, called on the Turkish government to provide about $190 million to rescue the embattled company, which is a major employer in Turkish-occupied Cyprus. Hurd's letter was in reply to a letter received from Turkish Economics Minister which said that Turkey was considering aid to Polly Peck, the Financial Times said.

DOC.HEAD: September Unemployment Rises to 5.7 Percent
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout with analysts' comment, editing; also on general news wires. ^By KAREN BALL
DOC.TEXT: America's unemployment rate posted its third consecutive increase in September, rising to 5.7 percent, the government reported today as the economy continued to flash warning signals of an impending recession. The 0.1 percentage point increase pushed the jobless rate to its highest level since the spring of 1988 and private economists predicted even higher unemployment figures in the months ahead, reflecting a deteriorating U.S. economy. More industries lost jobs than gained them in September, causing an overall loss of 101,000 jobs from non-farm payrolls, the Labor Department said. About 42,000 of those were census workers laid off by the government. It marked the first time since the 1981-82 recession that the unemployment rate increased three months in a row, the government said. While the Bush administration continues to insist that the country can avoid a recession, a growing number of economists think the country has either already entered a recession or will be in one before the end of the year. ``It's an economy that's started the slide down the slippery slope,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``The weakness has become more diffused, which is characteristic of an economy losing ground.'' Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, noted the weakness in September's jobs data had hit factories and service industries alike. ``Few areas of the economy are escaping the downward tug of the current economic slowdown,'' Mrs. Norwood said. Last month's 5.7 percent jobless rate was the highest since it was that same level in March 1988; the unemployment rate hasn't been worse since it was 5.8 percent in November 1987. The nation's employment picture began a downward spiral in July, as the nation's economy began failing to produce enough jobs to keep up with the number of Americans looking for work. Since then, the jobless rate has risen 0.5 percentage points from June's rate of 5.2 percent. The rapid jump in the jobless rate over the past three months reflected a U.S. economy that was showing little signs of life even before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices soaring and increased fears of an imminent downturn. The 101,000-job loss in September, though inflated by the census workers, was the biggest job decline since the economy lost 104,000 jobs in June 1986, the government said. A year ago, the economy was producing nearly 200,000 new jobs a month. The nation's jobless rate is derived from a household survey. But most economists consider a separate survey of business establishments - from which the government gets its figures on how many new jobs were created in a given month - a better barometer of economic activity. The slump in the manufacturing sector continued in September, as factory jobs posted a 66,000 job loss. It was the 17th time out of 18 months that manufacturing jobs declined. Since reaching a post recession peak in January 1989, the manufacturing sector has lost more than 500,000 jobs, the government said. In September, construction also continued on its downward slide, posting the fourth decline in as many months to reflect weakness in the housing market. After seasonal adjustment, construction jobs fell by 20,000, bringing losses in the industry to more than 100,000 in recent months. The service-producing sector, which until a few months ago had been enjoying robust job growth and providing most of the economy's steam, actually lost 17,000 jobs in September. Within the sector, the services industry itself, which employs one in four non-farm workes, added only 20,000 jobs, one of the smallest gains since the 1981-82 recession. Health services, which had added an average of 50,000 jobs each month in the first half of this year, continued to show healthy gains, adding 45,000 jobs last month. Labor costs, which are frequently blamed for worsening the nation's inflation problems, rose a sharp 0.5 percent. The average hourly worker made $10.13 an hour in September, up from the $10.08 made in August. The Labor Department's household survey showed that overall, total civilian employment was about 117.9 million in September, up from the 117.7 million employed in August. The jobless numbered nearly 7.1 million, slightly up from the 7 million employed in August. The average manufacturing workweek was 41 hours in September, unchanged from August. Manufacturing overtime was 3.7 hours last month, down from August's average of 3.8 overtime hours. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the September jobless rate was 5.6 percent, up from the 5.5 percent in August but lower than September's civilian rate of 5.7 percent. The unemployment rate among major demographic groups last month was: -Adult white men, 4.3 percent, unchanged from August. -Adult white women, 4.2 percent, unchanged from August. -White teen-agers, 12.5 percent, down from 13.2 percent. -All blacks, 12.1 percent, up from 11.8 percent. -Adult black men, 11.8 percent, up from 10.6 percent. -Adult black women, 10.3 percent, up from 9.9 percent. -Black teen-agers, 26.9 percent, down from 35 percent. -Hispanics, 8.7 percent, up from 7.8 percent.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 346.47 down 3.42 from the previous day's close.

The stock market declined broadly today as traders responded to the rejecion of a government budget plan. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 24.75 to 2,492.08 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 5 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 199 up, 1,086 down and 422 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 48.30 million shares at midmorning. The selloff at the opening had been widely predicted following the overnight news that the House had defeated the budget proposal worked out last weekend by President Bush and congressional leaders. Analysts said that development dismayed investors who had pinned their hopes on some tangible signs of progress in the struggle to narrow the government's chronic deficit. But after the initial wave of selling passed, the market steadied. Brokers said hopes lingered that Congress might come up with an alternative budget plan. Separately, the Labor Department issued monthly statistics showing an increase in the unemployment rate and a drop in nonfarm payroll employment. The figures, which came in a bit weaker than expected, were taken as corroborating evidence that the economy is close to or already in a recession. Some observers also saw them, however, as cause for hope that interest rates might soon decline. Losers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, down ~ at 107; General Electric, down \ at 54[; Philip Morris, down { at 47{, and Pepsico, down { at 24\. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.60 to 169.73. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.71 at 305.43.

Rising imports and overseas tourism helped slash Japan's trade and services surplus by 72.5 percent in August from the same month last year, the Finance Ministry said Friday. Despite some fluctuations, the surplus in the current account, the widest measure of a nation's trade in goods and services, has generally been declining in recent months. That has been good news to Japanese officials pressured by trading partners, particularly the United States, to cut the surplus. August's drop to $942 million from $3.43 billion in August 1989 was the largest decline in the surplus since January, when it registered a deficit for the first time in six years. In July, the current account surplus fell 63 percent from a year earlier to $2.02 billion, following a moderate 12 percent rise the previous month. The ministry said Japan's August trade surplus, which measures only goods, fell 15.4 percent from the previous year to $4.12 billion. Imports rose 7.2 percent to $17.77 billion for their fifth consecutive month of increase. The value of imports was the fourth-largest ever, the ministry said. Ministry officials said the effect of higher oil prices from Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait did not surface during the month. Although the total volume of Japan's crude oil imports rose 4.8 percent from August 1989 to 18.1 million kiloliters, the total value dropped 0.4 percent to $1.86 billion because of lower prices, the ministry said. The officials said the impact of higher oil prices was likely to start being felt in October trade figures. Auto imports in August rose 21.6 percent, while imports of machinery such as office equipment rose 7.1 percent. Art imports surged 160.3 percent. Exports rose for the third consecutive month, despite the recent strengthening of the yen against the dollar. They edged up 2.1 percent to $21.89 billion, in part because of stronger exports of automobiles, up 6.4 percent, and audio-video equipment, up 7.5 percent, ministry officials said. But the officials said the chief cause of the drop in the current account surplus was a rise in the ``invisible'' trade deficit - which includes investment flows and tourism - to its second-highest level ever. The tourism deficit rose to $2.09 billion in August, surpassing the record deficit set in August 1989 of $1.96 billion. Ministry officials said 1.09 million Japanese went abroad in August, the first time that more than 1 million people left the country during one month. Economists also pointed to a growing deficit in capital flows. The long-term capital account deficit in August was $4.84 billion, up sharply from $3.63 billion in August 1989, the ministry said.

DOC.HEAD: Grains and Soybeans Higher

Soybean futures rose amid strong buying and worry about the U.S. House defeat of the budget agreement and its possible effects on farm programs. Corn and wheat futures opened lower as harvest pressures but turned higher on expectations of export business with the Soviet Union and other nations.
