DOC.HEAD: Fed Ease May Not Have Much Affect on Economy
DOC.TEXT: A cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board could take months to affect the economy and even then it might be too little too late, economists say. Some say that regardless of what type of federal budget agreement ultimately is approved, they expect the central bank to moderately lower its target for the Federal Funds rate, the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans, to 7} percent from 8 percent. But as the economy moves closer to recession, it moves further from the Fed's control, analysts say. ``The Fed is going to be pretty much impotent to stop what's already on track,'' said Ray Stone, of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc., referring to beliefs that the economy is already in a recession or quickly headed for one. Such a small cut in the Fed Funds rate may be absorbed by banks trying to bolster earnings and never affect consumer and business loans through a cut in the prime rate, said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Investors Service Inc., a debt-rating agency. A lower Fed Funds rate would mean banks would pay a smaller wholesale price for money. Banks could widen their profit margin by holding the prime rate steady. ``Twenty five basis points (one-fourth of a percentage point) for the most part will help shore up bank earnings. Whether or not we'll see any discernible difference in lending rates remains to be seen,'' Lonski said. Lonski and others anticipate another 25 basis point cut in the Fed Funds rate before long. That would likely be enough to affect the prime, he said. It might be a longshot, but a move to lower interest rates could have a psychological impact on consumers by making them more confident that the economy will recover soon. Consumer confidence has sagged and, as people feel less secure in their jobs, they are more prone to spend less money. A signal that the Fed is trying to move the economy could boost spending. ``Maybe they'll go out and buy that new car,'' Stone said. Others were more skeptical. As far as consumer attitudes are concerned, more people will be looking to the Persian Gulf than the Federal Reserve, said Alan Levenson, of the Wefa Group, an economic forecasting firm in suburban Philadelphia. Moreover, it's doubtful most consumers know or care what the Fed Funds rate is doing. ``What the man on the street wants to see is a reduction in the cost in borrowing from banks such as a significant downward movement in variable rate mortgages,'' Lonski said. Economists warn that although Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan is confident that congressional approval of a credible budget agreement would lead to lower short-term interest rates, plans to ease monetary policy could still be scuttled. Members of the House, fearful of taking tax hikes and spending cuts to their constituents less than a month before an election, stalled passage of a compromise package of tax increases and spending cuts. The House on Friday rejected the $500 billion deficit-reduction proposal backed by President Bush and Greenspan. An alternative proposal might not be to Greenspan's liking and could steer the Fed away from following a more generous credit course. Then there's inflation. The Persian Gulf crisis has been sending oil prices on a roller-coaster ride, fanning inflation fears. More proof of the negative impact the Middle East situation is having on U.S. inflation will be available in a few weeks. The Labor Department will release the September Consumer Price Index on Oct. 18. It is expected to show a 1 percent jump. Many analysts have noted the Fed appears more concerned with controlling inflation by keeping interest rates high than with spurring economic activity by cutting borrowing rates. The rise in oil prices, the budget impasse and the weaker dollar, which increases the price of imports, have been blamed for inhibiting the Fed. Even assuming that Congress eventually cracks the budget deadlock, economists still warn that a sharp rise in prices could spook the Fed from relaxing its guard against inflation.
DOC.NOTE: End adv Monday, Oct. 8

DOC.HEAD: Saturn Sets Prices
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT mileage to 1,500 sted 15,000
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s new Saturn cars will carry a base price as low as $7,995 and a money-back guarantee good for a month, considerably more attractive terms than industry analysts had foreseen. Saturn Corp., GM's first new division in 58 years, said Thursday its four models of sedans and coupes will go on sale Oct. 25 at Saturn dealerships in the South, West and Southeast. The cars had been expected to have a base price as high as $12,000. ``We know we're in the most competitive segment of the small car market,'' Saturn President Richard S. LeFauve told dealers at a meeting in Nashville, Tenn., Thursday night. Saturn officials have said they expect 80 percent of the projected 250,000 annual car sales will come from people who seriously considered buying imported vehicles. Depending on model, the Saturn will be competing against the Toyota Corolla or Camry, Nissan Sentra, Honda Civic, Mazda Protege or Mitsubishi Eclipse. However, Saturn cars also will be going against the Chevrolet Corsica, Beretta and Cavalier and Geo Prizm, all sold by GM dealers. Analysts have wondered how deep Saturn sales will cut into GM sales, despite what LeFauve and other GM executives have said. Base prices for the four Saturn models will be: Sports Sedan, $7,995 or $8,595 depending on trim level; Sports Touring Sedan, $10,295; and Sports Coupe, $11,775. Saturn owners dissatisfied for any reason will be able to return their new cars within 30 days or 1,500 miles for a full refund. A roadside protection plan will go along with each Saturn sold. Volkswagen and GM's Oldsmobile divisions currently offer buy-back programs. Oldsmobile and some expensive European and Japanese automakers, including Mercedes-Benz and Toyota Motor Corp.'s Lexus Division, also offer roadside assistance programs.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Pound to Join European Currency System
DOC.NOTE: EDS: NEW thruout with background; rates; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The British pound will enter Europe's exchange rate mechanism, a move that will link the currency closely to its European neighbors and limit exchange rate movements, an official said today. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said that as part of the move, which will take effect Monday, a key British interest rate will simultaneously drop by one percentage point to 14 percent. Joining the Exchange Rate Mechanism symbolizes Britain's willingness to participate in European integration ahead of 1992, when Europe is scheduled to meld into one marketplace of 220 million consumers. Despite the cooperative stance, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher still remains opposed to creating single a European central bank and a single currency. The pound, which had been rising in anticipation of the announcement, surged on the news to $1.9360 from $1.9185 in early trading. Against the German mark, the pound also catapulted, to 2.9953 marks from 2.9492 marks. Stock prices also soared. The European Community's Monetary Committee is likely to approve the British plan for the pound to join the European Monetary System's ERM. Under the terms of entry, national central banks are obliged to prevent their currencies from falling outside prescribed bands by direct market intervention. The move, which takes a free-floating pound and ties it to other currencies, should limit disruptive exchange rate movements and promote economic stability. A high pound also should help fight inflation by lowering the cost of imports. Thatcher agreed in principle to link the pound to the other currencies at a community summit meeting in Madrid last year but said she would move only when Britain's inflation rate was lower. However, the government went ahead despite the current high inflation rate of 10.6 percent. The pound will enter the mechanism at a central rate of 2.9500 German marks and, like the Spanish peseta, will be allowed to fluctuate by 6 percent above or below that rate, the Treasury said. The other participating currencies are limited to a narrow 2.25 percent band. Rates have been adjusted 12 times since the mechanism's inception 11 years ago, the mechanism has avoided any major adjustments to rates in the last 3 12 years. The other currencies already in the mechanism are the German mark, the French franc, the Dutch guilder, the Italian lira, the Belgian and Luxembourg francs, the Danish krone, and the Irish pound. Not participating are the Portuguese escudo and the Greek drachma.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Want Accounting Overhaul
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission wants the accounting profession to change methods. Whoa! Don't stop reading yet! Altering the way the bean-counters count could mean big differences in the way a company reports its financial health. That could have far-reaching effects on your employer, investments and future. ``As we enter the decade of the 1990s, we should consider a fundamental shift in the goal we set for the accounting standards for financial institutions,'' SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden told the Senate Banking Committee. Had such a change been undertaken years ago, for example, it may have helped avoid one of the worst financial debacles of all time: the thrift industry's collapse, estimated to cost American taxpayers $500 billion over the next 40 years. How thrift assets were counted made all the difference, said Breeden. Using the currently approved method, savings & loans showed a healthy surplus in assets - the cash, securities and real estate they controlled. But when the thrifts began failing and the government took them over and began selling off those assets, the market value turned out to be a deficit, largely because of the accounting for the debt securities, which had made them grossly overvalued. Present accounting standards, known as Generally Accepted Accounting Principles or GAAP, allow financial institutions to count debt securities one of two ways depending upon whether they were bought for trading purposes or for long term investment. ``That treatment exalts psychology over economic worth,'' Breeden said in a recent interview. ``I mean it comes down to an exercise for the regulators and accountants to try and determine what the motivation or intent was with respect to the holding of that security.'' If the debt securities are being held for investment, their value is listed as the purchase price or historic cost, whereas if they were bought with imminent trading in mind, they have to be listed at their true value on the market, a practice known as marked to market. In essence, it's like picking grapes, leaving them in the sun and still calling them grapes long after they've turned to raisins. For example, says Breeden, take a hypothetical financial institution that buys $1 billion in 30-year Treasury notes for investment. ``The very next year they fell to $900 million. The idea that for the next 29 years that loss can be carried as if it didn't happen, it demonstrates the degree of distortion that can result from this distinction based on investment intent vs. trading intent,'' said Breeden, who as a White House aide, helped draft the thrift bailout legislation. Breeden has made changing that distinction a top priority and has called in officials of the top accounting standards-setting groups to persuade them. The SEC oversees the accounting profession because accountants must certify the accuracy of financial statements that companies file with the agency. But in the past, the SEC has left most of the rule-making authority to private industry organizations. The most important are the Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets the general rules for accounting, GAAP, and the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, which oversees testing of certified public accountants and provides accounting principles for specialized industries such as financial institutions. These groups tend to move cautiously when considering changes. Last month, the accounting institute's standards committee withdrew a proposal that would have created tougher standards for financial institutions' accounting methods but stopped short of a complete rollback after the SEC complained. At a meeting earlier this month with officials of the standards board and the accounting institute, Breeden urged them to reconsider guidelines for listing debt securities on financial institutions' balance sheets. ``We've committed to get back to chairman Breeden within 30 days on whether or not we are willing to undertake tis project,'' said Thomas Kelley, vice president of the accounting institute, said the accounting officials pledged to give Breeden a response to his proposal in 30 days. But Kelley said the earliest such a change could take place would be the end of 1991. ``There's no question something has to be done,'' said Walter Primhoff, director of professional programs for the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants. But he expressed worry over too much SEC meddling. ``The SEC has not very often interfered in this process,'' he said. ``There's only been a few times where they've come in and said `We don't like what you did with the rule, we're going to change it.' ``If it happens occasionally it just shows there is a responsible public oversight but if it becomes a very frequent occurence, accounting standards will become politicized, and if they do, the people who rely on them for making decisions probably will be forced to rely on them less.'' Eventually the SEC may push beyond the limited issue of debt securities at financial institutions. But even Breeden concedes ``moving beyond that to other types of assets is a direction that we think ought to be pursued but that has to be done very carefully and very deliberately.'' One of the other four SEC commissioners, Philip R. Lochner Jr., said the commission has taken no action yet to explore a wider use of market price accounting. ``It's kind of premature to go beyond that. We may go much farther but I'm just speaking for myself,'' said Lochner.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Woolrich to Lay Off More Than Half Its 2,600 Employees
DOC.TEXT: Woolrich Inc., which primarily manufactures outdoor clothing, will lay off more than half its 2,600 employees nationwide because it has few orders for deliveries beyond December, the company said. In a letter delivered to employees this week, Woolrich President S. Wade Judy said a soft retail market and high inventory levels would force the company to lay off about 1,500 employees at least until spring. Layoff notices will begin going out this month and those who will be released should know their fate by the end of November, said Rod Bailey, the company's vice president of human resources. ``We feel badly about this at this time of year, but we really don't have much choice about it,'' he said. Judy's letter said consumer buying habits were shifting away from Woolrich's basic line of outdoor clothing. He said the company has developed new lines of clothing for the current season, but that there were few orders for delivery in 1991. ``We don't have ample orders beyond Dec. 10, which is very unusual and a major reason for the work force curtailment,'' Bailey said. Woolrich has 2,600 employees nationwide at five plants in Pennsylvania, two in Georgia, two in Colorado and one in Nebraska. In the spring, Woolrich placed more than 1,000 workers on a three-day work week, but reinstated all to a 40-hour week within two months, Bailey said.

DOC.HEAD: Mutual Funds, Jobless Numbers Tell Sad Summer Story
DOC.TEXT: It's becoming clear just how bad a summer it was for business and the economy. Data reported this past week showed widespread damage from the slowdown in growth and the shock of the Middle East crisis. Among the grim findings: - Stock mutual funds lost an average of 15.5 percent during the third quarter, compared with a gain of nearly 6 percent in the preceding three months, according to Lipper Analytical Securities Corp. The quarter was the worst since the fourth quarter of 1987, which included Black Monday. - September was the worst month for American manufacturers since the end of the 1982 recession, the National Association of Purchasing Management said. - Unemployment increased for the third straight month in September to 5.7 percent, the highest level since the spring of 1988. - Help-wanted advertising dropped in August in another sign of labor market weakness, according to a business research firm. - Sales of new homes fell 1.4 percent in August, and would have fallen even further if not for some buyers who locked in deals before the Persian Gulf crisis pressured interest rates higher. - Sales of cars and trucks by U.S. automakers dropped 3.7 percent in late September, capping the worst model year since 1983. Adding insult to injury for American manufacturers, the Japanese Honda Accord was the best-selling car of the year.
DOC.HEAD: BUDGET FLOP: House Vote Kills Deal
DOC.TEXT: First, there was a budget agreement, then there wasn't. President Bush and congressional leaders presented a budget deal that promised to cut $500 billion from the federal deficit over five years. But despite the added support of Federal Reserve chief Alan Greenspan, who indicated easier credit might follow, the pact didn't survive the week. The House voted it down in the wee hours of Friday morning, after hearing loud complaints from businesses and consumers. Higher taxes on gasoline, lower farm subsidies and reduced Medicare benefits were more than many people could swallow. Wall Street, which had lobbied successfully to kill a proposed tax on securities trades, was disappointed when the deal collapsed since it revived uncertainty about the prospects for lower interest rates.
DOC.HEAD: INVESTING: Time for Vulture Funds
DOC.TEXT: In such a depressed climate, troubled companies could prove the best investment. Goldman, Sachs & Co. said it had raised $700 million to invest in companies with heavy debts. The strategy marked a big change from the days when investment houses chased takeover targets and helped companies pile up big debts for mergers and leveraged buyouts. The Goldman fund would seek profit in mopping up some of that mess by helping companies restructure their finances and rise from the ashes.
DOC.HEAD: JAPAN: Stocks Leap, Then Stumble
DOC.TEXT: Japanese stocks took their biggest one-day jump in history Tuesday, pushing a key market index up more than 13 percent. The runup was powered by the government's announcement of measures to prop up the ailing market, which had lost nearly half its value - or about $2 trillion - over the course of the year. The euphoria was short-lived, though. The market resumed its slide the next two days before rebounding slightly at week's end. The measures, which eased limits for buying stock on credit and shortened hours for trading futures contracts, were aimed at stimulating trading and reducing volatility. Most observers were pessimistic about the chances for turning the battered market around.
DOC.HEAD: CITIES: Who's On Top?
DOC.TEXT: Dueling lists of the best American cities for business reached different results. Cushman & Wakefield, the big commercial real estate firm, said the best was Seattle, the Northwest's biggest metropolis. Fortune magazine countered with Salt Lake City. Quality of life figured heavily on both lists. Still, there was little agreement. Indeed, neither of the list leaders merited so much as a mention in each other's ranking. Seattle was nowhere to be found on the Fortune list; Salt Lake was likewise missing from the C&W survey.

DOC.TEXT: Continuing the flood of technology announcements, Xerox Corp. rolled out a $220,000, car-length machine that can scan, copy and bind documents with print-shop quality. Apple Computer Inc. said it would bring three new Macintosh computers to market later this month, priced to do battle with lower cost competitors. One of the three would carry a price tag around $1,000. Apple was also reported in talks with two Japanese producers, Toshiba Corp. and Sony Corp., for possible joint ventures. General Motors Corp. said its long-awaited Saturn cars would carry a base price as low as $7,995 and a money-back guarantee good for a month, more attractive terms than expected. Two cigarette makers, Philip Morris U.S.A. and Brown & Williamson Tobacco, donated millions of smokes to American troops in the Gulf, but the Defense Department nixed any future shipments, saying the gifts violated its policy of discouraging tobacco use. USX Corp. and the United Steelworkers of America agreed to early talks on a new contract in an effort to avert a strike. A settlement ahead of the contract expiration Feb. 1 would help the company achieve its goal of selling off part or all of its steel operations. Campeau Corp. said its debt-laden retail empire would sell or close a number of stores over the next six years and emerge from bankruptcy as soon as 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Gets Temporary Moratorium on Debt Repayments
DOC.TEXT: Polly Peck International PLC on Friday secured a temporary debt repayment moratorium from lenders, gaining time to cope with a liquidity crunch, the company said. The food and electronics company controlled by Asil Nadir, its chairman and chief executive, had sought the freeze on repayments after lenders clamped down on its credit lines. The lines of credit were tightened after the Sept. 20 trading suspension in Polly Peck's stock. The suspension, which is still in force, caused the liquidity problems, the company said earlier this week. The trading halt stemmed from an inquiry by Britain's Serious Fraud Office into a possible stock manipulation scheme in Polly Peck shares. The payment moratorium came after bankers for the cash-starved conglomerate met with the company management on Friday. ``It was agreed by the bankers and other lenders . . . that a temporary standstill would be granted to the company so that the best way forward may be discussed,'' the company said in a brief news release late Friday. The release added that the discussions will be conducted by a steering committee of 10 representatives of the lenders and may lead to a longer standstill period. The panel may wait to conclude its business until after reviewing a report on Polly Peck being done by an accounting firm. Executives of Polly Peck weren't available to comment on the exact terms of the standstill arrangement. A company spokesman, speaking anonymously, said he wasn't authorized to elaborate on the matter. Banking industry sources gave conflicting reports on how long the moratorium would last. It was expected to run from one week to a few weeks but not as long as the 90 days Polly Peck had sought. Standard Chartered PLC, a major U.K. commercial bank, is leading the Polly Peck steering committee and will be responsible for coordinating further talks between the company and its lenders, according to banking sources who didn't wish to be identified. Polly Peck's announcement also suggested that the review being done by accountants from Coopers & Lybrand Deloitte would ease persistent doubts about the company's financial health. The report by the British arm of the international accounting and consulting firm isn't expected to be completed for three months. But preliminary findings might be available sooner to Polly Peck's major lenders. The company's main creditors had contemplated forcing Polly Peck into hands of a court-appointed adminstrator while questions over its financial and fiscal soundness were addressed. But banking sources who attended the Friday meeting with Polly Peck's management said the company made a strong case to maintain its independence while its financial affairs are sorted out. ``There are many, many questions which still have to be answered,'' said a banker leaving the talks. ``At this point, banks want to avoid administration,'' said the banker, who spoke on condition of anonymity. It also emerged Friday that the Bank of England last week advised Turkey of Polly Peck's urgent need for $190 million. The Bank of England, the country's central bank, declined to comment on its involvement with Polly Peck and the Turkish government, which has indicated it is considering offering some form of assistance to the company and its Turkish chairman.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Of Savings Bonds Hit Three-Year High
DOC.TEXT: Sales of U.S. savings bonds totaled a three-year high of $7.77 billion in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, the Treasury Department said Friday. Boosting the total were sales of $544 million in September, a 3 percent advance over the amount sold in September 1989. At the same time, redemptions in fiscal 1990 totaled $7.54 billion, a 1 percent drop from fiscal 1989. The value of savings bonds held by Americans rose 7 percent during the year, finishing at an all-time record $123.9 billion, up from $115.7 billion in fiscal 1989. Savings bonds currently earn interest at a rate of 7.01 percent when held five years or longer.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Looks For A Turning Point
DOC.TEXT: In the midst of a bear market on Wall Street, some analysts are keeping busy searching out the seeds of future opportunities. Prolonged declines in stock prices are naturally painful and dispiriting to investors, these observers acknowledge. But they add that many of the best opportunities to buy stocks for handsome returns have come in periods of financial travail. ``There is no question that the market is currently weak,'' says George Putnam III in the current issue of his investment advisory publication The Turnaround Letter. ``The word we hear most often to describe market conditions these days is `ugly.' Investors are very skittish, and any bad news will send a stock plummeting. ``But we view the current market as an attractive buying opportunity. Good companies in all categories have been hammered over the last two months, and they will recover sharply when investors regain some confidence in the market. ``It may not happen this month, or even this year, but it will happen.'' Or as Barton Biggs at the investment banking firm of Morgan Stanley & Co. puts it, ``The bear is aging. In the U.S., I think we are somewhere in the second half of a cyclical bear market, in which the averages normally decline in the range of 20 percent to 30 percent. ``The bad news is no secret anymore. Everyone knows most of the bear story. ``The news doesn't have to become good for stocks to stop going down - just that it is less bad than what has already been discounted in prices. ``The scare scenarios always seem more credible when the markets are falling, but you have to be careful not to get more bearish as prices decline. Instead, you logically should become more bullish because you can buy quality goods cheaper. ``I think we have further to go in this bear market, but as prices go down I want to begin averaging in.'' Observers like Putnam and Biggs readily concede how difficult it is to call a market ``bottom.'' Indeed, some analysts contend that stocks are likely to keep sliding as long as it takes to discourage just about all the ``bargain hunters'' and self-proclaimed patient optimists. ``This global bear market should still be respected and treated with great caution,'' says Stan Weinstein, publisher of the Professional Tape Reader advisory in Hollywood, Fla. In the past week the market made some fitful efforts to rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,510.64, up 58.16 from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 2.85 to 170.70; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 12.85 to 347.36, and the American Stock Exchange market value index lost 1.24 to 306.48. Volume on the Big Board averaged 164.96 million shares a day, against 171.48 million the week before. Most analysts believe stock prices at recent levels have already taken into account a moderate, relatively short recession. Their main worry is that confidence among investors will suffer some further blows, raising the prospect of a deeper and longer slump. ``In every bear phase there has been what seemed to be a plausible doomsday scenario that terrorized investors,'' Biggs said. ``In retrospect most of them seem far-fetched, but they sure scared me at the time. ``If the economic apocalypse does really come this time, it won't happen overnight, and my guess is that the central banks will try to inflate their way out. ``We are not going through the end of the world, just the end of the euphoria. Some gloomy, rainy day, for no clearly discernible reason, stocks will stop declining.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks, Bonds Tumble, Rebound After Budget Failure
DOC.TEXT: The failed federal budget accord slammed stock and bond prices Friday but the markets recovered nearly all the lost ground, partly on President Bush's tough stance against Congress. The key Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks dropped nearly 70 points after the opening bell before steadying to close the day down 6.19 points at 2,510.64. In a lengthy night session, a rebellious House early Friday overwhelmingly defeated the $500-billion compromise package of tax increases and spending cuts sought by Bush and congressional leaders. Wall Street professionals had hoped for a budget accord to help reduce the amount of borrowing needed to pay the federal deficit and spur the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates to stimulate economic activity. Lower interest rates tend to make stocks and bonds more valuable. In an unstable market already whipped by rising oil prices and the turmoil in the Persian Gulf, the congressional rejection initially appeared to quash those possibilities. ``It's more uncertainty,'' said Dan Williams, head of equity trading with Dillon, Read & Co. ``With the Middle East now, all you need is another guy throwing the hat in the ring.'' The opening plunge triggered a New York Stock Exchange restraint on computerized selling strategies aimed at helping stabilize the market, an outgrowth of the stock market crash nearly three years ago. But stocks and bonds staged a gradual recovery during the day as some traders believed the sell-off was too great and that budget negotiators would resolve their differences. Additionally, a White House statement that Bush would refuse to sign emergency financing legislation to keep the government operating heartened some traders looking for strong leadership in Washington. Ward McCarthy, a managing director of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., said the markets believe Congress will not allow a long-term government shutdown ``and therefor they will come to vote for the accord, and probably soon.'' Stock and bond prices also received a boost when Britain dropped a key interest rate and announced that the pound will enter Europe's exchange rate mechanism, effective Monday. Those moves incited a rally in British stocks and the buying mood spilled over to Wall Street. In the bond market, a sensitive barometer of the economy and interest rates, the key 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged after falling close to $6 per $1,000 in face amount earlier in the day. Its yield finished at 8.78 percent. Oil contracts traded in the futures market, which determines prices, rose $1.06 to around $37.99 a barrel after easing slightly on Thursday. A report from the Labor Department this morning showing unemployment in September rose slightly was overshadowed by the budget vote and had little effect on the markets, strategists said.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Catapulted Higher On News Of ERM Entry

DOC.TEXT: News of the pound's entry into Europe's exchange rate mechanism, coupled with a percentage point cut in Britain's base lending rate to 14 percent, sent the London stock market soaring Friday. The late news moved the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index, which was in negative territory, 110 points higher to a close of 2,143.9, up 73.5 points, or 3.6 percent, from Thursday's close. The London market closed an hour later than normal to take account of the increase in trading volume. ``Buying orders are coming out of our ears,'' one trader said. The Financial Times 30-share index closed up 43 points at 1,644.3. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 28.98 points to close at 1,132.96. Volume was 447.8 million shares, up from Thursday's 421.3 million shares.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell Friday, but the market managed to minimize the damage from an early selloff that followed the rejection of a government budget plan. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 6.19 to 2,510.64, reducing its gain for the week to 58.16 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 598 up, 893 down and 464 unchanged. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled about 60 points at the outset. Such a selloff had been widely predicted following the overnight word that the House had defeated the budget proposal worked out last weekend by President Bush and congressional leaders. Analysts said the news dismayed investors who had pinned their hopes on some tangible signs of progress in the struggle to narrow the government's chronic deficit. But after the initial wave of selling passed, the market steadied. Brokers said hopes lingered that the White House and Congress might come up with an alternative budget plan. Separately, the Labor Department issued monthly statistics showing an increase in the unemployment rate and a drop in nonfarm payroll employment. The figures, which came in a bit weaker than expected, were taken as corroborating evidence that the economy is close to or already in a recession. Some observers also saw them, however, as cause for hope that interest rates might soon decline. British stocks chalked up some of the day's most notable gains, responding to lower interest rates in London and plans for inclusion of the pound in the European Monetary System. Barclays climbed 2} to 28}; British Telecom 4[ to 55[; Glaxo Holdings 1} to 32{; British Steel 1} to 25\, and the United Kingdom Fund 1\ to 10]. Among U.S. issues, the battered bank stocks rallied a bit. Chase Manhattan gained ~ to 12}; Citicorp \ to 12[; BankAmerica { to 20], and Chemical Banking | to 15}. By contrast, Travelers Corp. fell 4] to 16]. The company reduced its dividend, and said an addition to its reserves for mortgage and real estate investments would result in a $500 million third-quarter loss. Other insurance stocks dropped sharply as well. Aetna Life & Casualty lost 3} to 33|; UNUM 3} to 35~; USF&G 1} to 15[; Continental Corp. 1{ to 19], and Monarch Capital ] to 4[. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 153.38 million shares, against 145.41 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 186.43 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $13.02 billion, or 0.44 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .63 to 170.70. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 1.40 to 367.02, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 1.19 at 311.50. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slumped 2.53 to 347.36. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 306.48, down 1.66.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 169.84 Friday, up 2.74, or 1.64 percent, from a week ago and down 27.44, or 13.91 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 160.62 Friday, up 2.73, or 1.73 percent, from a week ago and down 24.49, or 13.23 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 126.84 Friday, up 0.10, or 0.08 percent, from a week ago and down 41.47 or 24.64 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Back Up As Peace Hopes Wain
DOC.TEXT: Oil rose more than $1 per barrel Friday on harsh words from Iraq, though it still closed lower for the week due to resilient speculation that a diplomatic solution will be found to the Mideast crisis. ``That whiff of peace that the market smelled is wearing off,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Light sweet crude oil went up $1.06 to $37.99 per barrel for November delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. For the week, crude fell $1.52 per barrel, unable to erase sharp losses from Monday and Tuesday, when prices plummeted a total of more than $5 on what were construed as peaceful overtures from Iraq and the United States. On Friday, oil traders were responding mostly to news reports that Iraq would not make any conciliatory statements to the United Nations in a much-awaited speech that had been canceled twice during the week. An advance copy of Iraq's statement showed Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz was accusing the United States and its allies of bringing ``the entire world to the brink of a devastating war'' in a plot to gain control of Persian Gulf oil. America and other nations have assembled a military force in the Gulf in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August. Prices were boosted somewhat during late trading on news Friday that a Jordanian clergyman and government official had urged his countrymen to retaliate against the U.S. troops, possibly through terrorist acts, Hittle said. Crude oil's rise Friday was mostly steady, and it lifted futures for refined products. Home heating oil went up 2.78 cents to $1.027 per gallon for November delivery, while unleaded gasoline was up 1.78 cents to 92.64 cents per gallon for November delivery. Later contract months were higher for crude, heating oil and gasoline. For the week, heating oil went down 3.2 cents per gallon, while gasoline dropped 6.07 cents per gallon. Natural gas rose 3.7 cents to $1.935 per 1,000 cubic feet for November contracts on Friday, finishing the week unchanged. Most later contract months for natural gas were higher Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Arison Quits As Carnival Cruise Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Ted Arison, one of the nation's richest men, announced Friday he is quitting as chairman of Carnival Cruise Lines effective immediately. Arison, 66, will remain on the board of directors and act as a consultant. His son Micky, 41, who has served as president and chief executive officer since 1979, will take his place as chairman. ``The reality is that there won't be that much difference in my involvement,'' Arison said. ``I've been concentrating my efforts primarily on the new building program and Micky has been responsible for the day-to-day operations for the last 11 years.'' Arison was listed by Forbes magazine a year ago as the nation's third-richest man with a fortune valued at $2.86 billion. But he has suffered recent reverses, including the Aug. 31 seizure of Ensign Bank, his $1.9 billion New York thrift taken over by federal regulators. Ensign had unsuccessfully attempted a merger wih the now-defunct CenTrust Bank in January, but regulators vetoed the deal and later liquidated the Miami thrift.

DOC.HEAD: MCI Lines in Washington, D.C., Interrupted
DOC.TEXT: MCI long-distance customers in the metropolitan Washington area temporarily lost service Friday afternoon when a switch failed, the company said. The 45-minute outage affected perhaps 20 percent of the incoming and outgoing calls being made through MCI in Washington and the Maryland and Virginia suburbs, MCI Communications Corp. spokesman John Houser said. The problem was confined to the local area and service was restored at about 3:30 p.m. EDT, Houser said. Houser said the failure in the switch was ``comparable to a circuit breaker going out.'' The switch was one of five that MCI has in the Washington area and may have caused temporary backups for calls going through the other four switches, he said. Houser would not disclose the number of customers MCI has in the Washington area. Washington-based MCI is the nation's second-largest long-distance company after American Telephone & Telegraph Co. MCI has about 14 percent of the national market. A software problem in a computer in New York disabled about half of AT&T's national network on Jan. 15 for about nine hours.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Bellies Continue Surge
DOC.TEXT: Pork belly futures prices aimed for near-record prices Friday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as a perceived shortage on the market had traders fearing supplies would run ou before next summer. Frozen pork bellies settled .37 cent to the trading limit of 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in February at 66.45 cents a pound. On other commodity markets, livestock futures were mixed; soybeans were mixed, wheat gained and corn was lower; precious metals were mixed; and energy futures prices rose. Pork bellies futures continued to rise on last week's hogs-and-pigs report from the Agriculture Department that estimated the number of pigs born during the summer was 2 percent lower than had been expected. ``Pork bellies prices have been going absolutely crazy,'' said Thomas Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp. in Arlington Heights, Ill. ``There's going to be a tight fit on cattle and pork supplies.'' Pork and cattle futures prices already had been driven higher on indications the markets were low. Frozen pork bellies supplies reportedly are virtually depleted. Concern that U.S. packing plants might be shut down if a budget agreement is not reached by next week also drove prices higher, Morgan said. ``We may end up with days where there is no meat in the grocery stores, and that's certainly going to affect prices,'' he said. In livestock trading on the Merc, live cattle futures settled .30 cent lower to .23 cent higher with October at 79.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .35 cent lower to .10 cent higher with October at 87.82; and hogs were .08 cent lower to .45 cent higher with October at 57.17 cents a pound. Soybean and wheat futures prices were mostly lower, and corn was mixed at the close of a light day of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans futures opened slightly higher amid strong buying and worry about the U.S. House defeat of the budget agreement and its possible effects on farming programs. But trading became mixed after there were no reports of new export business, analysts said. ``There was some expected follow-through on Russian business and pre-hedging in advance of what appears to be a good harvest weekend in the Midwest,'' said Rich Feltes, director of commodities research for Refco Inc. Wheat futures settled 1{ cents to } cent lower with December at $2.73} a bushel; corn futures were 2{ cents lower to \ cent higher with December at $2.28} a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 1{ cents lower with December at $1.21{ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents lower to \ higher with November at $6.17 a bushel. Energy futures climbed higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange on technical buying. Little news from the Persian Gulf limited advances. Light sweet crude oil futures settled 21 cents to $1.06 higher with November at $37.99 a barrel; heating oil settled .35 cent to 2.78 cents higher with November at $1.027 a gallon; unleaded gasoline settled .20 cent to 1.78 cents higher with November at 92.64 cents a gallon. Gold followed the energy markets and silver fell in light trading on the New York Commodity Exchange. Gold settled $1.20 to $1.30 higher with October at $393.60 a troy ounce. Silver settled .2 cent to .1 cent lower with October at $4.667 an ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Soaring Pound Takes Spotlight; Dollar Mostly Higher
With AM-Britain-Pound Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A surging British pound dominated foreign exchange trading Friday as dealers scrambled to buy sterling on word it would be formally linked to other major European currencies. The dollar rose against its major foreign counterparts except the pound and the Japanese yen, rebounding from a selloff Thursday incited by expectations of lower U.S. interest rates. The dollar buying came mostly as a byproduct of cross trading between sterling and the German mark. Gold prices gained modestly in domestic trading but moved mostly lower overseas. Market participants in the United States said the dollar began on a weak note due to news of another deterioration in the country's job market. The Labor Department reported an increase in the unemployment rate for the third straight month and a decline in nonfarm payrolls. The jobless rate rose to 5.7 percent in September from August's 5.6 percent. The House's rejection of a $500 billion deficit-cutting compromise also was a negative for the dollar because it cast doubt on the government's ability to solve the chronic deficit problem. Andrew Busch, a currency dealer at Harris Trust in Chicago, said attention turned to sterling around midmorning in the United States when the British government announced the pound would join Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said starting Monday the pound will join the mechanism that presently links nine of the currencies of the 12-nation European Community. The move, which is expected to help Britain fight inflation and improve that country's economic prospects, will be coupled with a 1 percentage point cut in key British interest rates to 14 percent. The pound jumped to $1.9455 from $1.9185 before the announcement in London, and was more than three cents higher than its level of $1.9115 late Thursday. Against Europe's pivotal currency, the German mark, the pound finished at 2.9933 marks, up from 2.9322 late Thursday. Major said the pound will enter the ERM at 2.95 marks and be allowed to fluctuate by six percent either way. The pound also bounded ahead in New York. It took $1.9525 to buy a pound late in the session, more costly than $1.9145 late Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late quotes, included: 1.5475 German marks, up from 1.5340; 1.2940 Swiss francs, up from 1.2800; 5.1850 French francs, up from 5.1375; 1,160.25 Italian lire, up from 1,149.00; and 1.1524 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14865. Late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with late rates on Thursday, were: 1.5372 German marks, up from 1.5340; 1.2847 Swiss francs, up from 1.2760; 5.1473 French francs, up from 5.1400; 1.7340 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7300; 1,150.50 Italian lire, up from 1,150.00; and 1.1500 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1485. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 133.72 Japanese yen from 135.90 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, the dollar fell to 132.50 yen. The dollar closed at 132.20 yen in New York, down from 133.83 yen late Thursday. Gold prices were mixed. On New York's Commodity Exchange, bullion for October delivery settled at $393.60 a troy ounce, up $1.30 from Thursday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a bid for gold of $394 an ounce, 80 cents higher than Thursday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. In London, gold fell to a late bid of $394.35 a troy ounce from $396.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, Switzerland, the metal fell to a closing bid of $394.40 from $396.25 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.47 to close at a bid of $391.95. Silver prices edged down. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $4.667 a troy ounce, down from $4.668 on Thursday. In London, silver fell to a late bid of $4.69 a troy ounce from $4.71 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Bonds Recover After Sell-Off Pegged to Budget Failure
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices finished little changed Friday after a volatile session in which failure to reach a federal budget accord overshadowed another rise in unemployment. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond ended the day largely unchanged, recovering from a sharp decline earlier in the day that pushed prices down about $6 per $1,000 face amount. The bond's yield dipped to 8.78 percent from 8.79 percent late Thursday. The House voted 254-179 early Friday to reject President Bush's plan aimed at cutting $500 billion from the federal budget deficit. Bond traders said the rejection made it unlikely the Federal Reserve would take quick action to lower interest rates to spur the slumping economy, which would boost the value of fixed-income instruments such as bonds. The bond market for weeks has awaited a Fed easing and pinned its hopes to the budget deal. ``The market is realizing that without any federal budget accord, the Fed probably won't ease,'' said Kevin Flanagan, a money market economist with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The budget collapse took precedence over the Labor Department's report that unemployment rose to 5.7 percent in September, another sign of weakening. But analysts said the report had some inflationary signals, which dulled its impact on bonds. ``The significance of the report was severely diminished because of the knowledge that the Fed will not respond to any weak (economic) data until there is a budget-cutting accord,'' said Ward McCarthy of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. Treasury bills dropped sharply at the market's opening, with the discount yields on three-month and one-year bills dropping below 7 percent for a short time for the first time since August 1988. All maturities began rebounding around midmorning. Economists attributed some of the gain to President Bush's stance refusing to sign emergency legislation to keep the government operating. That was seen as an attempt by the White House to press for a quick resolution to the budget impasse. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term, intermediate and long-term government issues all ranged from unchanged to up 1-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.68 to 1155.31. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.25 percent as the discount tumbled 9 basis points to 7.03 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.42 percent as the discount dropped was down 6 basis points to 7.07 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.49 percent as the discount dropped 3 basis points to 7.01 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 7 15-16 percent, down from 8 3-16 percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 88 23-32, down 1-16 point. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.77 percent from 7.76 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Sale of UAL Stock Rights Seen As Sign Wolf Opposes Buyout
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. employees say Chairman Stephen Wolf will look hypocritical if he urges the company's board to reject a buyout offer, now that he's sold some of his UAL stock rights for less than the buyout bid. The United Airlines labor unions leading the buyout group contend Wolf has been lobbying the board not to accept any buyout offer less than $201 a share, or about $4.4 billion. The employees said Friday that Wolf's sale of stock rights indicates his lack of faith - if not downright opposition - to the employee buyout. But they said the news could help their effort because Wolf will look hypocritical if he urges UAL's board to reject an offer that's higher than the reported $150 sale price for his stock rights. Meanwhile, the buyout group awaited word on whether it has enough bank financing to approach the board next week with a bid expected to value UAL at $165 to $175 a share, or $3.6 billion to $3.8 billion. One person familiar with the situation said the unions expected to continue receiving loan commitments through the weekend. The group needs to line up financing by Tuesday, when UAL's board is expected to meet. The Wall Street Journal reported Friday that Wolf exercised 200,000 of his 208,333 stock appreciation rights last spring when UAL's stock was selling at about $150 a share. Wolf made a $14 million profit on the deal, the newspaper said. The Journal also said UAL's chief financial officer, John Pope, sold 50,000 of his 60,000 rights at the same time, earning $4.2 million. UAL stock closed down $2.62{ at $102.75 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Stock appreciation rights, when exercised, enable their owners to receive in cash the amount a stock has increased over the exercise price. The Journal said Wolf's rights had an average exercise price of $83.31 and Pope's exercise prices averaged $69. The company confirmed the executives had sold part of their stock rights in light of the unions' intent to replace them with their own senior management team if the buyout bid succeeds. Wolf was said to be worried the unions would nullify the rights if they succeeded in buying the company. Airline analyst Stephen Dexter of Kemper Financial Services Inc. said Wolf apparently sold his stock rights because he saw the employee buyout offer, which was then for $201 a share, as ``totally unreasonable, or at least he did not believe it was do-able. ``From what I can tell, he made a smart business decision,'' Dexter said, noting that UAL's stock fell as low as $87.25 a share during the summer. Some observers in the unions' camp said Wolf's actions confirmed that he opposes the employee buyout, despite his public statements to the contrary. ``We're offering the shareholders more (than $150 a share). How can Wolf tell the board our offer isn't enough?'' said Frederick Dubinsky, chairman of the United pilots union. The four large U.S. banks that are trying the arrange a loan for the buyout continued to receive commitments Friday from smaller banks, a source told The Associated Press. The banks likely will decide by Monday whether to finance the deal, the source said.

DOC.HEAD: Travelers Corp. Adds to Reserves; Third-Quarter Loss Put at $500 Million
DOC.TEXT: The Travelers Corp. said Friday it is adding $650 million to its reserves to cover expected real estate losses, a move that will result in a third-quarter net loss of $500 million. The Hartford-based insurance company will also reduce its quarterly dividend from 60 cents to 40 cents per share. Edward H. Budd, Travelers chairman and chief executive officer, said reserves were boosted to cover expected losses in the company's mortgage loan and real estate investments. He blamed the sharp decline in the commercial real estate market. ``Following an intensive review of our mortgage loans and real estate holdings, we determined it appropriate to increase reserves to provide for real estate losses which we expect to emerge over a number of years,'' Budd said. The company said this was the first major addition to reserves since June 1988, when Travelers added $415 million to cover anticipated real estate losses. The latest increase boosts reserves to $1.15 billion at quarter's end. Travelers said it will post a net loss of $500 million in the quarter, compared with net income of $94 million for the same period last year. The company also will have a net loss for the year, Budd said. He said the one-third reduction in the quarterly dividend, to save $100 million by the end of 1991, will allow the company to retain more earnings to support growth. Despite its losses in the real estate market, the company said its main businesses continue to be strong. Budd said the company has made progress in restructuring its insurance operations, generating cost improvements of nearly $200 million in the past two years. He said the company wrote a record $1.3 billion in new business in the managed care and employee benefits area in 1989. The company expects operating profits in the third quarter to surpass 1989 levels of $63 million, and operating income for 1990 to rise by about 25 percent above last year. Travelers stock fell sharply on the announcement, closing down $4.37{ on the New York Stock Exchange to $16.37{ a share. Two top rating agencies also acted negatively. Both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Corp. said Friday they had lowered their ratings on Travelers' debt because of continuing problems in the commercial mortgage and real estate markets. Moody's said the addition to reserves, combined with previous writedowns of mortgage assets, would give the company a cushion to absorb any increases in non-performing assets over the next few years. ``The company's decision to reduce its common stockholder dividend, and its conservative financial leverage, will provide the company with greater financial flexibility, enabling it to respond to this worsening environment,'' Moody's said. About $1 billion of long-term debt was affected by the Moody's downgrade. Standard & Poor's actions affected about $649 million in debt.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Extends Order Against Payments by Asbestos Trust
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday again extended a freeze on payments to asbestos disease victims by the Manville trust fund pending completion of a court-ordered reorganization. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein said the month-long extension was needed to finalize an agreement on a restructuring in which Manville Corp. would inject up to $520 million over seven years to reverse a cash shortfall. The shortage has jeopardized compensation payments to tens of thousands of victims. The agreement to refinance the trust was announced last month. The payments by Manville would begin late next year. It was the third month-long extension by Weinstein on the payments freeze, which applies to all claims or court judgments made since the first order in August or until the new Nov. 6 expiration date. The trust was created in 1988 as part of Manville's bankruptcy court reorganization, which was forced by mounting liability for lung cancer and other serious and fatal diseases caused by asbestos. Under the freeze, the trust is permitted to make payments for hardship claims and emergency health needs, as well as operating expenses, legal fees of trust attorneys and fees to a court adviser overseeing the restructuring. The trust to date has settled close to 24,000 claims for more than $1 billion from people made sick by inhaling asbestos fibers, mostly during shipbuilding and other construction. The trust faces 130,000 more claims it can't meet. Weinstein ordered the reorganization after the trust said it was out of money to pay new claims it said would not be met until well into the 21st century. The reorganization is designed to speed payments and alter the compensation scheme so that claims are processed based on victims' health and financial need rather than when they file a claim.

America's unemployment rate worsened for the third straight month in September, the government said. The Labor Department reported Friday that the civilian jobless rate rose to 5.7 percent last month. Coupled with unemployment rises in July and August, marked the first time since the 1981-82 recession that the jobless rate has increased three months in a row, the government said. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The failed federal budget accord slammed stock and bond prices but the markets recovered nearly all the lost ground, partly on President Bush's tough stance against Congress. In a lengthy night session, a rebellious House early Friday overwhelmingly defeated the $500-billion compromise package of tax increases and spending cuts sought by Bush and congressional leaders. Wall Street professionals had hoped for a budget accord to help reduce the amount of borrowing needed to pay the federal deficit and spur the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Charles Keating said he is innocent of a 42-count criminal indictment alleging fraud in junk bond sales through his failed Lincoln Savings & Loan. Keating and three co-defendants entered innocent pleas Friday to an array of charges accusing them of bilking investors in American Continental Corp. junk bonds sold through Lincoln branches. Keating, who has been unable to post $5 million bail, was then returned to jail. --- HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) - The Travelers Corp. said it is adding $650 million to its reserves to cover expected real estate losses, a move that will result in a third-quarter net loss of $500 million. The insurance company also said Friday it will reduce its quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share from 60 cents. The company said it was the first major addition to reserves since June 1988, when Travelers added $415 million to cover anticipated real estate losses. The latest increase boosts reserves to $1.15 billion at quarter's end. --- ST. LOUIS (AP) - Trans World Airlines Inc. sent layoff notices to 430 employees to cut its losses further in an industry hit hard by rising fuel prices and the slumping economy. A TWA spokesman said Frida that more layoffs, and possibly flight reductions, could come later. TWA, which has its hub in St. Louis, has about 33,000 employees worldwide. The spokesman said the layoffs were related to higher jet fuel prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. USAir Group Inc., Pan Am Corp. and Midway Airlines Inc. also have announced layoffs. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Federal Reserve policy-makers decided two weeks after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait to keep interest rates unchanged but to permit lower rates if economic conditions warranted, newly released records show. Short-term interest rates, which the Fed has used for two years in combatting inflation, did not change after the Aug. 21 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. They have remained at 8 percent since mid-summer. The Fed records were released Friday. --- LONDON (AP) - Dropping long-standing resistance, the government said it will link the pound to Europe's exchange rate mechanism, a move expected to help Britain's fight against inflation. The move Friday symbolized British willingness to participate in European integration, but Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher stressed her continued opposition to creating a single European bank and a single currency. --- DANBURY, Conn. (AP) - The executive who oversaw the manufacture of the Hubble Space Telescope has resigned from Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., a month after the company was blamed for a flaw that blurred the scope's view. John D. Rehnberg, 53, operations manager of the space science division, said his decision to resign this week was ``unequivocally'' his own. He oversaw the manufacturing of the Hubble mirror, which contained a flaw that has caused the $1.5 billion telescope to deliver blurry pictures to earth. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The decline of American banks compared with their foreign competitors threatens to harm an already weak U.S. economy and diminish the nation's world influence, a congressional report concludes. A House Banking Committee task force, chaired by Rep. John J. LaFalce, D-N.Y., strongly suggested that the Depression-era constraints barring banks from expanding into new services such as securities underwriting and insurance must fall if U.S. banks are to regain their edge. ---

Stock prices fell Friday, but the market managed to minimize the damage from an early sell-off that followed the rejection of a government budget plan. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 6.19 to 2,510.64, reducing its gain for the week to 58.16 points. The dollar rose against most major currencies. Gold gained modestly. Bonds were little changed. Pork belly futures prices aimed for near-record prices; livestock futures and soybeans were mixed; wheat gained and corn was lower; and energy futures rose.
